CONTAINING An exact and full De≈øcription of the Frame, Situation and Connexion of all his Parts, (with their Actions and ∆≤≈øes) expre≈øt in Forty nine Copper-plates.
To which is Added An APPENDIX, Containing two Di≈øcour≈øes: The one, of the GENERATION of ANIMALS; And the other, of the MOTION of the CHYLE, AND THE CIRCULATION of the BLOUD.
By ANDREW SNAPE, Jun. Farrier to His MAJESTY.
LONDON, Printed by M. Fle≈øher for the Authour, and are to be ≈øold by T. Fle≈øher at the Angel and Crown in S. Paul's Church-yard. An. Dom. 1683.

div.head: TO His Mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty, CHARLES II. KING of Great BRITAIN, FRANCE and IRELAND, &c.
div.p:
NOTHING could have excu≈øed, or induc'd me unto, the Pre≈øumption of this Addre≈øs unto Your MAJESTY, if Your Royal Bounty towards me, had not made ≈øuch an Application my Duty. For being a Son of that Family that hath had the honour to ≈øerve the Crown of this Kingdom in the Quality of Farriers for the≈øe two Hundred Years, and being my ≈øelf retain'd by Your MAJESTY's Favour in that capacity;
As the≈øe hereditary and per≈øonal Engagements were the fir≈øt Motives that put me upon di≈ø≈øecting of Hor≈øes, that I might be more capable of ≈øerving Your MAJESTY in my Station; ≈øo do they entitle Your MAJESTY to the Di≈øcoveries I have made, as being but the effects of ≈øuch Obligations. And I do the rather flatter my ≈øelf with the hope of Your MAJESTY's Pardon in this Particular, in regard that this E≈ø≈øay has ≈øomething in it that is new, and withall of Publick and Common Benefit, which Your Royal Goodne≈øs hath been plea≈øed upon all occa≈øions to Honour with Your Princely Encouragement and Approbation. For the Intention of publi≈øhing this Treati≈øe being to in≈øtruct Farriers in the Frame, Situation and U≈øe of the Parts of an Hor≈øe, which is the Subject of their Care; They will thereby, I hope, become more skilfull in applying and admini≈øtring proper Remedies to the Di≈øtempers of that Generous Animal, which yields Your MAJESTY and Your Subjects that great ≈øervice both in Peace and War.

May God Almighty long continue Your MAJESTY's Gracious Reign over a Loyal and Obedient People: And that Your MAJESTY will vouch≈øafe Your Royal Pardon for the boldne≈øs of this Dedication, is the humble Petition of

closer.signed: Your MAJESTY's Mo≈øt Loyal and Obedient Subject and Servant, A. Snape.

div.head: The Introduction.
div.p: THERE is nothing gives a greater check to the progre≈øs of an Art, than to believe it is already perfected by tho≈øe that have gone before us, and ≈øo to content our ≈øelves with their determinations: For had our ancient Arti≈øts been thus ≈øupinely credulous, and thought it ≈øufficient to have traced their predece≈ø≈øors, limiting their wits within other mens bounds, never had time brought to light ≈øuch di≈øcoveries in our Profe≈ø≈øion, nor had the my≈øteries of our Art been ≈øo far communicated to po≈øterity as they already are.

This con≈øideration induced me to make an attempt for the cultivating and improving our Art to a greater perfection than it had as yet attain'd to: In order to which con≈øidering the ≈øeveral parts of it, and ob≈øerving that our profe≈ø≈øion has ≈øuch a corre≈øpondence with that of a Phy≈øician, that they differ not at all ≈øaving in the ≈øubject they act upon; I begun to think, who≈øoever would excel in the knowledge of the one, mu≈øt arrive at it by the ≈øame method as the others do. Now he that once bends his mind toward the practice of Phy≈øick, fir≈øt applies him≈øelf to the ≈øtudy of Anatomy, to under≈øtand all the Parts (with their actions and u≈øes) of that Body which is to be the ≈øubject whereupon his Art is to be exerci≈øed; without which no wi≈øe man will think him capable of that profe≈ø≈øion. And yet how rare among≈øt the greate≈øt part of tho≈øe that think them≈øelves no mean Farriers, is the knowledge of that Creature they practi≈øe upon? whereas it is plain, ≈øeeing they know not the ≈øituation and u≈øe of the parts, they can make but wide gue≈ø≈øes at the ≈øeat or nature of the di≈øtemper, and ≈øo mu≈øt admini≈øter their Medicines at random and at all adventures, and be in the mo≈øt opprobrious ≈øen≈øe Hor≈øe-doctors.

Nay I will be bold to ≈øay ≈øomething more (which I hope I may ≈øpeak without the envy of Phy≈øicians, for whom I have a profound re≈øpect) that in ≈øome regards Anatomy is more nece≈ø≈øary
to Farriers than to them, in order to find out di≈øea≈øes: For be≈øides the pul≈øe and the urine, and the pathognomonick ≈øigns (as they call them) of each di≈øtemper, they are a≈ø≈øi≈øted in their enquiry moreover (not to ≈øay chiefly) by the complaints and relations of the Patients them≈øelves: whereas a Farrier having to do with a dumb creature, mu≈øt be very curious in his knowledge of the parts with their offices, and of the ≈øympathy or con≈øent that one part hath with another; or el≈øe, ≈øeeing all his information mu≈øt be of his own hammering out, he's like to make but a ≈øhort di≈øcovery of the di≈øtemper.

How nece≈ø≈øary the knowledge of the parts is to the di≈øcerning of di≈øea≈øes. Now there are two things chiefly nece≈ø≈øary to the judging or di≈øcerning of a di≈øea≈øe, namely the Affection or di≈øtemper, and the part Affected or di≈øtempered; the ≈øignes of which are many, but e≈øpecially from the action of the part affected: As for example, he that knows the action of the Stomach to be concoction or dige≈øtion, if the concoction be impaired or hindred, he may ea≈øily judge that the Stomach is ill affected. So likewi≈øe he that knows the ≈øituation of the Liver to be on the right ≈øide, and the Spleen on the left; if the right ≈øide be ≈øore or do ≈øwell, he cannot but know that the Liver and not the Spleen is affected, and will therefore apply his remedies accordingly. Now he that is ignorant of the parts of the Body ≈øhall ill know either the ≈øituation or action of either the≈øe parts mentioned or any other: and there is no way to come to the under≈øtanding of them but by Anatomy.

Seeing then the profit and nece≈ø≈øity of under≈øtanding Anatomy is ≈øuch and of ≈øo great u≈øe to us, I thought I could not ≈øpend my time and endeavours on any thing more conducing to the advancement of our profe≈ø≈øion, than by applying my ≈øelf unto it in the fir≈øt place; wherein having none that have gone before me or ≈øhew'd me the way, I hope all ingenuous men will be favourable to my undertaking, and not be over ≈øevere Cen≈øors of any Imperfections they may po≈ø≈øibly meet with in the following Treati≈øe; and I hope al≈øo that having broken the Ice, as we ≈øay, all de≈øerving Arti≈øts will be excited to Emulation.

A definition of Anatomy. This Treati≈øe then de≈øigning to teach the Anatomy of an Hor≈øe, we mu≈øt in the fir≈øt place let you know what Anatomy is: It is an opening or cutting up of the Body of any Animal or living Creature what≈øoever, whether frequenting the land or water,
whereby the knowledge of the frame of its body, and the u≈øe of its parts may be attained unto.

How it is taught. Now this knowledge may be obtained two ways, namely by In≈øpection, or by In≈øtruction; both which ways are very nece≈ø≈øary, but the fir≈øt is the more certain, though the latter carrieth more grace and ≈øtate.
The fir≈øt, which is In≈øpection, is to look into either the Figures of the parts of Hor≈øes onely, or into the bodies of Hor≈øes them≈øelves.
The latter, which is In≈øtruction, is by the Voice of a Teacher or In≈øtructor, or by the Writings of famous and renowned men.

The Figures of the parts how far nece≈ø≈øary. As to the Figures of the parts, they are thus far nece≈ø≈øary, viz. they daily repre≈øent to us ≈øuch parts as we have not the opportunity to ≈øee in the bodies them≈øelves: For it is not ea≈øy to find in all places (nor at ≈øuch times when we ≈øtand in mo≈øt need of them) ≈øuch a ≈øtore of dead bodies as is nece≈ø≈øary for us to practi≈øe upon; wherefore to ≈øupply the want of ≈øuch bodies, I do think the≈øe Figures u≈øefull, and have therefore accordingly by a curious draught or delineation repre≈øented to you ≈øuch ob≈øervations as are made in true di≈ø≈øections, not by copying out every part, but chiefly tho≈øe that are mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for us to under≈øtand, omitting tho≈øe of le≈øs con≈øideration, le≈øt I ≈øhould make this Volume ≈øwell too big, and become too chargeable, whereby ≈øuch would be di≈øcouraged from buying it, for whom I chiefly intend it.

A Caution. But although I approve of the≈øe Figures as nece≈ø≈øary, to be by us, upon occa≈øion; yet this caution I mu≈øt give to the Student, that he do not tru≈øt too much to the≈øe Copies, as I may call them, without practi≈øing upon the original body it ≈øelf: For as it is not po≈ø≈øible to make a good Commander by viewing onely repre≈øentative Armies, without practice and experience in real Engagements; ≈øo is it vain for you to think to attain to the exact knowledge of Anatomy by minding the Figures onely.

Neither would I have any that undertakes this ≈øtudy to be di≈øcouraged, for fear they ≈øhould not get ≈øuch bodies as I have
mentioned (I mean Hor≈øes bodies) ≈øufficient for them to practi≈øe upon; for they may, to ≈øupply the want of ≈øuch, take the bodies of A≈ø≈øes or Mules, of Sheep and Oxen, Hogs or Dogs, any of which come near the bodies you de≈øire, e≈øpecially as to the ≈øituation and u≈øe, as al≈øo hidden motions of the Internal parts: for if tho≈øe motions be the ≈øame in Bea≈øts as in Men, as by a very worthySee Doctor Crooke, lib. 1. chap. 9." Authour they are affirmed to be, (who ≈øaith that the motions of the Heart, the Arteries, the Midriff, the Brain and Guts are the ≈øame in Bea≈øts as in Men) they mu≈øt certainly be the ≈øame in one Bea≈øt as in another.

The method of Anatomy. Next we come to ≈øhew after what manner you are to take in hand the di≈ø≈øection of any of the≈øe Creatures, and that you mu≈øt not doe confu≈øedly nor di≈øorderly, but with due cour≈øe of proceeding. For the doing of which take the≈øe following Rules.

Fir≈øt then, you mu≈øt begin with that which is be≈øt known and mo≈øt ea≈øie, which are the external or outward parts; for as much as the knowledge of them is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, as to Cures Chirurgical: and the≈øe parts are commonly di≈øtingui≈øhed into two kinds; one of which are called ≈øpermatical and ≈øolid, which are ≈øuppo≈øed to be bred of ≈øeed, and ≈øuch are Bones, Gri≈øtles and Ligaments; and the other ≈øanguineous, ≈øaid to be generated of bloud, as Mu≈øcles.

I ≈øhall not in this place give you any particular in≈øtructions for the anatomi≈øing any of the≈øe parts, referring you for them to the book it ≈øelf: onely adverti≈øe you of this, that when you de≈øire a Body for examining the ≈øolid parts, the bodies of old and lean Hor≈øes are the fitte≈øt, in regard the fle≈øh and fat will not ≈øo much hinder, nor hide the parts from you, as in fat Hor≈øes they will.

You are al≈øo to ob≈øerve that there is a two-fold way of proceeding in di≈ø≈øection: The one is where there is a plenty, the other where there is a ≈øcarcity of dead bodies. If there be a plenty, then you may look into the Mu≈øcles of one, into the Entrails of another, and into the Ve≈ø≈øels of a third, &c. not mattering though you ≈øpoil one part in di≈øcovering another: but where they are ≈øo ≈øcarce that you can get but one body and that ≈øeldome too, then if you would ≈øee all in that body, great skill mu≈øt be u≈øed to ≈øhew every thing in its order and place.

Now order of di≈ø≈øection requires that you ≈øhould fir≈øt begin with the Head, it being the mo≈øt noble and excellent part; next to that the Che≈øt, and la≈øtly the Belly: but this (as I have ≈øaid) is not to be done where there is but one body, for there you mu≈øt begin with tho≈øe parts that are mo≈øt ≈øubject to Corruption, wherefore you mu≈øt fir≈øt cut up the Lower Belly, then the Che≈øt, and la≈øtly the Head; both which ways are often u≈øed; the fir≈øt being called the way of dignity, and the other of diuturnity; the one being more noble, and the other of a longer durance.

I ≈øhall not here treat of any of the parts contained in the≈øe three Regions or Venters, but will leave them till I come to ≈øpeak of them in their order in the following Treati≈øe, my de≈øign being to be as brief as may be, and not to repeat any thing over ≈øeveral times, as I have ≈øeen ≈øome Authours have done. Therefore I ≈øhall put an end to this Introduction when I ≈øhall have informed you, that all the parts which fall under the Anatomi≈øts knife to be examined are commonly reduced to two heads, namely, ≈øimple or ≈øimilar, and compound or di≈ø≈øimilar.

1. The divi≈øion of the parts, into Simple, Tho≈øe that are generally accounted ≈øimple parts, are in number ten, namely, a Bone, a Gri≈øtle, a Ligament, a Membrane, a Fibre, a Nerve, an Artery, a Vein, Fle≈øh and Skin. The≈øe are called ≈øimple or ≈øimilar, becau≈øe every particle of them is of the ≈øame name and ≈øub≈øtance; as every part of a bone is bone, &c.

Yet three of the≈øe ten, though they are generally accounted ≈øimple parts, if ≈øtrictly taken cannot be truly reputed ≈øo; for fir≈øt, Veins are made of a coat, fibres and valves; ≈øecondly, Arteries are made of two coats or skins different from one another; and for Nerves, their inner ≈øub≈øtance is medullar or marrowey, and the outward, membranous or skinny: ≈øo that of truly ≈øimilar or ≈øimple parts, there are onely ≈øeven, namely, Bones, Gri≈øtles, Ligaments, Membranes, Fibres, Fle≈øh and Skin.

2. Compound. The Di≈ø≈øimilar or compound parts are tho≈øe, which, contrary to the ≈øimple, may be divided into ≈øeveral particles or parcels of unlike or different ≈øub≈øtance and denomination: As
for example, A Leg may be cut into ≈øeveral pieces, yet not into ≈øeveral Legs, but into Fle≈øh, Bones, Veins and other things which it is compounded of; whereas, as was ≈øaid, a ≈øimilar part though it be divided into parcels, yet tho≈øe are ≈øtill like one another, and of the ≈øame nature: for ≈øuppo≈øe a Ligament be cut into many pieces, every piece partakes onely and truly of the nature of a Ligament, and all remain what they were before, their length or other accident onely excepted.

Thus much for the Introduction, wherein I mainly intended to ≈øhew the method of Anatomy, and to hint the rea≈øon of my undertaking; It now remains that I addre≈øs my ≈øelf to the Work it ≈øelf, which ≈øhall be writ with the greate≈øt plainne≈øs its nature is capable of, that I may thereby attain to that wi≈øhed end I ≈øet before me, namely, the benefiting of my Reader.

div.head: THE ANATOMY OF AN HORSE.
BOOK I. Of the Lowe≈øt Belly or Paunch.
CHAP. I. Of the Parts inve≈øting the whole Body, and fir≈øt of the Hair.

argument.p: Whereof Hairs are ingendred. How nouri≈øhed. How the Hair comes to fall off. Rea≈øons for the different colour of the hairs. Their u≈øe.

div.p: BEFORE I take in pieces this Goodly Creature, It will not be ami≈øs if I fir≈øt give you an account of all the≈øe Parts as they lie in order, beginning with that which fir≈øt appeareth to our View, and that is the Scarf-skin adorned with hairs, wherein (as in a Ca≈øe) Nature hath wrapped this ≈øtately Bea≈øt; be≈øides which there are other four, that, with this, are common to the whole body, which are, fir≈øt, the true skin, which lieth next under it; then the fle≈øhy pannicle; under that the fat; and la≈øtly the common membrane of the Mu≈øcles. Be≈øides the≈øe five, there are other Inve≈øting parts, but they are onely proper to particular parts of the body, to which I will ≈øpeak in their due place, and onely of the common ones here.

Fir≈øt then I will begin with the Hairs, becau≈øe they meet fir≈øt with the Sen≈øe. They are ≈øaid to be ingendred of a clammy and earthy Excrement of the third concoction, ≈øo that them≈øelves are reputed not ≈øo properly to be called parts of the body, as Excrements. They are void of ≈øen≈øe and of animal life, yet they have a vegetative life, ≈øuch as Plants have, to which they owe their growth.

The≈øe Hairs are by ≈øome thought to have for their nouri≈øhment a proportionable quantity of that juice of which they are generated, continually mini≈øtred unto them. Others think that the Hairs being hollow and porous are nouri≈øhed as the Feathers of Fowl are, and that is by bloud; for if one pull off a Feather from a young Bird that is unfledged, a pretty deal of its ≈øtem will appear bloudy. But though we ≈øhould grant that the matter of their nouri≈øhment were made of bloud, yet certainly it mu≈øt be very much altered and degenerate from its own nature, before it can be adapted to the hair, ≈øeeing the hair of a Man's head (for example) grows not onely in living per≈øons, who≈øe bloud runs briskly in their Arteries and Veins, whereby it is kept from corruption, but al≈øo in the dead, in whom the whole ma≈øs of bloud is devoid of all nutritive power, as has been often ob≈øerved in bodies pre≈øerved unburied. But what≈øoever the humour be that nouri≈øhes them, it is thru≈øt through the skin by the pores thereof, the action and heat of the body a≈ø≈øi≈øting thereunto, where the purer part of it enters the roots of the hair, but the more earthy not being able to enter ≈øuch almo≈øt unperceivable pores, is driven out among≈øt the hair where it becomes du≈øt; which du≈øt is that that is brought forth with the Curry-combe when a Hor≈øe is dre≈øt. From hence then it is, that a Hor≈øe, though he be never ≈øo well dre≈ø≈øed one morning, and never ≈øo clean kept till the next, he ≈øhall notwith≈øtanding be as full of du≈øt as he was the morning before; for the cleaner the skin of a Hor≈øe is kept, the more open are its pores to tran≈ømit a more plentifull nouri≈øhment to the hair, whence al≈øo there is a greater collection of this excrementitious du≈øt.

And hence may be gathered a rea≈øon of the ≈øhedding of the hair, which is ob≈øerved to happen in many Hor≈øes that have ill keeping, ≈øuch as your Cart-hor≈øes that ≈øeldom have any labour be≈øtowed upon them, for want of which dre≈ø≈øing, to remove the du≈øt which lieth upon the mouths of the pores or at the roots of the hairs, the pa≈ø≈øages, through which the juice ≈øhould come that nouri≈øhes the hair, are ob≈øtructed or ≈øtopped, and ≈øo like dead Leaves from a Tree in Autumn they drop off, or as untimely Fruit falls before the ≈øea≈øon of the year requireth it.

As for the Colours of the hairs, they are various, according as is the humour which doth predominate in the body: for ≈øuch as the humour is which is driven forth towards the skin for their nouri≈øhment, ≈øuch will the colour of the hair be. As for In≈øtance:

If the cholerick humour doth mo≈øt predominate, then are the hairs of a black, a Sorrel or a Che≈øtnut colour; If bloud mo≈øt predominate, then will the Hor≈øe be a bright Bay or Roan; If flegme, then the Hor≈øe will be of a milk-white or yellow-dun; If melancholy, then will the Hor≈øe be of an Iron-gray or Mou≈øe-dun. Thus much for the colour of the hairs, next I come to the u≈øe of them.

The u≈øe of the hairs is, fir≈øt, to cover the skin; ≈øecondly, to defend it; thirdly, to be an ornament to it; and la≈øtly, as I have before ≈øhewed, to ≈øuck up that excrementitious ≈øuperfluous juice which through the pores of the skin is ≈øent from all parts of the body to them.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Cuticle or Scarf-skin.

argument.p: The Scarf-skin. Its u≈øe.

div.p: THE Hide on which the hairs already ≈øpoken of do grow, con≈øi≈øts of two Skins, the outer of which is called the Scarf-skin, ≈øerving to defend the Body from outward Injuries, and for that intent is of it ≈øelf In≈øen≈øible, that it may the better indure the violence of the weather, or other harms which many times happen to it. And for that cau≈øe, Nature hath ≈øo ordered it, that if at any time it happeneth to be rubb'd off, as often it is by an ill Saddle, and many other ways, it groweth again without a ≈øcar or blemi≈øh, provided the Parts under it (as particularly the true Skin) be not al≈øo violated; for they being ≈øpermatical Parts, or made of Seed, cannot ea≈øily be re≈øtored, which is the rea≈øon that mo≈øt Wounds will not heal up without a ≈øcar. Now this Scarf-skin having its matter (of which it is made) from the true Skin and the Ve≈ø≈øels that terminate in it, which are of all ≈øorts, both Veins, Arteries and Nerves, none of which reach any farther than the true Skin, it is apparent that this Skin is without ≈øen≈øe, it being their office alone to communicate both life, ≈øen≈øe and motion to all parts of the Body. And that this Skin is void of ≈øen≈øe, may be ≈øeen by the cutting of it; as thus, If you cut onely through this Skin, when you go to Rowel a Hor≈øe, you ≈øhall not find the Hor≈øe move for it, neither will it bleed; but if you cut ≈øo far as to touch the true Skin under it, you will find him both ≈øtir and bleed, for then you touch the little threads of the Ve≈ø≈øels, and by violating them, you cau≈øe the Hor≈øe to feel pain, and al≈øo bloud to i≈ø≈øue forth.

The u≈øe of this Skin, be≈øides being a covering to the whole Body, is to cover the mouths of tho≈øe ≈ømall hairy Ve≈ø≈øels already ≈øpoken of, that the bloud, ≈øpirits, or other ichorous or watery Matter do not i≈ø≈øue from them, which otherwi≈øe they would. Yet its Pores are ≈øo large as to permit the vapourous moi≈øture that is thru≈øt out of all parts of the Body to it, to pa≈øs through them, either in the form of ≈øweat, or by in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration. The≈øe Pores being many times ob≈øtructed or con≈øtringed by a ≈øudden cold taken after hard riding, by giving the Hor≈øe cold Water too ≈øoon after it, or by wa≈øhing him too high in cold Water when he is hot, the Vapours are thereby hindered from coming forth, and ≈øo are detained between the two Skins, and there generate evill Di≈øtempers, or at lea≈øt fall from thence into the Limbs, and there cau≈øe Inflammations and breakings out, which we call Grea≈øe in the heels or Scratchets.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Cutis or true Skin.

argument.p: The true Skin. Its ≈øub≈øtante. Ve≈ø≈øels. Colour. ∆≤≈øe.

div.p: UNder this Scarf, lieth the true Skin, which the Latines call Cutis. Its ≈øub≈øtance, as I have before ≈øhewed, is ≈øaid to be ≈øpermatical, ≈øuch as being once lo≈øt, cannot be re≈øtored as formerly it was, but is reunited by a cicatrice or ≈øcar, that is bred of the dried and con≈øtringed fle≈øh under it; which is the rea≈øon no hairs will grow upon that part of the Skin where the ≈øcar is, becau≈øe it is callous and de≈øtitute of Pores in which they ≈øhould grow. This Skin doth encompa≈øs the whole Body as well as the Scarf, and hath the ≈øame pa≈ø≈øages for the receiving in, and letting out, for the ea≈øe and relief of the Body, as that hath.

It hath for its nouri≈øhment, life, and ≈øen≈øe, Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts, Veins, Arteries and Nerves, divaricated and branched through it in the ≈ømalle≈øt hair-like threads, all which terminate in it, none of them being in≈øerted into the Cuticle.

As for its colour, it varieth as do the humours in the Body; for that humour which mo≈øt abounds, coloureth it with its proper re≈øpective colour; as for example, If bloud mo≈øt abound, then is it mo≈øt red; if choler do mo≈øt predominate, then is it yellowi≈øh; and ≈øo for the other humours.

Its u≈øe is principally to inve≈øt and defend the Body, as I have ≈øaid before of the Scarf-skin: for as that keeps it from the violent impre≈ø≈øion of either exce≈ø≈øive heat, or cold; ≈øo doth this Skin re≈øtrain, and, as it were, wall in (as in a Ca≈øtle) all the ≈øpirits and natural heat, which would otherwi≈øe in hot weather, or in violent exerci≈øe be ≈øo fa≈øt ≈øpent, that they would leave the vital parts de≈øtitute, which would occa≈øion the lo≈øs of your Bea≈øt. But though Nature has made this provi≈øion to hinder the di≈ø≈øipation of the ≈øpirits, yet has ≈øhe framed the Skin (as well as the Scarf-skin) full of ≈ømall Pores, through which upon violent exerci≈øe do i≈ø≈øue in great plenty hot and moi≈øt vapours, which are that we call ≈øweat; yea though the Bea≈øt be at re≈øt, if the Air be any whit mild or temperate, warm ≈øteams are continually a pa≈ø≈øing through them by in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration.

It's al≈øo as ≈øerviceable in cold weather, for then the more fiercely it is be≈øieged by the cold, the narrower do the afore≈øaid Pores pur≈øe up them≈øelves, whereby the internal heat is detained within, and the external cold kept out.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the fle≈øhy Pannicle.

argument.p: The names of the fle≈øhy Pannicle. Its ≈øituation, and extent. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its ∆≤≈øe.

div.p: NEXT to the true Skin, lieth the fle≈øhy Pannicle, called membrana Carno≈øa, or panniculus carno≈øus, becau≈øe in mo≈øt parts of the Body, it comes near to the nature of fle≈øh, and is truly mu≈øcular.

In Man this Membrane is ≈øaid to lie under the Fat, though ≈øome very curious Anatomi≈øts deny that Man has any ≈øuch Membrane at all, ≈øave in the Forehead; and of this opinion is Dr. Gli≈ø≈øon. I will not intermeddle in that Controver≈øie, as being not proper for me; but in Hor≈øes it lies immediately under the Skin, above the Fat, and is more like to a Mu≈øcle than a Membrane. In fleying off the Skin, you mu≈øt be very carefull and curious, or el≈øe you will take this Pannicle off along with it, it is ≈øo clo≈øely knit to it by Fibres and innumerable Ve≈ø≈øels that go between. It is of the ≈øame extent and figure as the true Skin, inve≈øting the whole Body as that does; but in ≈øome Parts it is almo≈øt wholly fle≈øhy, and in others altogether membranous.

It has Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts as the Skin has, for before they can reach the Skin, they mu≈øt pierce through this Membrane; and as they pa≈øs through, they ≈øend forth many ≈ømall twigs into it, both Veins, Arteries and Nerves, but e≈øpecially Nerves to a≈ø≈øi≈øt its motion, whence it is by ≈øome called the nervous Membrane.

The u≈øe of it is chiefly to ≈øerve for a Mu≈øcle to move the Skin, whereby the Bea≈øt ≈øhakes off the Flies, or any other thing that offends him. It ≈øerves al≈øo to defend the neighbouring Parts, and to ≈øtrengthen in their pa≈ø≈øage the Ve≈ø≈øels which are di≈ø≈øeminated into the true Skin. It al≈øo hinders the Fat from being melted and ≈øpent by the continual motion of the Mu≈øcles. And la≈øtly, it helpeth to heal or clo≈øe up the Skin when it is cut or otherwi≈øe hurt; for the Skin being a ≈øpermatick Part cannot be bred anew, and therefore this fle≈øhy Membrane helps to glew as it were the ≈øides of it together again, growing into one body with it, and making what we call a Scar.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Fat, and Common Membrane of the Mu≈øcles.

argument.p: Fat, its difference and matter. How generated. The u≈øes of Fat. The common membrane of the Mu≈øcles.

div.p:
FAT is of two ≈øorts, and is di≈øtingui≈øhed by two ≈øeveral Names as well in Latin as Engli≈øh. That which we are to ≈øpeak of in this Chapter is called in Latin pinguedo, and in Engli≈øh Fat; but that which is within the Belly and makes up the Caul and Me≈øentery and covers the Kidneys, is named ≈øevum, Suet or Tallow. The former will not congeal
≈øo quickly or ≈øo hard as this latter will. Both the one and the other are made of an oily part of the bloud; and this we are to treat of here, is congealed between the Carnous Membrane de≈øcribed in the foregoing Chapter, and the Common Membrane of the Mu≈øcles.

This Fat is the fourth common covering of the whole Body, for there is no Part which has the re≈øt of the common coverings, but has this al≈øo, if the Hor≈øe be not extreme lean; though the fatte≈øt have it not in any great plenty. Now as all Food that is eaten, con≈øi≈øts of ≈øeveral parts or principles, which the Chymi≈øts can ≈øeparate one from another, namely Salt, Spirit and Oyl; ≈øo the Food, that con≈øi≈øts of the≈øe ≈øeveral principles, when it is taken into the Body, and concocted in the Stomach (which is natural Chymi≈øtry, as I may call it) has them ≈øo loo≈øened one from another, that each principle pa≈ø≈øes into the nouri≈øhment and increa≈øe of that part that is of the ≈øame nature with it. Among≈øt the re≈øt the oily part, (which is otherwi≈øe called the Sulphureous, becau≈øe it will flame like Brim≈øtone) ≈øweating as it were through the pores of the Ve≈ø≈øels and ≈øubjacent parts towards the ≈øurface of the Body, is ≈øtopt by the clo≈øene≈øs and compactne≈øs of the fle≈øhy Membrane, and there congeals into Fat. Now this Fat is not one continued body as Butter or (what we call) tryed Suet is; but is included in innumerable membranous partitions or cells, almo≈øt like Honey-combs, (which it is likely are borrowed from the fle≈øhy Pannicle) which makes the Fat to appear ≈øomewhat ≈øpongy. It is not ea≈øie to give a rea≈øon of this oily humour's turning into Fat; for it cannot be by cold, ≈øeeing the Bea≈øt is always actually warm; much le≈øs can it be by heat, which is apter to melt Fat into Oyl, than to harden Oyl into Fat: therefore ≈øome make a moderate heat to be the efficient of it. 'Tis true indeed that the Bea≈øt is moderately hot, and we ≈øee by experience that Fat is generated; but that that is the cau≈øe of this, I dare not affirm. My apprehen≈øion of it is this: That when the oily Matter i≈ø≈øues out of the Veins and Arteries, &c. there pa≈ø≈øes along with it much thin watry humour; And when they both come to the fle≈øhy Membrane, this latter being thin, evaporates through it and is evacuated by ≈øweat or in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration; but the other being thicker and more clammy, is forced to ≈øtay behind, and lo≈øing by degrees that wheyi≈øh humour that before kept it liquid, it curdles into Fat.

The u≈øe of the Fat is, like a Garment, to keep the Body warm, and cheri≈øh the natural heat, which by its clammine≈øs it hinders from evaporating too much; and on the other ≈øide by its thickne≈øs it ≈øtoppeth the Pores ≈øo, that the cold cannot enter in.

It al≈øo fills up the empty ≈øpaces between the Mu≈øcles, and the wrinkles of the Skin, by which the Hor≈øe is made plump, ≈ømooth and beautifull; and therefore old, lean and decrepit Hor≈øes are deformed for want of Fat.
It ≈øerves al≈øo as a pillow or bulwark again≈øt any violence, either from blows, brui≈øes or heavy weights, and the like.

Finally, it relieveth ≈øuch Creatures as abound with it, in time of ≈øcarcity or want of ≈øu≈øtenance, by being converted into nouri≈øhment; for it ≈øerves as aliment, and holdeth the parts of the Body in play, till the Creature attain its proper Food.

The fifth and la≈øt common Covering of the Body, is the Common Membrane of the Mu≈øcles. This is ≈øpread over all the Mu≈øcles (immediately under the Fat) and is knit by Fibres to that Membrane which is proper to each Mu≈øcle, but ≈øomewhat loo≈øely, that it might not hinder
their motion by inve≈øting them too clo≈øely. It is ≈øaid to ari≈øe from the Back-bone, becau≈øe it cleaves mo≈øt firmly to the Spine thereof, and is ≈øtronger there, than in its other Parts. In an Hor≈øe it is as thick as Parchment, and very ≈øtrong. And its u≈øe is to confirm and ≈øtrengthen the Mu≈øcles in general in their proper ≈øituation, and to be as it were a Ca≈øe for them to move glibly in, and to defend them from injuries.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Inve≈øting Parts proper to the Lower Belly.

argument.p: The Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen or Paunch. What a Mu≈øcle is. Mu≈øcles are the in≈øtrument of voluntary motion. Involuntary or natural motion is performed without Mu≈øcles, properly ≈øo called. A Mu≈øcle is an organical and di≈ø≈øimilar part. Of what ≈øimple parts it con≈øi≈øts. Why called a Mu≈øcle. Whence Mu≈øcles have di≈øtinct names. A Mu≈øcle divided into parts. The Oblique de≈øcending external pair. The Oblique a≈øcending internal pair. Their Action. The right or ≈øtreight pair. Their Action. The pyramidal Mu≈øcles. The tran≈øver≈øe or overthwart Mu≈øcles. Their Action. The action of all the≈øe Mu≈øcles together. The white Line what it is.

div.p: HAVING ≈øhewed you what are the common inve≈øting or containing parts of the whole Body, I come now to ≈øhew which are tho≈øe that are proper to the Lower Belly in particular, and tho≈øe are onely two, be≈øides tho≈øe common ones already ≈øpoken of, namely the Mu≈øcles of the Paunch, and the Rim of the Belly.

Now by the Lower Belly we under≈øtand all that cavity (and onely that) which is below the Midriff, and is encompa≈ø≈øed by the ≈øhort Ribs, the point of the Brea≈øt-bone, Loins, Haunch-bones, and Share-bones, and is filled with the Guts and other Entrails.

The Mu≈øcles are in all Hor≈øes of a like number,which is on each ≈øide four. The fir≈øt pair that ≈øhew them≈øelves are called the External oblique pair; the next are the Internal oblique pair; the third are the two right or ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles; and under the≈øe are the two tran≈øver≈øe Mu≈øcles, ≈øo called from their going cro≈øs the Belly.
But before I proceed any further in de≈øcribing the≈øe Mu≈øcles, I will fir≈øt ≈øhew what a Mu≈øcle is, and whereof it is compounded, and al≈øo the ≈øeveral u≈øes of the Mu≈øcles in general.

The Mu≈øcles, if you take them in a large ≈øignification, are all that which we call Fle≈øh; which Fle≈øh may be divided into many pieces or parcels without cutting or breaking any of them, if with care undertaken; and each piece ≈øo ≈øeparable, is named a Mu≈øcle.

Now the≈øe pieces have each their ≈øeveral di≈øtinct Epithets, appellations or names from ≈øeveral con≈øiderations, as from their ≈øituation, ≈øhape, u≈øe, &c. but are all called Mu≈øcles, their office being to perform the voluntary motion: which motion is performed ≈øix ≈øeveral ways, namely, upwards, downwards, forwards, backwards, to the right hand and to the left. All which motions are performed in this manner.

You mu≈øt know that all or mo≈øt of the Mu≈øcles of the Body have each their Oppo≈øite or Antagoni≈øt, ≈øo that the one being contracted or drawn together, (which is its proper motion) the oppo≈øite at the ≈øame time is relaxed or loo≈øned; and contrarily when that which upon the former motion was relaxed, does it ≈øelf enter upon motion, it is contracted, whil≈øt that which was before contracted, is now relaxed. As for example, when you ≈øtretch out either your Arm, or Leg, that motion is performed by one of the≈øe Mu≈øcles; and when you draw your Arm, or Leg back again, that is performed by the other.

But here let none ≈øo far mi≈øunder≈øtand me as to think that either an Arm or Leg can be either ≈øtretcht forth or drawn back by the help of one Mu≈øcle alone; but as to either of the before mentioned Limbs there are ≈øeveral parts belonging, ≈øo do the di≈øtinct Mu≈øcles of every part perform (at the ≈øame time) the offices afore≈øaid.
Neither can this voluntary motion be performed without the help of a Sinew or Nerve, by which the Spirits are brought from the Brain which give the Mu≈øcles their moving faculty.

Now there are other motions of the Body which are not performed by the Mu≈øcles, ≈øuch as is (according to ≈øome) the pul≈øation of the Heart and Arteries, the peri≈øtaltick motion of the Stomach and Guts, of the pa≈ø≈øage of the Gall, and of the Ureters, and ≈øeveral other Parts which have their continual motions whether the Hor≈øe be ≈øleeping or waking, and will perform their ≈øeveral motions as well in Men as Bea≈øts, whether we will or not. Wherefore the≈øe are called not Voluntary, or Natural.
I ≈øhall in the next place ≈øhew what parts the Mu≈øcles are compounded of, and tho≈øe are agreed upon by all Authours of Anatomy to be the≈øe.

A Mu≈øcle being an organical Part is compo≈øed of Nerves, Fle≈øh, Fibres, Veins and Arteries, all covered or inve≈øted with a proper Coat or Skin. It is called organical, becau≈øe it is the in≈øtrument or organ of an action, to wit, motion. And that it is al≈øo di≈ø≈øimilar, the ≈øeveral kinds of parts whereof it is made, do evidently prove. The ≈øeveral u≈øes of the parts that make up a Mu≈øcle are the≈øe: The Fibres and Tendon are the immediate in≈øtruments of its action; The Fle≈øh properly ≈øo called filleth up the inter≈øtices or di≈øtances between the Fibres; The Arteries by importing vital ≈øpirit and bloud do con≈øerve the inbred heat, and help to nouri≈øh it; The Veins do convey back to the Heart all that bloud that remains from the nouri≈øhment of the Mu≈øcle; The Nerves convey animal Spirit to the Fibres and Tendon, whereby they are enabled for their action; and the Membrane or Skin which incompa≈ø≈øeth the Mu≈øcle, doth keep it together, and di≈øtingui≈øhes one from another.

Having ≈øhewed what a Mu≈øcle is, and the ≈øeveral ≈øimple parts whereof it is made, I ≈øhall next ≈øhew you why it is ≈øo called. It is called mus, or mu≈øculus, by the Latins, for that it is like a fley'd Mou≈øe, or a Fi≈øh which is called mu≈øculus; and by ≈øome Authours it is called by the name of lacertus, from its ≈øimilitude with a Creature called a Lizard. Yet there can be no one certain figure whereby to re≈øemble it, by rea≈øon of its ≈øundry ≈øhapes; but that it is like a fley'd Mou≈øe in colour, cannot be denied.

Now the Mu≈øcles being many in number have accordingly many names, which names they take from either their Figure, their Situation, or their Action, and many times from their U≈øe; al≈øo ≈øometimes from their In≈øertion, and ≈øometimes from their Magnitude.

And although there be ≈øuch difference in the Mu≈øcles, in re≈øpect of their Figures, their Magnitude, their Situation, and the like, yet are they ≈øo united or conjoyned together through the whole Body, in ≈øo clo≈øe a manner, that in many places they are hard to be ≈øeparated, except at ≈øome times, when either wind, ≈øome wheyi≈øh humour or ≈øome other matter gets between them, and then many times they will gape, and are at ≈øome di≈øtance the one from the other.

Yet are they not ≈øo clo≈øely united neither, but that by a carefull and expert Di≈ø≈øector they may be ≈øeparated, and one divided from another;
after which, to ≈øee the ≈øeveral parts of a Mu≈øcle ≈øeverally, you mu≈øt divide it al≈øo, which is on this manner.

Some divide a Mu≈øcle into two parts, which are a fle≈øhy and a tendinous part; Again, they divide it into other three parts, namely, the Head, the Middle and the Tail. By the Head is to be under≈øtood the beginning or original of a Mu≈øcle, which is one while ligamentous and nervous, and otherwhiles fle≈øhy: By the Middle is that part meant which is ab≈øolutely fle≈øhy; and by the Tail, the Tendon, con≈øi≈øting of the numerous Fibres that are extended through the Mu≈øcle, and the Membrane that inve≈øts it, which grow by little and little into one body, and compo≈øe this Tendon, that is the tail of the Mu≈øcle. It is ≈øometimes round, ≈øometimes broad; other times long, and otherwhiles ≈øhort, thicker or ≈ølenderer according to the part it appertains to, or according to the u≈øe it is put to; it being but nece≈ø≈øary that tho≈øe Parts which are moved mo≈øt ≈øtrongly or vehemently, ≈øhould have thicker and ≈øtronger Tendons. Thus much for the Mu≈øcles in general.

Now I come to the particular Mu≈øcles, the fir≈øt of which are the Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen or Paunch, of which I have ≈øpoken ≈øomething in the beginning of this Chapter, the which I ≈øhall now further pro≈øecute, and let you know how they are ≈øituated. The pair that in di≈ø≈øection fir≈øt offer them≈øelves are called the Oblique (or ≈ølanting) De≈øcending External pair, which pair are the broade≈øt of all the re≈øt,though it is by many Authours ≈øaid that the oblique internal are equal in figure, magnitude, ≈øtrength and action. The original or ri≈øe of the≈øe Mu≈øcles is from the ≈øide of the Brea≈øt-bone, the lower edge of five or ≈øix of the lowe≈øt Ribs, and from the tips of the cro≈øs or tran≈øver≈øe proce≈ø≈øes of the Joints of the Rack-bone in the Loins. Their ri≈øe from the Ribs imitates the teeth of a Saw; for ≈øpringing with a narrow point from the lower ≈øide of the Rib, every ≈øuch point grows broader and broader, till it unite with the two next it on each ≈øide, ≈øo that there is a ≈øpace of above an inch between every point, into which empty ≈øpaces the greater Saw-like Mu≈øcle of the Brea≈øt ends with like points. From their ri≈øe they run ≈øloping downwards toward the white line (≈øo called) in the middle of the Belly; but before they reach half way thither, they lo≈øe their fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance, and become tendinous, and their Tendon is ≈øo united to the common Membrane of the Mu≈øcles, de≈øcribed in the foregoing Chapter, that it ≈øeems to become one with it, and running over the ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles is in≈øerted into the fore≈øaid white Line, down even to the very Share-bone, into which al≈øo it is in≈øerted.

The next to the≈øe are the Oblique A≈øcending Internal pair, ≈øo called becau≈øe of the contrary cour≈øe of their Fibres to tho≈øe of the External; for as tho≈øe de≈øcend obliquely or a≈ølant, ≈øo do the≈øe a≈øcend in like manner. Their ri≈øe is from the Rib of the Haunch-bone, and from the proce≈ø≈øes of the vertebrae of the Loins and os ≈øacrum; and their Tendon is extended to the ≈øhort Ribs partly, and partly to the white line, above the Navel, adhering to the common Membrane of the Mu≈øcles as was ≈øaid before of the oblique de≈øcending, where it is not cover'd by the Tendon of that Mu≈øcle. The≈øe have a different action from the former; for whereas the External pair do draw the lower part of the Belly towards the Brea≈øt, where they have their original; the≈øe on the contrary draw down the Che≈øt with a kind of ≈ølanting motion towards the Hips; it being the action of all Mu≈øcles to draw towards their original, and the original of the≈øe Mu≈øcles is (as was ≈øaid) at the Rib of the Haunch-bone.

After the≈øe follow the Right or Streight Pair, ≈øo called becau≈øe their Fibres run ≈øtreight down the Belly as do the Mu≈øcles them≈øelves: for their original is at the ≈øides of the ≈øword fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle at the end of the Brea≈øt-bone, and from the gri≈øtly ends of the ba≈øtard Ribs, whence they go all along the eminente≈øt part of the Belly ≈øtreight to the Share-bone where they terminate. Now in the≈øe Mu≈øcles there are ≈øeveral In≈øcriptions or tendinous Inter≈øtices, which are, according to the bigne≈øs of the Hor≈øe, more or fewer in number, but mo≈øt commonly there are in each Mu≈øcle eight, not ≈øo fair indeed as in Humane Bodies, but yet ≈øo plain, that they do di≈øtingui≈øh the Mu≈øcles into nine parts or more, as there are eight of the≈øe in≈øcriptions or more; and be≈øides, each part has a di≈øtinct Nerve: and yet notwith≈øtanding, becau≈øe they cannot be ea≈øily ≈øeparated one from another, they do by mo≈øt Anatomi≈øts go for onely one pair. On the in≈øide of the≈øe Mu≈øcles are to be ≈øeen the Epiga≈øtrick Arteries and Veins a≈øcending, and the Mammary Arteries and Veins de≈øcending, which by an ancient Tradition have been held in Humane Bodies to ino≈øculate one with another, the Arteries with the Arteries, and the Veins with the Veins; but later and more inqui≈øitively curious Anatomi≈øts have di≈øcovered it to be a mere fancy, invented to ≈øupport the erroneous Opinion, That whil≈øt the Young was in the Womb, it was nouri≈øhed with bloud carried to it by the Hypoga≈øtrick Arteries and Veins; but after the birth, the bloud altering its cour≈øe, regurgitated up from the Womb, by the Epiga≈øtrick Ve≈ø≈øels, which ino≈øculating with the Mammary, conveyed it to the Brea≈øts, where it was converted into Milk. This I ≈øay was the opinion as to Women, which has in ≈øeveral particulars been detected of errour: and may receive a further confutation in Mares, from the different ≈øituation of their Udders from the Brea≈øts in Women; whereas the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels have the ≈øame Cour≈øe in both. The action of the≈øe Mu≈øcles is to ≈øhorten the Belly by drawing the Brea≈øt and Share-bone towards one another, whereby it is drawn as it were on a heap, to ≈øqueez forth the Excrements or Urine, whence Dogs that ≈øtrain ≈øo hard to dung, have the≈øe Mu≈øcles ari≈øing as high up as the Channel-bones.

There are other two Mu≈øcles (≈øometimes to be found) which do re≈øt upon the Tendons of the Right Mu≈øcles at the lower end of them, which I have not yet ≈øpoken of, and the≈øe are called the pyramidal Mu≈øcles. They are of a triangular figure, and their u≈øe is to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles in their ≈øqueezing forth the Excrements, ≈øaith Fallopius. I believe the≈øe Mu≈øcles are ≈øo ≈øeldom found, that they ought to be accounted lu≈øus Naturoe, a ≈øport of Nature; for I do not remember that ever I have ob≈øerved any other here, but what ought to be accounted the lowe≈øt part or portion of the ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles before de≈øcribed.

Under all the≈øe lie the tran≈øver≈øe or overthwart Mu≈øcles, ≈øo called from their own and their Fibres running cro≈øs or overthwart the Belly. They are of a quadrangular or four≈øquare figure, and do ≈øtick ≈øo clo≈øe to the Rim of the Belly (which is under them) that they cannot ea≈øily be ≈øeparated.

Their Original is from the one or two lowe≈øt ba≈øtard Ribs, the tran≈øver≈øe proce≈ø≈øes of the Joints or vertebrae of the Loyns, and the Haunch-bones; and their Tendons reach to the white line, where they terminate.
Their Action is to pre≈øs the Guts for the expul≈øion of Excrements.

Now as each Mu≈øcle has a peculiar action to it ≈øelf, which is that already a≈øcribed to each, ≈øo have all the≈øe ten Mu≈øcles two Actions general to them all conjoinedly, which are the≈øe; The fir≈øt is, that they ≈øerve for a defence or bulwark for all the Parts underneath them, and do by their fle≈øh (which pretty much aboundeth in them) cheri≈øh their natural heat and a≈ø≈øi≈øt concoction; The next is, that they do all a≈ø≈øi≈øt together in the compre≈ø≈øing of the Guts for the voiding of the excrements, the Midriff a≈ø≈øi≈øting thereunto, by who≈øe help the excrements are thru≈øt downwards, which otherwi≈øe would be onely ≈øqueezed together, and not thru≈øt any more downward than upward.

I think it not ami≈øs in this place to explain what it is I call the white Line, for fear the naming of it ≈øo often as I have done in this Chapter, without ≈øhewing what it is, ≈øhould puzzle the Reader.

The white Line is nothing el≈øe, but the extremities or tendinous endings of the≈øe Mu≈øcles of the Paunch, and is called white from its colour, becoming ≈øo, becau≈øe it con≈øi≈øts of Tendons and Fibres onely, wherewith no fle≈øhy part or particle is interwoven, whereby to change or alter the colour. It di≈øtingui≈øheth the Belly into two parts, a right and a le≈øt, and is placed all along the middle of the Belly both below and above the Navel, running from the ≈øword-pointed Gri≈øtle of the Brea≈øt as low as to the Share-bone.

Now the ∆≤dder being an external part of the Belly in Mares, I might in this place (in order) treat of it; but becau≈øe its Action, to wit the making of Milk, has ≈øo near relation to the Foal, for which it provides nouri≈øhment, I ≈øhall omit it in this place, and de≈øcribe it at the latter end of this fir≈øt Book, after I have done with the generative parts of Mares, and the breeding, nouri≈øhing, &c. of the Young in the Womb.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Rim of the Belly, called the Peritonaeum.

argument.p: What the Petitonaeum is. Its original. Its perforations. The outmo≈øt Skins of all the parts of the Lower Belly, have their original from this. Its Compo≈øition. Its ∆≤≈øes.

div.p: THE Mu≈øcles of the Paunch being all removed, as al≈øo their Tendons which make the white Line before ≈øpoken of, the Peritonaeum or Rim of the Belly comes next into ≈øight.

This Peritonaeum is of a ≈øpermatick ≈øub≈øtance (as are all other Membranes or Skins) and is of an oval Figure, or like a long fa≈øhioned Egg, for it compa≈ø≈øeth all the Lower Belly and ingirts all the Parts therein contained, and al≈øo ≈øtrengthneth them, from whence it hath its name, from its office of ≈øpreading and ≈øtretching about. It is thin and ≈øoft, that it might not be either heavy or burthen≈øom; yet is it very ≈øtrong and compact, that it might be ≈øtretched without danger, when the Belly is full of Meat, or the Womb is full of the Burthen. Its in≈øide is ≈ømooth, and by rea≈øon of the Guts is daubed with moi≈øture; but its out≈øide is rough, which makes it ≈øtick ≈øo clo≈øe to the Mu≈øcles that lie above it, that they can hardly be ≈øeparated, as I have before ≈øhewed.

It takes its original from the vertebrae or joints of the Loins, where it is very thick, and is therefore believed to proceed from the Membrane that inve≈øts the Marrow in the Back-bone, and is propagated from the double Membrane of the Brain. It is in all places double, and betwixt its Membranes I have always ob≈øerved good ≈øtore of Fat, which Anatomi≈øts do not ≈øpeak of in other Creatures. The Ve≈ø≈øels run along this Fat between the Membranes, that they may be the better ≈øecured and defended, and may with more ≈øafety di≈øper≈øe their branches all over it; and for that purpo≈øe it is perforated in ≈øeveral places, ≈øo wide as is proportionably nece≈ø≈øary to the largene≈øs of the Ve≈ø≈øels that are to go through, and no larger, le≈øt in di≈øtentions or ≈øtrains they ≈øhould tear, as too apt they are to do, as Experience daily te≈øtifies in Men and Children, when vehement coughs or long and ≈øtraining cries do, in ≈øome, open the orifice of the Navel, and in others the orifices in the Groin, where the ≈øpermatick or ≈øeminary Ve≈ø≈øels go forth to the Stones, ≈øo that the widene≈øs gives liberty for the ≈ømall Guts to fall out of their places into the outward parts, which cau≈øeth Ruptures and broken Bellies. The like I have ≈øeen in Hor≈øes.

From the inner Membrane of this Rim of the Belly, all the outmo≈øt Skins or Coats which cover every Part contained in the Lower Belly do proceed, and from it have their original, ≈øome thicker and ≈øome thinner, according to the nece≈ø≈øity or u≈øe of the Part re≈øpectively. As for Example, the Common Membrane of the Kidneys, the proper one of the Liver and Spleen (each of which have but one) are but very thin, for ≈øeeing they are never (naturally) extended, there was no nece≈ø≈øity for their being otherwi≈øe; but the Common Skin of the Stomach, the Guts, the Bladder and the Womb are ≈øomewhat thicker, but much ≈øtronger and more compact, becau≈øe the u≈øes they are put to require it, that they may without danger be ≈øtretched, when there is occa≈øion. Now as the Entrails are many and of divers kinds, and al≈øo ≈øituated in ≈øeveral places different from one another, ≈øo does their outward Inve≈øting Membrane
take its original from that part of this Peritonaeum or Rim of the Belly which is next to them; as the upper Entrails, which are the Stomach, the Liver, the Spleen, &c. borrow it from that part of the Rim which makes the under Membrane of the Midriff; ≈øo do the lower Entrails (as the Bladder, Womb, &c.) borrow it from that part of the Rim, which cleaveth to the Share-bone, it being the neare≈øt to them.

From this Peritonaeum or Rim of the Belly do al≈øo proceed two double Membranes or Skins, which are tho≈øe of the Caul and of the Me≈øentery; as al≈øo ≈øeveral Ligaments, of which the mo≈øt remarkable are tho≈øe of the Liver and Guts.

This Peritonaeum is compo≈øed of membranous and nervous Fibres which are very ≈ømall. The Ve≈ø≈øels that are di≈øper≈øed through it are ≈ømall branches of Veins and Arteries which it hath from the Midriff, and other neighbouring Parts, as the Seminary and Mammary; and for Nerves, it hath them from the branches which are carried to the Mu≈øcles of the Lower Belly.

Its ∆≤≈øes are ≈øeveral, the fir≈øt of which is, to cover and contain all the Parts or Entrails of the Lower Belly; ≈øecondly, to further the expul≈øion of the Excrements by pre≈ø≈øing the Stomach and Guts before and on the ≈øides, as the Midriff doth above. Again, it binds with its Ligaments all the Guts in their proper places by mediation of the Me≈øentery, that no violent motion (≈øuch as running or leaping) ≈øhould move them out: By Ligaments proceeding from it, is the Liver al≈øo ≈øu≈øpended in its place. Its la≈øt u≈øe is to be a ≈øafeguard to the Ve≈ø≈øels that run through it, which being but ≈ømall and having a long cour≈øe to run, would be in danger of breaking, were they not ≈øecured between its two Skins.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Omentum or Caul.

argument.p: The Caul what it is. How far it ≈øpreads over the Guts. It is ≈øometimes the cau≈øe of barrenne≈øs. Its connexion or origine. Figure. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its Fat. The u≈øe of its Fat. The u≈øe of its Membranes or Skins.

div.p: HAVING according to the order of di≈ø≈øection, removed all the inve≈øting or containing Parts of the Lower Belly, and ≈øhewed which, and what they are; it now follows that I ≈øhew which are the parts inve≈øted or contained. And becau≈øe the Caul appears fir≈øt in di≈ø≈øection, I will fir≈øt treat of it.

This Caul is in Latin called Omentum, from Omen, becau≈øe the Roman Sooth≈øayers pretended by it to foretell things. It is al≈øo called mappa ventris, the Map or Di≈øh-clout of the Belly, becau≈øe it ≈øeemeth to lick up the ≈øuperfluities thereof. It doth cover all or mo≈øt of the Guts in many Creatures; but in a Hor≈øe it is mo≈øt times removed from all the lower parts of the Belly, and lieth in wrinkles or folds near and about the Stomach. The rea≈øon of its being removed, I do ≈øuppo≈øe, is the hard labour and violent Exerci≈øe a Hor≈øe undergoeth; for whil≈øt he is young, and before he comes to his labour, it is ≈øpread as far over his Entrails as in other Creatures, as hath been ob≈øerved by the Learned Marcus Aurelius Severinus, who did in a She foal which he di≈ø≈øected at Naples, ≈øee the
Caul ≈øpread all over the Guts as far as to the bottom of the Womb, to which it was al≈øo joined with a ≈øtrait connection.

It ≈øometimes happeneth that the Caul falleth between the bottom of the Bladder and the neck of the Womb in Women, and then it ≈øo compre≈ø≈øeth the mouth of the Womb, that it leaveth very little or no pa≈ø≈øage for the Man's ≈øeed to enter in, which when it ≈øo happeneth is a cau≈øe of barrenne≈øs. But I believe no ≈øuch thing can happen in Mares.

It is compo≈øed of two Membranes, the uppermo≈øt or formo≈øt of which ari≈øeth at the bottom of the Stomach to which it is fa≈øtned, as al≈øo to the hollow ≈øide of the Liver and Spleen: The inner or backer Membrane ≈øprings from the Peritonaeum, immediately under the Midriff towards the Back, and is tied to that part of the Gut Colon that pa≈ø≈øeth under the Stomach lengthways, as likewi≈øe to the Sweetbread and to the beginning of the ≈ømall Gut, next to the lower Orifice of the Stomach. The≈øe Membranes are larded with plentifull Fat.

It is in figure like a Pur≈øe net, or Faulkner's Bag, con≈øi≈øting as is ≈øaid of a double Coat, ≈øeparate at the top, but knit together at the bottom, where it is round ≈øometimes, and ≈øometimes unequal, but at its upper part or orifice it is orbicular.

It has Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts, which do run through the ≈øub≈øtance thereof. It hath its Veins and Arteries from the Coeliacal and Me≈øenterical branches, and Nerves from a double branch of the Interco≈øtal pair.

In Hor≈øes it has much Fat, e≈øpecially in tho≈øe that are ≈øound and have not wa≈øted it by either ≈øickne≈øs or long fa≈øting, for in ≈øuch it con≈øi≈øts of little but the Membranes and Ve≈ø≈øels, the Fat ≈øerving for a ≈øub≈øidiary nouri≈øhment to the natural heat to feed upon when the Bea≈øt eats nothing. Now this Fat is not di≈øtributed equally to all the parts of the Caul, but runs here and there in ≈øtreaks accordingly as the larger Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels do, the ≈øpaces between being wholly membranous and ≈øeemingly tran≈øparent, ≈øo that it imitates a Net, whence in ≈øome Countries they call it ≈øo. Now the Fat adhering to and accompanying the Ve≈ø≈øels in this manner, it ≈øeems to be bred of an unctuous or oily part of the Bloud that ≈øweats through the Ve≈ø≈øels, but is detained by the clo≈øene≈øs or den≈øene≈øs of the Membrane, by who≈øe re≈øpective coldne≈øs al≈øo it is curdled or congealed into Fat. But very unlikely it is that it ≈øhould be made of I know not what Vapours ≈øteaming out of the Parts contained in the Lower Belly, and conden≈øed by the≈øe Membranes; for not to mention the many ab≈øurdities of this Opinion, if it were ≈øo bred, then would all the Membranes be evenly and equally be≈ømeared with it, which it is obvious to any Eye that they are not.

The u≈øe of this plentifull Fat is to cheri≈øh and heat the bottom of the Stomach, the upper part of which has no need of its warmth, it being covered with the Liver, who≈øe Lobes hang over it and lie upon it. It ≈øerves al≈øo to moi≈øten the Guts, which have great need of being kept ≈ølippery and glib, that they may the better perform their continual peri≈øtaltick motion.

The u≈øe of the Membranes or Skins be≈øides their congealing and including the Fat, is to prop up and ≈øu≈øtain all the branches of the Ve≈ø≈øels which lie between and pa≈øs through them, to the Stomach, the Spleen, the beginning of the ≈ømall Gut, and Colon, &c.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the Gullet and Stomach.

argument.p: The Gullet. Its origine and de≈øcent. Its ≈øub≈øtance. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its Kernels. Its ∆≤≈øe. The Stomach. Its figure, And magnitude. Its Orifices. The upper and left Orifice of the Stomach. Its ∆≤≈øes. The lower Orifice, and its office. The compo≈øition of the Stomach. 1. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Veins. 2. Arteries. 3. Nerves. Its Action. How it concocts.

div.p: AFTER the Caul is removed, the Inte≈øtins or Guts do appear in their natural ≈øituation, as is ≈øhewed in the foregoing Figure; but there is another Part that lies ab≈øconded under them, which mu≈øt fir≈øt be ≈øpoken of according to the order of di≈ø≈øection, and that is the Stomach. It is ≈øingle in an Hor≈øe as it is in Man, though ≈øuch Creatures as have Horns, as Beeves, Sheep, &c. and ≈øuch as having no Horns yet chew the Cud, as Camels, Hinds, &c. have four. This is the Kitchin of the Body and receptacle of Meat and Drink; as al≈øo the ≈øeat of Appetite, by rea≈øon of the Nerves that are di≈øper≈øed chiefly in its upper Orifice, but run in ≈ømall twigs al≈øo through its whole ≈øub≈øtance. It is called in Latin ventriculus, which is as much as to ≈øay a little Belly; and is placed or ≈øeated ju≈øt under the Midriff between the Liver and the Spleen, almo≈øt in the very middle of the Body, inclining a little towards the left Side that it might ballance the Body again≈øt the Liver, which is much bigger and heavier than the Spleen.

But before we enter upon the Stomach it is convenient fir≈øt to de≈øcribe the Gullet which is an Appendage to it, and ≈øerves as a Tunnel to convey the Food out of the Mouth into it, though the greate≈øt part of it be contained in the Neck and Brea≈øt.

It is an organical or di≈ø≈øimilar Part, hollow and round, beginning at the root of the Tongue, behind the head of the Windpipe, and pa≈ø≈øeth down from thence directly between the Windpipe and the Joints of the Neck and of the Che≈øt, about the fifth or ≈øixth Joint of which latter it turneth a little to the right ≈øide, to give way to the trunk of the great Artery, but about the ninth Joint it turns toward the left again and climbs upon the great Artery, and pa≈ø≈øing through the Midriff at an hole proper to it ≈øelf it is in≈øerted into the Stomach toward its left ≈øide, as you may ≈øee in the following Figure.

It con≈øi≈øts of three Membranes or Skins. The outermo≈øt is common,which it hath from the Pleura or from the ligaments of the Joints of the Neck and Brea≈øt on which it re≈øteth: This inve≈øteth the two proper. The middle or fir≈øt proper one is thick and fle≈øhy, con≈øi≈øting of two ranks of
fle≈øhy Fibres, obliquely or ≈ølopingly a≈øcending and de≈øcending, ≈øo that they cro≈øs one another like an X. The innermo≈øt or ≈øecond proper is membranous, and hath onely ≈øtreight Fibres.

It has Veins in the Neck from the Jugulars, in the Brea≈øt from the Vein without a fellow; and where it is joined to the Stomach, from the coronary branch of the Porta. Arteries in the Neck it has from the Carotides, in the Brea≈øt from the Interco≈øtals; and where it joins to the Stomach, from the coeliack coronary branch. It hath Nerves from that pair that is commonly called the ≈øixth.

It has two notable Glands or Kernels at its beginning in the Throat,called Almonds from their ≈øhape, which ≈øeparate a kind of ≈ølegmatick humour to keep the in≈øide of the Gullet moi≈øt and glib, that the Food may ea≈øilier de≈øcend down by it.
Its u≈øe is, to convey Meat after it is chewed in the Mouth, as likewi≈øe Drink, down into the Stomach, there to be turned into chyle.
Having done with the Gullet, we now return to the Stomach.

Its figure is round and ≈øomewhat long, re≈øembling a Bag-pipe; though on the left ≈øide and at the bottom it is bunching and more capacious than on the right ≈øide; for there it is by little and little narrowed that it might give place to the Liver.

Its magnitude is divers according to the largene≈øs of the Hor≈øe, or according to the quantity of Meat or Drink (be it little or much) that is in it; for it contracteth or di≈øtendeth it ≈øelf as there is occa≈øion. As for example, if there be a great quantity of Meat and Drink let into it, it doth extend it ≈øelf to that largene≈øs as to contain it; and as that Meat is by little and little concocted, and then let forth through the lower Orifice into the ≈ømall Guts to be there ≈øuckt up by the milky Veins, the Stomach doth accordingly by little and little contract or draw it ≈øelf up ≈øo clo≈øe to that which remains, that it embraceth it on all ≈øides, ≈øo that there is never any cavity or hollowne≈øs to ≈øpeak of to be found in the Stomach; whence we ≈øee in Tripes, that the in≈øide is by ≈øuch contracting always rugged or in wrinkles, whereas the out≈øide is ≈ømooth and plain. Onely this we may note as to its bigne≈øs, that in con≈øideration of the bigne≈øs of an Hor≈øes Body or the largene≈øs of his Guts, it is far le≈øs in him than in mo≈øt Animals.

The Stomach hath two Orifices, a left and upper, which is to receive in Meat; and a right which is the lower, to let it out after concoction. The fir≈øt being the uppermo≈øt I will fir≈øt ≈øpeak of, which is much wider and larger than the other, becau≈øe it admits the Meat, many times not half chewed, into the Stomach (and for that cau≈øe is much thicker and al≈øo ≈øtronger than the other) whereas all is reduced into a fluid ≈øub≈øtance, before it pa≈øs out at the other.

This Orifice being a continuation of the Gullet is called the mouth of the Stomach, and hath an exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe of feeling becau≈øe of the Nerves which encompa≈øs it, and by which it the ≈øooner perceives the emptine≈øs and want of Meat, and therefore ≈øtirs up the Hor≈øe to ≈øeek Food to ≈øatisfy his want. It is near the middle of the Stomach, and not ≈øo near the left ≈øide of it as in Men.

It is furni≈øhed with fle≈øhy and circular Fibres, that it may naturally ≈øhut up and ≈øtraiten it ≈øelf after the Meat is received in, and al≈øo may intercept or hinder the Vapours from coming forth, which would by their a≈øcent up to the Brain be very injurious, by breeding di≈øea≈øes and evil
di≈øtempers in the Head; which Vapours would be al≈øo wanted in the Stomach to further concoction: for as it is an u≈øual cu≈øtom when Meat is over the fire for the Pot-lid to be put on to keep the Vapours or Reek from coming forth; ≈øo likewi≈øe it is requi≈øite in this ca≈øe that the Vapours of the Stomach ≈øhould be kept in, that Concoction ≈øhould be thereby furthered, or the Food be ≈øooner dige≈øted, the Vapours a≈ø≈øi≈øting thereunto.

The lower and right Orifice is called pylorus, which is to ≈øay, the Porter,from its office, which is to open and ≈øhut as occa≈øion ≈øerves; to open, when the chyle is let forth and ≈øent into the Gut duodenum, and then to contract or draw it ≈øelf clo≈øe up again, that nothing may pa≈øs through it which is not fully concocted. Which contraction is performed by tran≈øver≈øe or overthwart Fibres, with which it is plentifully furni≈øhed for that purpo≈øe; as al≈øo a thick and compact circle doth encompa≈øs it round, which circle is in ≈øhape like the ≈øphincter Mu≈øcle of the Fundament. By the≈øe Fibres and this Circle the action of the Porter, or lower Orifice, is performed, that is to ≈øay, it is either opened or ≈øhut, widened or ≈øtraitned as there is occa≈øion, as I have ≈øaid before. And the≈øe are the offices of the Orifices of the Stomach.

Now I proceed to the compo≈øition of it, which is of three Membranes or Skins, the fir≈øt or outmo≈øt of which it hath from the Peritonaeum, or Rim of the Belly. The ≈øecond and middlemo≈øt is more fle≈øhy than the former, con≈øi≈øting of fle≈øhy Fibres, which do mightily ≈øtrengthen the Stomach and by their heat do further concoction. The third and inmo≈øt is nervous, into which all the Ve≈ø≈øels do terminate or end. This Coat or Skin is continued with the Gullet up to the Mouth, that the Mouth ≈øhould not admit or receive in any thing that is offen≈øive to the Stomach.

The Stomach is furni≈øhed with Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts. Veins it hath fir≈øt from the Splenick branch, as 1. The vas breve, or ≈øhort Vein, which is in≈øerted into the bottom of the Stomach, whence afterwards it creeps up between the Coats towards the upper Orifice, but is obliterated before it comes quite to it. 2. The two Ga≈øtrick Veins (the greater and le≈øs) which creep along the bottom of the Stomach, and in their cour≈øe ≈øpread many branches into it; but the large≈øt branch of the greater of the≈øe two is that which is called the Crown-vein, that encompa≈ø≈øes the upper Orifice of the Stomach. 3. A Vein that is common to the left ≈øide of the Stomach and the Caul. Secondly, it hath another common to its right ≈øide and the Caul, from the Me≈øenterick branch. And la≈øtly, its lower or right Orifice has a ≈ømall Vein from the trunk of the Porta it ≈øelf, which is called pylorica or Porter-vein. Now before the circulation of the bloud was found out, it was believed that all the≈øe Veins brought bloud to the Stomach for its nouri≈øhment: but ≈øince that was di≈øcovered by Dr. Harvey, every one knows that they carry nothing to the Stomach, but bring back from it ≈øo much of the Arterial bloud as is not ≈øpent upon its nouri≈øhment. But be≈øides the bloud ≈øome learned Men have entertained an opinion that they ≈øuck out of the Stomach a thinner and more ≈øpirituous part of the chyle, which pa≈ø≈øes along with the bloud to the Heart by a far ≈øhorter pa≈ø≈øage than if it de≈øcended into the Guts and entred into the milky Veins, &c. (as ≈øhall afterwards be fullier declared.) And this they think it rea≈øonable to ≈øuppo≈øe, becau≈øe of the ≈øudden and quick refre≈øhment that Creatures receive from Cordial Drinks, and the like. I ≈øhall
not pretend to decide the controver≈øie betwixt tho≈øe that affirm this, and others that deny it, but do think this opinion to be very probable, becau≈øe of the very ≈øpeedy revival of Hor≈øes (that I have ob≈øerved) which being ready to faint away, have ≈øuddenly grown brisk upon the giving them ≈øome comfortable draught: unle≈øs we ≈øhould think with ≈øome, that the Nerves of the Stomach do imbibe ≈øome ≈øpirituous parts of ≈øuch potions, and ≈øo the refre≈øhment ≈øhould come that way.

The Stomachal Arteries are twigs from the Coeliacal branch of the Arteria magna or great Arterie, and the≈øe do accompany the Veins in all their cour≈øe, and be≈øtow nouri≈øhment and vital heat upon it. For the Stomach is not nouri≈øhed with the Chyle, any more than any other part, but with arterial bloud which by the≈øe Arteries is brought from the Heart.

It hath two notable Nerves from the ≈øixth pair (reckoned by Dr. Willis to be the eighth) propagated from tho≈øe branches which make the recurrent Nerves. The≈øe do encompa≈øs the upper Orifice, and then are carried, in oblique or ≈ølanting lines, cro≈øs one another over mo≈øt part of it; the right branch compa≈ø≈øing the foremo≈øt and left part, and the left branch compa≈ø≈øing the hindermo≈øt and right part thereof.

The Stomach has ≈øeveral Actions, as fir≈øt Hunger and Thir≈øt, which are the ≈øen≈øe that it has of the want of Meat and Drink, and an Appetite that is excited in it for the obtaining of them. Secondly, it has an action of retention, whereby it contracts it ≈øelf clo≈øe about the Food that is taken in, and detains it ≈øo long till it is throughly concocted or turned into a thin juice called Chyle. Thirdly, it has a motion that is called peri≈øtaltick, ≈øuch as the Guts al≈øo have, re≈øembling the motion of a Worm, whereby its parts contracting them≈øelves ≈øucce≈ø≈øively from above downwards, thru≈øt out the chyle into the Guts gently and by degrees. But the chief and mo≈øt con≈øiderable action of the Stomach, is, fourthly, Chylification, or turning the aliment into a whiti≈øh liquor commonly known by the name of Chyle, which being expelled out of the Stomach into the Guts, is, the thinner part of it, ≈øuckt up by a ≈øort of Ve≈ø≈øels called milky Veins, (≈øo called from that colour which this liquor gives them) that are in≈øerted every where into the Guts, and which carry it towards the Heart, by tho≈øe ways that hereafter ≈øhall be de≈øcribed: but the thicker and more dreggy part is driven along the Guts and ca≈øt out at the Fundament as excrement.

Now there are ≈øeveral things that concur to this la≈øt and principal action of the Stomach, viz. Concoction. As fir≈øt, the very numerous Arteries that are di≈øper≈øed through it which much fo≈øter and encrea≈øe its heat, which though it be not the main in≈øtrument of concoction, yet much furthers it. And this heat is al≈øo encrea≈øed by the Liver which covers the upper and fore-part of its right ≈øide, as al≈øo by the Caul which by its two Membranes inve≈øts its bottom. But ≈øecondly, that to which concoction is mainly owing is a certain ferment in the Stomach, which is compounded partly of the ≈ølaver with which the Hor≈øes mouth always abounds for the moi≈øtening and ≈øoftning of his Meat while he chews it, and part of which is continually ≈øwallow'd down into his Stomach together with the Food; and partly of an acid or ≈øharp and ≈øalt liquor bred in the Stomach, as is mo≈øt likely, of ≈øalt and acid ≈øteams evaporating out of the ≈øtomachal Arteries, and conden≈øed in it into this juice: And this liquor is that which di≈ø≈øolves and melts as it were the ≈øolid Meats that are
≈øwallowed (≈øomething like as Aqua fortis di≈ø≈øolves Steel) and reduces the whole ma≈øs into fluid ≈øub≈øtance, which then pa≈ø≈øes down into the Guts, as above≈øaid. This acid Juice was formerly thought to come from the Spleen by a Vein called the ≈øhort Ve≈ø≈øel; but later Anatomi≈øts have di≈øcovered from the circulation of the Bloud, that that Vein brings nothing from the Spleen to the Stomach, but contrariwi≈øe carries the Bloud, that is ≈øuperfluous to the nouri≈øhment of the Stomach, from it into the ≈øplenick Vein, by which it goes to the Liver, and from thence to the Heart in its circulation. So that no ≈øuch original or ≈øpring of this ferment is to be imagined.
