div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Guts in general.

argument.p: The Guts. Their Name, Figure and Length. How knit together. Their Coats. 1. Ve≈ø≈øels. Veins. Viz. fir≈øt, Bloud-veins. Secondly, milky Veins. 2. Arteries. 3. Nerves.

div.p: THE Guts are called in Latin Inte≈øtina, becau≈øe they are placed in the inmo≈øt part of the Body, as you ≈øee them placed in the Third Figure, which ≈øhews their natural po≈øition or ≈øituation, they taking up the mo≈øt part of the cavity or hollowne≈øs of the Lower Belly. They are oblong, round, hollow Bodies, in number ≈øix, and are bigger or le≈ø≈øer as is the bigne≈øs of the Hor≈øe. They are the In≈øtruments of di≈øtribution of the Chyle and expul≈øion of the Ordure, being continued with the Pylorus or Porter of the Stomach and reaching to the Fundament. They are in length about thirty ≈øix yards, a little under or over according to the largene≈øs of the Hor≈øe; wherefore they are nece≈ø≈øarily girded and wound into manifold convolutions or folds, that the cavity of the Lower Belly might be capable of containing them, which otherwi≈øe it could not do.

They are gathered up and entwi≈øted in the folds of the Me≈øentery, by which coming between they are al≈øo knit to the Back: all which is to keep them from falling out of their places or rolling upon one another, which would have often hapned, had not Nature ≈øo well provided for the contrary, e≈øpecially in violent exerci≈øe, as hunting, running, leaping and the like; and if it had hapned, the weight of the one lying upon the other would have ob≈øtructed the pa≈ø≈øage of the Excrements, and ≈øo caus'd exce≈ø≈øive pains, as gripings, ≈øtrainings to dung, and the like, and upon the continuance of ≈øuch ≈øtoppage, death it ≈øelf.
The Guts are on the out≈øide mo≈øt times fat, but on the in≈øide they are covered with a ≈ølimy or ≈ønotty ≈øub≈øtance, for the more free and glib pa≈ø≈øage of the Dung.

They have three Coats, like as the Stomach hath. The outermo≈øt or common one is nervous, ≈øpringing mediately from the Rim of the Belly, but immediately from the Membranes of the Me≈øentery; ≈øaving that of the beginning of the fir≈øt Gut, and of that part of the Colon which runneth under the Stomach, where it immediately proceedeth from the Caul adhering to tho≈øe Parts. The middle is thicker and fle≈øhy, having two ranks of Fibres, the outer of them ≈øtreight, and the inner tran≈øver≈øe or overthwart. The innermo≈øt is al≈øo nervous like the outmo≈øt, but on its in≈øide it is cru≈øted over with a kind of ≈øpongy ≈øub≈øtance, that ≈øerves as a ≈øtrainer for the Chyle to pa≈øs through out of the Guts into the milky Veins. This Coat has all forts of Fibres, and is very wrinkled, to prevent the too quick gliding away of the Ghyle. The Fibres of this and the middle Coat ≈øerve to perform the peri≈øtaltick or worm-like motion of the Guts, by which what≈øoever is contained in them is gently driven along downwards towards the Fundament.

The Guts have all ≈øorts of Ve≈ø≈øels. As 1. Veins. The≈øe they have from ≈øeveral branches of the Porta, but the mo≈øt come from that branch of it that is called the Me≈øenterick. The u≈øe of which Veins was by the Ancients thought to be, both to carry Bloud to them from the Liver for their nouri≈øhment, and to bring back from them the Chyle to the Liver,
there to be turned into bloud. But as to the fir≈øt, the circulation of the Bloud makes it evident, that they carry no bloud to the Guts, but all that is contained in them, is received from the Arteries that are in≈øerted into the Inte≈øtins, and returns by them to the Liver, through which it pa≈ø≈øes into the Vein called Cava, and by it a≈øcends to the Heart. And as to the latter u≈øe a≈ø≈øigned to the≈øe Veins, namely the bringing of Chyle from the Guts to the Liver, there was another ≈øort of Ve≈ø≈øels found out by one A≈øellius about three≈øcore years agoe, that perform this office, called by him (from their colour) milky Veins. But neither do the≈øe conveigh the Chyle to the Liver, as the fir≈øt Inventor of them thought, but running from the circumference of the Me≈øentery they unite and di≈øcharge them≈øelves into one common receptacle near its centre at the Back-bone, from whence the Chyle pa≈ø≈øes up along the ≈øide of the Back-bone as high as the Collar-bone by a proper pipe, where it is emptied into the ≈øubclavian Vein, in which being mixed with the Bloud it glides along with it immediately into the Heart. I ≈øay then the u≈øe of the Bloud-veins of the Guts, is onely to receive ≈øo much of the Arterial bloud as is ≈øuperfluous from their nouri≈øhment.

A ≈øecond ≈øort of Ve≈ø≈øel di≈øper≈øed through the Guts are the Arteries, which ≈øpring partly from the Coeliack branch, and partly from the Me≈øenterick. The≈øe afford both Vital heat and nouri≈øhment to the Guts, and be≈øides upon admini≈øtring a Drench to ≈øcour your Hor≈øe, they di≈øcharge the impurities and bad humours flowing in the ma≈øs of bloud, into the Guts, to be thrown out in the draught.

3. Their Nerves are from that pair that has commonly been called the ≈øixth, but according to Dr. Willis's di≈øtinction is now generally reputed for the ninth pair, and otherwi≈øe called the Interco≈øtal, becau≈øe as it de≈øcends down the Che≈øt, it ≈øends out a ≈ømall twig between every Rib. The≈øe contribute to the Guts their ≈øen≈øe of feeling, and furni≈øh their Fibres with animal Spirits, whereby they are enabled to perform their worm-like motion.
As for the milky Veins, we have mention'd them before, and ≈øhall treat further of them in the Chapter of the Me≈øentery.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Guts in particular.

argument.p: The Guts are in number ≈øix. 1. The ≈ømall Gut. 2. The Caecum or blind Gut. Three Colons. 6. The ≈øtreight Gut.

div.p: NOW though the Guts be one continued Body from the lower Orifice of the Stomach to the Fundament, yet they are wont to be di≈øtingui≈øhed into ≈øeveral; In Men they are divided into ≈øix, three ≈ømall, and three thick: but in a Hor≈øe we cannot ≈øo well follow this divi≈øion, there being not any difference in the ≈ømall Guts ≈øo con≈øiderable as to ground a di≈øtinction upon. However, becau≈øe the ≈øecond of the thick Guts ≈øeems to have three partitions, we ≈øhall make three of it, and ≈øo will they an≈øwer to the number in Men, and be reckoned ≈øix.

The fir≈øt we ≈øhall di≈øtingui≈øh onely by the name of the ≈ømall Gut. This is twenty ≈øix or twenty ≈øeven yards in length, ≈øomething narrower at a foot and half di≈øtance from the Stomach than towards its ending, but through the whole it is wider than in an Oxe, being about two inches or two and an half over. Pre≈øently at its beginning it bends under the Stomach towards the Back-bone, ≈øtreight along which it de≈øcends a pretty way, being annexed firmly to it by a ≈øtrong Membrane (that ≈øeems to be borrow'd of the Caul here knit to it) which is all the e≈øtabli≈øhment it has. But by and by it leaves this hold, and beginning to wind about, is received into the folds of the Me≈øentery, whereby it is admirably kept from twi≈øting and entanglement. Now there are far more of the milky Veins in≈øerted into this Gut than into all that follow; and be≈øides tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels which are common to it with the thick Guts, namely Veins, Arteries and Nerves, it has two other Ve≈ø≈øels in≈øerted into it, one from the Liver and another from the Sweet-bread. By the fir≈øt is yellow Choler, and by the latter a peculiar Juice from the Sweet-bread (called the pancreatick Juice) di≈øcharged into it. The≈øe two Liquors flowing into it from the afore≈øaid Bowels about a foot below the Stomach, within an inch or two one of another, make a notable ferment in it, which mixing with the Chyle that is pa≈ø≈øing down this way, cau≈øes it al≈øo to ferment, whereby it comes to work it ≈øelf ≈øomething clearer, as I may ≈øay, even as Ale or Beer in a Barrel does. For by this fermentation the impurer and more earthy or dreggy part of the Chyle, is ≈øeparated and precipitated as it were from the more pure and ≈øpirituous, whereby this latter part is made capable of being received in at the ≈ømall mouths of the milky Veins that gape in abundance into this Gut, whil≈øt the thicker and excrementitious part is thru≈øt along the Guts by their worm-like motion, and makes the Dung. This Gut for about two hands breadth at its beginning from the Pylorus is wider, and for the like ≈øpace at its end before it is joined to the following, is a little narrower, than in its other parts.

Having done with the ≈ømall Gut, we next come to the thick ones, in number five, of which the fir≈øt is called Caecum or the blind Gut, becau≈øe it has but one pa≈ø≈øage for the Excrements both into and out of it, which come into it out of the ≈ømall Gut, and go out of it into the next thick Gut. It is not round in ≈øhape like the ≈ømall Gut, but as it were four≈øquare, which figure it comes to have from four Ligaments that run along it, one on each ≈øide, which contain it in that ≈øhape; and the≈øe Ligaments being ≈øhorter than its Coats, make them bag out in many Cells as the Colon does in other Creatures. It is almo≈øt a yard long, and unequal in breadth: for though at its mouth, where it joyns to the ≈ømall Gut and the Colon, it be near a quarter of a yard over, yet towards its clo≈øe end it grows ≈øo by degrees narrower, that it is not above three inches. This Gut is very incon≈øiderable for its bigne≈øs in mo≈øt Creatures, particularly in Man, in whom it is not ordinarily above four inches long, and hardly ≈øo thick as ones little Finger: onely in a Rabbit it bears much the ≈øame proportion with the re≈øt of the Guts, as it does in an Hor≈øe. In ≈øuch Creatures as have it ≈øo very ≈ømall, its u≈øe is very ob≈øcure; but in an Hor≈øe where it is ≈øo very large, its u≈øe is apparent to be, to ≈øtay the too quick pa≈ø≈øage of the Excrements by receiving them into it ≈øelf as it were into an Inn, whereas if they kept directly the ≈øtreight Road of the re≈øt of the Guts without turning in here, they would come too ≈øoon to their journeys end, namely the Fundament: I mean the Hor≈øe would be continually
a-≈øcouring, and ≈øo fall from his fle≈øh and langui≈øh, by rea≈øon that the milky Veins would not have time to ≈øuck up all the Chyle out of the Guts to turn into his nouri≈øhment; be≈øides that it would be trouble≈øome to the Hor≈øe, and offen≈øive to his Rider to have him always a-dunging. Its connexion to the ≈ømall Gut and Colon you may better conceive of by the following Figure, in which it is well expre≈ø≈øed, than by my de≈øcription of it in words.

That which is the ≈øecond thick Gut and in Man is called the Colon, ≈øeems in an Hor≈øe to be divided into three, to which I ≈øhall not take upon me to a≈ø≈øign di≈øtinct names, but onely call them three Colons. The fir≈øt of them is about a yard and a half in length, and for the mo≈øt part of it a quarter of a yard over. The ≈øecond is as wide as the fir≈øt, but onely about a yard in length. The≈øe two are divided one from the other by a narrow neck about half a yard long, and four inches over. The fir≈øt of the≈øe two wide Colons, is that which in its upper part joyns with the blind Gut above de≈øcribed, where it has a Valve, con≈øi≈øting of a loo≈øe Membrane or Skin that hangs round its mouth, which permits any thing to come into the Colon out of the Caecum or out of the ≈ømall Gut, but when any thing would pa≈øs out of that into the≈øe, then the edges of this loo≈øe Skin flap clo≈øe one again≈øt another and hinder it, whereby Nature has prevented the return of the Excrements back out of the Colon into the ≈ømall Gut. And the lower end of the latter of the≈øe two wide Colons joins to the third, which is very narrow in compari≈øon of them, but yet is more than twice as long as both of them, namely about ≈øix yards. Now all the≈øe three Colons are contracted into Cells by two Ligaments, one of which runs along the upper part, and the other on the lower ≈øide of them: and be≈øides the≈øe two which are common to them all, the larger ones have ≈øomewhere other two that run along their ≈øides, but e≈øpecially ≈øo has the Neck that divides them whereby it is made four≈øquare like the blind Gut. The rea≈øon why the≈øe Colons (as well as they are in other Creatures, and the Caecum al≈øo in this) are contracted into Cells, is for the ≈ølower pa≈ø≈øage of the Excrements, that what of the Chyle was not drunk in by the milky Veins of the ≈ømall Gut, might be lei≈øurely ≈øuckt up by tho≈øe that are in≈øerted into the≈øe thick ones; for though we call their Contents Excrements, yet that is onely becau≈øe the much greater part is ≈øo, for all the Chyle is not clear imbibed from them till they come towards the end of the la≈øt Colon, though the milky Veins are not a tenth part ≈øo numerous in the≈øe as in the ≈ømall Gut.

To the lower end of the ≈ømall Colon is joined the la≈øt Gut called Rectum or the ≈øtreight Gut, becau≈øe it runs ≈øtreight along without any windings. It is al≈øo called the Ar≈øe-gut, becau≈øe it reacheth to the Fundament. The Coats of this Gut, e≈øpecially the middle, are much thicker than any of the other, and the whole ≈øeems fle≈øhy and mu≈øcular. It is but about half a yard long, and betwixt three and four inches over. This is not gathered in the foldings of the Me≈øentery, but in≈øtead of that, is from its beginning at the lower end of the Loins, to its ending at the Ar≈øe-hole, fa≈øt tied by a Membrane to the Back and Rump-bones, which keep it from falling out upon ≈øtraining to dung. At its lower end at the Ar≈øehole it has a round Mu≈øcle that encompa≈ø≈øes it, called the ≈øphincter Mu≈øcle, whereby it is pur≈øed up ≈øo, that nothing can pa≈øs out, except when the Bea≈øt loo≈øens it of his own accord when he goes to dung, and then at the ≈øame time he ≈øqueezes the Guts by help of the Mu≈øcles that environ his
Paunch, which we de≈øcribed above in chap. 6. and ≈øo forces the Dung to i≈ø≈øue out at the Fundament.

And thus we have fini≈øhed the Hi≈øtory of the Guts, not needing to add any thing of the u≈øe of them, becau≈øe their u≈øe is all along interwoven in their de≈øcription, and therefore we ≈øhall pa≈øs on to the other parts.

argument.p: The Me≈øentery why ≈øo called. Its ri≈øe. Its Fat. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. 1. Veins. 2. Arteries. 3. Nerves. 4. Milky Veins. 5. Lympheducts. Its Glands. Its ∆≤≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the Me≈øentery.
div.p: THE Me≈øenterium or Me≈øentery is ≈øo called from its being placed in the middle of the Guts, which it embraces round, gathering them together in form of a Globe, but is it ≈øelf gathered into folds. This Me≈øentery is of a circular figure, compo≈øed of a double Coat, between which do run many Ve≈ø≈øels and tho≈øe of all ≈øorts, and betwixt which al≈øo there is a collection of much fat. Dr. Wharton ≈øays that in Man there is a third Membrane betwixt the two commonly known, in which are ≈øeated the Glands or Kernels, and through which the Ve≈ø≈øels run. If ≈øo, 'tis likely there is the ≈øame in an Hor≈øes Me≈øentery, which abounds with Glands. 'Tis a little above a quarter of a yard broad from its centre to its circum≈øerence.

Now its centre or ri≈øe is at the fir≈øt and third Rack-bone of the Loins, where membranous Fibres are produced from the Rim of the Belly, and ≈øpread into the two inve≈øting Coats or Skins of the Me≈øentery.

The fat with which the≈øe Membranes are ≈øtuft, is collected in the ≈øame manner as that of the Caul above-de≈øcribed in chap. 8. namely the oily part of the Bloud ≈øweating out of the Arteries that run in abundance between the≈øe Membranes, is ≈øtopt by them, (they being more compact and clo≈øe than the Coats of the Arteries) and by their re≈øpective coldne≈øs is congealed into fat.
There are almo≈øt innumerable Ve≈ø≈øels running through it, but ≈øuch as are rather ≈øu≈øtained and conducted by it, than for its own u≈øe.

The fir≈øt ≈øort are the Veins, to which it gives the denomination of Me≈øaraick. The≈øe are all branches of the Porta, and their office is to receive ≈øo much of the Arterial bloud as is not ≈øpent on the nouri≈øhment of the Guts and Me≈øentery, and to convey it to the Liver, and from thence to the Heart. Before the milky Veins were found out, it was believed they brought the Chyle to the Liver; but that opinion is now out of doors, as we have more fully ≈øhewn before in the tenth Chapter.

Its Arteries al≈øo from its name are called Me≈øaraick or Me≈øenterick; the≈øe run in great numbers through it to the Guts, to which what office they perform was likewi≈øe declar'd above, chap. 10. And be≈øides the u≈øes there a≈øcribed to them, they continually ≈øupply new oily Vapours for the maintenance of the ≈øat of the Me≈øentery.
Its Nerves are very numerous, and ≈øpring from that pair which is now (from Dr. Willis) commonly called the Interco≈øtal, and reckoned for the ninth pair, but was formerly reputed the ≈øixth.

All the venae lacteae or milky Veins run through it from the Guts towards its centre. The≈øe are very ≈ølender and almo≈øt tran≈øparent Ve≈ø≈øels, having but one ≈øingle Coat, and gaping with their mouths in the inmo≈øt Coat of the Guts do there ≈øuck up the Chyle, and take the neare≈øt cour≈øe thence to tho≈øe Glands or Kernels of the Me≈øentery that are next to them, ≈øeveral ≈ømaller in their pa≈ø≈øage growing into one greater. From the ≈øeveral ≈ømaller Glands they proceed to the greate≈øt that is placed at the Back at the centre of the Me≈øentery, and from thence to the common receptacle
that is ≈øeated betwixt the Kidneys. What cour≈øe it takes from thence the Reader may ≈øee in the already twice mentioned tenth Chapter.

Be≈øides all the≈øe ≈øorts of Ve≈ø≈øels there was a fifth ≈øort found out by Thomas Bartholin (a Dane) ≈øome thirty years ago, which indeed are to be found in mo≈øt parts of the Body, but mo≈øt abound in the Me≈øentery, and are called Lympheducts, as much as to ≈øay, Water-pa≈ø≈øages. Their Coat is ≈øingle as that of the milky Veins, but more tran≈øparent; and the lympha or water that is contained in them, is very clear. This Liquor differs from the ≈øerum or wheyi≈øh watery part of the Bloud, which one may di≈øcover by this Experiment; If you take a little of this Liquor into a Spoon, it will ≈øoon thicken into a gelly of its own accord, which the ≈øerum of the Bloud will not do unle≈øs you heat it over the fire. It is ≈øuppo≈øed to be made of thin moi≈øt Vapours of the Bloud, which being conden≈øed into water, are imbibed by the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels. All tho≈øe that run through the Me≈øentery di≈øcharge their water into the common receptacle of the Chyle above-mentioned, ≈øo that it pa≈ø≈øes together with the Chyle up the pa≈ø≈øage that a≈øcends by the Back towards the Shoulders, and there mixes with the Bloud in the ≈øubclavian Vein.

In the middle Membrane of the Me≈øentery (fir≈øt found out by Doctor Wharton as above≈øaid) there are a great many Glands or Kernels, into which the milky Veins as they pa≈øs through the Me≈øentery are in≈øerted, and then ri≈øe out of them again, continuing their cour≈øe to the one great Gland at its centre, in which they all meet together, and from it hold on their way to the common receptacle as was above-declared. By the≈øe Glands the ≈øaid Veins are ≈øupported and ≈øtrengthened in their pa≈ø≈øage.

Now the u≈øe of the Me≈øentery is to be as it were a tie or band to the Guts to bind or gather them together, and to fa≈øten them to the Back, that their great weight do not cau≈øe them in violent motion either to break or twi≈øt or roll confu≈øedly one over the other, whereby their gentle worm-like motion would be hindred, if not perverted or aboli≈øhed. And be≈øides by its Membranes and Glands it does guard and ≈øu≈øtain the ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels who≈øe way lies through it.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Pancreas or Sweet-bread.

argument.p: The Pancreas why ≈øo called. Its ≈øituation. Its ≈øub≈øtance. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its proper pa≈ø≈øage. Its ∆≤≈øe. The Pancreatick Juice.

div.p: THE Sweet-bread is an un≈øhapely body, of a glandulous yet fle≈øhlike ≈øub≈øtance, from whence it hath its name Pancreas which ≈øignifies all fle≈øh.

In di≈ø≈øection it is at the end of the Liver and bottom of the Stomach; but while the Hor≈øe is living, it is ≈øituated on the back≈øide of the bottom of the Stomach, and lies cro≈øs the Belly lengthways as that does.

Its proper fle≈øh is white and ≈øoft, but the little Kernels with which it is plentifully ≈øtored, are of a more reddi≈øh colour. It is covered with a ≈øingle Membrane which it has from the Rim of the Belly, as all the Bowels of the Lower Belly have, of which it is almo≈øt the lea≈øt.

It has Veins from that branch of the Porta that runs to the Spleen, and is called the Splenick. Its Arteries ≈øpring from the Coeliacal; and its Nerves from the Interco≈øtal or ninth pair. This Bowel for its bigne≈øs has very many of tho≈øe Lympheducts that we de≈øcribed in the foregoing Chapter running through the Me≈øentery.

Be≈øides the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels which are common to it with other parts, it has a pipe or pa≈ø≈øage peculiar to it ≈øelf, which was fir≈øt found out at Padua in an humane Body about forty years ago. This pa≈ø≈øage is membranous, and though it be but one in its going out, yet within the Sweet-bread it is divided fir≈øt into two, and tho≈øe two into innumerable ≈ømall branches which are di≈øper≈øed all over its Body, but their extremities terminate in the above≈øaid reddi≈øh Kernels with which the Sweet-bread abounds.

Before this pa≈ø≈øage was found out, ≈øome thought the u≈øe of the Sweetbread to be only to ≈øerve as a Cu≈øhion (being very ≈øoft) for the Stomach to bol≈øter upon, and to ≈øu≈øtain the Ve≈ø≈øels that run through it; and others, that it ≈øent a ferment to the Stomach to a≈ø≈øi≈øt concoction. As to this latter u≈øe it mu≈øt needs be onely imaginary, ≈øeeing there is no pa≈ø≈øage from it to the Stomach. And as to the former, though it doe tho≈øe offices mentioned, yet from its proper pa≈ø≈øage (which opens into the beginning of the ≈ømall Gut very near the ≈øame place where the Gall-pa≈ø≈øage enters) it gives ≈øu≈øpicion that it has a further u≈øe. Now ≈øome have been ≈øo curious as to open Dogs alive, and cutting off this pa≈ø≈øage where it is in≈øerted into the Gut, to receive its end into a narrow-mouth'd Ve≈ø≈øel, (you may ≈øee the manner of it in Barthol. Anat. l. 1. c. 13.) into which Ve≈ø≈øel in a few hours time there has a Spoonfull of Juice de≈øtilled out of it. And this Juice, to di≈øtingui≈øh it from all other Liquors in the Body, they call the Pancreatick juice, from the name Pancreas whereby the Sweet-bread is otherwi≈øe called. So that it ≈øeems there is a peculiar Liquor ≈øeparated from the Arteries into this pa≈ø≈øage in the little Kernels or Glands above-≈øpoken of, which tho≈øe that have ta≈øted it, ≈øay, is of a ≈øalti≈øh and ≈øomewhat ≈øowri≈øh ta≈øte. Now this Juice pa≈ø≈øing by its Pipe into the beginning of the ≈ømall Gut, meets there with the Gall, with which it ferments, and cau≈øes ≈øome fermentation in the Chyle as it de≈øcends that way, whereby its purer parts are ≈øeparated from the more impure and earthy, as was di≈øcour≈øed more fully in the eleventh Chapter, when we were de≈øcribing the ≈ømall Gut, (to which the Reader may plea≈øe to turn back.)
As for the figure of the Sweet-bread, you have it expre≈øt in the next Table but one, namely in that wherein the Spleen is al≈øo de≈øcribed.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Liver.

argument.p: Its ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øituation and figure. Its Ligaments and inve≈øting Membrane. Veins. Arteries. Nerves. Lympheducts. Its ∆≤≈øe.

div.p: HAVING now done with the Parts that mini≈øter to the fir≈øt concoction, namely Chylification, we proceed to tho≈øe other that in ≈øome mea≈øure, ≈øome more ≈øome le≈øs, a≈ø≈øi≈øt Sanguification, of which the Liver was e≈øteemed by the Ancients the principal, nay almo≈øt the onely in≈øtrument. Which errour of theirs was founded on this mi≈øtake in Anatomy, That having not then found out the milky Veins which we have before de≈øcribed, they thought that the Chyle was received out of the Guts by the Me≈øaraick Veins, which being branches of the Porta, all run to the Liver; And the Cava or large hollow Vein that ari≈øes out of the Liver, and is the trunk whence all the branches of Veins in the whole Body ≈øpring, containing nothing in it but bloud, it nece≈ø≈øarily follow'd that if the Chyle came to the Liver, it mu≈øt by it be turned into bloud before it departed from it again. Yea ≈øo deep was this Opinion of the Liver's making bloud fixed in Mens Brains, that for ≈øome while after the milky Veins were found out, they would needs have them to convey the Chyle to the Liver, though they were forced to a thou≈øand ≈øhifts to apologize for their non-appearance between the great Gland of the Me≈øentery, (whither they might be ea≈øily traced) and the Liver. But this prejudice was ≈øoon overcome when about thirty years ago the common Receptacle (de≈øcribed before in the tenth and twelfth Chapters) was found out, and a new office was invented for the Liver, which yet may in ≈øome ≈øort be ≈øaid to a≈ø≈øi≈øt Sanguification: and what this office is, ≈øhall be ≈øhewn by and by in this and the next Chapters.

The ≈øub≈øtance of it is like concrete or congealed Bloud, for which cau≈øe it is called Parenchyma, which is to ≈øay an affu≈øion or ≈øhedding forth of bloud. It is one in number, and ≈øituated in the Lower Belly in the upper part thereof on the right ≈øide under the ≈øhort Ribs, near to the Diaphragma or Midriff, in its upper ≈øide, and its lower lies upon the right and fore≈øide of the Stomach. It is divided into ≈øeveral Lobes or Flaps, in Hor≈øes, otherwi≈øe than in Men, in whom it is one continued body. The≈øe Lobes do cover the Stomach, gra≈øping of it (as it were) as one ≈øhould gra≈øp any thing with their hand by ≈øpreading their fingers about it. This covering the Stomach ≈øtands in great need of, for thereby is the heat thereof much cheri≈øhed for the furthering concoction. As for its ≈øhape, you cannot ≈øo well conceive it by any de≈øcription, as by the figure of it annexed at the end of this Chapter, which you may plea≈øe to take a view of.

It is tied in its place by three Ligaments: the ≈øtronge≈øt of which is that which is called its ≈øu≈øpen≈øory Ligament. This ≈øprings from the Peritonaeum where it is ≈øpread over the under ≈øide of the Midriff. It is very ≈øtrong and membranous, and ari≈øing from the Midriff ≈øomewhat towards its right ≈øide, it is in≈øerted into the upper or bunching ≈øide of the Liver, into which it enters a little way; but in its entrance it lo≈øes one of its Membranes, which dilating or ≈øpreading it ≈øelf makes the skin that enwraps
wraps the whole Liver; for the Liver is onely covered with one thin skin which it has from this Ligament. There is a ≈øecond Ligament which ≈øeems to ≈øpring from this skin of the Liver, and is in≈øerted into the ≈øharppointed Gri≈øtle at the bottom of the Brea≈øt-bone. By the≈øe two is the Liver kept from falling lower down into the Belly, or from ≈ølipping out of its place ≈øideways. The third Ligament is not one originally, but when the Foal is in the Womb it ≈øupplies the place of a Vein, running from the Navel to the lower or hollow ≈øide of the Liver, and by it is nouri≈øhment brought from the Dam to the Foal. But as ≈øoon as it is foaled, and it begins to take its nouri≈øhment by the mouth onely, and not any longer at all this way, this Vein dries and clo≈øes up, and ≈øo degenerates into a Ligament, whereby the Liver is kept from a≈øcending or bearing up again≈øt the Midriff, as it might have done in an Hor≈øes leaping or the like. This is ju≈øt oppo≈øite to the Su≈øpen≈øory one, entring in at the lower ≈øide over again≈øt where that does on the upper.

It hath two ≈øorts of Veins. The fir≈øt are the roots of the Vena cava or large hollow Vein, which ≈øpreading them≈øelves through all its parts, do receive into them the bloud that is brought into the Liver by the Porta; which having done, the ≈ømaller roots two or three of them grow into one, and this one uniting with two or three of the like kind into another larger root, they do at la≈øt all of them meet in one trunk and make the hollow Vein, which i≈ø≈øuing out of the upper part of the Liver pre≈øently enters the Midriff, and ≈øo a≈øcends up to the Heart. The ≈øecond ≈øort of Vein is the Porta, all who≈øe branches coming from the Guts, Spleen, Stomach, &c. and uniting into one trunk enter the Liver on its lower or hollow ≈øide, into which it is no ≈øooner entred, but pre≈øently it di≈øper≈øes it ≈øelf into innumerable branches through all the Lobes of the Liver, affording nouri≈øhment unto it, in that regard ≈øupplying the place of an Artery, which it re≈øembles the more, becau≈øe within the Liver it has two Coats, the outer whereof it receives from that skin that cloaths the Liver, in its entrance into it. Now ≈øo much of the bloud that is imported by the Porta, as is not ≈øpent on the nouri≈øhment of the Liver, is drunk in by the roots of the hollow Vein before-mentioned, and returned to the Heart. This Vein is called Porta or Vena portae, the Gate-vein, from two bunchings out, of the Liver, (called gates by Hippocrates) between which it enters it.

Yet is not the Liver, at lea≈øt all the parts of it, onely nouri≈øhed by the bloud that is brought in by the Porta; for there is a branch which comes from the Coeliack Artery that a≈øcends to its hollow ≈øide ju≈øt by the Porta, which ≈øends forth twigs all over its Coat, as likewi≈øe through the Coats of the Porta and the Choler-Ve≈ø≈øels: but whether any of them enter into its parenchyma or ≈øub≈øtance, is not di≈øcovered. The≈øe twigs of Arteries bring vital heat and nouri≈øhment to tho≈øe parts through which they run.

Its Nerves ≈øpring from the Interco≈øtal pair, viz. partly from the ≈øtomachick and partly from the me≈øenterick branch thereof. The≈øe onely are communicated to tho≈øe parts to which the Arteries are di≈øper≈øed, ≈øo that the ≈øub≈øtance of the Liver has very little ≈øen≈øe.

We ≈øhew'd before how that for ≈øome while after the milky Veins were found out, they were believ'd to convey the Chyle to the Liver: and all the colour for this Opinion was a few ≈ømall clear, limpid and almo≈øt tran≈øparent Ve≈ø≈øels, that run between the Me≈øentery and it. But as on
the one hand they are too few in number for that office (e≈øpecially being ≈øo ≈ølender) being ≈øcarce one for ten of the milky Veins in the Me≈øentery: ≈øo on the other, they are neither of the ≈øame colour (as being much clearer) nor does the Liquor they contain come from the Me≈øentery to the Liver, but runs from this to that, as has been ob≈øerved in Live-di≈ø≈øections, in which having been tied they have ≈øwelled on that ≈øide of the Ligature toward the Liver, and grown empty toward the Me≈øentery. They are indeed then truly Lympheducts, which carry that water that is ≈øeparated from the bloud in the Liver, towards the Me≈øentery, and from it to the common receptacle of the Chyle with which it mixes.

Be≈øides the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels there are the numerous branches of the Gall-pa≈ø≈øage, of which we ≈øhall treat more fully in the next Chapter. And ≈øhall ≈øay no more here, but onely how one may di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt the branches of the Cava, Porta and the≈øe of the Gall-pa≈ø≈øage, ≈øo as to know which are which. Tho≈øe of the Cava are clad but with one Coat, are white, thin and of a large cavity. Tho≈øe of the Porta have a double Coat, and ≈øo are thicker and ≈øtronger, and yet not ≈øo wide as tho≈øe of the Cava. La≈øtly, the branches of the Gall-pa≈ø≈øage are of a duski≈øh yellow, have a thicker Coat than either the Cava or Porta, and yet have the narrowe≈øt channel. The≈øe are included in a common ca≈øe with tho≈øe of the Porta, which makes their outer Coat.

Having in the beginning of this Chapter detected the errour of the Ancients in a≈øcribing Sanguification to the Liver in ≈øo eminent and large a ≈øen≈øe; we mu≈øt however confe≈øs that it does ≈øomething towards the purifying of the Bloud, and that is, by ≈øeparating the Choler from it, as ≈øhall be fullier ≈øhewn in the next Chapter. In it al≈øo is a pretty quantity of ≈øerous or wheyi≈øh humour filtrated or ≈øtrained from the Bloud, which is ≈øent by the Lympheducts to the common receptacle of the Chyle as afore≈øaid. In the third and la≈øt place it furthers the concoction of the Stomach by its kind and cheri≈øhing heat.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Porus Bilarius, or Gall-pa≈ø≈øage.

argument.p: Its branching in the Liver, and its tendency without it. Choler how ≈øeparated from the Bloud, and its u≈øe.

div.p: IT is difficult to give a ≈øatisfactory account why mo≈øt Creatures ≈øhould have both a Gall-bladder, for the collection of the Choler, and be≈øides, a Gall-pa≈ø≈øage; and yet a Hor≈øe and all whole-hoofed Bea≈øts, as al≈øo Harts, Fallow-deer and ≈øome few others, ≈øhould onely have the pa≈ø≈øage without the Bladder. It would be worth the while for our Virtuo≈øi to invent a probable rea≈øon of it, but for my own part I dare not pretend to be ≈øo ≈øagacious. But much have tho≈øe been mi≈øtaken that not finding any Bladder of Gall, have affirmed that an Hor≈øe hath no gall at all. And this, Dr. Brown reckons up among≈øt vulgar Errors.

Now the trunk of this Gall-pa≈ø≈øage enters the Liver very near the ≈øame place with the Porta, together with which it is enwrapped in one common Cover, which they both borrow from that skin wherewith the Liver is cloathed. I mean they begin to be ≈øo inve≈øted ju≈øt at their entrance into the Liver, for before they have but each one ≈øingle Coat. Its branches run along with tho≈øe of the Porta through all parts of the Liver, and it has the ≈øame Artery and Nerve running through its Membrane. All the≈øe branches uniting into one trunk, it pa≈ø≈øes the directe≈øt way to the ≈ømall Gut, into which it is in≈øerted about a foot from the lower Orifice of the Stomach, where it di≈øcharges it ≈øelf of the Choler.

Having de≈øcribed the Ve≈ø≈øel, there remain two things to be enquired into, fir≈øt how the Choler is ≈øeparated in the Liver, and ≈øecondly of what u≈øe it is. As to the fir≈øt, we mu≈øt con≈øider that there can be no ≈øuch ≈øeparation as this, without ≈øome ≈øort of ferment to cau≈øe it. There comes indeed nothing to the Liver but under the form of bloud, but however it will be of u≈øe to examine from what parts that bloud comes: And among≈øt the re≈øt we find that a con≈øiderable quantity comes from the Spleen by the ≈øplenick branch. Now every one that will ta≈øte it may di≈øcern that the
bloud that comes out of the Spleen by this branch has a kind of a ≈øowri≈øh har≈øh ta≈øte to what the re≈øt of the ma≈øs of bloud has. This then mixing with the re≈øt of the bloud and pa≈ø≈øing with it through the narrow Ve≈ø≈øels in the Liver, cau≈øes it there to ferment (as a ≈ømall piece of ≈øowr Dough will I know not how much that is not leavened) and in that fermentation this yellow Choler is ≈øeparated from the Bloud, much in the ≈øame manner as Ye≈øt from Beer in a Barrel, (which it partly re≈øembles in colour.) And this fermentation is a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the proper nature and faculty of the Liver given by Nature to it; who hath al≈øo framed this liquor of Particles ≈øo differing from tho≈øe of the Bloud, that though the Bloud pa≈øs out of the Porta into the Cava, yet the Choler ≈øtays behind and is received by the ≈ømall mouths of the Choler-pa≈ø≈øage. Some affirm this ≈øeparation is performed by the help of ≈øome Glands or little Kernels into which the ends of the ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels are in≈øerted, but I have not been able to di≈øcern them. The u≈øe of the Gall is, Together with the Juice that is ≈øent from the Sweet-bread, to make a ferment in the fir≈øt Gut for the u≈øes that are fully enough delivered in the eleventh Chapter: to which we ≈øhall onely add, that it ≈øerves by its acrimony to ex≈øtimulate the Guts to expell the Excrements contained in them. And ≈øeeing there is no bag or repo≈øitory to ≈øtore it up in, it pa≈ø≈øes continually to the Guts, whereby Hor≈øes come to dung oftener than mo≈øt other Creatures: which as Dr. Brown notes, was prudently contrived by Providence in this Animal, con≈øidering his plentifull feeding, the largene≈øs of his Guts, and their various circumvolution. For, ≈øays he, Choler is the natural Gly≈øter, or one excretion whereby Nature excludes another, &c.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Spleen or Milt.

argument.p: The ≈øub≈øtance of the Spleen. Its ≈øituation and connexion. Its Figure. Its Colour. Whether an Hor≈øe can live without it. Its Membrane. 1. Ve≈ø≈øels. Veins. 2. Arteries. 3. Nerves. 4. Lympheducts. Its action and u≈øe.

div.p: THE Spleen or Milt is of a ≈øoft, ≈øpongious ≈øub≈øtance, like thick, black and congealed Bloud, from which it is ≈øaid to be generated; though ≈øome that of late have examined it more curiou≈øly with Magnifying Gla≈ø≈øes, declare the greate≈øt part of its ≈øub≈øtance, be≈øides the Bloudve≈ø≈øels, to con≈øi≈øt of abundance of little Kernels inclo≈øed in skinny Cells like Honey-combs, which in their own nature are of a white colour, and will appear ≈øuch when the Bloud is wa≈øht from them. For my own part, I que≈øtion whether there be any ≈øuch Kernels in it, or if there be, they mu≈øt be far different from tho≈øe of any other part, and be of a much loo≈øer ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øeeing I have onely in River-water (after I had taken off the inve≈øting skin) wa≈øht off the parenchyma ≈øo clearly from the Ve≈ø≈øels, that there has ≈øeem'd to be nothing el≈øe remaining. A figure of which Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øo cleared of the parenchyma by wa≈øhing, you have in the following Table.

Its ≈øituation is under the ≈øhort Ribs on the left ≈øide over again≈øt the Liver, between the Stomach and the ≈øhort or ba≈øtard Ribs. It cleaveth oft-times to the Midriff by a skin or coat, which it hath from the Rim of the Belly. It is al≈øo fa≈øtned by a skin to the Stomach.
It is of a triangular ≈øhape, yet long, and ≈øomething ≈øharp-pointed, as you may ≈øee in the Figure.

Its Colour is (in a ≈øound Hor≈øe) reddi≈øh, inclining ≈øomewhat to black; but in an un≈øound Hor≈øe it is more inclining to black, or of a leaden or a≈øhey colour: yet mo≈øt times in an un≈øound Hor≈øe it is of the colour of the Humour which offends.

There are ≈øeveral Creatures that naturally have no Spleen, as all In≈øects; and therefore that Proverb is not literally true, That even a Fly has a Spleen; Such al≈øo as have no Pi≈øs-bladder, want the Milt, as the Chameleon, and many ≈øuch like: But now it is a great que≈øtion, whether ≈øuch Creatures as by Nature have Spleens, can have them taken out, and yet live. It is true indeed that other Parts that ≈øeem to be as con≈øiderable, have been taken even out of Humane Bodies, and yet the Parties have lived: So I have read of ≈øome Women that upon incurable di≈øtempers in the Part, have had their Womb cut out, and yet have liv'd in tolerable health afterwards (Barthol. Epi≈øt.) And it is a common thing to geld any ≈øort of Creature, though there be con≈øiderably large Ve≈ø≈øels that run to the Stones. But it is to be confe≈øs'd that the≈øe parts in≈øtanc'd in, ≈øeem to be wholly framed for the propagation of the ≈øeveral kinds of living Creatures, and not for the nece≈ø≈øary ≈øervice of the Individual that has them. And therefore when they are taken away, though the end for which they were created, to wit generation, be fru≈øtrated by the lo≈øs of them; yet may the Creature it ≈øelf that lo≈øes them, live well enough without them. But now as for the Spleen, it does not at all ≈øerve for procreation, but is of u≈øe onely to that Body that has it. (What its u≈øe is, we ≈øhall ≈øhew towards the latter end of this Chapter.) Yet ≈øeveral have boa≈øted that they have taken it out of Dogs and Cats, and that they have lived in pretty good plight a con≈øiderable while after. The operation mu≈øt needs be ≈øomewhat difficult, ≈øeeing the Spleen is ≈øeated on the in≈øide of the ≈øhort Ribs, nearer the Back than the Brea≈øt: nor can I believe that a Hor≈øe could live any while if it were taken out of him; but lea≈øt of all could Man, in whom it is larger than in any other Creature, as Bartholin affirms. For the Ve≈ø≈øels that are in≈øerted into it are ≈øo many and large, that it would ≈øeem impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øtanch the Bloud; be≈øides the nece≈ø≈øary u≈øe that it ≈øeems to be of to the Body, of which by and by.

The skin that it is covered with, is thicker than that of the Liver, both becau≈øe of the loo≈øe and ≈øoft ≈øub≈øtance of the Spleen that required a ≈øtronger covering to defend it; and al≈øo that it might the better ≈øu≈øtain the ≈øtrong beatings of its Arteries that are pretty large and many. This skin it has from the Peritonaeum or Rim of the Belly, to which it is commonly knit, as al≈øo to the left Kidney and the Midriff, and on its in≈øide to the Caul. Some late Anatomi≈øts have affirmed it to be clad with two Coats, the outer that which we have mentioned, and the inner ari≈øing from the Ve≈ø≈øels that enter the Spleen.

All the Veins that it has, are from that branch of the Porta that is called the Splenick branch. For the Porta as ≈øoon as it comes out of the lower or hollow ≈øide of the Liver, ≈øends one notable Branch to the Spleen, which pa≈ø≈øing cro≈øs the Body from the right to the left ≈øide under the Liver and Stomach, enters the Spleen and di≈øper≈øes it ≈øelf into innumerable Twigs all over it. A Twig of the ≈øplenick Artery opens into this Vein a little before it enters the Spleen: And from the lower end of the Spleen
there go two or three Ve≈ø≈øels to the Stomach, which are called Va≈øa brevia or ≈øhort Ve≈ø≈øels. The u≈øe of the ≈øplenick Vein is to bring from the Spleen all that arterial blood that is not ≈øpent on its nouri≈øhment; and be≈øides, that proper and peculiar juice that is made in the Spleen, of which pre≈øently.

Its Arteries are three or four times more in number than the Veins, and all of them ≈øpring from the left Coeliack branch that has the name of Splenick, from the Spleen, into which it is in≈øerted. Hereby it receives vital heat and nouri≈øhment, and matter out of which to make its proper juice. Before this Artery enter the Spleen, it ≈øends forth one twig that unites with and opens into the ≈øplenick Vein, as was noted before.

Its Nerves are but ≈ømall yet pretty numerous. They ≈øpring from a me≈øenterick branch of the left Interco≈øtal Nerve, and are di≈øper≈øed principally through the skin that covers it, though ≈øome few enter its ≈øub≈øtance.

La≈øtly, it has ≈øeveral Lympheducts, or Water-pa≈ø≈øages, which creeping all over its Coat, take their way along the Caul towards the common receptacle of the Chyle, into which they empty the liquor contained in them, as all tho≈øe that ari≈øe from the ≈øeveral parts of the lower Belly do. What the≈øe Lympheducts are, and what that liquor is which they contain, I have ≈øhown above in the 12th Chapter, of the Me≈øentery.

There is no part of the Body concerning who≈øe u≈øe there has been greater diver≈øity of opinion. Some have made it the receptacle of black Choler (or of thick dreggy Bloud) ≈øeparated in the Liver and brought hither by the ≈øplenick branch. Others that thought this too ignoble and ba≈øe an u≈øe for ≈øo con≈øiderable a part, e≈øteem'd it to be as it were a ≈øecond Liver: For as they believed that the thinner and more ≈øpirituous part of the Chyle pa≈ø≈øed to the Liver; ≈øo, that a thicker and more dreggy part went to the Spleen, of which was made a blacker and more earthy ≈øort of Bloud, partly for its own nouri≈øhment, and partly for the nouri≈øhment of the Stomach, Guts, Me≈øentery, &c. In an≈øwer to the≈øe two opinions it will be ≈øufficient to ≈øay, That the fir≈øt is contrary to the circulation of the Bloud, nothing pa≈ø≈øing from the Liver to the Spleen, but contrarily from the Spleen to the Liver: and the latter, be≈øides that it is contrary to the ≈øaid circulation, is repugnant al≈øo to the true motion of the Chyle, none of which either pa≈ø≈øes to the Liver or Spleen, as we have more than once ≈øhown already. A third opinion is, That of the bloud that the Arteries bring to it in great plenty, is made a certain acid or ≈øowr Juice, which is ≈øent by the va≈øa brevia or ≈øhort Veins to the Stomach, into which being di≈øcharged, it partly provokes appetite, and partly helps concoction: And this Opinion has had a great many Abettors, whereas its fal≈øity may be demon≈øtrated by this, that if one open a Dog (or the like) alive, and tie the≈øe ≈øhort Veins with a thred, they will fill and ≈øwell betwixt the Stomach and Ligature, but will grow empty on that ≈øide toward the Spleen; which is a plain evidence that the Bloud or whatever other Humour that runs in the≈øe ≈øhort Veins, flows from the Stomach and not to it. However we will grant that the Spleen does indeed make ≈øuch a ≈øowr Juice, of part of the Arterial bloud that is imported into it by the ≈øplenick Artery; but then it pa≈ø≈øes not from thence to the Stomach, but to the Liver by the ≈øplenick branch of the Porta: for if one tie the ≈øaid branch, as was ≈øaid above of the ≈øhort veins, it will fill towards the Spleen and grow empty towards the Liver. And the u≈øe of this Juice ≈øeems to
be this, viz. That mixing in the trunk of the Porta with all the Bloud that is received by the branches thereof out of the ≈øeveral parts of the Lower Belly, e≈øpecially from the Guts, it enters with it into the Liver, where it cau≈øes the Bloud to ferment, whereby the Choler is ≈øeparated from it, for the u≈øes mentioned in the foregoing Chapter, where we have treated more at large of this ≈øeparation.

Another u≈øe of the Spleen is, by its warmth to cheri≈øh the left ≈øide of the Stomach, as the Liver does the right, to further the concoction thereof. And this it may be conceived to doe in a very con≈øiderable degree; for ≈øeeing it has ≈øo very many Arteries, it mu≈øt needs be very warm.

There are many more Opinions concerning the u≈øe of the Spleen than the≈øe I have mentioned: but as it would be tedious to recite them, ≈øo it would be but needle≈øs to refute them, the new Doctrines of the circulation of the Bloud and the motion of the Chyle being improveable to a general confutation of them.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Kidneys, and Deputy-kidneys.

argument.p: Their name. Number, ≈øituation and connexion. Figure. Membranes. Sub≈øtance. Ve≈ø≈øels, viz. Emulgent Arteries, and Veins. The Papillary Caruncles. The pelvis or Ba≈øon. Their Action. Deputy-kidneys, their name, ≈øituation, bigne≈øs and ≈øhape. Their Ve≈ø≈øels. Their ∆≤≈øe.

div.p: THE Kidneys are otherwi≈øe called Reins from their Latine name Renes, which is derived from a Greek word which ≈øignifieth to flow, becau≈øe the watery or wheyi≈øh part of the Bloud doth continually flow through them, and maketh the Urine.

They are in number two, that when one is ≈øtopt with a ≈øtone or gravel, or hurt by any accident, the Urine might be ≈øeparated in the other, or otherwi≈øe the Bea≈øt would die. They are ≈øeated in the Loins behind the Stomach and Guts, the right under the Liver and the left under the Spleen, on each ≈øide of the hollow Vein and great Artery, oppo≈øite to one another. They re≈øt upon the Mu≈øcles of the Loins, and are included betwixt the Membranes of the Peritonaeum which keeps them firm in their place. They are knit to the hollow Vein and great Artery by the Emulgent Ve≈ø≈øels, and to the Bladder by the Ureters which we ≈øhall de≈øcribe in the next Chapter.

They are ≈øeldom like to one another in ≈øhape; for the Right is in figure like a Heart, but ≈øomething flatter; whereas the left is like that of a Man, viz. of the ≈øhape of a Kidney-bean, as you may ≈øee them repre≈øented in the following Figure.

They are covered with two Membranes, an inner which is proper, and an outer which is common. The inner Skin ≈øeems to ≈øpring from the outer Coat of tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels that enter into them: this cleaves ≈øo clo≈øe to them, that it can hardly be ≈øeparated, being very thin, and having ≈ømall threds of Nerves running along it from a twig of the Interco≈øtal Nerve. The outer which is common, is borrowed from the Rim of the Belly, and is wrapped ≈øomewhat loo≈øely about the Kidney. This Skin is bedaubed with fat, and is therefore called the fatty Coat; and into it are in≈øerted an Artery
and Vein, which have al≈øo the title of fatty, and ≈øpring from the great Artery and hollow Vein.

As to their ≈øub≈øtance, it has been always till of late held to be hard and compact fle≈øh; and indeed it handles pretty firm to the touch, and ≈øeems to be fle≈øhy to the bare eye. But ≈øeeing there is no ≈øeparation made of any thing from the Bloud in other Parts, but by the help of Glands or Kernels; (for ≈øo is the Slaver ≈øeparated in the Mouth, the Choler in the Liver, bad Humours in the Guts upon taking a purge, &c.) I ≈øay, for that cau≈øe it is rea≈øonable to give credit to tho≈øe curious Anatomi≈øts that by their Magnifying Gla≈ø≈øes or Micro≈øcopes have di≈øcovered the ≈øub≈øtance of the Kidneys to be for the greate≈øt part made up of ≈øuch Glands, by means of which the Urine is ≈øeparated from the Bloud, in ≈øuch manner as we ≈øhall ≈øhew by and by.

Their Arteries and Veins are called Emulgents, becau≈øe they do as it were milk out the Urine from the ma≈øs of Bloud. Each Kidney has for the mo≈øt part but one Artery and one Vein; yet ≈øometimes two or more of a ≈øort. But whether the Trunk be one or more, each as it enters the Kidneys is branched into ≈øeveral, and tho≈øe into more ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, till they become as ≈ømall as hairs. The Emulgent Arteries ≈øpring from the Trunk of the great Artery, and the Veins from the hollow Vein: Both the≈øe as they enter the Kidney, are deve≈øted of their outer Coat, which makes the proper Coat of the Kidneys, as was ob≈øerved above: but in≈øtead of that lo≈øs they are inve≈øted in one common Ca≈øe with the branches of the Ureter, even as we ≈øhewed in the fifteenth Chapter that the branches of the Gall-pa≈ø≈øage in the Liver are included in one common Coat or Ca≈øe with tho≈øe of the Porta. The Arteries bring bloud for their nouri≈øhment, and moreover the watery humour that is ≈øeparated in them and makes the Urine. By the Veins the bloud circulates back again to the hollow Vein or Cava, and by it a≈øcends up to the Heart.

Be≈øides the innumerable little Kernels which we have ≈øhewn the ≈øub≈øtance of the Kidney to con≈øi≈øt of, there are about ten of a more con≈øiderable bigne≈øs in the middle or centre of it, placed at the entrance into the pelvis or Ba≈øon, which are in Latin called Carunculae Papillares, in Engli≈øh Papillary Caruncles, and by ≈øome they are called Teat-like Productions, both which names they have from the likene≈øs they have to the Teats or Nipples of Women. They are ≈øomething harder than the re≈øt of the ≈øub≈øtance of the Kidney, and al≈øo of a fainter colour. They are in bigne≈øs as large as a ≈ømall Hor≈øe-bean. They have each ≈øeveral ≈ømall holes or pores, through which the Urine de≈øtills out of the ≈ølender Urinary Pipes in the body of the Kidneys, into the cavity of the pelvis.

Now this pelvis or Ba≈øon is a membranous cell or cavity in the middle of the Kidney, and is nothing el≈øe but the head of the ∆≤reter widened. There run out of it ≈øeveral large pipes to the afore≈øaid Teat-like Kernels, (one pipe to each Kernel) by which the Urine drils into this cavity, and out of it into the ∆≤reter.

The action of the Kidneys, is to ≈øeparate the wheyi≈øh Humour from the Bloud, which they do in this manner and order. We find that an Hor≈øe can no more live without drink than meat: Now the drink ≈øerves not onely to cool the Body, but much more is it of u≈øe to make the Chyle thin, that it may be able to pa≈øs through the narrow ways of the milky Veins; ≈øo that the water which the Hor≈øe drinks, pa≈ø≈øes along with the more oily Chyle into the ma≈øs of Bloud, whither having conducted
it, the water is now of no more u≈øe, and therefore the Emulgent Arteries above-de≈øcribed conveigh it to the Kidneys together with the Bloud, to ca≈øt it out: But the Bloud, being of a thicker body than the water, cannot enter through tho≈øe narrow pa≈ø≈øages which the other de≈øtils through, and therefore what is more than ≈øerves for their nouri≈øhment, returns back from the Kidneys by the Emulgent Veins into the Cava, and ≈øo returns to the Heart again in its circulation. But the watery or wheyi≈øh part running out of the larger into the ≈ømaller branches of the Emulgent Arteries ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, and the ≈øaid branches ≈øo often dividing them≈øelves till at la≈øt they become as ≈ømall as an hair and end in the little Kernels towards the out≈øide of the Kidneys, this watery Humour is milked as it were through the≈øe Kernels into ≈ømall urinary pipes, as ≈ølender almo≈øt as Fibres, by which it drills along to the Papillary Caruncles, and is again ≈øtrained through them into the Ba≈øon, from whence it glides down the Ureters into the Bladder, where when it becomes trouble≈øome either by its quantity or ≈øharpne≈øs, &c. it provokes the Hor≈øe to ≈øtale, and is called Urine. But ≈øeeing the Pi≈øs is not of the ≈øame colour with the water that was drunk, but generally a great deal yellower, it is likely it gains that colour from a little quantity of Choler mixed with it: And as the Choler either retains it natural colour, to wit yellow, or is preternaturally of ≈øome other, as black, greeni≈øh, &c. the Urine will be tinctured accordingly; as any Man may ob≈øerve in Hor≈øes that are di≈øtempered. So that in Hor≈øes as well as in Men, one may many times gain ≈øome knowledge of the Di≈øtemper from the Urine.

Over the Kidneys a little more outward, and about an inch from them, there ≈øtand two Kernels, which are known by ≈øeveral Names, from the ≈øeveral u≈øes that Authors have a≈øcribed to them. Some call them Deputy-kidneys, becau≈øe of ≈øome re≈øemblance they have to the true ones in their frame, and becau≈øe they have been thought to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in ≈øeparating the Urine. Bartholine calls them Black-choler Ca≈øes, from an Opinion that they receive black Choler from the Spleen. Others have impos'd other Names on them, which we ≈øhall not recite. It is not long ≈øince they were fir≈øt found out. They are in an Hor≈øe about as big as a Garden-bean, and of that ≈øhape as they are repre≈øented in the Figure. They are covered with a ≈øingle thin skin, which commonly ≈øticks to the fatty skin that inve≈øts the Kidneys. They have a ≈ømall cavity in them.

Their Veins and Arteries generally come from the Emulgents, but ≈øometimes immediately from the great Artery and hollow Vein. The Arteries bring them bloud for nouri≈øhment, from which what remains, returns back by the Veins, as al≈øo does that Humour whatever it be that is concocted and ≈øeparated in them, for there is no other ve≈ø≈øel to do it. They have indeed ≈øome Lympheducts, but tho≈øe are common to them with other parts, and have no peculiar u≈øe here. Their Nerves ≈øpring from that branch of the Interco≈øtal pair that goes to the Stomach, to the Spleen, and to the inner or proper skin that cloaths the Kidneys.

In their Cavity there is commonly found a blacki≈øh Humour, which is made of part of the Arterial bloud that flows to them; but of what nature or u≈øe this Humour ≈øhould be, is very uncertain. It has no way to go out of the Cavity but by the Veins, which depo≈øite what is contained in them into the Emulgent Veins, or into the Cava, and ≈øo it mu≈øt needs pa≈øs with the Venal bloud to the Heart. If there could be
found out any way whereby it could probably pa≈øs to the Kidneys, then Bartholine's Opinion, that they make a ferment for the u≈øe of the Reins, for the better ≈øeparating of the wheyi≈øh Humour from the Bloud, were very plau≈øible; but till then, one mu≈øt ≈øu≈øpend their belief of it. As for mine own part, ≈øeeing ≈øo many learned Anatomi≈øts as have treated of them, are at a lo≈øs in di≈øcovering their true u≈øe, I will not be a≈øhamed to confe≈øs my own ignorance and un≈øatisfiedne≈øs therein al≈øo.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the ∆≤reters or Pa≈ø≈øages of ∆≤rine.

argument.p: The ∆≤reters. Their ≈øub≈øtance, and Ve≈ø≈øels. Their cavity and u≈øe.

div.p: THE ∆≤reters or Urine-pipes or Chanels are in number two, ≈øeated on each ≈øide of the hollow Vein and great Artery, at ≈øome di≈øtance from them. Their head or beginning is the Ba≈øon of the Kidneys, at who≈øe hollow ≈øide they come forth, and run in a crooked line like an ≈ø down to the Bladder, into who≈øe back and lower part they are in≈øerted not far from the Sphincter, running for an inch between its two proper Coats, to prevent the return of the Urine back this way. For when the Bladder is ≈øqueezed, its Coats clap clo≈øe together, and ≈øo ≈øhut up the mouths of the Ureters.

They are in ≈øub≈øtance much like a Vein, onely whiter and thicker, and more nervous. They are commonly held to con≈øi≈øt of two Coats, an inner which is proper, and an outer which is borrowed from the Rim of the Belly. They have ≈ømall Veins and Arteries from the neighbouring Ve≈ø≈øels, and ≈ølips of Nerves in a con≈øiderable number from the Interco≈øtals, whence proceeds that intolerable ≈øen≈øe of pain when a ≈øtone ≈øticks in them.

They are indifferent large, having a hollowne≈øs through them which is ≈øo wide, that they will admit of a large ≈øtraw in a dead Hor≈øe, and therefore may be conceived in a living Hor≈øe to be much wider. Through the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages or hollowne≈ø≈øes, the Urine doth pa≈øs from the Kidneys to the Bladder, and that is their ≈øole and true u≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the Pi≈øs-bladder, or Bladder of ∆≤rine.

argument.p: The ≈øituation and ≈øub≈øtance of the Bladder. Its Figure. Membranes. Its perforations. Its parts and connexion. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its ∆≤≈øe.

div.p: THE Bladder of Urine is ≈øeated at the bottom of the Belly, in that hollowne≈øs that is formed of the Os ≈øacrum, Hips and the Os pubis, between the Coats of the Rim of the Belly; and is of a ≈øub≈øtance partly membranous, for ≈øtrength, exten≈øion and contraction; and partly fle≈øhy, for motion; for by its fle≈øhy Fibres are its Membranes contracted: and the≈øe fle≈øhy Fibres are wholly ≈øeated in its middle Coat, which is truly mu≈øcular, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed by and by.
It is of a round globous figure, in ≈øhape like a Pear, having within it a large cavity or hollowne≈øs, wherein to contain the Urine.

It is compo≈øed of a treble Coat or Skin. The fir≈øt and outwardmo≈øt of which it hath derived to it from the Rim of the Belly, which Skin is very ≈øtrong and clo≈øe. The innermo≈øt is thin, white and bright, of an exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe, and is interwoven with all ≈øorts of Fibres, that it may the better bear inlarging and drawing up together, as need requireth. Within I have often found it covered with a mucous cru≈øt, which I take to be an Excrement of the third concoction of the Bladder, and to ≈øerve to defend it from being too much grated upon by the acrimony of the Urine. The middle betwixt the≈øe two, is as thick or thicker than them both, and is ≈øtuff with fle≈øhy Fibres, even as the ≈øame Coat of the Stomach and Womb are. Its Fibres run lengthways of the Bladder, and by contracting of them≈øelves ≈øqueeze out the Urine, forcing open the ≈øphincter Mu≈øcle that encompa≈ø≈øeth the neck of the Bladder.
It hath three perforations or holes, two on the hinder part a little below the neck to let in the Urine from the Ureters, and one in the neck to let the Urine out.

The parts of the Bladder are two, its bottom and its neck. The bottom is its wider, more capacious part, and its neck, its narrower and more contracted. The bottom is fa≈øt tied by a Membrane to the Inte≈øtinum rectum or Ar≈øe-gut, and to the Aorta (a little before its divi≈øion) by the Umbilical Arteries, ≈øo that no violent motion can cau≈øe it to fall down upon its neck, which if it ≈øhould happen, would hinder the outgate of the Urine. The neck is narrower but longer in Hor≈øes than in Mares, and in both it is fle≈øhy, being incompa≈ø≈øed with a ≈øphincter Mu≈øcle, which is woven with very many Fibres, ≈øome of which are ≈øtreight, and ≈øome overthwart, the≈øe la≈øt lying under the former. Now this ≈øphincter Mu≈øcle ≈øeems to be nothing el≈øe but the middle Coat of the Bladder made thicker here than in any other part, by the acce≈ø≈øion of the circular or overthwart Fibres. And its u≈øe is to pur≈øe up the neck of the Bladder ≈øo, as no Urine can pa≈øs out, till by its quantity or ≈øharpne≈øs it becomes ≈øo trouble≈øome to the Bea≈øt, as provokes him to force open the Sphincter by contracting the Mu≈øcles of the Paunch, and the mu≈øcular Coat of the Bladder. If this Sphincter happen to be overcooled, &c. the Hor≈øe lo≈øeth its u≈øe, and ≈øo for want of it his Water drops from him as fa≈øt as it comes into the Bladder.

Its Veins and Arteries proceed from the hypoga≈øtrick branches of the hollow Vein and great Artery, and are implanted into its neck, on which, part of them is ≈øpent, and the remainder runs through the bottom. Its Nerves come partly from the Interco≈øtals and partly from the Marrow of that Bone of the Back that is called Os ≈øacrum, that is next to the Crupper.

The u≈øe of the Bladder is to receive the Urine from the Kidneys by the Ureters, and to contain it, like a Chamber-pot, till it is ≈øo full as to become trouble≈øome and unea≈øy to the Bea≈øt; for as ≈øoon as it becomes ≈øo, by the help of the Mu≈øcles of the Belly and the middle mu≈øcular Coat of the Bladder it is pre≈ø≈øed out of it by pi≈ø≈øing.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the Yard and Sheath.

argument.p: The parts of the Yard. Its Nervous bodies. The Pi≈øs-pipe The Glans. The Mu≈øcles. The Ve≈ø≈øels. Its ∆≤≈øe. The Sheath.

div.p: BEcau≈øe the Yard of ≈øton'd Hor≈øes be≈øides its principal u≈øe which is to copulate with the Mare, has al≈øo an inferiour u≈øe, viz. to di≈øcharge the Urine out of the Bladder; and becau≈øe this latter is the ≈øole u≈øe of it in Geldings, we will here treat of it next to the Bladder, in re≈øpect to the office it performs to it, and not defer it, as many Anatomi≈øts of Humane Bodies do, till we have di≈øcour≈øed of the parts that prepare, make and retain the Seed, to which it al≈øo mini≈øters.

The Yard of an Hor≈øe lies hid for the mo≈øt part within the Sheath, from which, when it is drawn, it borrows its covering, con≈øi≈øting of the Scarf-skin and true Skin, and the carnous Membrane, which are common to it with other parts of the Body: Its Glans has a proper Membrane that inve≈øts it, as the Glans of a Man's Yard has; and the whole con≈øi≈øts of two Nervous bodies (which make up the greate≈øt part of its bulk) a Partition-skin that goes betwixt them, the ∆≤rethra or Pi≈øs-pipe, the Glans, four Mu≈øcles and the Ve≈ø≈øels; of which in order.

The two Nervous bodies are encompa≈ø≈øed with a thick, firm and white skin, but their inner ≈øub≈øtance is very ≈øpongy and flaggy unle≈øs di≈øtended and filled with bloud and ≈øpirit, con≈øi≈øting for the greate≈øt part of nothing but Ve≈ø≈øels, to wit, Veins, Arteries and Nervous threads, which are wonderfully interwoven one with another. They ari≈øe from the lower part of the Share-bone at a ≈ømall di≈øtance one from the other, giving the Pi≈øs-pipe room to go betwixt them, but in a little while they meet together, and ≈øo are extended one by the ≈øide of the other the whole length of the Yard to the Glans, onely a thin skin coming betwixt them. At their ri≈øe they re≈øemble the letter Y.

The Pi≈øs-pipe is ≈øeated betwixt the≈øe, or rather below them, and is of a ≈øub≈øtance much like them. On its in≈øide it is membranous and very ≈øen≈øible. It is continued from the neck of the Bladder, and is much of an equal width through its whole length. At its beginning where it is joined to the neck of the Bladder it has a membranous valve, that permits the Urine to come out, but hinders the Seed or any thing ≈øquirted
into the Pi≈øs-pipe to go in, unle≈øs it be forced open with a Probe or Catheter, or the like.

Before the ends of the Nervous bodies there is prefixed the Glans, which is di≈øtingui≈øhable from the re≈øt of the Yard by a round circle like a Crown going between them. This is of a more exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe than the Nervous bodies, but of not much an unlike ≈øub≈øtance, though ≈øome ≈øay it is glandulous. When the Yard is drawn, it has no other covering, but one proper thin coat.

The Yard has two Mu≈øcles on each ≈øide at its root: The fir≈øt pair are ≈øhort and thick, ≈øpringing from the knob of the Hip-bone, and are in≈øerted into the Nervous bodies near their beginning: they are called Erectors, becau≈øe they help the Yard to ≈øtand. The ≈øecond are longer and ≈ømaller, ari≈øing from the ≈øphincter Mu≈øcle of the Ar≈øe-hole, and pa≈ø≈øing along the ≈øides of the Pi≈øs-pipe end about the middle of it, ≈øerving to open or widen it for the freer pa≈ø≈øage of the Seed and Urine, and are therefore called Dilaters.
Its Veins and Arteries ≈øpring from the Hypoga≈øtricks, and enter it at the meeting of the Nervous bodies. Its Nerves come from the lowe≈øt Vertebral.

The principal and primary u≈øe of the Yard is for copulation, to convey the Seed into the Womb of the Female: but the ≈øecondary, and to ≈øuch Creatures as are gelt, the onely u≈øe of it, is to ≈øerve as a Tap to the Bladder, to let out the Urine when it becomes trouble≈øome; in which office the ∆≤rethra or Pi≈øs-pipe is chiefly concerned.

Except when the Yard is di≈øtended with bloud and Spirits, (which is called its erection or ≈øtanding) it lies hid in its Repo≈øitory, the Sheath, of which little need to be ≈øaid, ≈øeeing it is onely a duplicature of the common coverings of the Body, and con≈øi≈øts onely of the ≈øcarf and true Skin, and the fle≈øhy Membrane, which is here but thin. It ≈øeems to an≈øwer to the prepuce or Fore-skin in Men: for as that in ≈øome Men, when the Yard is erect, turns back towards the root of the Penis and leaves the Glans wholly bare; ≈øo when a Hor≈øe's Yard is drawn out to the full length, the Sheath is al≈øo drawn out or unfolded, and appears to be knit to the Yard a little behind the Glans, even as the prepuce is to a Man's Penis at the ≈øame place. I ≈øhall not need therefore to ≈øpeak any more of it.
