div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Parts mini≈øtring to Generation in Hor≈øes, and Fir≈øt of the Preparing, Spermatick or Seed-ve≈ø≈øels.

argument.p: The preparing Ve≈ø≈øels. Their u≈øe.

div.p: HAVING ≈øhewed the Parts appointed for and ≈øub≈øervient to Chylification, and in ≈øome mea≈øure to Nutrition and Sanguification, I come in the next place to ≈øpeak to tho≈øe ≈øerving for Generation. And as the former, all except the Yard treated of in the la≈øt Chapter, are common to and alike in both Male and Female; ≈øo the≈øe latter differing con≈øiderably in the different Sexes, we mu≈øt treat of them apart: and ≈øhall begin with the Generative Parts of an Hor≈øe, and afterwards treat of tho≈øe of a Mare.

The fir≈øt in order are the preparing or ≈øpermatick Ve≈ø≈øels, Arteries and Veins. The Arteries carry bloud and vital ≈øpirit to the Stones to make Seed of, and the Veins bring back from thence ≈øo much of the bloud as remains ≈øuperfluous or unfit for that purpo≈øe. The Arteries ≈øpring out of the de≈øcending Trunk of the great Artery, almo≈øt two hands breadth below the Emulgents, one on each ≈øide: and the Veins out of the like Trunk of the hollow Vein, two on each ≈øide, a pretty deal higher up than the Arteries, as you may ob≈øerve in the foregoing Figure. The le≈øt of the≈øe Veins in Humane Bodies commonly ≈øprings from the left Emulgent Vein, (and is but one) the rea≈øon whereof Anatomi≈øts give to be, le≈øt, if it ≈øhould have ≈øprung from the Cava, and thereby been nece≈ø≈øitated to have marched over the great Artery, the return of the bloud from the Stones by it ≈øhould have been hindred by the continual beating of the Artery. But ≈øeeing Nature has not here made the like caution, where there was as great need of it, I cannot tell whether that be any ≈øatisfactory rea≈øon. Now the≈øe Arteries and Veins do at a little di≈øtance from their beginning meet with one another on their re≈øpective ≈øides, to wit the right Artery with the right Veins, and the left with the left, and at their meeting they acquire one common covering from the Rim of the belly, between who≈øe two Membranes they de≈øcend down the Loins,
running over the Ureters, as the figure ≈øhews. As they de≈øcend, they be≈øtow little twigs upon the Rim of the Belly, and the Veins do divide them≈øelves into ≈øeveral, and by and by unite again; but the Arteries pa≈øs along a great way by one Pipe onely, though variou≈øly twi≈øted and interwoven with the Veins, with which yet they do no where ino≈øculate, or unite into one body, as was generally affirmed they did before the circulation of the bloud was found out. For till then it was believed, that the Veins carried bloud to the Stones, and the Arteries vital Spirits, and that the Arteries opened into the Veins, and contrarily the Veins into the Arteries, for the mixing the bloud and vital ≈øpirits together, and thereby preparing matter for the Stones to make Seed of. But ≈øince the circulation of the bloud was fully under≈øtood, and it became certain that bloud and ≈øpirit flowed to the Stones by the Arteries onely; upon a ≈øtrict enquiry after the≈øe ino≈øculations, they were no where to be found, nor is there any thing like them, ≈øaving that both Veins and Arteries pa≈øs along in one common Cover, which it is likely gave occa≈øion to the mi≈øtake. When the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels are arrived within little le≈øs than a quarter of a yard of the Stones, the Arteries then begin to branch them≈øelves into ≈øeveral, but the Veins into far more. And both of them pa≈øs out of the Belly by the hole of the proce≈øs of the Rim into the Cod. The ≈øpace betwixt where the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels begin ≈øo much to divide them≈øelves, and the Stones, is called the Pyramidal body, becau≈øe from the Stones upwards, it grows ≈ømaller and ≈ømaller like a Pyramid, as is repre≈øented in the Figure. It is al≈øo called Corpus varico≈øum, becau≈øe the Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øo divided make a thicker body; and la≈øtly plexus pampiniformis, the tendril-like plexus or interweaving, becau≈øe the Veins and Arteries twine and cla≈øp about one another like the tendrils of Vines. Both of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels enter the Stones by ≈øeveral branches, but the Veins by a far greater number than the Arteries, which was nece≈ø≈øary, for that the bloud flows very quick to the Stones by the Arteries, but returns but ≈ølowly back again by the Veins, and therefore it was convenient it ≈øhould have more conducts or chanels to run in.

The u≈øe of the≈øe Preparing Ve≈ø≈øels may be ≈øufficiently learned by what we have already di≈øcour≈øed of them, by which it is al≈øo clear that the name of Preparers belongs onely properly to the Arteries that carry bloud and ≈øpirits to the Stones to nouri≈øh them and to make Seed of, and not at all to the Veins, which onely bring back that bloud that is not converted to tho≈øe u≈øes.

As for the Nerves and Lympheducts that run with the afore≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øels to the Te≈øticles, becau≈øe the Te≈øticles are the parts for which they are de≈øigned, and they are onely in their pa≈ø≈øage thither while they accompany the≈øe Veins and Arteries, we ≈øhall ≈øay nothing further of them here, but ≈øhall ≈øhew their origine and u≈øe in the following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of the Te≈øticles or Stones, and the Para≈øtatae or Attenders.

argument.p: Their name. Their ≈øhape and ≈øub≈øtance. Their Ve≈ø≈øels. Their Coats. Their Mu≈øcles. Para≈øtatae. The u≈øe of the Stones and Para≈øtatae.

div.p: THE Te≈øticles or Stones are called in Latin Te≈øtes, which otherwi≈øe ≈øignifies Witne≈ø≈øes, becau≈øe they witne≈øs the ≈øtrength and courage of the Creature; or perhaps rather, as ≈øome think, becau≈øe no Man among≈øt the Romans was admitted to be a Witne≈øs that had lo≈øt his Stones. They are always according to Nature two, and therefore the Greeks call them by a word that ≈øignifies Twins.

They are of an oval figure, but ≈øomewhat flatti≈øh: and their ≈øub≈øtance has been formerly held to be glandulous, as if they were onely two great Kernels, not differing from other Kernels in other parts of the Body ≈øaving in bigne≈øs and u≈øe. But later Anatomi≈øts have di≈øcovered them to be of no ≈øuch ≈øolid ≈øub≈øtance as Glands are, but wholly to con≈øi≈øt of Ve≈ø≈øels that twi≈øt and twine this way and that way, and are kept in their order clo≈øe to one another by the inmo≈øt Skin that cloaths the Stones. When they are cut in two, they appear not red, but of that colour the Seed is of, becau≈øe the bloud as ≈øoon as it enters them, begins to lo≈øe its colour and nature, and to be turned into Seed. And ≈øeeing I could never ob≈øerve any bloud in the Stones, it is likely that the Veins reach no further than their Coats, ≈øeeing the Seed is not received into the Veins, but into peculiar Ve≈ø≈øels called Deferent or back-carrying, of which in the next Chapter. I ≈øay, I believe the Veins onely run through the Coats of the Stones, and have the ≈øuperfluous bloud tran≈ømitted into them from the Arteries, before ever they enter into the body of the Stones: And then tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels that the Te≈øticles con≈øi≈øt of, will onely be Arteries, run out into very fine and almo≈øt innumerable threads, for the elaborating of the Seed.

If this notion of mine be true, then I may ≈øay that both Veins and Arteries run through all the Coats wherewith the Te≈øticles are inve≈øted, but that they them≈øelves have no Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels but Arteries. And whether they have any other ≈øort of Ve≈ø≈øel, is uncertain. 'Tis true there are both Nerves and Lympheducts that come towards the Stones, as I ob≈øerved in the foregoing Chapter; but I que≈øtion whether they reach any farther than their Coats any more than the Veins. As for the Nerves, they ≈øpring from a Vertebral pair according to ≈øome, from the Interco≈øtal ≈øay others, and a third ≈øort think from both. But be their original where it will, I think they are mo≈øtly if not altogether ≈øpent upon the ≈øu≈øpending Mu≈øcles by which the Te≈øticles are ≈øu≈øtained, and upon the Coats ≈øo often mentioned. So far am I from thinking with ≈øome, that the≈øe Nerves contribute the greate≈øt or any con≈øiderable ≈øhare of matter for the making of the Seed. The Lympheducts ≈øpring manife≈øtly from among≈øt the Coats of the Stones, and a≈øcend up into the Belly by the ≈øame hole, by which the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels came down, running ≈øo far till they reach and empty them≈øelves into the common Receptacle of the Chyle, de≈øcribed above chap. 10. and 12.

The Te≈øticles being ≈øen≈øible, tender and noble parts, are defended from the external cold or other Injuries by ≈øeveral Coats, of which ≈øome are
common to them with other parts of the Body, and ≈øome proper to them≈øelves onely. The common incompa≈øs both the Stones within one cavity, as in a Bag, and make that which we call the Cod. And the≈øe are two. The outer of them is the Skin with its Scarf-skin, and the inner the fle≈øhy Membrane. The outer is not divided as it is in Man, by a line that runs along the middle of it lengthways. The inner, as it ≈øticks pretty clo≈øe to this on one ≈øide; ≈øo to the next proper one ≈øomewhat loo≈øely, by many membranous Fibres, on the other or inner ≈øide. The proper are al≈øo two, though by ≈øome they are reckoned to be three. The outmo≈øt is called Vaginalis, or the Sheath-like Coat, becau≈øe the Stone is included in it as in a Sheath. This is thick and ≈øtrong; ≈ømooth on the in≈øide, but rough on the out≈øide, by rea≈øon of many Fibres or Threads by which it is knit to the inner of the common Coats. It is full of Veins, and is a production of the Rim of the Belly: for as the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels de≈øcend over the Share-bone into the Cod, the Rim makes a Ca≈øe for them for their defence and ≈øecurity, and reaches with them down to the Stone, encompa≈ø≈øing it as well as them. Into this Coat is the Mu≈øcle in≈øerted that ≈øu≈øpends the Stone, (which we ≈øhall de≈øcribe pre≈øently.) Some make two Coats of this, the outmo≈øt of which retains the name of ≈øheath-like above-mentioned; and the inner they call the red Coat, from its colour; but indeed this latter is nothing el≈øe but the fore≈øaid Mu≈øcle ≈øpreading it ≈øelf broad and thin on the Sheath-like Coat. The la≈øt and inmo≈øt, which immediately cloaths the Stone, (being the ≈øecond proper one) is called the nervous, and otherwi≈øe the white, Membrane, being thick and ≈øtrong, and of a whiti≈øh colour. It ≈øeems to ari≈øe from the outer Coat of the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels, and is rough on its in≈øide next the Stone, but ≈ømooth and ≈ølippery on its out≈øide.

Each Stone is ≈øu≈øpended or hangs by a Mu≈øcle called Crema≈øter, or the ≈øu≈øpender. The≈øe Mu≈øcles ari≈øe from the Ligament of the Share-bone, and de≈øcending by the proce≈øs of the Rim of the Belly (before ≈øpoken of) are in≈øerted into the Sheath-like Coat, which they ≈øtrengthen, the better to ≈øu≈øtain the weight of the Stones; and in the act of Copulation are ≈øaid to pull up the Stones, and thereby to ≈øhorten the ways the Seed has to pa≈øs.

On the top or back as it were of each Stone there lies a longi≈øh, whiti≈øh and ≈øomewhat round body, di≈øtingui≈øhable very ea≈øily from them, though not of much an unlike ≈øub≈øtance; onely they are not ≈øo firm and compact as the Stones are. They are named Para≈øtatae or Attenders, becau≈øe they wait as it were on the Stones; and al≈øo Epididymidae, becau≈øe they are placed upon the didymi or Twins, by which name the Stones are otherwi≈øe called. They con≈øi≈øt (as the Stones do) wholly of Ve≈ø≈øels running this way and that way, all which are united into one Thread or Chord, which is continued into the deferent Ve≈ø≈øel, of which in the next Chapter.

From what has been already di≈øcour≈øed of the≈øe Parts, their u≈øe appears to be, to make and elaborate the Seed, for the propagation of the kind. Now the Matter out of which the Seed is made, ≈øeems to be onely the Arterial bloud, unle≈øs one ≈øhould admit ≈øome Animal ≈øpirits conveyed hither by the Nerves and mixed therewith. But ≈øeeing any ino≈øculations of the Nerves with the Arteries is a thing not yet di≈øcovered either in the≈øe or any other parts, I incline to believe that the Nerves onely contribute ≈øen≈øe to the≈øe parts, that the Animal may have the greater plea≈øure
in Copulation. A ≈øecondary u≈øe or rather effect of the Stones, is to cau≈øe courage and genero≈øity in the Hor≈øe; for we ob≈øerve that our Ston'd Hor≈øes are generally much higher-≈øpirited than Geldings.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of the Deferent or Ejaculatory Ve≈ø≈øels, the Seed-bladders and the Pro≈øtates.

argument.p: Deferent Ve≈ø≈øels. Seed-bladders. Their u≈øe. The Pro≈øtates. Their ≈øeat, bigne≈øs and ≈øhape. Their Ve≈ø≈øels and Pores. Their u≈øe.

div.p: HAVING done with tho≈øe Parts that prepare and elaborate the Seed, we come next to tho≈øe that are the Store-hou≈øes or Repo≈øitories of it, from whence it is ejected in Copulation. And of the≈øe the fir≈øt are the deferent or back-carrying ve≈ø≈øels, otherwi≈øe called Ejaculatory or ≈øquirting, becau≈øe in tho≈øe Animals that have no Seed-bladders to ≈øtore up the Seed in (≈øuch as Dogs and the like) it does immediately ≈øquirt through the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels from the Stones in Copulation: though in others that have Seed-bladders (as Hor≈øes have) it is continually a-pa≈ø≈øing by the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels from the Stones to the Bladders by little and little as it is prepared.

The≈øe deferent Ve≈ø≈øels are two, one on each ≈øide; they begin at the ≈ømaller end of the para≈øtatae (de≈øcribed in the former chapter) and are indeed but a continuation of them. They are whiti≈øh and pretty hard; not hollow like a Vein, but more like a Nerve, for their cavity is hardly di≈øcernable, unle≈øs the Seed-bladders be full of Seed, and ≈øo it regurgitate as it were into the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels, as I have ≈øometimes ob≈øerved. As ≈øoon as they are ari≈øen from the Para≈øtatae, they a≈øcend ≈øtreight out of the Cod into the Belly by the ≈øame proce≈øs of the Rim of the Belly by which the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels de≈øcended. Being entred the Belly, by and by they cro≈øs over the Ureters from the out≈øide to the in≈øide of them, and taking a little compa≈øs they turn back again under the Bladder till they arrive almo≈øt at its neck, (towards which they grow wider than before) and there their ≈øides open into the Seed-bladders, into which they de≈øtill the Seed; notwith≈øtanding them≈øelves ≈øtill keep on their cour≈øe as far as the Pi≈øs-pipe between the Pro≈øtates, but are grown much ≈ømaller before they reach them. The≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øerve as Conduit-pipes for the Seed to drill along from the Stones to the ≈øeminal Bladders; and through their necks, that reach from the Bladders to the Pi≈øs-pipe, does the Seed i≈ø≈øue in the act of generation.

The place where the Seed is ≈øtored up and pre≈øerved, is the Seed-bladders. Dr. Wharton affirms that in an Hor≈øe they con≈øi≈øt of two parts, of which one is a mere membranous or skinny Bladder, the other glandulous. The Bladder, he ≈øays, he has found ≈øix inches long and near three broad, although it was empty and not opened; but it ≈øeem'd capable of being ≈øtretched out to a greater length and width, if it had been filled. If one opened the bottom of this Bladder, and put a Probe into it, the Probe pa≈ø≈øed obliquely towards the Pi≈øs-pipe, and entred into it through the ≈øame hole with the deferent Ve≈ø≈øel of the ≈øame ≈øide.
The other part of the≈øe Bladders, which we called glandulous, was thicker, and broader on that ≈øide which joyned to the Pi≈øs-pipe; and where the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels were in≈øerted, without de≈øcending towards the bottom, it grew thinner and thinner like a wedge. The ≈øub≈øtance of this glandule was not much unlike to that of the Stones, but of a more clayie colour, and had holes within it ≈øo apparent that they would admit an indifferent Probe: all which holes were united into one common duct, namely before they reach the ∆≤rethra. For putting a Probe into any one of the ≈øaid holes, it was driven ea≈øily and without any lett into that common pa≈ø≈øage. But the pa≈ø≈øage it ≈øelf did not quite penetrate the Pi≈øs-pipe, but was covered with the thin and ≈øpongie Membrane of the ∆≤rethra. Through this Membrane is the ≈øpermatick Matter ≈øtrained in Copulation. Thus far Dr. Wharton in his 30. chap. of the Glands. Now as for my ≈øelf, I could never ob≈øerve ≈øo great a difference of one part of the ≈øeminal Bladders from another, as that one ≈øhould appear membranous and the other glandulous. And I would not imagine that ≈øo skilfull an Anatomi≈øt ≈øhould mi≈øtake the Pro≈øtates for a part of the ≈øaid Bladders, though the≈øe are the onely Parts that to me appear glandulous thereabouts. All the Seed-bladders that I have ob≈øerved have been much of a like ≈øub≈øtance, though perhaps a little thicker in one place than another: they are whiti≈øh and very ≈øtrong, being within all full of little Cells like Pomegranates. They have no communication the one with the other; for as their bottoms or thicker ends bunch out a little on each ≈øide of the Bladder (as you ≈øee in the Figure) ≈øo their ≈ømaller ends or mouths, that are neare≈øt to one another, do each of them open apart into the deferent Ve≈ø≈øel of their re≈øpective ≈øide, by who≈øe neck they pour out their Seed in Copulation into the Pi≈øs-pipe. The Seed comes into them out of the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, and goes out of them again into the ≈øame Ve≈ø≈øels, at one and the ≈øame pa≈ø≈øage or orifice. Dr. Wharton ≈øays, that the ≈øeminal Matter contained in them differs much from that which is made in the Stones: whence he concludes that the Seed-bladders receive not the matter which they contain, from the Te≈øticles by the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, but do elaborate it in their own glandulous ≈øub≈øtance; and he calls it Seed of a peculiar kind. For my own part I have not di≈øcovered any difference, to ≈øpeak of, betwixt this and that which I have ≈øometimes ≈øeen in the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, when the Bladders have been very full; nor is it probable they can be of a different kind or nature, ≈øeeing there is that manife≈øt communication between the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels and the Bladders, that the≈øe latter ≈øeem to contain or receive nothing, but what the former bring into them. Nor do I think that any Part does elaborate any Liquor that can with any propriety be called Seed, except the Te≈øticles contained in the Cod, who≈øe ≈øole office and prerogative it is to make it.

The u≈øe of the≈øe Bladders (as hath been ≈øaid) is to receive the Seed from the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels, and to re≈øerve it untill the time of Copulation. Now the Seed may (to ≈øatisfy the curio≈øity of the Ingenious Anatomi≈øt) be plainly ≈øeen, if you take the Bladders in your hand and ≈øqueeze them with your finger; for by ≈øuch ≈øqueezing you ≈øhall force the ≈øeminal Matter into the Pipe of the Yard, where you may by di≈ø≈øecting the Yard or opening that Pipe plainly ≈øee it. Or if you think it too much to take that pains, you may by di≈ø≈øecting the Bladders them≈øelves ≈øee it; but then you lo≈øe the ≈øight of one of the curious contrivances of Nature,
which is a little Caruncle or Kernel that is placed at the mouth of the hole where the Seed di≈øtills into the Yard, which Caruncle is by Nature placed there, to prevent the i≈ø≈øuing forth of the Seed when there was no need for it; for the continual gleeting of it, which would have happened but for this Caruncle, would be extremely prejudicial to the Creature. This Caruncle in Men being impaired or injured by the Venereal Di≈øtemper, or by their over≈øtraining them≈øelves in the act of Copulation, is generally by Phy≈øicians believed to be the cau≈øe of the running of the Reins. And this Di≈øea≈øe Hor≈øes are not exempted from, although it doth not happen to them on the like occa≈øions as to men it doth; for this Di≈øea≈øe, which in Hor≈øes we call the mattering of the Yard, happens to them upon their catching ≈øuddain colds after hard riding; Likewi≈øe over-hard riding it ≈øelf will bring it; and very often it is cau≈øed by weakne≈øs occa≈øioned by great poverty and the like.

In the next place we come to the Pro≈øtates, which are ≈øo called from their ≈øtanding before the Seed-bladders. They are Glandulous bodies, almo≈øt of the ≈øame nature and ≈øub≈øtance as other Glandules of the Body. They are ≈øituated at the root of the Yard above the ≈øphincter Mu≈øcle of the Bladder, being in number two, on each ≈øide of the neck of the Bladder one; their quantity about the bigne≈øs of a ≈ømall Burgamy Pear. They are of an oval figure, onely ≈øomewhat flat, and are covered with a very thick Coat to hinder the oily ≈øub≈øtance with which they are well ≈øtored, from i≈ø≈øuing forth.

They have Veins, Arteries, Nerves and Lympheducts; and be≈øides, many Pores that open into the ∆≤rethra. In mo≈øt Creatures, e≈øpecially the le≈ø≈øer ≈øort, the≈øe Pores are ≈øcarcely di≈øcernible in an healthfull ≈øtate, but in an Hor≈øe they are very plain, and open into the upper part of the Pi≈øs-pipe about an inch di≈øtance from the in≈øertion of the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels into the ≈øame. Dr. Wharton has told twelve ≈øuch little holes, before each of which as they open into the Pi≈øs-pipe, is placed a little Gland, about the bigne≈øs of a grain of Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, which ≈øerve to hinder the entrance of the Urine into the≈øe holes, as it runs by them out of the Bladder.

The nature and u≈øe of the Liquor that is contained in the≈øe Pro≈øtates, and that i≈ø≈øues out of them into the Pi≈øs-pipe, is ≈øomewhat difficult to determine. Some take them to be a kind of Te≈øticles, and think that they make a ≈øort of Seed, which though it be not of ≈øo noble a nature as that which is made in the Te≈øticles contained in the Cod, yet is as nece≈ø≈øary for generation: ≈øeeing ≈øuch Men as are cut for the Stone become incapable of generation, if the Stone be ≈øo big and ragged as much to tear the Pro≈øtates in pulling of it out. But it is likely, ≈øuch barrenne≈øs happens not ≈øo much from the tearing of the≈øe, as that the ends of the deferent Ve≈ø≈øels are torn likewi≈øe, or it may be the Seed-bladders al≈øo: and ≈øo when the Wound is healed up again, the ≈øides of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels grow together, ≈øo that they can neither contain nor convey into the Pi≈øs-pipe any Seed. It is probable therefore that this oily clammy Humour that the Pro≈øtates di≈øcharge into the Pi≈øs-pipe, is of a nature far different from that of Seed, even as them≈øelves are bodies of a far other nature than the Stones are. For, as was ≈øhewn above, the Stones are wholly va≈øcular, that is, con≈øi≈øt wholly of Ve≈ø≈øels; whereas the≈øe are glandulous, or kernelly. So that I believe this Humour ≈øerves onely to make the ∆≤rethra ≈øupple and ≈ølippery, and to defend it from the acrimony or ≈øharpne≈øs of the Urine.

And thus we have done with all the Parts that make or retain the Seed: as for the Yard, which ≈øome treat of in this place, becau≈øe it ≈øerves for injecting the Seed into the Womb; we de≈øcribed the Parts thereof above chap. 20. next to the Bladder, becau≈øe it ≈øerves as well for making water as for Copulation, and thither the Reader may plea≈øe to turn back.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Of the Parts mini≈øtring to Generation in Mares, and Fir≈øt of the Preparing Ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øo called.

argument.p: Preparing Ve≈ø≈øels. 1. Arteries. 2. Veins. Their u≈øe.

div.p: IT was Galen's opinion, and from his authority, of many others, that the Parts ≈øerving for generation in the Female differed not from tho≈øe of the Male ≈øaving in ≈øituation; the Male's Genitals being without the Body, and the Females within. And this diver≈øity of ≈øituation they attributed to defect of heat in the Female, ≈øo that the Genitals could not be thru≈øt out of the Body as in the Male they are. But the truth is, they differ not onely in ≈øituation, but in number, bigne≈øs, figure, office and u≈øe, as will be apparent as well from the de≈øcription of them, as from their repre≈øentation in the Figures.

The fir≈øt in order are the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels, Arteries and Veins. In the≈øe it was till of late believed that the bloud was prepared for the Stones the readilier to be turned by them into Seed. But as when we treated above of the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels of the Hor≈øe, we ≈øhewed that the Veins could not properly be called preparing Ve≈ø≈øels, becau≈øe they carry nothing to the Stones, but bring bloud back again from them: ≈øo in Mares we cannot allow the name of preparers or ≈øpermatick to be proper even to the Arteries them≈øelves, ≈øeeing neither Mares nor any other Females have any true Seed. For their Stones are but improperly ≈øo called, being more truly Ovaries or Egg-beds, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew by and by in the next Chapter. However we ≈øhall retain the old name for di≈øtinction's ≈øake, and ≈øtill call both Veins and Arteries preparing Ve≈ø≈øels.

The preparing Arteries of the Hor≈øe we ≈øhewed to be onely two, one on each ≈øide; but in the Mare there are ≈øeveral, three or more on each ≈øide. All of them ari≈øe out of the great Artery, below the Emulgents, ≈øome higher, ≈øome lower. They pa≈øs down along with the Veins of their re≈øpective ≈øides, with which they are very much interwoven, but no where open one into the other. Some branches of them go to the Te≈øticles, ≈øome to the Horns of the Womb, and ≈øome to its Sheath.

The preparing Veins in the Hor≈øe were two of each ≈øide, though the Arteries were but one; yet in the Mare where the Arteries are ≈øeveral, the Veins are but one of each ≈øide. The rea≈øon whereof ≈øeems to be, That the Arteries in the Mare being not ≈øo much intended for the nouri≈øhment of her Genitals as of the Foal contained in her Womb, it was requi≈øite there ≈øhould be ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels for the bringing the greater plenty of nouri≈øhing juice for it; all or the greate≈øt part of which being received by the Foal, there was not need of the like number of Veins to carry
back the bloud that came along with it, that being very incon≈øiderable for its quantity to what was imported by the Arteries. But now all the bloud brought by the preparing Arteries of the Hor≈øe, ≈øerving for no other u≈øe but for the nouri≈øhment of the Genitals, and for the making of Seed: As a le≈øs quantity of bloud will ≈øuffice for the≈øe two u≈øes, and ≈øo there is no need of a plurality of Arteries; ≈øo the bloud that is brought to the Genitals, is but a very ≈ømall part of it ≈øpent in performing the≈øe two offices, and therefore more Veins were nece≈ø≈øary to carry the ≈øurplu≈øage back again, ≈øeeing the motion of the bloud in the Arteries is far quicker than of that in the Veins. The≈øe two preparing Veins then ari≈øe out of the Cava a little below the Emulgents, and neither of them from the Emulgent it ≈øelf, any more than in the Hor≈øe, though in Men and Women the Left generally ≈øprings from the left Emulgent. They join in like manner with the Arteries as we ≈øhewed above that they did in Hor≈øes, and go to all tho≈øe parts of the Genitals to which we ju≈øt now ≈øhewed that the Arteries run.

When the Mare is not with Foal, the Arteries bring onely bloud for the nouri≈øhment of the ≈øeveral Parts into which they are in≈øerted: but when ≈øhe is with Foal, they bring be≈øides the bloud a nutritious juice, (which is Chyle, impregnated with ≈øpirit, but not as yet perfectly changed into bloud) for its growth and nouri≈øhment, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew more afterwards when we come to ≈øpeak how the Foal is nouri≈øhed in the Womb. And whether ≈øhe be with Foal or not, the Veins ≈øerve to carry back to the Cava and ≈øo to the Heart, the bloud that is ≈øuperfluous.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. Of the Te≈øticles or Stones in Mares, otherwi≈øe called Ovaries; and of the Trumpets of the Womb.

argument.p: The Te≈øticles. Their ≈øituation. Bigne≈øs, and figure. Coat. Sub≈øtance, and u≈øe. The Trumpets of the Womb. Their ≈øub≈øtance, capacity and length. Their u≈øe.

div.p: THE Te≈øticles in Mares do not agree in their de≈øcription with tho≈øe of Hor≈øes in any one particular thing, nor ≈øhould I call them by that name, if the general mi≈øtake of ≈øo many Ages (in thinking the Female's Stones to have the ≈øame office with tho≈øe of the Male) had not made it nece≈ø≈øary to retain that appellation, if I would be under≈øtood by vulgar Readers of what part I am treating. For it has been an old Opinion, that the Male and Female's Seed being mixed in the Womb, doth make the Conception; and there are many that will not yet be beaten out of it. Whereas the Female hath no Seed at all, but their Te≈øticles (≈øo called) are as it were knots of Eggs, which being impregnated by the Male's Seed, one or more at a time, do each make a Conception. But of this more by and by.
The Mare's Te≈øticles differ from the Hor≈øe's in the≈øe Particulars.

Fir≈øt, The Hor≈øe's Stones hang without the Body in the Cod, but the Mare's lie within the cavity of the Belly, a little di≈øtance from the horns of the Womb, to which they are knit by a ≈øtrong Ligament.

Secondly, The Mare's Te≈øticles are hardly half as big as the Hor≈øe's, nor are they of the ≈øame ≈øhape, but more flat and thin, having no Para≈øtatae upon them. And be≈øides, they are ≈øomewhat uneven in their ≈øurface, whereas tho≈øe of an Hor≈øe are ≈ømooth.

Thirdly, The Hor≈øes Te≈øticles are covered with four Coats, two common, and two proper; but the Mare's are clad onely with one for about one half of them, and the other half with two; the outer of which they have immediately from the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels that enter into them, but mediately from the Rim of the Belly.

Fourthly and la≈øtly, They differ very much from one another in their ≈øub≈øtance and u≈øe. For we ≈øhewed above in chap. 22. that the Hor≈øe's Stones did wholly con≈øi≈øt of Seed ve≈ø≈øels turn'd and roll'd this way and that way: but the Mare's con≈øi≈øt principally of numerous Membranes and ≈ømall Fibres loo≈øely united to one another; among≈øt which there are ≈øeveral little Bladders, about as big as a Pea≈øe, ≈øome bigger, ≈øome le≈øs, that are full of a very clear and thin liquor. Tho≈øe that were of opinion that the Females made Seed as well as the Males, thought that the≈øe Bladders that are chiefly in the ≈øurface of the Te≈øticle, an≈øwered to the Seed bladders in the Male, and that the humour contained in them was true Seed. And whereas it might be objected that it is far more clear and watery than the Male's Seed, they thought it ≈øufficient to an≈øwer, that that was from the colder and moi≈øter nature of the Female, that could not concoct it to that con≈øi≈øtency as the Male's is of. But the truth is, it is not Seed; and if it were, there is no way whereby it could po≈ø≈øibly arrive at the Womb. For that which was reputed to be the deferent Ve≈ø≈øel, appears to be nothing el≈øe but a ≈øhort and broad Ligament for fixing the Te≈øticle in its place; for it has no cavity at all, but is of a ≈øolid, firm and clo≈øe ≈øub≈øtance. The≈øe Bladders therefore mu≈øt be concluded to be Eggs, an≈øwering to tho≈øe of Fowl and other Creatures: which will be the more manife≈øt if you boil them, for then, as tho≈øe that have tried it do affirm, they will have the ≈øame colour, ta≈øte and con≈øi≈øtency with the whites of Hens-eggs. Whence the≈øe Te≈øticles may more properly be called Ovaries or Egg-beds, who≈øe Eggs are nouri≈øhed by the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels de≈øcribed in the foregoing Chapter; and when upon Copulation one (or more) of them is made fruitfull by the Male's Seed, it ≈øeparates from the re≈øt, and being received by the mouth of the Trumpet of the Womb, it de≈øcends by it into the Horn, and ≈øo to the bottom of the Womb, and there becomes a Conception. And whereas it has been thought a ≈øtrong argument for the Female's having true Seed, and that the≈øe Te≈øticles made it, in that when they are cut out of the Body in Bitches, Hogs, or any other Creature, ≈øuch Creatures are always barren afterwards; this new Opinion ≈øhews that there is no ≈øtrength or certainty at all in that argument. For granting, what is mo≈øt certainly true, that Females that are gelt or ≈øpay'd, have never any Young after; yet it does not at all follow, that therefore their Stones make and con≈øerve Seed; but onely that they contain ≈øomething that is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary for generation and conception: but whether that be Seed or ≈øomewhat el≈øe, is indifferent. And therefore that Argument will be as ≈øtrong for the Opinion that the Te≈øticles are Ovaries, ≈øeeing without the Eggs it is ≈øo far from po≈ø≈øible that there ≈øhould be a conception, that they are the very conception it ≈øelf.

Of the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels that run through the Te≈øticles we treated in the foregoing Chapter under the name of Preparing Ve≈ø≈øels: As for their
Nerves, they ≈øpring from the Interco≈øtal pair, and from the Nerves of Os ≈øacrum. Bartholin affirms that they have al≈øo Lympheducts.

There hath not been greater di≈øpute about the matter of the Conception, than by what way any thing could go to the Womb or its Horns from the Te≈øticles to make it. Some have pretended to the di≈øcovery of Ve≈ø≈øels or Pipes for conveyance thereof, which others altogether as skilfull Anatomi≈øts could find no foot≈øteps of. At la≈øt Fallopius a≈ø≈øigned this office to two Ducts, which from their ≈øhape he called Tubae or Trumpets; and from him (as being the fir≈øt Inventer of them, or at lea≈øt the fir≈øt that a≈øcribed this u≈øe to them) they are commonly known by the name of the Fallopian Trumpets. He ≈øays, they are nervous and white, ari≈øing from the Horns of the Womb, where they are very ≈ølender, but at a ≈ømall di≈øtance from it they grow wider, bending this way and that way, till near their end, where cea≈øing their winding they grow pretty large, and ≈øeem ≈øomewhat carnous.] Their ends next the Te≈øticles are torn and jagged, and lie loo≈øe, being freed from the Membrane that ≈øu≈øtains them the greate≈øt part of their length.

Their ≈øub≈øtance ≈øeems rather membranous than nervous, (as Fallopius would have it.) And they con≈øi≈øt of two Membranes; the inner is propagated from the inmo≈øt Tunicle of the Womb, and the outer from the outmo≈øt of the ≈øame. Where they are wide≈øt they will admit ones little finger, but towards the Horn of the Womb, they are not ≈øo thick as an ordinary ≈øtraw, but yet are pervious; and where they open into the in≈øide of the Horn, their Orifice looks like a little Teat. As to their length, it is ≈øomething difficult to determine it exactly, becau≈øe they run ≈øo to and again in their cour≈øe; but I believe they are very near a quarter of a yard long.

Their u≈øe is, both to ≈øerve as two Funnels whereby ≈øome ≈øubtile particles or ≈øteams may i≈ø≈øue from the Seed, that is injected by the Male into the Womb, to the Te≈øticles of the Female for the fecundating or making fruitfull the Eggs thereof, one or more, according to the different ≈øpecies of living Creatures; (but it is very rare, that there is above one ≈øo impregnated in a Mare, ≈øeeing it is ≈øo ≈øeldom that any brings forth twins:) and al≈øo when the Egg is fecundated by this means, and growing ripe as it were, drops off or ≈øeparates from the Te≈øticle, it is received by the jagged mouth of the Trumpet, along which it pa≈ø≈øes till it arrive in the Horn of the Womb, into which (as was ≈øaid above) the Trumpet is in≈øerted; and on this con≈øideration the old name of deferent Ve≈ø≈øels may ≈øtill be granted them, from their conducting the Eggs from the Te≈øticle to the Womb. Now ≈øeeing the wide ends of the Trumpets that fir≈øt receive the Eggs lie loo≈øe, and are not fa≈øtened to the Te≈øticle, it is probable that in Copulation the≈øe become turgid as well as all the other parts of the Genital, and with their jagged mouths cla≈øp hold upon the Te≈øtes (as a Lamprey's mouth fa≈øtens upon a ≈øtone) and ≈øo convey to them a ≈øeminal air, and afterwards receive from them a fecundated Egg.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Of the Womb and its Horns.

argument.p: The ≈øhape and parts of the Womb. Its ≈øituation. Ligaments. Sub≈øtance. Ve≈ø≈øels. 1. Arteries. 2. Veins. 3. Nerves. 4. Lympheducts. Its Horns. Its u≈øe.

div.p: THE Womb of a Mare is ≈øhaped much like the Greek Letter Y, in which the ≈øingle ≈øtroak that is ≈øtreight, an≈øwers to the vagina or Sheath, which receives the Hor≈øe's Yard in Copulation, and the two crooked ≈øtroaks that turn one the one way, and the other the other, are called Horns, becau≈øe they in ≈øome ≈øort re≈øemble them; and that part of the Sheath where the Horns begin to ≈øeparate, being ≈øomewhat wider than the re≈øt, is the fundus or bottom of the Womb, where the Foal lies. For though in Dogs, Rabbets, &c. that have many young ones at one time, their burthen is contained wholly in the Horns of the Womb, as well as the Conception is fir≈øt made there; yet in a Mare that commonly brings forth but one at a time, it is otherwi≈øe; for there is little or nothing that belongs to the Foal, contained in them, except ≈øome part of the Skins wherein the Foal is covered while it is in the Womb.

The Womb is ≈øeated in the lowe≈øt part of the Lower Belly, in that wide Cavity that is formed out of and invironed with the Hip-bones, the Share-bone, and the os ≈øacrum. It is placed betwixt the Pi≈øs-bladder and the Ar≈øe-gut, and is firmly tied in its place by two pair of Ligaments.

The fir≈øt pair ari≈øe from the Rim of the Belly, being ≈øhorter by much than the other, but broader, being for their ≈øhape re≈øembled to Bat's wings. They are of a membranous, loo≈øe and ≈øoft ≈øub≈øtance, and are in≈øerted into the Horns of the Womb, taking hold al≈øo of the Te≈øticles, and tying them both fa≈øt to the Hip-bones, from whence they ≈øpring.

The ≈øecond pair of Ligaments ≈øpring from the bottom of the Womb, and are called the round or worm-like Ligaments. They a≈øcend on each ≈øide between the two Coats of the Rim of the Belly, towards the Share-bone, over which they pa≈øs ≈ølantingly, and then parting into many jags as it were, they end near the clitoris. This al≈øo ≈øerves to fa≈øten the Womb the more firmly in its place.

It is of a nervous or rather membranous ≈øub≈øtance, more compact and clo≈øe in Mares that are not with Foal, but more ≈øpongie in ≈øuch as are. It con≈øi≈øts of two Membranes, and a certain fle≈øhy or fibrous parenchyma or ≈øub≈øtance between, unle≈øs one will make this a third Membrane. The outmo≈øt Membrane is borrowed from the Rim of the Belly, and therefore is truly double as that is, though we reckon it but for one. This is very ≈øtrong. The inmo≈øt is not ≈øo ≈øtrong nor firm as it, but ≈øeems to be ≈øomewhat porous. The middle ≈øub≈øtance betwixt the≈øe two is that which makes up the greate≈øt part of its thickne≈øs at all times, but particularly when the Mare is with Foal, it imbibes ≈øo much of the nutritious Juice that flows plentifully hither at that time, that it is ≈øtuft up to almo≈øt an inch thickne≈øs.

Its Arteries are branches partly of the Preparing Arteries and partly of the hypoga≈øtrick. The≈øe do ino≈øculate or communicate by open mouths one with another, but not ≈øo with the Veins. They run along the Womb bending and winding, and not in a ≈øtreight cour≈øe, le≈øt they ≈øhould be
broken when the Womb is extended to that va≈øt bulk as it is when the Mare is with Foal.

Its Veins ≈øpring al≈øo from the preparing and hypoga≈øtrick Veins, but are much fewer in number than the Arteries. For Nature having formed the≈øe Parts not ≈øo much for the benefit of the Individual, as for propagating the Kind; and the Foal while it is in the Womb receiving no nouri≈øhment but what is brought to it by the Arteries, it was nece≈ø≈øary that they ≈øhould be large and numerous for conveying the greater plenty of it: but ≈øeeing the greate≈øt part of that which is brought by the Arteries is ≈øpent in the nouri≈øhment of the Young and the Parts in which it is contained, a fewer number of Veins are ≈øufficient to convey back again what is not ≈øo ≈øpent. The Veins do ino≈øculate with one another like as the Arteries did.
It has Nerves from the Interco≈øtal pair, and from the Nerves of os ≈øacrum.

Some have al≈øo ob≈øerved many Lympheducts creeping along its ≈øurface, which one after another meeting into one, empty them≈øelves into the common receptacle of the Chyle and Lympha; and the≈øe Lympheducts ≈øome have mi≈øtaken for Milky-veins.

Thus much of the Womb properly ≈øo called: and what we have ≈øaid hereof, may be all applied to its Horns likewi≈øe as to their ≈øub≈øtance and ve≈ø≈øels. As for their figure, you may view it in the following Cut. The≈øe Horns are le≈øs in Mares than in any other Creature that has them, in proportion to the bigne≈øs of their Bodies. From their fir≈øt ri≈øe from the Womb to their end, they grow by degrees narrower and narrower, and about their middle are the Trumpets of the Womb in≈øerted into them. They have a worm-like or ≈øucce≈ø≈øive motion as the Guts have, by which the Egg being received from the Trumpet is driven gently along till it come to the bottom of the Womb in Mares, and there becomes a Conception: but in ≈øuch Creatures as bring forth many Young at one time, the Conceptions ≈øtay in the Horns till they are come to maturity, and never de≈øcend into the bottom of the Womb till they are about to be excluded.

By what has been ≈øaid, it appears, that the u≈øe of the Womb is to receive the Seed of the Male, from which Seed a certain air or ≈øpirit ≈øteams through the Trumpets to the Te≈øticles, where impregnating one or more Eggs, tho≈øe that are ≈øo impregnated, are conveyed by the Trumpets into the Horns, and by the≈øe into the bottom of the Womb, where they become Conceptions, and ≈øtay (according to Nature) ≈øo long till all their Parts are fini≈øhed, and they are become perfect Animals of their proper kind; and then the Womb being irritated by the motion and bigne≈øs of the Young, does by the help of the Mu≈øcles of the Belly, and the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Midriff exclude it. But having de≈øigned a particular di≈øcour≈øe of the generation of Animals to be annexed to this Treati≈øe, we ≈øhall pur≈øue it no further here.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of the Vagina or Sheath of the Womb, the Caruncles call'd myrtiformes, (of the ≈øhape of Myrtle-berries) the Clitoris and the external Privity.

argument.p: The Vagina or Sheath. The myrtiform Caruncles. The Clitoris. The outward Privity. The Lips. The Nymphs.

div.p: WE ≈øhall not need to enter upon the de≈øcription of the Ve≈ø≈øels running through the Sheath of the Womb, they being wholly the ≈øame that are di≈øper≈øed through the Womb it ≈øelf, and therefore the Reader may have recour≈øe to the former Chapter for them: nor is it nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øpeak much of its ≈øub≈øtance, that being al≈øo much like to that of the Womb, though not ≈øo thick and ≈øtrong, but more ≈øoft, nervous and ≈øpongie. It is near half a yard long, being much of an equal width from one end to the other, but very uneven and wrinkled in its inner ≈øurface. Into its lower ≈øide (or that ≈øide next the Belly) a very little di≈øtance from the external Privity, is the neck of the Bladder in≈øerted; oppo≈øite to which in its upper ≈øide it is ≈øtrongly knit to the Sphincter Mu≈øcle of the Ar≈øe-gut. There is no ≈øuch neck to di≈øtingui≈øh or ≈øeparate the Sheath from the bottom of the Womb, as Anatomi≈øts ≈øay there is in Women: but the Sheath it ≈øelf ≈øeems to be widened into what I call the bottom of the Womb.

Whether there be any ≈øuch Membrane that goes cro≈øs the Vagina in Mares that have never been cover'd, as Anatomi≈øts ≈øay there is in Maids, I never made any carefull examination, but believe there is none. But as for tho≈øe Caruncles or little kernelly knobs that are called myrtiformes, from their re≈øembling the Berries of the Myrtle in ≈øhape, they are to be found: yea they may be ≈øeen without di≈ø≈øection, if one look near the Privity of a Mare when ≈øhe is lu≈øtfull and de≈øires the Hor≈øe; for as ≈øhe opens the Orifice of the Vagina, one may di≈øcern the≈øe Caruncles to ≈øtrut out. They are ≈øaid to be four in number, the large≈øt of which ≈øtands ju≈øt at the mouth of the Water-pa≈ø≈øage, which it helps, partly, to clo≈øe up. Their u≈øe ≈øeems to be, by their roughne≈øs and unevenne≈øs to cau≈øe the greater plea≈øure to the Hor≈øe in Copulation.

On the ≈øame ≈øide of the Vagina with the Bladder is placed a long ≈øpongie body called Clitoris, but lies a great deal farther within the Vagina than it is ≈øaid to doe in Women. For, that end of it which is next to the outward Privity is ≈øeven or eight fingers breadth from it, whereas in Women it is de≈øcribed to be within an inch. Tho≈øe that would make the generative Parts of the Male and Female exactly to re≈øemble one the other, ≈øay that this body in the Female, an≈øwers to the Yard in the Male. And indeed it is of not an unlike ≈øub≈øtance, but is not the twentieth part ≈øo big. It is ≈øoft and ≈øpongie, but it is likely when the Mare is lu≈øtfull and de≈øires the Hor≈øe, it plumps up and ≈øuffers a ≈øort of erection, being the principal ≈øeat of plea≈øure in the Mare. It has two pair of Mu≈øcles belonging to it, as well as the Yard of the Hor≈øe. One pair is round, and ≈øprings from the Hip-bones: The other from the Sphincter of the Ar≈øegut. Its Veins and Arteries ≈øpring from tho≈øe that are called Pudendae (or belonging to the Privity) and its Nerves, (which are pretty large,
to make it the more ≈øen≈øible) ari≈øe from the ≈øame origine with tho≈øe that are di≈øper≈øed through the Sheath and Womb.

As to the outward Privity, the Labia or Lips are the fir≈øt things that offer them≈øelves. Be≈øides the common Coverings, to wit the Skin and fle≈øhy Membrane, they are ≈øtuft with a little ≈øpongy Fat. They ≈øerve to cover the outer orifice of the Sheath for comeline≈øs ≈øake, and to defend it from the cold, and In≈øects, or other injuries. The clo≈øing of the≈øe two makes that which is called the fi≈ø≈øure or chink. If one draw the Lips a little a≈øide, then appear the Nymphs, ≈øo called becau≈øe they ≈øtand next to the Urine as it ≈øpouts out from the Bladder, and hinder it from wetting the Lips. They are two, on each ≈øide one, ju≈øt within the Lips, beginning at the jointing or middle of the Share-bone, at the lower ≈øide of the Privity, from whence they a≈øcend clo≈øe by each other to a little above half the breadth of the orifice of the Sheath, and end each in a blunt corner. Their ≈øub≈øtance is partly fle≈øhy and partly membranous; they are ≈øoft and ≈øpongie and of a red colour, having the ≈øame Ve≈ø≈øels with the Clitoris. Be≈øides their u≈øe to keep off the Pi≈øs from wetting the Lips, they ≈øerve, as well as the Lips, for clo≈øing up and covering the mouth of the Vagina, at lea≈øt ≈øo much of it as they reach unto.
And now we have done with all the Parts belonging to Generation, both in Male and Female.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. How the Foal is nouri≈øhed in the Womb; of the Membranes wherein it is wrapt, and the Liquors contained in them; and la≈øtly of the Navel-≈øtring.

argument.p: How the Young is nouri≈øhed. The fir≈øt Opinion. The ≈øecond Opinion. The third and true≈øt Opinion. The Membranes that the Foal is wrapt in. The Amnios. The Chorion. Allantoides. The Navel-ve≈ø≈øels. One Vein. Two Arteries. The Urachus.

div.p: HAVING de≈øcribed all the Parts in Mares that do any ways ≈øerve for generation, and ≈øhewn their ≈øeveral u≈øes, I ≈øhould put an end to this Fir≈øt Book, but that it may be convenient to ≈øpeak ≈øomewhat of the Young contained in the Womb, for the conceiving and generating of which all the≈øe Parts were formed. But this I ≈øhall not do largely in this place, but onely ≈øummarily and in ≈øhort, referring the Reader for his fuller information and ≈øatisfaction to the Treati≈øe of the generation of Animals annexed to the latter end of this Volume; where by ob≈øerving in what order and by what degrees the conceptions in other Creatures arrive to perfect Animals of their kind, he may by the rule of proportion conceive how they proceed in Mares al≈øo.

Now before we come to ≈øpeak of the Membranes that inve≈øt the Foal, &c. which will be the ≈øubject of this Chapter, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to premi≈øe ≈øomething concerning the ways or Ve≈ø≈øels by which nouri≈øhment is conveyed to it, whereby it grows from no bigger than a Bee to ≈øo va≈øt a bulk.

It is not long ago till when it was the general opinion, that the Young was nouri≈øhed by the Dam's Bloud; namely, that the hypoga≈øtrick and ≈øome of the ≈øpermatick Ve≈ø≈øels of the Dam did ino≈øculate with or open into the branches of the umbilical or Navel-ve≈ø≈øels of the Young, and ≈øo the bloud run from one to the other in a ready cour≈øe. And this Opinion had ≈øo far prevailed, and was taken for ≈øo certain a truth, that after the Young was excluded out of the Womb, and mu≈øt needs receive its nouri≈øhment by the mouth, they believed that it was nouri≈øhed by Bloud ≈øtill: For they thought that Milk was fir≈øt Bloud, onely it changed its colour, and its ta≈øte partly, in the white Kernels of the Dugs. This was a ≈øtrange fancy, that Nature ≈øhould thus doe and undoe, fir≈øt turn Chyle into Bloud, and then turn that Bloud again into a Liquor re≈øembling Chyle, and in truth differing very little from it. But this by the way. I ≈øay, the Dam's Ve≈ø≈øels were ≈øuppo≈øed to ino≈øculate with the Navel-ve≈ø≈øels of the Young; whereby Bloud was carried to it for its nouri≈øhment: but they never troubled their heads about making it out how the Young ≈øhould be nouri≈øhed before it had ever a Navel-ve≈ø≈øel, or before ever the Conception adhered to any part of the Womb. Now the Embryo or fir≈øt draught (as I may call it) of the Young is formed in all Creatures before the Navel-ve≈ø≈øels, and it is grown to a pretty bulk before they are ≈øo well perfected as to be capable of receiving any Liquor into them. And when they are perfectly formed, and can perform their office, whatever it be; in ≈øome Creatures, as particularly in a Sow, they never reach further than the Chorion or outmo≈øt Membrane wherein the Pig is included, and therefore have no contact or communication with tho≈øe of the Sow, who≈øe Veins and Arteries reach no further than the inmo≈øt Membrane of
the Womb. And in the Creature we have now under con≈øideration, namely a Mare, it is near ≈øix months before the Chorion adhere to the inmo≈øt Membrane of the Womb, (which how it does, we ≈øhall ≈øhew by and by.) Now the≈øe ob≈øervations plainly demon≈øtrate that the Young cannot be nouri≈øhed by the Bloud of the Dam, ≈øeeing there is no way whereby the Bloud can be conveyed to it, in any Creature for a con≈øiderable time, and in ≈øome Creatures, at all.

Others ≈øufficiently di≈øcovering the errours of this Opinion, and inclining to believe that the Young in the Womb was nouri≈øhed with the ≈øame Liquor while it was there, as it is after it comes into the World, namely Chyle a little refined, and not finding any other convenient ways (as they thought) whereby the Chyle could be conveyed to the Womb, have fancied that they have found Lacteal or Milky-ve≈ø≈øels going thither directly either from the great Kernel at the centre of the Me≈øentery, or from the common receptacle of the Chyle it ≈øelf: but others that favour not this Opinion, ≈øuppo≈øe tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels that the≈øe have fancied to be Lacteals, to be onely Lympheducts, conveying the Lympha or ≈øuperfluous Water from the Womb to the common Receptacle, whither the Lympha of all the other Parts contained in the Lower Belly is by the ≈øame Ve≈ø≈øels likewi≈øe di≈øcharged. So that though this Opinion be very plau≈øible for its inventing ≈øo ready a way for the Chyles coming to the Womb; yet it is very probable that the≈øe ≈øuppo≈øed Milky-veins are nothing but Lympheducts, and then the whole Suppo≈øition falls to the ground.

But yet though this ≈øecond Opinion be mi≈øtaken in the Ve≈ø≈øels that bring the Liquor to the Womb whereby the Young is nouri≈øhed, yet it ≈øeems to have hit right on the Liquor it ≈øelf. For as it cannot be Bloud for the rea≈øons I have before given, ≈øo there is no other Liquor in the Body but Chyle, that is capable of being turned into nouri≈øhment. For though they call that Juice, by which Bodies come to maturity are nouri≈øhed, (and al≈øo the Young in the Womb) nutritious Juice, yet that name onely denotes its office, and does not ≈øuppo≈øe that a Liquor quite di≈øtinct in nature from Bloud or Chyle is under≈øtood by that denomination: but it does indeed partake of the nature both of the Bloud and Chyle; for it is Chyle a little exalted or impregnated with the ≈øpirit and life of the Bloud. Now this Juice arrives at the Womb by the≈øe ways. Fir≈øt the Chyle a≈øcending from the common Receptacle by the thoracick Duct to the right Ventricle of the Heart, it is ≈øent out from thence together with the Bloud into the Lungs, from whence they both return to the left ventricle of the Heart, out of which they are ejected into the Aorta or great Artery, by which means the Chyle runs confounded with the Bloud into all the Parts of the Body; but when the Dam is with Young we may conceive that a greater quantity of it may tend towards the Womb than to other parts: even as it is probable that more wheyi≈øh or watery Humour accompanies that Bloud that flows by the Emulgent Arteries to the Kidneys, than that which flows to other Parts, becau≈øe Nature has appointed the Kidneys for the ≈øeparating of it from the Bloud. I ≈øay it is al≈øo likely that more Chyle de≈øcends to the Womb by the ≈øpermatick and hypoga≈øtrick Arteries than to any other part, becau≈øe a great quantity of it is to be ≈øeparated from the Bloud here for the nouri≈øhment of the Young. Now the≈øe Arteries, as all others in the Body, do divide them≈øelves ≈øo often, till they end in very ≈ømall capillary or hair-like threads, which terminate in the inmo≈øt Membrane of the

Womb. But all the branches of the≈øe Arteries about the Womb are much larger when the Female is with Young than at other times, which is an argument that nouri≈øhment is indeed brought by them. The greate≈øt difficulty is, how it can be di≈øcharged out of the Arteries into the Womb, and no Bloud go along with it. To ≈øolve this difficulty we mu≈øt con≈øider, that the Particles of ≈øeveral Liquors are of different figures, as ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øome round, ≈øome corner'd, &c. Now we know that if two bodies of the ≈øame bulk be one round, and another four≈øquare, the round will go through a hole which the four≈øquare body will not, and on the contrary the four≈øquare body will pa≈øs through a hole that the round will not; accordingly as the hole is round or four≈øquare. And this may be the rea≈øon that the Chyle can pa≈øs out of the ≈ømall ends of the Arteries, and yet the Bloud cannot accompany it, but mu≈øt return back by the Veins. And be≈øides the difference of figure, it is probable the Particles of that Chyle that ouzes into the Womb, are of much ≈ømaller bulk than tho≈øe of the Bloud, ≈øeeing it is a much thinner and watery body; and therefore may as ea≈øily be ≈øeparated from the Bloud into the Womb, as the Urine is by the Kidneys into the Ureters. And to further and a≈ø≈øi≈øt this ≈øeparation ≈øome do believe there is a certain fermentation in the Womb, even as there is in other Parts of the Body, where other Juices are ≈øeparated from the Bloud, as Choler in the Liver, and according to ≈øome, Urine in the Kidneys. But be the ≈øeparation by what means it will, that there is ≈øuch a thing is mo≈øt certain, and how the Young comes to partake of it for its nouri≈øhment we ≈øhall next ≈øhew.

While it was believed that a Conception was made of the Male and Female's Seed mixed together, it was ≈øomewhat difficult to imagine how ≈øuch a fluid ≈øub≈øtance ≈øhould ≈øo ≈øpeedily acquire ≈øo compact Membranes to include it, as we ≈øee it has in a few days. But now that it is believed that a Conception is nothing el≈øe but an Egg dropt off from the Te≈øticle and received into the Womb, that difficulty vani≈øhes, for tho≈øe Membranes do originally inve≈øt the Egg, even as we ≈øee the like Membranes lie under the ≈øhells of the Eggs of Fowls, and encompa≈ø≈øing the whole. The≈øe Membranes are at the fir≈øt but two, called Amnios and Chorion; but after a while there is a third commonly called Allantoides, or the Pudding-like Membrane.

That Membrane or Skin that immediately infolds the Young is called Amnios. It is very thin, ≈ømooth and clear, and in it is contained that Liquor out of which the Young is fir≈øt formed, and by which it is afterwards nouri≈øhed. That Liquor out of which the Young is formed, is originally in it, even while the Conception is under the form of an Egg: but that by which the Young is nouri≈øhed and its Parts increa≈øed, ≈øweats into this Membrane immediately out of the Chorion or outmo≈øt Membrane for the fir≈øt months, till the Navel-≈øtring is perfected, and that there grows a new Membrane betwixt the≈øe two, that contains a peculiar ≈øort of Liquor, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew by and by. But the Juice that is in the Amnios from fir≈øt to la≈øt (except that out of which the Embryo is formed) is Chyle, which at fir≈øt ≈øweats into it out of the Chorion, and afterwards is conveyed into it by the umbilical Arteries of the Young, who fir≈øt received it by its umbilical Veins. For the≈øe Arteries ≈øend many branches into the Amnios, which di≈øcharge them≈øelves into it, even as the hypoga≈øtrick and ≈øpermatick Arteries do into the Womb. Now this Liquor that is thus collected in this inmo≈øt Membrane, does at fir≈øt nouri≈øh the Embryo or fir≈øt rudiments of the Young by appo≈øition, that is, tho≈øe rudiments do attract to them≈øelves ≈øuch particles of the Liquor as are ≈øuitable for them; and thereby their bulk comes to be encrea≈øed by degrees: but as ≈øoon as the Young has its Mouth and Stomach perfected, it then ≈øucks it up and drinks it in by its Mouth, and it pa≈ø≈øes by the ≈øame ways to the Heart as it does after the birth.

The ≈øecond Membrane, that is originally in the Egg, and that inve≈øts the Young from fir≈øt to la≈øt, is called the Chorion. This is ≈øomewhat thicker than the Amnios; it is ≈ømooth on its in≈øide, but rough and unequal on its out≈øide. This Membrane drinks up that nutritious Juice that is emptied into the Womb from the hypoga≈øtrick and ≈øpermatick Arteries, which Juice is again filtred as it were out of it into the Amnios for the nouri≈øhment of the Young. For the Liquor contained in this Membrane is altogether the ≈øame with that of the Amnios. Now this Membrane for ≈øeveral months (five or ≈øix) adheres not to the Womb in any part, but the Young that is clad with it, lies as loo≈øe in the Womb, as a Bladder in a Foot-ball that is not at all tied to the leather. (Thus I ≈øay it is in a Mare, though in mo≈øt other Creatures this Membrane begin much ≈øooner to be fa≈øten'd to the Womb.) But at length fir≈øt of all there begin to grow in the ≈øurface of it certain reddi≈øh ≈øpecks or caruncles no bigger than a Vetch, and at the ≈øame time the Membrane grows thicker, and there appear innumerable Ve≈ø≈øels in it. And the≈øe Caruncles as they become more in number, ≈øo they grow broader in dimen≈øion, in≈øomuch as at la≈øt they are ≈øpread all over the Chorion, ≈øo that on its out≈øide it ≈øeems to have lo≈øt the nature of a Membrane, and to have become a placenta or Womb-cake. At the ≈øame time that the≈øe Caruncles grow thus on this Membrane, the Navel-≈øtring penetrating the Amnios is in≈øerted into it, and tho≈øe numerous Ve≈ø≈øels that are ≈øeen in the Chorion, are onely branches of the Navel-arteries and Veins di≈øper≈øed through it. And now the Chorion by means of the Caruncles that grow upon it, adheres to the inner Membrane of the Womb, from whence the Navel-veins imbibe nutritious Juice and carry it to the Young for its ≈øu≈øtenance, (as ≈øhall be further ≈øhewed pre≈øently, when we come to ≈øpeak of the Navel-≈øtring.) But the Caruncles do not ≈øtick ≈øo fa≈øt to the Womb, but that they may be ≈øeparated without tearing, much le≈øs are there any Ana≈øtomo≈øes or Ino≈øculations
of the Ve≈ø≈øels that run through the Chorion with the hypoga≈øtrick or ≈øpermatick Ve≈ø≈øels of the Dam, as the Ancients believed. Nor is there in a Mare any of tho≈øe Glandules that are commonly called Cotyledons or Sawcers, ≈øticking to the inner Membrane of the Womb, into which the Caruncles of the Chorion are in≈øerted, like an Acorn into its cup, ≈øuch as are in Sheep and Goats: but the ≈øo often mentioned Caruncles ≈øtick immediately to the Membrane it ≈øelf, and ≈øeem to ≈øerve as Sponges to imbibe the nutritious Juice that plentifully bedews it; which having done, the ≈øaid Juice is ≈øuckt up by the mouths of the Navel-vein, as was ≈øaid before. Part of this Membrane does on each ≈øide bag out into the Horns of the Womb.

As ≈øoon as the Navel-≈øtring has penetrated the Amnios, there begins to appear a third Membrane betwixt the≈øe two already de≈øcribed, which contains a Liquor wholly different from what ≈øwims in them; for that we have ≈øhewn to be Chyle, but this is the ∆≤rine of the Young, which, while the Young is in the Womb, is not emptied out of the Bladder the common way, but there is a Pipe called ∆≤rachus that pa≈ø≈øes from the bottom of the Bladder out at its Navel, and empties the Urine into this Membrane, in which it is collected to the quantity of many quarts. This Membrane is called Allantoides or Pudding-like, becau≈øe in many Creatures, as Cows, Sheep, &c. it is of that ≈øhape, and ≈øeems to be onely the ∆≤rachus a little widened. But it is of another figure in Mares (as it is al≈øo in Women) and is of the ≈øame dimen≈øion with the other two already de≈øcribed, incompa≈ø≈øing the whole Young. It is more den≈øe than they, and may be ea≈øily di≈øtingui≈øhed from them by this, that they are full of Ve≈ø≈øels, but this has not one, that one can di≈øcern. Although this Membrane appear not till the time afore≈øaid, yet 'tis like it was originally in the Egg; and at its appearance the Chorion becomes empty, becau≈øe there is now no longer pa≈ø≈øage of any thing out of the Chorion into the Amnios, by rea≈øon of this Membrane and its Liquor interpo≈øing. Whence the Chorion claps pretty clo≈øe to the Allantoides, ≈øo that they cannot be ea≈øily ≈øeparated. In the Liquor contained in the Allantoides there ≈øwim ≈øeveral gobbets that look like as if they were fle≈øhy, but being pulled to pieces they appear skinny. They are ≈øuppo≈øed to be concretions of ≈øome part of the nutritious Juice that may come along with the Urine into this Membrane, wherein by its long ≈øtay it curdles into the≈øe kind of bodies. But there is one more notable one, that is ≈øaid to grow on the Forehead of the Colt, of the ≈øhape of a Tongue, and is called hippomanes, which, Tradition ≈øays, the Mare is wont to eat as ≈øoon as ≈øhe has foal'd; which if ≈øhe do not, ≈øhe will never care for her Foal. This they were wont to dry and powder, and to put into drink for a Love-potion, as if there were ≈øome witchery in it. But ≈øuch things I can ≈øay nothing to, having never experimented them. This Membrane ≈øticking pretty clo≈øe to the Chorion, bags out on each ≈øide into the Horns of the Womb as well as it. The Liquor contained in it, is Urine, as was ≈øaid above, which daily increa≈øes in quantity, being imported into it by the ∆≤rachus from the Bladder of the Foal.

div.p: La≈øtly, We are come to the Ve≈ø≈øels that make up the Navel-≈øtring, and tho≈øe are four, one Vein, two Arteries, and the ∆≤rachus. The≈øe are all infolded in a common Coat, and are wreathed one about another like a Rope. The greate≈øt part of its length is contained in the Amnios, the re≈øt in the Allantoides; for as ≈øoon as it has penetrated that, it is immediately and directly implanted into the Chorion.

The Vein is as big as both the Arteries, and ari≈øes out of the hollow or lower ≈øide of the Liver of the Young, and coming out ≈øingle with the re≈øt at the Navel, is immediately divided into two, which as they pa≈øs through the Amnios, ≈øend ≈øome twigs to it, and from thence continue their march through the Allantoides to the Chorion, in which and the Caruncles that grow upon it they terminate, being divided into innumerable branches. Its u≈øe is to imbibe the nutritious Juice and al≈øo the Bloud that is ≈øuperfluous to the nouri≈øhing of the≈øe Parts, and to convey them to the Young.

The Arteries being two, do ari≈øe on each ≈øide from the inner Iliacal Branches of the great Artery, (as is commonly held, but I have always ob≈øerved them to ≈øpring from the Aorta it ≈øelf before the divi≈øion) and a≈øcending by the ≈øides of the Bladder, they meet the Vein at the Navel, and there begin to be wreathed with it. Their march and in≈øertions are the ≈øame with tho≈øe of the Vein, onely they ≈øend more twigs into the Amnios than the Vein doth. Their u≈øe is to carry vital heat and nouri≈øhment to the Parts that include the Young, to wit to the Amnios, Chorion and its Caruncles: and be≈øides, its branches that are di≈øper≈øed through the Amnios do di≈øtill into it ≈øome of that nutritious Juice which could not be turned into Bloud by once circulating through the Heart of the Young. Which Juice being collected in the cavity of the Amnios, is drunk in by the Young at its mouth, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øes the ≈øame ways as it does after the birth.

The fourth Ve≈ø≈øel included in the Navel-rope is called ∆≤rachus, from its office of conveying the Urine. It ≈øprings from the bottom of the Bladder, and pa≈ø≈øing out of the Navel with the Vein and Arteries, as ≈øoon as it has pierced the Amnios it opens it ≈øelf with a full mouth into the cavity of the Allantoides, ≈øerving as a Pipe to rack the Urine as it were out of the Bladder of the Young into this Membrane. For though the Young void no Excrements at the Fundament, while it is in the Womb, nor has any Repo≈øitory or Storehou≈øe for them ≈øaving its own Guts, (among≈øt which the Gut Caecum ≈øeems fitte≈øt for that office:) yet ≈øeeing it is nouri≈øhed altogether with Liquor that has a good quantity of wheyi≈øh humour mixed with it for its better conveyance through tho≈øe narrow ways by which it is to pa≈øs, I ≈øay for this rea≈øon it is nece≈ø≈øary there ≈øhould be ≈øome particular Repo≈øitory for it, ≈øeeing it cannot return to the Dam again, and the Bladder of the Young is not capable of containing a fifth (may be a tenth) part of it; and this Repo≈øitory is the Membrane Allantoides, into which it is poured out of the Bladder by the ∆≤rachus.

The≈øe four Ve≈ø≈øels after they come out of the Navel are included in one common Coat, which con≈øi≈øts of a double Membrane, borrowed from the Rim of the Belly the inner of them, and the outer from the fle≈øhy Membrane or Pannicle de≈øcribed above chap. 4. After the birth of the Foal, the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels lo≈øing their original u≈øe, the two Arteries ≈øerve for Ligaments to keep the Bladder in its place, and the Vein performs the ≈øame office to the Liver; but the ∆≤rachus quite di≈øappears.

And thus much of the Membranes and Navel-ve≈ø≈øels, that are included in the Womb when the Mare is with Foal; and which at the Foaling make the After-birth or Cleaning as we call it: We might in this place further ≈øhew, what Parts of the Foal are fir≈øt formed, and which ≈øoone≈øt perfected; al≈øo in what particulars a Foal in the Womb differs from it ≈øelf when foaled; and la≈øtly we might have been more full in ≈øhewing how it is nouri≈øhed in the Womb: but the di≈øcour≈øing of the≈øe things we purpo≈øely wave in this place, and refer the Reader to the Di≈øcour≈øe of the generation of Animals annexed to this Treati≈øe of Anatomy, wherein we will endeavour to ≈øatisfy his curio≈øity to the uttermo≈øt.

GGG The urinary Membrane, (which here is not Allantoides, or of the ≈øhape of a Pudding) inve≈øting the whole Foetus as well as the Amnios; which is common to it with a Man, Dog, Cat, Coney, and perhaps others that have Womb-cakes; although they differ from one another in ≈øeveral circum≈øtances.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX. Of the ∆≤dder.

argument.p: Its ≈øub≈øtance. Number. Its Glands. The Paps. The Ve≈ø≈øels belonging to the ∆≤dder. The milk-pipes. The u≈øe of the ∆≤dder.

div.p: THOUGH the Udder be an external Part of the Lower Belly, yet we have deferr'd the de≈øcription of it till this place, becau≈øe of the dependance that it has upon the Womb, and its office of yielding the ≈øame nouri≈øhment to the Foal when it is excluded out of the Womb, as it was nouri≈øh'd by while it remain'd in it.

It is ≈øeated at the bottom of the Paunch upon the lower ends of the ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles; very ≈ømall, if compar'd to the bigne≈øs of a Mare's Body, and to its bulk in many other Creatures. When the Mare gives no ≈øuck, it almo≈øt di≈øappears.
It con≈øi≈øts of the common coverings, Fat, a multitude of Ve≈ø≈øels, Glands or Kernels, and Pipes to convey the Milk to the Paps that is ≈øeparated from the Ve≈ø≈øels in the Glands.

Now though when the Mare gives ≈øuck it ≈øeems to be but one roundi≈øh body, like a Brea≈øt with two Nipples, yet it truly con≈øi≈øts of two bodies, one being joined to the other onely by contiguity, for they have each their proper Ve≈ø≈øels, Pipes and Pap; and do indeed appear to the eye to be di≈øtinct when the Mare is neither with Foal nor ≈øuckles one.

The greate≈øt part of its bulk con≈øi≈øts of Glands, which are many in number, though they be ≈øo united to one another as to appear one continued body to an unwary ob≈øerver, which they come to do from that Fat that fills up the ≈øpaces between them, and is much of the ≈øame colour with the Glands. There is one Gland greater than the re≈øt ≈øeated at the root of each Pap. By means of the≈øe Glands it is that the Milk is ≈øeparated from the Bloud, as ≈øhall be further ≈øhewn by and by.

The Paps are round in ≈øhape and of a ≈øpongie ≈øub≈øtance, cloathed with a thinner Skin than the re≈øt of the Udder. At their head or end they have many little holes through which the Milk i≈ø≈øues when the Foal ≈øucks.

The Udder has all ≈øorts of Ve≈ø≈øels, Veins, Arteries, Nerves and Lympheducts; and be≈øides the≈øe it has peculiar Pipes for containing and conveying the Milk. The Veins and Arteries are branches of the Hypoga≈øtricks, which proceed from the internal Iliack branches of the Cava and Aorta: 'tis likely there come ≈øome twigs to it al≈øo from the external branches, which are called the Epiga≈øtrick Ve≈ø≈øels. Its Nerves I have not examin'd, but 'tis very probable they are the ≈øame with tho≈øe di≈øper≈øed into the Matrix and Sheath, which are twigs of the Interco≈øtal pair and of ≈øome of the Os ≈øacrum. Its Lympheducts are pretty numerous, and tend, as all tho≈øe of the Lower Belly do, to the common Receptacle of the Chyle at the centre of the Me≈øentery.

It has al≈øo a peculiar ≈øort of Ve≈ø≈øels, which may be called Milk-pipes, being the Repo≈øitories or Store-hou≈øes of the Milk. At the root of each Pap they are but one on each ≈øide, but a great many ≈ømaller ones coming from every part of the Udder di≈øcharge them≈øelves into this one, when the Pap is ≈øuckt by the Foal. But the Pipes belonging to one Pap have no communication with tho≈øe that belong to the other, but in re≈øpect of
the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels the two ≈øides of the Udder are as di≈øtinct Parts, as the Brea≈øts of a Woman are di≈øtinct one from another, as was noted before. The≈øe Pipes have been mi≈øtaken by ≈øome to be true Milky-veins, as if ≈øome of the Milky-veins of the Me≈øentery reached hither. But ≈øeeing there are no foot≈øteps of them in the track betwixt the Me≈øentery and Udder, we may well deny them to be found in the Udder it ≈øelf.

The u≈øe of the Udder is to prepare and ≈øeparate the Milk for the nouri≈øhment of the Foal, which it does in this manner. The Chyle of the Mare being mixed with her Bloud in the Heart, flows from thence along with it by the Arteries into all Parts of the Body in the circulation, but mo≈øt plentifully ('tis probable) towards the Udder, even as it does to the Womb while the Mare is with Foal. The Arteries that convey it immediately to the Udder are the hypoga≈øtrick Branches, which terminating in its Glands do ≈øquirt or ≈øtrain the Chyle through them into the Milk-pipes. And as for the Bloud that was mixed with the Chyle in the Arteries, that being of a thicker body, or con≈øi≈øting of Particles of another form, cannot enter the narrow pores of the Glands, and therefore is received by the ≈ømall mouths of the Veins that are likewi≈øe in≈øerted into them. So that it appears to be an erroneous Opinion, That Milk is made of Bloud, if we ≈øpeak of Bloud properly ≈øo called; yet ≈øeeing the Chyle, when it is confu≈øedly jumbled with the Bloud in the Arteries, is not ea≈øily di≈øtingui≈øhable from it, but the whole Ma≈øs ≈øeems to be homogeneal or of the ≈øame nature, in a large and le≈øs proper ≈øen≈øe we may affirm it to be ≈øo made. After that the Chyle is thus ≈øeparated by the Glands, it drills along the Milk-pipes, out of the ≈ømaller into the larger, in which it is re≈øerved for the u≈øe of the Foal.
