div.head: THE ANATOMY OF AN HORSE. BOOK II. Of the Middle Venter, or Che≈øt.
CHAP. I. Of the inve≈øting and circum≈øcribing Parts of the Che≈øt.

argument.p: By what parts the Thorax is bounded. Its common inve≈øting Parts. Its proper containing Parts. Its contained Parts.

div.p: HAVING fini≈øhed the Fir≈øt Book, wherein I have ab≈øolved or explained all the Natural Parts contained within the Lower Venter, as well nutritive as generative, and annexed a Di≈øcour≈øe of the Foal in the Matrix or Womb; order of di≈ø≈øection requires that in the next place I come to treat of the Middle Venter, the Thorax or Che≈øt, and the Vital Parts contained therein.

Where, in this one ≈øtep higher that I have climbed, I am methinks much delighted to ≈øee, how Nature in this place di≈øports her ≈øelf, having as in a curious Cabinet lockt up, as it were, her mo≈øt exqui≈øite pieces of Workman≈øhip, the Vital In≈øtruments, by who≈øe motion the life of the Creature is continued. Which motion is performed by ≈øo ju≈øt a counterpoi≈øe, as no art of Man could ever with all their contrivances be able in the lea≈øt to imitate. Nay Ari≈øtotle, that wi≈øe Philo≈øopher, who was in his time thought to be the neare≈øt of coun≈øel to Nature, was not able
(notwith≈øtanding his incomparable ≈øagacity) to find out the true cau≈øe of the Vital motion, any more than he was, to find out the reciprocal Ebbing and Flowing of the Sea.
The Place wherein the≈øe In≈øtruments are contained, is called the Thorax or Che≈øt, which is compo≈øed of or environed with the≈øe Parts following.

Fir≈øt it is bounded or circum≈øcribed, above, by the Coller-bones, and below by the Diaphragm or Midriff; on the fore-part by the Brea≈øt-bone, and on the hinder part by the Spondyls or Back-bones; and on the two ≈øides by the true and ba≈øtard Ribs and Interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles. All which Parts are framed and compo≈øed by Nature for the benefit of the Creature, as well for the defence of the contained Parts from external Injuries, as for the u≈øe of Re≈øpiration or breathing: both which are very needfull; for without them the Creature cannot be pre≈øerved. Now that it might ≈øerve for the≈øe ends, it was nece≈ø≈øary it ≈øhould con≈øi≈øt of ≈øundry Parts; for ≈øhould it have been made all bony, it could not have been contracted and dilated as occa≈øion ≈øerved, whereby the Lungs could not have had the liberty to play as now they have: And if it had been wholly fle≈øhy, then would not the contained Parts have been ≈øufficiently fenced. It is therefore made partly bony, partly gri≈øtly, and partly fle≈øhy, that it might the better perform both the offices afore≈øaid.
In the next place I come to ≈øpeak particularly to the Inve≈øting Parts of the Che≈øt, ≈øome of which are Common, and others Proper.

The Common inve≈øting or containing Parts are the ≈øame as the Lower Belly hath, namely the Scarf-skin, the true Skin, the fle≈øhy Pannicle, the Fat, and the common Membrane of the Mu≈øcles. Of all which having di≈øcour≈øed at large in the Fir≈øt Book, we ≈øhall ≈øay nothing of them here.

The Proper containing Parts of the Che≈øt are the Mu≈øcles, the Bones, the Pleura or Membrane that cloaths its in≈øide, the Midriff and the Media≈øtinum, which is the Skin that goes acro≈øs from the Brea≈øt to the Back, and parts the Lungs, called by ≈øome, the Partition-wall.

The contained or inve≈øted Parts, are the Heart with the Heart-bag called the Pericardium, and by ≈øome the Pur≈øe of the Heart, the Lungs and part of the Weazand or Wind-pipe, by Anatomi≈øts called A≈øpera Arteria, or Rough-artery, and ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels, with the Trunks of Vena cava and Arteria magna, who≈øe a≈øcending branches are underpropped by the Thymus, or Kernel in the Throat.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Middle Venter or Che≈øt, called the Interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles.

argument.p: Interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles why ≈øo called. The External. The Internal. Their number. Their action.

div.p: THERE are ≈øeveral pairs of Mu≈øcles that lie upon the Che≈øt on the out≈øide of the Ribs; but becau≈øe one may ea≈øily enough cut open the Che≈øt for examining the Parts contained in it, without defacing any part of tho≈øe Mu≈øcles, we ≈øhall omit to ≈øpeak of them in this place, referring the Reader to the Book of the Mu≈øcles; and here onely de≈øcribe the Interco≈øtal, which in laying open the Brea≈øt, whiles one breaks the gri≈øtly ends of the Ribs, happen part of them to be defaced.

The≈øe Mu≈øcles are called Interco≈øtal from their being placed between the Ribs, and filling up the ≈øpaces between them. Betwixt every two Ribs there are placed two of the≈øe Mu≈øcles, the one lying upon the other; the uppermo≈øt being called the External, and the undermo≈øt the Internal one.
The External one takes his ri≈øe from the lower part of the upper Ribs, and ends in the upper part of the lower.
The Internal takes his ri≈øe contrary to the former; for it ari≈øes or takes its original from the upper part of the lower Rib, and ends in the lower part of the upper.
Now it is to be under≈øtood that tho≈øe are called the upper Ribs that are next to the Head, and tho≈øe the lower, that are next to the Paunch.

And as the≈øe Mu≈øcles do differ as to their original and in≈øertion, ≈øo likewi≈øe in the cour≈øe of their Fibres; for although they be both furni≈øhed with oblique or ≈ølanting Fibres, yet they run contrary ways, cro≈ø≈øing one the other, and making as it were a St. Andrew's Cro≈øs, or the letter X.

The≈øe Mu≈øcles are in number ≈øixty four, that is to ≈øay on each ≈øide thirty two, there being on each ≈øide of the Hor≈øe ≈øeventeen Ribs, and between every Rib two Mu≈øcles, as I have before intimated.

Now the action of the≈øe Mu≈øcles is to a≈ø≈øi≈øt Re≈øpiration by widening, and contracting the Che≈øt. Fir≈øt the external ones ≈øerve to rai≈øe the Ribs and draw them backward, whereby the Cavity of the Che≈øt is enlarged, and thereby free room made for the Air to enter into the Lungs in In≈øpiration, or taking in the breath. And on the contrary the internal pull in the Ribs by drawing them ≈ølanting downwards towards the Brea≈øt-bone, whereby the Che≈øt is ≈øtraitned, and thereby the Air, wherewith the Lungs are puff'd up, expelled, which action is called Expiration, or breathing forth. But the≈øe Mu≈øcles are not of them≈øelves alone ≈øufficient for the≈øe actions, but they a≈ø≈øi≈øt towards them, being aided by the other that lie upon the Che≈øt, by the Midriff, and by the Lungs them≈øelves.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Pleura, or Coat which inve≈øts or lines the Ribs on the In≈øide.

argument.p: The original of the Pleura or Rib-skin. Its Perforations. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its u≈øe.

div.p: THIS Coat or Skin called the Pleura, is the Skin which covereth all the Ribs on the in≈øide of the Che≈øt, being of the ≈øame nature and u≈øe here, as the Peritonaeum or Rim of the Belly is in the Lower Belly. It is al≈øo of the ≈øame ≈øub≈øtance as the Rim of the Belly is, but much ≈øtronger and thicker, though Riolanus affirmeth the contrary as to Men.

It is as it were of a middle nature or temper, that is, neither too hard nor too ≈øoft; not too hard, le≈øt it ≈øhould not reach and yield in the act of Re≈øpiration, and ≈øo hinder the motion of the Che≈øt; neither too ≈øoft, le≈øt the motion of the Che≈øt ≈øhould violate it: but it is rather hard than ≈øoft, the better to defend the Vital Parts.

It is believed to take its original from the Coats of the Nerves of the Spinal Marrow, which come out of the Back-bones (or vertebrae of the Back) into the Che≈øt, and is therefore thought to be continued with the Coats of the Brain: wherefore it is ob≈øerved to be thicker upon the back part of the Che≈øt than any where el≈øe, where it ≈øticks ≈øo clo≈øe to the Backbones, that it can hardly be ≈øeparated.

It is all over double, that the Interco≈øtal-ve≈ø≈øels might run without danger between its Membranes, and by it be pre≈øerved from the hardne≈øs of the Ribs, which would be apt to violate or break them.

The outward Skin of this Coat, namely that which is next to the Cavity of the Che≈øt, is harder and thicker; and the inward (which is fa≈øtned to the Ribs) is ≈øofter and thinner. Now between the≈øe two Skins is bred that mortal Di≈øea≈øe (in Men) called the Pleuri≈øie, by which the never to be forgotten Doctor Willis, (for being in his time the honour of his Univer≈øity and Country) was notwith≈øtanding the great pains he took in the inquiry into and finding out remedies again≈øt this Di≈øea≈øe, (as his learned Works make appear, by which great benefit hath accrued to others) was, I ≈øay, him≈øelf by the tyranny of it taken from among≈øt the Living.

This Pleura is perforated in many places, for the Ingate and Outgate of the Ve≈ø≈øels. For above, it letteth out the Jugular and Axillary Arteries and Veins, and below, through the Midriff, the Trunks of the hollow Vein and great Artery. Be≈øides where it receiveth in the Nerves of the wandring pair, the Windpipe, and both letteth in and out the Gullet.

Its proper Ve≈ø≈øels are, Veins from the Vena ≈øine pari, or Vein without a pair, and from the upper Interco≈øtal Vein. Its Arteries ≈øpring al≈øo from the upper Interco≈øtals (as tho≈øe from the Subclavian) which de≈øcend to about the ≈øeventh or eighth Rib: below which it receives twigs of Arteries from the back part of the de≈øcending great Artery. It has as many pairs of Nerves (wanting one) as there are Joints in the Backbone the whole length of the Che≈øt: for betwixt each Joint there comes out a pair; but then the uppermo≈øt and lowe≈øt Joints being reckoned for
the two extremes, (and not a pair of Nerves for either extreme) there mu≈øt be one pair of Nerves le≈øs than there are Joints. The Joints therefore (or vertebrae) being ≈øeventeen, there mu≈øt onely ≈øixteen pair of Nerves be reckoned to the Che≈øt. Now the≈øe Nerves as ≈øoon as ever they come out of the Joint, are immediately divided into the fore and hinder-branches. Of which the fore-branches ≈øerve the Interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles and the Pleura; but the hinder are be≈øtowed on the Mu≈øcles that lie upon the Back.

The u≈øe of it is much like that of the Rim of the Belly; for (as hath been ≈øaid) as the Rim of the Belly is ≈øtretched about all the Lower Belly, and furni≈øheth all the Bowels therein contained with Coats or Skins, (every Bowel with a particular Coat) ≈øo doth this Pleura the Bowels of the Middle Venter: for it is ≈øtretched about all the Cavity of the Che≈øt, and giveth a Coat to every particular Part therein contained, (either mediately or immediately.) It covers al≈øo the Interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles, and makes the upper Membrane of the Midriff. Next to the Cavity of the Che≈øt it is bedewed with a watery humour, that the Lungs which lie again≈øt it on their out≈øide, may move the more glibly, and not be offended by its roughne≈øs.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Midriff or Diaphragm.

argument.p: The Diaphragm why ≈øo called. Its ri≈øe. Its ≈øub≈øtance. Its Perforations. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. The ≈øeveral u≈øes of the Midriff. 1. It a≈ø≈øi≈øts Re≈øpiration. 2. Its motion helps the di≈øtribution of the Chyle. 3 It helps to expel the Excrements, and in Mares the Foal. 4. It ≈øerves to divide the Abdomen from the Che≈øt.

div.p: THE Diaphragm (or Midriff) is ≈øo called from its office of di≈øtingui≈øhing or ≈øeparating; becau≈øe it ≈øeparateth or di≈øtingui≈øheth the Bowels of the lower, from the In≈øtruments of Life and Re≈øpiration in the middle Belly.

It is a Mu≈øcle, long and round, ≈øeated at the lower part of the Che≈øt, overthwart which it runs, ≈øloping a little lower towards the Paunch backward. It hath a figure and action different from all other Mu≈øcles.
It is as broad as the Che≈øt is wide: for its edges are knit to the lower part of the Brea≈øt-bone, and all round on each ≈øide to the Ribs, and to the lowe≈øt vertebral Joint of the Che≈øt.

It is ≈øaid to ari≈øe from its two long and fle≈øhy Productions, which ≈øpringing from the vertebrae of the Loins (to the mu≈øcles whereof they are ≈øtrongly knit) do, as they go upwards, grow wider and wider, till they come to the lowe≈øt vertebrae of the Che≈øt, where they grow and unite together, and ≈øo ≈øpread them≈øelves into this Mu≈øcle called the Midriff. Others, though they grant that the≈øe are part of its original, yet think that it does equally ari≈øe from its whole fle≈øhy circumference, by which it adheres to the ends of the lowe≈øt Ribs. And a third opinion is, that its original is from its centre or middle where its Nerve is in≈øerted into it, from that common Maxim of Galen's, That whereever the Nerve is in≈øerted, there is the head of the Mu≈øcle. But as that Maxim does not hold in all other Mu≈øcles, ≈øo this being a Mu≈øcle of a peculiar ≈øhape and u≈øe, it may well be excepted therefrom, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing the centre of the Midriff is
tendinous, which the origine of a Mu≈øcle does not u≈øe to be, but onely its end.

As for its ≈øub≈øtance, it is partly fle≈øhy, partly nervous and partly membranous. For Membranes, becau≈øe it requireth great ≈øtrength (it being in continual motion) it is furni≈øhed with two, and tho≈øe very ≈øtrong ones, the uppermo≈øt of which it hath from the Pleura, and the lowermo≈øt from the Peritonaeum or Rim of the Belly. To the uppermo≈øt the lower part of the Media≈øtinum is knit, (and of the Heart-bag in Men, but not in Hor≈øes or other Brutes) and ≈øometimes the lower tips or ends of the two great Lobes of the Lungs. Its circumference is fle≈øhy, and its middle or centre nervous, in which part a wound is mortal, but one in the fle≈øhy ≈øometimes admits of cure.

It hath in it ≈øeveral perforations or holes, ≈øome of which are little, and others bigger. The little ones are the pores, through which the Vapours are ≈øaid to a≈øcend from the lower Parts into the Che≈øt; but be≈øides that ≈øuch a≈øcent of impure Vapours from the Guts, &c. into the Che≈øt, where the Vital Parts are ≈øeated, would be very inconvenient and prejudicial, I think the Midriff is ≈øo compact a body, and its Membranes ≈øo clo≈øe, that we may either deny any pores at all, or however that they admit not any ≈øuch ≈øteams. The larger holes (being tho≈øe that ought to be reckon'd alone for ≈øuch) are, fir≈øt, that which is very near its middle or centre, but ≈øomething towards the right ≈øide, which gives pa≈ø≈øage for the Trunk of the hollow Vein a≈øcending from the Liver. The ≈øecond is on the left ≈øide of the centre, being bigger than the former, and ≈øomewhat backwarder; and this ≈øerves for the letting forth of the Gullet and two Nerves which go to the Stomach. There is al≈øo a third hole more backwards by the vertebrae, for the through-fare of the great Artery, and the Vein without a fellow, and for the Nerve which Doctor Willis di≈øtingui≈øhes from the wandring or eighth pair, by the name of the Interco≈øtal.

The Midriff hath Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts; for it hath Veins ari≈øing from the Trunk of the hollow Vein, which are called Venae phrenicae, and al≈øo ≈øome twigs branching to it from the Vena adipo≈øa, or Fat-vein, ≈øo called becau≈øe it is mo≈øtly be≈øtowed on the fat Membrane that inve≈øts the Kidneys.
It hath Arteries from the Trunk of the great Artery, called al≈øo Phrenicae.

Its Nerves are in number two, proceeding from the ≈øpinal Marrow at the third or fourth jointing of the Rack-bones or vertebrae of the Neck, from whence they de≈øcend through the cavity of the Che≈øt, being in their cour≈øe ≈øu≈øtained and ≈øtrengthened by the Media≈øtinum, le≈øt by any violent motion they ≈øhould be hurt. As ≈øoon as the≈øe Nerves reach the Midriff, they enter it in its centre, and thence di≈øper≈øe them≈øelves into its whole ≈øub≈øtance, terminating in it. But be≈øides the≈øe ≈øome have ob≈øerved ≈ømall twigs to be ≈øent into it from the Nerves of the eighth pair, as they de≈øcend through it toward the Stomach.

Various are the ∆≤≈øes that might be a≈øcribed unto the Midriff, the chief are the≈øe that follow. Fir≈øt, It is the principal Mu≈øcle that a≈ø≈øi≈øts the action of Re≈øpiration. Which action whether it be animal and voluntary, or natural and involuntary, has occa≈øion'd great di≈øputes. True it is, that it moves in breathing as well while we ≈øleep, as when we are awake, ≈øo that our Will, which in ≈øleep is dormant as well as the Body, ≈øeems not to be nece≈ø≈øary to its motion: and yet we can hinder it from moving when we plea≈øe by holding in our breath. We may therefore call its motion, a mixt motion, to wit, partly
voluntary (or rather ≈øpontaneous in Bea≈øts, becau≈øe they have not properly any Will) and partly natural. Which motion is performed on this manner. In taking in ones breath it is ≈øtretched out and becomes plain and ≈øtiff, pre≈ø≈øing down a little the Parts contained in the Lower Belly: but in letting out ones breath, it is relaxed and a≈øcends ≈øomewhat up into the Che≈øt, being partly driven up thither by the a≈øcent of the Bowels of the Lower Belly, which in expiration is a little ≈øtraitned by its Mu≈øcles, and therefore the Parts contained therein as they have le≈øs room breadthways, mu≈øt have more lengthways. Now we mu≈øt note, that onely one ≈øort of motion agrees to one Mu≈øcle, to wit, that of contraction; for that of re≈øtitution or relaxation is owing to the oppo≈øite Mu≈øcle, as was ≈øhewed at large in the Fir≈øt Book, chap. 6. The proper motion of the Midriff therefore is onely in In≈øpiration or taking in ones breath, when all its Fibres being contracted quite round, it is ≈øtretched out plain, ≈øomewhat like the Parchment upon a Drum's head: but when it is relaxed and becomes flaggy in Expiration, that is onely a motion of re≈øtitution, and is not owing to it ≈øelf, but to tho≈øe Mu≈øcles that con≈øtringe or ≈øtraiten the Che≈øt, which are that called ≈øacrolumbus, and the triangularis or three-corner'd one, which two lie on the out≈øide of the Ribs as ≈øhall be ≈øhewn in the Book of the Mu≈øcles; and la≈øtly, the internal Interco≈øtals, de≈øcribed before in the ≈øecond Chapter, to which ≈øome of the Mu≈øcles of the Lower Belly perhaps yield ≈øome a≈ø≈øi≈øtance.

Secondly, By its a≈øcending and de≈øcending, and ≈øo occa≈øioning the Stomach, Guts, &c. to be always in a motion upwards and downwards, it a≈ø≈øi≈øts them in driving forward the Liquors or whatever el≈øe contained in them, and ≈øo helps the di≈øtribution of the Chyle, which by the wormlike motion of the Guts alone could not ≈øo well be ≈øent through tho≈øe innumerable ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels through which it is to pa≈øs. And this I take to be a con≈øiderable u≈øe of it, though few Anatomi≈øts have taken any notice of it.

A third u≈øe is to help forward the expul≈øion of the Excrements, and a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Mare in the time of her foaling. For in both tho≈øe offices the Midriff by holding in the breath is kept on the tenters as it were and pre≈ø≈øed down upon the Parts contained in the Lower Belly that are next it, and tho≈øe do ≈øucce≈ø≈øively bear hard upon others that are next them, whereby every Part contained therein is ≈øomewhat ≈øtraitned, and ≈øo what≈øoever is contained in any of them, be it the Dung, Urine or Foal, is ≈øqueezed out and expelled.

The la≈øt u≈øe is what was mentioned at the beginning of this Chapter, namely, to di≈øtingui≈øh the Lower Belly with its natural Parts, from the Che≈øt and its vital Parts; le≈øt from the inferiour ignoble Parts noi≈øom Vapours ≈øhould a≈øcend up to the more noble, ≈øuch as are tho≈øe contained in the Che≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Partition-membrane called Media≈øtinum.

argument.p: The Media≈øtinum why ≈øo called. Its ri≈øe and ≈øub≈øtance. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its u≈øes.

div.p: THIS Membrane is called by the Latins Media≈øtinum, from its office of partitioning or dividing, becau≈øe it divides the Che≈øt into two parts, ≈øtanding acro≈øs the middle of it.

It is derived or hath its original from the Pleura or Rib-coat, of which we have already ≈øpoken in the third Chapter. For the Pleura ≈øpringing from the Back-bone, keeps its way on each ≈øide of the cavity of the Che≈øt (cloathing the in≈øide of the Ribs) till it comes to the Brea≈øt-bone, where the two Membranes join together, but do not unite into one. From the Brea≈øt-bone the≈øe two Membranes hold a direct cour≈øe back again towards the Back-bone through the middle of the Che≈øt, but before they have gone an Inch, they begin to ≈øeparate again, and that ≈øo far from one another by degrees, as to make a cavity wide enough for containing the Heart and the Heart-bag. But when they are arrived near the Back, they join together again. Note that the Media≈øtinum being compo≈øed of the doubling of the Pleura, mu≈øt con≈øi≈øt of four Membranes when united, (though onely of two where divided) ≈øeeing the Pleura it ≈øelf con≈øi≈øts of two. It is wholly membranous, as is the Pleura of which it is formed; ≈ømooth on the out≈øide towards the Lungs, but rough on its in≈øide towards the Heart, by rea≈øon that the Heart-bag adheres to it by ≈øeveral Fibres.

Between the duplicature of this Membrane there are many ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts di≈øper≈øed. For fir≈øt there are Veins branching to it from the Phrenica or Midriff-vein and from the ≈øolitary Vein or Vena ≈øine pari; it has likewi≈øe one proper Vein of its own from the ≈øubclavian branch, called after its own name, Media≈øtina. Secondly, its Arteries come from the Phrenica or Midriff-artery, which ≈øpring out of the de≈øcending Trunk of the great Artery. Thirdly, it hath Nerves from the Phrenick or Midriff twigs of tho≈øe two branches of the eighth pair that de≈øcend through it to the upper orifice of the Stomach. Bartholin a≈øoribes al≈øo Lympheducts unto it.

The u≈øe of the Media≈øtinum is fir≈øt, to divide the Che≈øt and Lungs into two parts, that if any hurtfull Accident ≈øhould happen to one of the ≈øides, the other notwith≈øtanding might be pre≈øerved. And this hath been ob≈øerved by Anatomi≈øts, who have found in di≈ø≈øections the one ≈øide or Lobe of the Lungs wa≈øted and almo≈øt dryed away in Phthi≈øical and Con≈øumptive Per≈øons, and at the ≈øame time the other hath been perfectly fre≈øh and ≈øound. And it hath been likewi≈øe ≈øeen and ob≈øerved in wounds of the Che≈øt, that if therewith one Lobe of the Lungs ≈øhould happen to be hurt ≈øo much as to occa≈øion the lo≈øs of the u≈øe of that Lobe, yet the other by performing his part hath pre≈øerved life.
The next u≈øe of the Media≈øtinum is to permit the Heart in the Heartbag to hang dangling in a free po≈øture, that in its motion it might not ≈øtrike again≈øt the bony ≈øides of the Che≈øt.

Again, it ≈øerves to ≈øu≈øtain and pre≈øerve the Ve≈ø≈øels running through it; and by its being knit to the Midriff, pre≈øerves that al≈øo from being drawn too much downwards by the weight of the Bowels of the Lower Belly, e≈øpecially by the Liver, who≈øe ≈øu≈øpen≈øory Ligament hangs by it.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Thymus or great Kernel at the Throat; and of the Pur≈øe of the Heart called Pericardium, together with the water contained therein.

argument.p: What the Thymus is. Its u≈øe. The Ve≈ø≈øeli which pa≈øs over it. What the Pericardium is. From whence it takes its original. The ≈øub≈øtance of the Pericardium. Its Perforations. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its u≈øe. Of the Water contained in the Pericardium. The u≈øes of the Water. Of the Humour contained in the Che≈øt.

div.p: THE Thymus (named the Sweet-bread by ≈øome) is a glandulous or kernelly body, ≈øoft and ≈øpongie, placed in the upper part of the Che≈øt near the hole of the Throat, lying upon the ends of the Clavicles or Collar-bones.
It hath its name Thymus from the leaf of Time, which it very much re≈øembleth in ≈øhape.

Its u≈øe is to ≈øerve as a Boul≈øter or Pillow for the Veins and Arteries to pa≈øs over or lie upon, to keep them from the hardne≈øs of the Collar-bones, the ≈øharpne≈øs of which would el≈øe be apt to break them or fret them a≈øunder.

Now the Ve≈ø≈øels which do cro≈øs over this Thymus are the hollow Vein and the great Artery, with the many divi≈øions and branches of the ≈øame, which are in number many, di≈øper≈øed from thence into mo≈øt of the extreme Parts of the forepart of the Body, as ≈øome to the Shoulder-blades, and ≈øo down the Fore-legs; again, ≈øome to the Neck and Head, namely the internal and external Jugular Veins, and the Carotid Arteries; as al≈øo tho≈øe branches which run all along the Belly, which are by us Farriers called the Liver-veins. This Kernel is bigger in Foals than it is in grown Hor≈øes in proportion to their Bodies; and in Calves it is pretty large, and is reckoned for a dainty delicate bit.

Next come we to treat of the Pericardium, or Pur≈øe of the Heart, or Heart-bag, for by the≈øe ≈øeveral nominations or names it goes. This is
that Coat or Skin which compa≈ø≈øeth the Heart, and in which the Heart hangeth, it being for that purpo≈øe made in figure like it.
It takes its original at the ba≈øis or upper and broad end of the Heart, from the outer Coats which compa≈øs the Ve≈ø≈øels that enter into the Heart, which Coats do ≈øpring from the Pleura.

Its ≈øub≈øtance is thick and ≈øomething hard, though not ≈øo hard as to hurt the Lungs when it pre≈ø≈øeth again≈øt them, or they again≈øt it; neither is it too ≈øoft, le≈øt it ≈øhould it ≈øelf be hurt by the hardne≈øs of the Ribs, which in ≈øtrong pul≈øations of the Heart it beats again≈øt, the Media≈øtinum onely coming between: but being placed between two contraries, I mean, between the ≈øoft Lungs and hard Bones, it ought to have its ≈øub≈øtance of a middle nature between both. On the out≈øide it is rough and fibrous, adhering in many places to the Media≈øtinum; but within, it is ≈ømooth and ≈ølippery, that the Heart might move more freely in it.

It is perforated in five places; namely on the right ≈øide by the a≈øcending Trunk of the hollow Vein, which comes up from the Liver and enters the right Ventricle of the Heart; and by the Subclavian Vein which de≈øcends from the Channel-bones into the ≈øame Ventricle; and thirdly by the Pulmonary Artery which goes out of the right Ventricle into the Lungs. On its left ≈øide it is perforated by the Pulmonary Vein which comes from the Lungs and enters the left Ventricle of the Heart; and la≈øtly by the great Artery that pa≈ø≈øes out of the ≈øaid Ventricle.

The Veins that it is furni≈øhed with, it receiveth at the lower part of it from the Phrenick or Midriff-vein, and at the upper part from the Axillaries; but the Ve≈ø≈øels from each place are mighty ≈ømall.

There are no Arteries derived to it from any place, that are vi≈øible; and the rea≈øon ≈øuppo≈øed is, becau≈øe it is ≈øo near the Heart, that it is immediately ≈øupplied from it with vital heat and ≈øpirit. But ≈øeeing the Heart it ≈øelf is not without Arteries, though it be reckon'd the fountain of life, much le≈øs can any other part be ≈øuppo≈øed to be, and therefore neither this, though they are ≈øo ≈ølender as not to be di≈øcernible.
Tho≈øe ≈ømall Nerves it is furni≈øhed with, are branched to it from the left recurrent Nerves of the eighth or wandring pair.
To the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels Bartholin adds Lympheducts, which ≈øerve to drink up part of the Liquor contained in the Heart-bag, to hinder its two great encrea≈øe.

Next come we to the u≈øe of the Heart-bag, which is, to cover and pre≈øerve the Heart, and to contain a certain moi≈øture or Humour in it for the u≈øes after-mentioned. Now concerning this Humour there are various di≈øcour≈øes and different opinions of Authours, I mean, as to the fountain from whence it proceeds; for ≈øome will have it, that it is fed by Liquors which we drink, of which opinion is the Learned Hippocrates, whence in his Book de Corde he ≈øaith, that the Heart dwelleth in a Bladder, becau≈øe of the re≈øemblance the Humour in the Heart-bag hath to that in the bladder of Urine; though at the ≈øame time he denies this Water or Humour to have any acrimony or bracki≈øhne≈øs, as the Water contained in the bladder of Urine hath.

And to confirm this Opinion of his, that this Humour contained in the Heart-bag doth proceed from Liquors taken in at the Mouth, he cites an Experiment to be tried on a Pigg, (though I ≈øuppo≈øe any other Creature may ≈øerve as well) which after it is kept fa≈øting for ≈øome time ≈øhould have given it to drink Water or Milk mingled with Vermillion, and after
it hath drunk it, ≈øhould immediately be killed, and as ≈øoon after as po≈ø≈øible have his Wind-pipe opened, and al≈øo all or mo≈øt of its branches, in which, ≈øaith my Authour, you will find along all its in≈øide, the colour of the Liquor which it drank, even to the extremities or ends of the ≈ømalle≈øt Pipes; out of which Pipes (≈øaith he) part of it is di≈øtilled into the Heart-bag. I confe≈øs this is no very probable Opinion, but I mention it for the great antiquity and fame of the Authour of it.

But other Authours are of opinions contrary to this, ≈øome ≈øaying that it proceeds from a moi≈øture, ≈ølaver or ≈øpittle, which di≈øtils out of the Kernels under the Tongue into the Weazand, and from thence into the Arteries and Heart, and ≈øo into the Heart-bag. But this is as improbable as the former.

A late Learned Authour thinks that it i≈ø≈øues out of certain Glands or Kernels ≈øeated at the ba≈øis of the Heart. And this is an Opinion that is ≈øomewhat likely, though I think the next is to be preferr'd before it.

La≈øtly, Others (among≈øt whom is Bartholin) See Bartholin, lib. 2. chap. 5. conceive that it proceeds from moi≈øt Vapours and Exhalations forced out of the Humours of the Heart by the motion and heat thereof, which being ≈øtopt by the clo≈øene≈øs of the Heart-bag, are by its re≈øpective coldne≈øs congealed into Water.

The u≈øe of this Water or Humour is, in the fir≈øt place, to keep the Heart moi≈øt and cool; for the Heart being a very hot Part, requires ≈øomething of this nature to cool it, e≈øpecially if that be true which ≈øome report of the left Ventricle, that it hath been found in live Di≈ø≈øections ≈øo hot, as almo≈øt to ≈øcald the Di≈ø≈øector's finger which he put into it.

By this Humour the Heart al≈øo becometh more ea≈øy in its motion, for by it, it is as it were born or buoy'd up, ≈øo that it ≈øwimmeth in a manner, whereby the ≈øen≈øe or feeling of the weight of it is taken away.

Such a Humour as this before-≈øpoken of is al≈øo found in the cavity of the Che≈øt, onely ≈øomething of a more ruddy colour, looking like Water and Bloud mingled together; and this I have never found wanting, but that there hath been ≈øome either little or much; with which moi≈øture the Parts of the Che≈øt are moi≈øtened and cooled, even as the Heart is by the moi≈øture contained in the Heart-bag.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Heart.

argument.p: The Heart a principal Part. From whence it derives its name Cor. Its ≈øituation. Why the Pul≈øe is felt on the left ≈øide and not the right. The motion of the Heart. The rea≈øon of the Pul≈øe. The figure of the Heart. Its ≈øub≈øtance. Its connexion. Its External Parts. Its Coat. Its Fat. The difference between the Fat of the Heart and other Fat. The External Ve≈ø≈øels of the Heart. One Vein. Two Arteries. Their Valves. Nerves.

div.p: THERE is none can be ≈øo ignorant of the Parts of the Body, as not to know that the Heart is one of the principal Parts thereof: for as it is the fountain of the Vital faculty and power, it ought to be ≈øo ≈øtyled. It is al≈øo the place of natural heat, the root of the Arteries from whence they all ≈øpring. It is moreover the Authour of the Pul≈øe, and the fir≈øt Bowel living (as I ≈øhall more at large declare in the following Chapter) and the la≈øt dying.
It is called in Latine Cor, √† currendo from running, becau≈øe of its continual motion.

It is onely one in number, ≈øituated in the mid≈øt of the cavity of the Che≈øt, as well for its ≈øecurity, as for the equal ballancing of that part of the Body; in which place it is incompa≈ø≈øed by the Lobes of the Lungs.

Yet notwith≈øtanding the ≈øituation of it in the middle part of the Che≈øt, it is to be under≈øtood that not the whole Heart but onely the ba≈øis or root of it is directly in the middle; for the point of it leans toward the left ≈øide, by rea≈øon of the ≈ømallne≈øs of the compa≈øs it hath to perform its motion in; for it would be apt to ≈øtrike again≈øt the Midriff, ≈øhould it not be ≈øo drawn to one ≈øide, which would not onely hinder its own motion, but al≈øo indanger the violating of the Midriff and hinder its motion; for it al≈øo is known to have a perpetual motion as well as the Heart.

And it is from the point of the Heart's inclining to the left ≈øide, that the motion of the Heart or its pul≈øe is ≈øo plain to be felt on that ≈øide: which not being equally to be felt on the right, many, who have not taken the pains of looking or in≈øpecting into Bodies to ≈øee the contrary, do conclude, that the Heart is ≈øituated altogether on the left ≈øide, and that it is not the point alone which they feel beat, but the whole Heart.

Another rea≈øon there is why it ≈øhould incline to the left ≈øide, namely, becau≈øe the a≈øcendent Trunk of Vena cava lieth on the right ≈øide, ≈øo that were the point not drawn ≈øomething to the other ≈øide, it would be apt
to lie upon or ≈øtrike again≈øt that Ve≈ø≈øel, and ≈øo hinder the a≈øcent of the Bloud which is brought from the Liver by that Vein to the Heart.

The Heart has a double motion, Contraction called its ≈øy≈øtole, and Relaxation called its dia≈øtole. (Though this latter may rather be deemed a cea≈øing from motion, than a motion.) While it is relaxed or becomes flaggy and loo≈øe, it receives the Bloud into its Ventricles out of the hollow Vein and Lung-vein; out of the former into its right Ventricle, and out of the latter into its left. And when it contracts it ≈øelf, it expels or ≈øquirts out the Bloud out of its Ventricles into the Lung-artery and great Artery; out of the right Ventricle into the Lung-artery, and out of the left into the great Artery.

As to the pul≈øation or beating of the Heart, it is very difficult, if not impo≈ø≈øible to give any ≈øatisfactory rea≈øon of it. Some impute it to the flowing in of the Animal Spirits by the Nerves; others to the boiling and rarefaction of the Bloud in its Ventricles. 'Tis mo≈øt certain that the mu≈øcular Fibres of the Heart are the immediate in≈øtruments of its motion, and that the≈øe receive their power to move, from the Animal Spirits conveyed by the Nerves: but what it is that puts the≈øe Fibres upon ≈øuch a reciprocal motion of contraction and relaxation as the Heart ob≈øerves, is the greate≈øt difficulty to determine. The greate≈øt Anatomi≈øts have confe≈øt their ignorance in this point: I ≈øhall not therefore pretend to give a rea≈øon of it, but admire the wi≈øedom of the great Creator in framing ≈øuch an Engine, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary for the conveying life, heat and nouri≈øhment to all the Parts of the Body. Waving this then, I ≈øhall proceed to the further de≈øcription of the Heart.

The figure of the Heart is pyramidal or conick, that is, it is broad at the ba≈øis or bottom, and narrow at its ≈øummity or top. On the fore-≈øide it is bo≈ø≈øy or bunching, but on the hinder ≈øide more flat. It is ≈øometimes longer and ≈øometimes ≈øhorter, as thus: When in its motion it is contracted (at which time it pours out the Bloud) then is it ≈øhorter, but broader; and again when it is dilated, at which time it receives in the Bloud, then is it longer and narrower.

Its ≈øub≈øtance is a ≈øolid, thick and compact fle≈øh, that it might the better indure the perpetuity of the motion, and with more force drive the Bloud into the extreme or farthe≈øt Parts of the Body. It con≈øi≈øteth mo≈øtly of mu≈øculary or fle≈øhy Fibres, a few of which run ≈øtreight and are outmo≈øt, but the far greate≈øt part run ≈ølanting or rather ≈øpiral-wi≈øe, e≈øpecially towards its point, re≈øembling ≈øomewhat the winding-rings of a Snail's ≈øhell.
It is tied by the mediation of the Heart-bag to the Media≈øtinum and by its own Ve≈ø≈øels to ≈øeveral Parts of the Body.
Its Parts are ≈øome External and ≈øome Internal. Tho≈øe which be External or outward, are the Pur≈øe, the Coat, and the Fat; to which may be added ≈øome of its Ve≈ø≈øels.

As to the Pur≈øe or Heart-bag, we have treated of it in the foregoing Chapter. As to the Ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øome of them encompa≈øs the Heart, as the Coronary Vein and Arteries; others reach into its Entrances and into the Ventricles, and tho≈øe are the A≈øcendent and De≈øcendent Trunks of the hollow Vein and Great Artery, al≈øo the Pulmonary Ve≈ø≈øels. Of the Coronaries we ≈øhall ≈øpeak by and by in this Chapter; but of the re≈øt, in the next.

It hath a Coat proper to it ≈øelf, like the Coat of a Mu≈øcle, for its greater firmne≈øs, which Coat ≈øticks ≈øo clo≈øe to it, that it is hard to be ≈øeparated or removed from it. It is the ≈øame with the outer Coat of the Great Artery, as that Skin which cloaths the in≈øide of its Ventricles is continued unto and con≈øtitutes the inmo≈øt Membrane of that Artery.

The Heart becau≈øe of its continual motion and great heat, is plentifully ≈øtored with Fat, to keep it from being over-dried, which Fat is mo≈øt of it placed at the ba≈øis or bottom of it; for its point hanging in the Humour contained in the Heart-bag is continually moi≈øtned with that, ≈øo that it ≈øtands not in need of being moi≈øtned or cooled any other way.

Yet thus much notice is to be taken, as to this Fat which grows to the Heart, that it differs in con≈øi≈øtence from all or mo≈øt of the other Fat of the whole Body, as being much harder: for ≈øhould the Heart, which is a very hot Part, have any ≈øuch ≈øoft Fat near it, it would certainly melt it. And as the Fat which grows or ≈øticks to the remoter Parts of the Body differs from this in nature, ≈øo hath it al≈øo a name different from this; for the former is called pimele, which ≈øignifies a kind of grea≈øie Fat; but the latter is called Adeps, which is to ≈øay Tallow, and is indeed as hard as Tallow, differing much from pimele or Grea≈øe.

Next come we to the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Heart, and of the≈øe it is furni≈øhed with all ≈øorts; ≈øome of which do compa≈øs it round about at its ba≈øis, like a Garland, which are one Vein and two Arteries.

The Vein, from its encompa≈ø≈øing or encircling it round, is called Coronaria, or the Crown-vein, which Vein ari≈øes from the Trunk of the hollow Vein a little before its entrance into the right Earlet of the Heart. Small branches do ≈øpring from this Coronary Vein, and are di≈øper≈øed or ≈øprinkled all down the ≈øurface or out≈øide of the Heart from the ba≈øis to the point.

Its Arteries are in number two, which are al≈øo called Coronariae or Crown-arteries, from their encircling the Heart as the Vein does, where like it they di≈øper≈øe ≈ømall branches about all the external ≈øurface of the Heart, furni≈øhing it with arterial Bloud for its life and nouri≈øhment.

There is ob≈øerved at the original of each of the≈øe Arteries, as is likewi≈øe in the Vein, a certain Valve which is to be ≈øeen if you di≈ø≈øect either Ve≈ø≈øel, opening it a little before it pa≈ø≈øeth out of the Heart-bag; which Valve or Floud-gate in the Vein lets the Bloud into the Heart, but ≈øuffers none to come out again that way; and in the Artery it permits the Bloud to i≈ø≈øue out of the Heart, but will let none return back out of it into the Heart.
The Heart is al≈øo furni≈øhed with very many but very ≈ømall Nerves, ≈øpringing from branches of the eighth pair, which branches are tho≈øe that are ≈øent to the Heart-bag.
They branch into and enter the Heart in three ≈øeveral places; fir≈øt, one enters into the Heart it ≈øelf, another into the Earlets of the Heart, and a third into its Ve≈ø≈øels.
Thus much of the Parts of the Heart which in ≈øome regard may be called External; in the next Chapter we ≈øhall proceed to tho≈øe that are more Internal.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Ventricles, internal Ve≈ø≈øels, Valves and Earlets of the Heart.

argument.p: The right Ventricle. Its figure. Its ≈øub≈øtance. Its u≈øe. Why Fi≈øh have but one Ventricle. The left Ventricle. Its largene≈øs. Its figure. Its ≈øides are thicker, and harder than tho≈øe of the right. Its u≈øe. The in≈øides of the Ventricles. The ≈øeptum. Its pores. The internal Ve≈ø≈øels of the Heart. Vena cava and vena Arterio≈øa belong to the right Ventricle; Arteria veno≈øa and Aorta to the left. Three Valves to the Vena cava, called tricu≈øpides. Three al≈øo to the vena Arterio≈øa, called ≈øigmoideae. Two to the Arteria veno≈øa, called mitrales. Three to the Aorta, called ≈øemilunares. The auriculae of the Heart. Their ≈øurface. Their ≈øub≈øtance. Their motion. Their u≈øe.

div.p: WE will fir≈øt ≈øpeak of the Ventricles or Sinus's of the Heart, being in number two, on each ≈øide one, di≈øtingui≈øhed or divided by a fle≈øhy partition into a right and a left.

The right (called the right Sinus or Ventricle, and by ≈øome the Cave or Chamber) is ≈øomewhat bigger than the left, becau≈øe it receives as well that Bloud which is ≈øpent upon the nouri≈øhment of the Lungs, through which the Bloud pa≈ø≈øes from this Ventricle to the left, as that which actually is conveyed into the left, and from thence ≈øent forth by the Arteries into all parts of the Body. But its larger capacity is onely in re≈øpect of its width, for the left is rather longer than it, as reaching nearer the tip of the Heart.
It is in figure not exactly round, but rather ≈øemicircular, or half-moon fa≈øhioned.

The ≈øub≈øtance of its ≈øides is not ≈øo hard and thick as is that of the left,nor is the ≈øurface of its inner cavity ≈øo uneven; nor has it ≈øo many and ≈øo ≈øtrong fle≈øhy Fibres reaching this way and that way, as the left hath. For it was not nece≈ø≈øary it ≈øhould be of ≈øo ≈øtrong a compo≈øure as the left, ≈øeeing neither is the Bloud rarefied ≈øo much in it, nor does it ≈øend the Bloud out of it to any greater di≈øtance than the Lungs, whereas the left pours it into the remote≈øt Parts of the Body, and therefore requires a ≈øtronger con≈øtitution to ≈øquirt it out.

The u≈øe of this Ventricle is fir≈øt to receive the Bloud out of the hollow Vein returning from the circulation, as al≈øo the Chyle and Lympha mingled with the Bloud, out of the axillar Vein, and then to attenuate, concoct and in≈øpirit them for the nouri≈øhment of the Lungs, to which they
are carried under the form of Bloud by the Pulmonary Artery, otherwi≈øe called the Arterial vein. But it is but a very ≈ømall portion of the Bloud that is ≈øpent upon the Lungs, the greate≈øt part of it pa≈ø≈øing by the Pulmonary Vein to the left Ventricle, there to receive a greater perfection.

Now it is worth ob≈øervation in this place, that ≈øuch Creatures as live in the Water, as Fi≈øh in general, which have no Lungs, have but one Ventricle in their Heart. For the rea≈øon why Animals that live upon the Land have two Ventricles, being, that the Bloud as it pa≈ø≈øes from one to the other, ≈øhould be conveyed through the Lungs, there to be ventilated and cooled by the Air drawn in in in≈øpiration; and ≈øeeing Fi≈øh live in a cold Element, viz. the Water, which encompa≈ø≈øes their whole Body, that, of it ≈øelf, is ≈øufficient to attemper the heat of the Bloud; therefore as it is impo≈ø≈øible they ≈øhould make any u≈øe of Lungs in the Water, ≈øo there ≈øeems to be no need of them, nor con≈øequently of two Ventricles in the Heart, which are nece≈ø≈øary for Land-animals that have Lungs, and breathe in the free Air. How far Water approaches to the nature of Air, or whether there be any truly airy particles contained in the pores of the Water; and if there be, whether there be any way imaginable whereby they can in≈øinuate them≈øelves into the Bloud and Hearts of Fi≈øhes, are Points too nice and philo≈øophical for me to intermeddle with. But ≈øeeing Fi≈øh can live ≈øo brisk for very many years without re≈øpiration (at lea≈øt properly ≈øo called, or that we can conceive of) one would ≈øu≈øpect that ≈øome of our late Anatomi≈øts attribute too much virtue to the Air that we breathe in, as if it were the All that continues the Vital flame as they ≈øpeak, and that the Vital heat and ≈øpirit are no otherwi≈øe owing to the Heart, than as like an Engine it keeps the Bloud in motion, and di≈øtributes it with the Spirits into all Parts of the Body by the Arteries. But this by the bye.

Next come we to the left Ventricle, which in magnitude doth not equal the former, it being much le≈øs, by rea≈øon it is to contain a le≈øs quantity of Bloud than the right Ventricle doth, part of that Bloud that comes out of the right, being ≈øpent upon the nouri≈øhment of the Lungs, before it reaches the left.

This left Ventricle differs al≈øo in figure from the right: for as the right is ob≈øerved to be ≈øemicircular, the left is almo≈øt round and longer, reaching almo≈øt down to the point of the Heart, which the other doth not.

Likewi≈øe the fle≈øh or wall of the left is much thicker than that of the other, and that partly becau≈øe of the ≈ømallne≈øs of the cavity, which the narrower it is, mu≈øt needs leave the ≈øides ≈øo much the thicker. Onely the left ≈øide of this Ventricle near the lower end or tip of the Heart, is thinner than any part of the ≈øides of the right.

Al≈øo it is harder and more compact than the other, that the Vital Spirits might not exhale or evaporate, and that its con≈øtriction might be the ≈øtronger, ≈øo that the Bloud might with more force be thrown or pul≈øt out and vented into the farthe≈øt parts of the Body.

Into this Ventricle is the Bloud received out of the Lungs by the Pulmonary Vein (otherwi≈øe called the veinous Artery.) Which Bloud when it is ≈øquirted out of this Ventricle into the great Artery, differs very much in colour from that which i≈ø≈øues out of the right Ventricle into the Pulmonary Artery: for this latter is of a dark purple colour, but the former of a florid ≈øcarlet. But mo≈øt think that this alteration of colour is not
≈øo much owing to any ≈øupereminent virtue in this Ventricle above the right, as to the particles of Air that in≈øinuate them≈øelves into the Bloud in the Lungs whiles it pa≈ø≈øes out of the Pulmonary Artery into the Pulmonary Vein; for Dr. Lower affirmeth, that if in Live-di≈ø≈øections one open the Pulmonary Vein in its pa≈ø≈øage from the Lungs to the left Ventricle, the Bloud will appear to be of the ≈øame ≈øcarlet colour as when it comes out of the ≈øaid Ventricle. Suppo≈øing this to be ≈øo (which I think we may do upon the te≈øtimony of ≈øo worthy and creditable an Authour) yet it cannot be denied but that the airy particles mu≈øt be more intimately mixed with the Bloud by the great agitation it receives in the left Ventricle, ≈øo that we may ≈øtill con≈øent to the Ancients, that Vital Spirits (in which, Air ≈øeems to be a main Ingredient) are perfected and rectified to their height (as it were) in it more than in the right. The u≈øe therefore of the left Ventricle is to perfect the Vital Spirits, and to tran≈ømit them, together with the Bloud, by the Arteries over all the Body, for the pre≈øervation of the Vital heat, and for the nouri≈øhment of each Part.

The in≈øides of both the Ventricles are unequal or uneven and rugged,being hollowed into many furrows di≈øtingui≈øhed by fle≈øhy Fibres, that the Bloud which comes into the Heart might be the more agitated in them, and thereby more intimately mixed with the Chyle and Air that come along with it, the fir≈øt into the right Ventricle, and both into the left. From the≈øe fle≈øhy Fibres are nervous ones extended to the Valves, of which we ≈øhall di≈øcour≈øe by and by. They are more numerous and ≈øtronger in the left Ventricle than in the right, becau≈øe a ≈øtronger con≈øtriction was nece≈ø≈øary for the former than for the latter, ≈øeeing from the former Bloud is ≈øent to all Parts of the Body, but from the latter to no greater di≈øtance than the Lungs, as was ob≈øerved before. The≈øe Fibres, Furrows and Valves you may ≈øee very well expre≈øt in the following Figure.

The≈øe Ventricles are divided by a Wall called the ≈øeptum or partition,which is nothing el≈øe but the right wall of the left Ventricle; wherefore its right ≈øide is bunched, but the left hollow. On its left ≈øide it is furrowed and unequal as the re≈øt of the Ventricle is, but on the right it is well nigh ≈ømooth. It is a very ancient opinion, that there are a great many large pores or holes in this ≈øeptum, whereby the thinne≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øpirituous part of the Bloud pa≈ø≈øes out of the right Ventricle into the left immediately, without taking that circuit through the Lungs that the re≈øt doth. They are ≈øaid to be wider on its right ≈øide, and going ≈ølanting to grow narrower towards the left. There are many Modern as well as Ancient Vouchers of this opinion: among≈øt whom is Bartholin, who having enumerated ≈øeveral Anatomi≈øts that have affirmed to have ≈øeen them them≈øelves, ≈øays that he him≈øelf has ≈øeen the ≈øeptum of a Hog's Heart ≈ølantingly pervious in ≈øeveral places with great and manife≈øt pores, ≈øo large as to admit a pretty big Pea≈øe, and lying open without a Probe, which being put into any one of them on the right ≈øide pa≈ø≈øed to the left Ventricle, where a thin Membrane did hang before the mouth of the Pore like an Ana≈øtomo≈øis (as he calls it, I ≈øuppo≈øe he means a Valve) which hindred the putting in the Probe on that ≈øide, and con≈øequently mu≈øt have hindred the return of the Bloud out of the left Ventricle into the right when the Animal was living. And he thinks that the ≈øeptum is nouri≈øhed by the Bloud that pa≈ø≈øes through the≈øe Pores, ≈øeeing the Coronary Veins (abovede≈øcribed) run onely through the ≈øurface or out≈øide of the Heart. And
he will have not onely the more ≈øpirituous part of the Bloud, but the thinner part of the Chyle al≈øo to pa≈øs through them. It would be tedious to recite all tho≈øe Authours that he quotes to ≈øecond him, as al≈øo his Apology for their often not-appearing in many dead Bodies, ≈øeeing there are many pa≈ø≈øages be≈øides the≈øe in Live-creatures, that there are no foot≈øteps of after they are dead: for as it ≈øeems not likely that the ≈øeptum ≈øhould be nouri≈øhed by bloud that pa≈ø≈øes ≈øo rapidly through the≈øe ≈øuppo≈øed holes; ≈øo by the carefulle≈øt examination of other skilfull Anatomi≈øts there have been no ≈øuch holes to be found, unle≈øs they were fir≈øt made by the Probe; though indeed there are ≈øeveral pits that look as if they went through, which I believe to be onely framed for the greater agitation of the bloud in the Ventricle.

In the foregoing Chapter we de≈øcribed tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels that may be called external from their running chiefly on the out≈øide of the Heart,(commonly named the Coronary) by which it is nouri≈øhed: but there are another ≈øort that may be termed internal, which are ≈øuch as open into and out of its Ventricles or inward Sinus's, but yield no nouri≈øhment to it. The≈øe are four, the Vena cava, and pulmonary Artery; the pulmonary Vein, and great Artery.

Of the≈øe, the Vena cava or hollow Vein, and the Vena Arterio≈øa or pulmonary Artery do belong to the right Ventricle; the hollow Vein filling it with venal bloud returning from all Parts of the Body, which it receives in when the Heart is relaxed, which ≈øtate is called its dia≈øtole; and the pulmonary Artery carrying forth the ≈øaid bloud into the Lungs when the Heart is contracted, which ≈øtate of the Heart is called its ≈øy≈øtole.

To the left Ventricle do al≈øo belong two Ve≈ø≈øels, namely, Arteria veno≈øa or the pulmonary Vein, and Aorta or the great Artery. The pulmonary Vein within the ≈øub≈øtance of the Lungs doth receive the bloud from the pulmonary Artery, and pours it into the left Ventricle, there to kindle and ventilate the vital flame, and to perfect the arterial bloud and ≈øpirits. The great Artery is the trunk from which all other Arteries do branch, and through which the arterial bloud (after it is in this Ventricle perfected as afore≈øaid) is di≈øper≈øed or thrown into all the Parts of the Body, for the life and nouri≈øhment thereof.

Now to each of the≈øe four Ve≈ø≈øels do belong Valves, for the better performance of their offices before ≈øpoken of. And fir≈øt to the hollow Vein do belong three, which are of a triangular figure, and are from that ≈øigure called treble-pointed Valves. They are placed at the ba≈øis or bottom of the Heart at the entrance of the ≈øaid Vein into the Heart, and do look from without inward, that ≈øo they may admit of the bloud's pa≈ø≈øing through them into the Heart, but ≈øuffer none to pa≈øs out again that way.

To the pulmonary Artery do al≈øo belong three Valves, which, contrary to the former, look from within outward, and from the re≈øemblance they have with the letter C, are called Sigma-fa≈øhioned, the old Greek Sigma being of that ≈øhape. The≈øe Valves as the former are placed at the ba≈øis of the Heart, and at the entrance or rather outlet of the Ventricle. And their u≈øe is, to let the bloud, brought into this Ventricle by the hollow Vein, pa≈øs again out of the ≈øaid Ventricle into the pulmonary Artery, to be carried by it into the Lungs; but they will not admit of any bloud to return from the Lungs into it.

To the pulmonary Vein do belong two Valves, which look from without inward, as the treble-pointed Valves do, and their u≈øe is to admit of the bloud brought out of the Lungs by the pulmonary Vein, into the left Ventricle, but they will ≈øuffer none to pa≈øs by that Vein back to the Lungs again. The≈øe, from the re≈øemblance they are ≈øaid to have with a Bi≈øhop's Mitre, are called Mitre-≈øhaped Valves.

To the Arteria magna or great Artery do al≈øo belong three Valves,which go by the name of Semilunary or Half-moon-fa≈øhioned Valves. Their u≈øe is to hinder any bloud from returning into the left Ventricle out of the great Artery; but they permit the Bloud to pa≈øs by them out of the Heart into the ≈øaid Artery, from whence it is ≈øent by its ≈øeveral branches into all the Parts of the Body.

Having ≈øpoken to the Ventricles, Ve≈ø≈øels and Valves of the Heart, we are in the next place come to treat of the two Appendices or Proce≈ø≈øes which are placed at the bottom or ba≈øis of it, and are called the Ears or Earlets of the Heart, from ≈øome re≈øemblance in ≈øhape which they have to the Ears of the Head. They are in number two, to each ≈øide of the Heart one, an≈øwerable to the number of the Ventricles. Of the≈øe, the right is larger, but ≈øofter; the left le≈ø≈øer, but harder. The right is larger, becau≈øe the orifice of the hollow Vein belonging to the right Ventricle, is much bigger and larger than the orifice of the pulmonary Vein belonging to the left Ventricle. For it was not needfull that the Lung-vein ≈øhould be ≈øo large as the hollow Vein, ≈øeeing the bloud that it conducts to the left Ventricle is neither ≈øo much as that which is brought by the cava to the right, and be≈øides is thinner and more ≈øpirituous being impregnated with Air in the Lungs, and therefore pa≈ø≈øing more quickly needs the narrower channel.
The external part or ≈øurface of them, when full or extended, is ≈ømooth and bunching; but when empty, wrinkled.

Their ≈øub≈øtance is peculiar, ≈øuch as is to be found in no other part,thin and ≈øoft that they might be the ea≈øilier contracted, and yet nervous and ≈øtrong, that they might endure that continual motion to which they are de≈øtin'd. Of the two, the left is the more compact, thick and fle≈øhy. On their in≈øide they have Fibres running from their ba≈øis where they are joined to the Heart, towards their top where the Veins enter them, (≈øuch as the Ventricles of the Heart them≈øelves have) by help whereof they contract them≈øelves in their ≈øy≈øtole, and ≈øqueeze the bloud contained in them, into the Ventricles.

The≈øe Ears or Earlets have (as the Heart it ≈øelf hath) two motions,fir≈øt the ≈øy≈øtole or contractive, next the dia≈øtole or dilative motion. There is al≈øo betwixt the≈øe two motions (both in the Ears and Heart) a re≈øt or pau≈øe, ea≈øy to be di≈øcerned in ≈øick Hor≈øes, or Hor≈øes ready to die, but not ≈øo ea≈øy to be either di≈øcerned or felt in a ≈øound or healthfull Hor≈øe; for in ≈øuch, the motions are performed ≈øo ≈øwiftly, that there ≈øeems to be an immediate pa≈ø≈øage from one to the other, without any intermi≈ø≈øion or re≈øting between. This pau≈øe or re≈øt between the two motions, is called peri≈øy≈øtole.

The ≈øy≈øtole and dia≈øtole of both Earlets do happen at one and the ≈øame time; for when the right undergoes its dia≈øtole, then and at the very ≈øame in≈øtant the left undergoes the ≈øame. And they do the like in the ≈øy≈øtole. But though the Heart hath the ≈øame motions as the≈øe Earlets have, yet it doth not perform them when the≈øe do; for the ≈øy≈øtole of the Earlets happens at the ≈øame time with the dia≈øtole of the Ventricles; and on
the contrary, the ≈øy≈øtole of the Ventricles, with the dia≈øtole of the Earlets.

Now the u≈øe of the≈øe Ears or Earlets is, to prevent the too violent ru≈øhing in of the bloud out of the Cava and Lung-vein into the Ventricles of the Heart, whereby both the Valves might have been violated, and the Vital faculty ≈øuffocated. For the≈øe receiving the bloud out of the ≈øaid Veins, do mea≈øure it as it were into the Heart, ≈øo much bloud di≈øtilling out of tho≈øe Veins into the≈øe Earlets in each of their dia≈øtole's, as can be conveniently rarefied and elaborated at one time in the Ventricles.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the Organs of Breathing, and their ∆≤≈øe; viz. of the Lungs, and Wind-pipe.

argument.p: The names of the Lungs. Their ≈øituation and Lobes. Their ≈øub≈øtance. The Wind-pipe. The Parts of the Wind-pipe. Whether any part of the drink pa≈øs by the Wind-pipe into the Lungs. The coats of the Wind-pipe. The Gri≈øtles which make the Wind-pipe. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its divi≈øion. Its u≈øes. The Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels of the Lungs. Their Lympheducts. Their Nerves. Their inve≈øting Membrane. Their action and u≈øe.

div.p: THE Lungs, which are the chief In≈øtruments of breathing or re≈øpiration,are called in Latin Pulmones, in Greek Pneumones, from their office of drawing in and blowing out the Breath or Air.

Their ≈øituation is in the cavity or hollowne≈øs of the Che≈øt, which cavity they almo≈øt fill up; e≈øpecially when they are di≈øtended or filled with wind. They are divided into two equal parts called Lobes, one of which lies on the right ≈øide of the Media≈øtinum, or Partition-membrane of the Che≈øt, and the other on the left.

Their ≈øub≈øtance hath hitherto been taken to be a parenchyma or fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance; but by the diligent ≈øearching into Nature of ≈øome of our Modern Authors, e≈øpecially of an Italian named Malpighius, they have been found of a contrary ≈øub≈øtance; for he affirms them to be excarnous or without fle≈øh, and merely membranous, made up of the branches of the Wind-pipe and little bladders at the ends of them, likewi≈øe of the pulmonary Ve≈ø≈øels, and the Skin that cloaths them. But the greate≈øt part of their ≈øub≈øtance con≈øi≈øts of the little bladders.

This that worthy Man experienced by ca≈øting Water into the Lungs of ≈øome Creatures he di≈ø≈øected, while they were yet warm, ≈øo often till the whole frame of the Lungs appeared white; then ≈øqueezing the water clean out, he with a pair of Bellows or Pipe filled them by the Wind-pipe full of Air, and pent it in by tying the Windpipe; which done, he hung them up to dry; and when they were dried, he could di≈øcover (by holding them up to the light) the little bladders at the ends of each little branch of the Wind-pipe, as they are lively repre≈øented in Figures by that great Inquirer into Nature, the never to be forgotten Doctor Willis,
See Willis Part 2. Sect. 1. cap. 1. of his Pharmaceutice rationalis. ju≈øtly ≈øtyled the honour of his Univer≈øity and Country, in the ≈øecond Part of his Book called Pharmaceutice rationalis.

Again, ≈øaith the forementioned Malpighius, If you cut any part of the Lungs thus dried, you may very plainly ≈øee a great number of the≈øe bladders looking white. Moreover he affirms that by the help of a Micro≈øcope he could di≈øcern a certain wonderfull Net as it were, tying all the≈øe bladders to one another, which he conceived to be made up of the ≈ømall branchings of the pulmonary Artery and Vein, which Ve≈ø≈øels convey the bloud through
the ≈ølender and winding ducts, and through the manifold bendings of the Pipes. And be≈øides the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels which make this Net, Doctor Willis ≈øaith that there are another ≈øort to be perceived in living Di≈ø≈øections, which are called Lympheducts, and are di≈øper≈øed all over the Lungs. Of what nature and u≈øe the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels are, we have ≈øhewn above in the Fir≈øt Book, chap. 12. and ≈øhall do further by and by. And la≈øtly, he ≈øays there are abundance of twigs of Nerves di≈øtributed every-where through them. Onely one thing further is to be noted concerning the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Lungs from the ≈øaid Doctor's ob≈øervation, that the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels thereof are not onely branches of the pulmonary Artery and Vein, but al≈øo ≈øome proceed from the Aorta it ≈øelf; which ≈øhould ≈øeem to intimate that the Lungs are truly nouri≈øhed by the≈øe la≈øt, as are all other Parts of the Body, and that the bloud that comes to the Lungs from the right Ventricle of the Heart by the pulmonary Artery, and returns to the left by the pulmonary Vein, pa≈ø≈øes not this way for the nouri≈øhment of the Lungs, but onely that it may be impregnated with Air, without which as it wants of its perfection, ≈øo is it unfit and unable to pre≈øerve the vital heat of any Part, or to contribute any nouri≈øhment to it. But this onely by the bye.

div.p: Now the ≈øeveral things here named, of which the Lungs are compo≈øed or framed, do plainly ≈øhew their ≈øub≈øtance is not carnous or fle≈øhy, but merely fi≈øtulous, being compacted of Pipes of ≈øeveral kinds and magnitude, and variou≈øly and intricately di≈øpo≈øed; which Pipes we will particularly ≈øpeak to in order, and fir≈øt of the chief of them, which is the Wind-pipe, called A≈øpera Arteria the rough Artery.

The A≈øpera Arteria is a Pipe or Chanel which de≈øcends down the Neck beginning in the Throat at the root of the Tongue, and reaches as far as the Lungs, in which it di≈øper≈øes it ≈øelf into innumerable branches great and ≈ømall, which branches reach to all the extreme parts of their
≈øub≈øtance, and at la≈øt end in little bladders, each of them in re≈øemblance like a Grape, into which they conveigh the Air in in≈øpiration. The≈øe Grape-like Bladders are lively repre≈øented by Doctor Willis Willis Pharmaceut. Ration. Part. 2. ≈øect. 1. cap. 1. in a Lobe of the Lungs of an Ox, as you may ≈øee in the fir≈øt Figure of the third Table in his ≈øecond Part of the operation of Medicines; of which bladders you may there reade more at large.

The fore-mentioned Wind-pipe is by Anatomi≈øts divided into three principal parts, viz. the Larynx or Throttle, which is the upper end of it (of which more afterwards.) The ≈øecond part between the Larynx and the Lungs, being a long Pipe, is called particularly Trachea or a≈øpera Arteria, the rough Artery; rough, to di≈øtingui≈øh it from the ≈ømooth Arteries which contain the bloud and vital ≈øpirits; and an Artery, becau≈øe it keeps or contains the Air in re≈øpiration. The la≈øt part of the Wind-pipe is di≈øtingui≈øh'd by the name of bronchus or bronchia, which includes the ramifications or branchings of it in the Lungs; though the name bronchus is ≈øometimes u≈øed to ≈øignify all of it.

Now before we pa≈øs on further to the de≈øcription of this Wind-pipe, it will not be ami≈øs to examine whether any part of the Liquors that an Hor≈øe drinks pa≈øs along it, or whether all go down the Gullet. That part of the drink glides down the Weazand was the opinion of the Ancient Phy≈øician Hippocrates, who experienced the ≈øame in an Hog newly killed, in who≈øe Lungs was found a quantity of Liquor of the ≈øame colour with that which the Hog had drunk a little before. And Bartholin thinks that the ≈øame thing may be proved from an ob≈øervation of Julius Ja≈øolin an Anatomi≈øt of the City of Naples, who ≈øeeking in the Body of a Noble Per≈øon the cau≈øe of his death, found his Heart-bag ≈øo filled with humour, that it being ≈øqueezed, ≈øome of the ≈øaid humour came out of his Mouth. But methinks it is an odd inference to conclude from hence, that therefore ≈øome part of the drink u≈øually pa≈ø≈øes down the Wind-pipe. For if one ≈øhould ≈øuppo≈øe that it did ≈øo pa≈øs, it cannot ea≈øily be imagined by what ways it could pa≈øs from thence to the Heart-bag; ≈øeeing all the branches of the Wind-pipe end in the Lungs, which are covered with a Membrane that never adheres to the Heart-bag, and very rarely if ever to the Media≈øtinum that comes between the Heart-bag and the Lungs. 'Tis true it ≈øeems ≈øomewhat ≈øtrange, that upon pre≈ø≈øing the Heart-bag, the liquor contained in it ≈øhould come up at the Mouth; but if the matter of fact be true, it mu≈øt do ≈øo by ≈øome preternatural pa≈ø≈øage, ≈øeeing every one that is skilled in Anatomy knows, that there is no communication between the Pericardium and a≈øpera Arteria. Indeed as to the great quantity of humour in the Heart-bag, I have ob≈øerved the ≈øame in Hor≈øes, in which I have ≈øeen both it and the Che≈øt extremely filled with liquor, but I dare not conclude from thence, that it came thither down the Wind-pipe; for ≈øeeing it has been onely in di≈øea≈øed Hor≈øes, that have been broken-winded and troubled with coughs, I am much rather inclined to think, that ≈øo great quantity of water proceeded from a Drop≈øie of the Che≈øt, which is a di≈øea≈øe not unfrequent in Mankind, in whom yet the be≈øt Anatomi≈øts deny that the lea≈øt drop of drink does naturally pa≈øs down their Wind-pipe: of which any one may be pretty well ≈øatisfied, that has ob≈øerved in him≈øelf or others, how when upon occa≈øion of laughing or the like in drinking, any of the drink pa≈ø≈øes down the wrong Throat as we ≈øay (which is down the Wind-pipe) the party falls pre≈øently into a mo≈øt violent cough. And as to Hippocrates's ob≈øervation, 'tis more likely the Hog's Lungs ≈øhould
be tinctured by ≈øome preternatural and di≈øea≈øed humour lodged in them, of a like colour to which his drink happened to be, than that they were tinctured by the drink it ≈øelf.
The Wind-pipe is covered with two coats or skins, one outward and the other inward.

The outwardmo≈øt is but of a rea≈øonable thickne≈øs, neither ≈øo thick nor ≈øo ≈øtrong as the other. It ≈øprings from the pleura or skin which inve≈øts the Ribs, and ≈øticks clo≈øe to the Ligaments of the Gri≈øtles, yea does it ≈øelf ≈øerve to knit them more firmly one to another, and is a mean of connecting the whole Pipe more ≈øtrongly to its neighbouring Parts. It al≈øo u≈øhers along the Nerves of the Wind-pipe and Lungs.

The innermo≈øt is thicker and more ≈øolid than the former, in the Throttle e≈øpecially, who≈øe in≈øide it covers, as al≈øo all the in≈øide of the Wind-pipe and its branches from thence to the bottom of the Lungs. It has two rows of Mu≈øcular Fibres, the outer ≈øtreight, the inner ≈ølanting; the fir≈øt ≈øerving to ≈øhorten the Wind-pipe, the latter to ≈øtraiten it. And one rea≈øon of the great ≈øtrength of this Membrane ≈øeems to be, that it might the better endure the violent motion of coughing without being injured. It is very ≈øen≈øible, and has its in≈øide be≈ømear'd u≈øually with a fatti≈øh or ≈ølimy humour, which likely is ≈øeparated in the Kernels of the Throat, and this ≈øerves to keep it moi≈øt and glib, that re≈øpiration may be performed with the greater ea≈øine≈øs and freedom.

Between the≈øe two coats or skins is the body or ≈øub≈øtance of the Wind-pipe,being partly of the nature of a Gri≈øtle and partly of a Ligament; for it is made up of many round Gri≈øtles like Rings, being pretty round on its fore-part, but on the back-part which is next to the Gullet a fourth part of the circle is wanting, in the room of which there is a thick, ≈øtrong and membranous ≈øub≈øtance, more ≈øoft than the Gri≈øtles, that the Gullet which lies upon it on that ≈øide, might not be hurt by them.
The≈øe Ring-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtles are joined together by ≈øtrong Ligaments, which Ligaments do every-where keep the Gri≈øtles at an equal di≈øtance one from the other.

div.p: The Wind-pipe like other Parts hath Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts; fir≈øt it hath Veins from the external Jugulars; Arteries from the Carotides; and Nerves from the recurrent Nerves of the wandring or eighth pair, (commonly reckoned for the ≈øixth.)

When it is de≈øcended about two hands-breadth into the Che≈øt, it is divided into two trunks, one whereof goes into the right Lobe of the Lungs, and the other into the left. Into which as ≈øoon as they are entred, each is again ≈øubdivided, and tho≈øe ≈øubdivi≈øions ≈øtill branch out into more, till they become very numerous and ≈ølender, and are di≈øper≈øed among the pulmonary Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels, but end into the little bladders above-de≈øcribed.

The u≈øe of the Wind-pipe is, fir≈øt, to ≈øerve as a nozle to a pair of Bellows,to wit, that the Lungs by the Air entring in by it may be heaved up. Whence when the in≈øide of it is ≈ølabby with too much flegmatick humour, or there happens to be any ob≈øtruction in it, or any of its branches in the Lungs, there follows a wheazing and ≈øhortne≈øs of breath, becau≈øe the Air has not a free ingre≈øs into the Lungs.

The next u≈øe of it is to let the Air out from the Lungs, and together with it ≈ømoaky vapours ≈øteaming through the pores of the Lungs out of the bloud. By help of it al≈øo, but e≈øpecially of the Throttle or upper part, does the Hor≈øe neigh, or whinney as they call it in ≈øome Countrys, while the Air is driven forcibly out of it in expiration. And thus much as to the Wind-pipe.

A ≈øecond ≈øort of Ve≈ø≈øel or Pipe di≈øper≈øed through the Lungs, and compo≈øing a con≈øiderable part of their bulk, are the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels, which are partly a branch from the great Artery, but principally the pulmonary Artery and Vein, who≈øe branches are ≈øpread to and fro in a great number through its whole ≈øub≈øtance, and there complicated and twi≈øted with the branches of the Wind-pipe, the Artery running along the under ≈øide and the Vein the upper ≈øide of it, both cleaving ≈øo clo≈øe to it that they are not ea≈øily to be ≈øeparated. The≈øe Arteries and Veins have communication one with another in ≈øeveral places by ana≈øtomo≈øes, the little twigs of the Arteries opening into tho≈øe of the Veins, for the readier circulation of the bloud through the Lungs. Mo≈øt admirable is the contexture of the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels about the Air-bladders; for their ≈ømall thred-like twigs are interwoven one with another with the mo≈øt curious artifice (≈øomewhat re≈øembling a Net) round about all of them; which mo≈øt probably is ≈øo done, to the end that all the particles of the bloud may be impregnated with Air, while it pa≈ø≈øes through the≈øe fine Ve≈ø≈øels that twine about the Air-bladders on all hands.
