div.p: A third ≈øort of Ve≈ø≈øel branching in the Lungs are the Lympheducts, ≈øo called from their office, which is to hold and convey a certain kind of water or humour called Lympha. The≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels we de≈øcribed more fully in Book I. chap. 12. Here they wait on the Veins and Arteries through the whole ≈øurface of the Lungs, and receive the humour or water that they contain from them, being fir≈øt ≈øeparated by the Glands; which humour ≈øeems to be a ≈øuperfluity of the bloud and it may be the nervous juice, which after they have received, they di≈øcharge into the thoracick duct, into which the greater branches of them are in≈øerted. Though the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels be but ≈ølender, yet they are of great u≈øe and nece≈ø≈øity; for as Doctor Willis affirms, if at any time any of the branches of them happen to be ob≈øtructed or broken, there follows thereupon in Man a Drop≈øie of the Lungs and Brea≈øt, oft-times accompanied with Coughs or Phthi≈øicks: and this happens, becau≈øe by their being ob≈øtructed or broken, the ≈øuperfluous humour which they like ≈øo many chanels u≈øe to contain or let pa≈øs through them and carry off, is left behind, or di≈øtils into the Che≈øt, which there breeds the ≈øore-mentioned Di≈øtempers. Which opinion of his confirms me in my belief of the original of that watery humour in a Hor≈øe, which I have very often in a plentifull manner found in his Thorax in di≈ø≈øection, as I have above in this Chapter already ≈øaid.

To the≈øe three ≈øorts of Ve≈ø≈øels a fourth is al≈øo added, which are the Nerves, with which they are well ≈øtored, having innumerable branches of them di≈øper≈øed through all their ≈øub≈øtance, accompanying the Bloudve≈ø≈øels and Pipes of the Wind-pipe; which Nerves do branch to them from the recurrent Nerves of the wandring pair.
Now the Lungs being thus interwoven with the≈øe four ≈øorts of Ve≈ø≈øels, are covered with a ≈øtrong skin, or indeed two skins, for it is no hard matter to ≈øeparate it into two.

The≈øe skins are furni≈øhed with very many pores or holes of an indifferent largene≈øs, plain to be ≈øeen (≈øaith Bartholin) if you blow up the Lungs with a pair of Bellows or Pipe. Which he doth not onely affirm that him≈øelf hath ≈øeen, but al≈øo quotes Johannes Waloeus, who (≈øaith he) hath ob≈øerved them to be in Live-anatomies as large as to contain a pretty big Pea≈øe. Such pores, perhaps, there may be di≈øcernible in Live-anatomies, though whether ≈øo large as to receive a Pea≈øe I ≈øomewhat
que≈øtion. Indeed I had never my ≈øelf the opportunity of ob≈øerving the Lungs in Creatures yet alive, but as ≈øoon as they have been dead, though I have made never ≈øo great ha≈øte to take the Lungs out before they ≈øhould be any thing cold, yet I could never ≈øee any of them, although I have blown the wind through the Wind-pipe with ≈øuch violence, that I have broke ≈øome of the ≈ømall branches of it, and with the ≈øaid wind have rai≈øed little bladders in the outer skin of the Lungs; I ≈øay notwith≈øtanding, I could never ≈øee or di≈øcern any of the≈øe little pores, that did let any of the ≈øaid wind out, but the wind hath continued in tho≈øe little bladders ≈øeveral days. Which experiment I alledge not with a de≈øign to di≈øprove tho≈øe worthy and learned Anatomi≈øts, that affirm to have ≈øeen them; but onely to ≈øhew that if any ≈øuch there be, nothing pa≈ø≈øes through them out of the Lungs into the Che≈øt. But now on the other hand, that ≈øomething may be received by them out of the cavity of the Che≈øt into the Lungs, is not improbable; ≈øeeing one cannot imagine how corrupt purulent matter collected in the Che≈øt from an Impo≈øthume breaking in it, or the like, ≈øhould by any other way get into the Wind-pipe, ≈øo as to be cough'd up, which it often is as well in Hor≈øes as in Men. If the inve≈øting skins be removed in any part of the Lungs, and afterwards one blow into them through the Wind-pipe, then will the Air i≈ø≈øue pretty ≈øtrongly out at the Breach. The outer of the skins is ≈ømooth and thin, but the inner is pretty thick, and on its in≈øide rough, appearing like an Honey-comb, by rea≈øon of the extremities of the Ve≈ø≈øels, and of the bladders ending at it. Both growing clo≈øe together as they do, make a very ≈øtrong Membrane, which is very nece≈ø≈øary; for otherwi≈øe in anhelation, or deep and violent in≈øpiration, it would have been in danger of breaking when the Lungs are ≈øo much di≈øtended, to the great inconvenience if not certain death of the Creature to which it ≈øhould ≈øo have happened.
Having fini≈øhed the de≈øcription of the ≈øeveral things of which the Lungs are compounded or framed, in the next place we proceed to ≈øpeak of their action and u≈øe.

Their fir≈øt u≈øe then is, (according to Galen) to ≈øerve as a ≈øoft Pillow or Bol≈øter for the Heart to re≈øt upon, that the hardne≈øs of the Parts behind them ≈øhould not offend it in its pul≈øation.

Secondly, They are the in≈øtruments of re≈øpiration or breathing, which is their proper action. Now re≈øpiration is performed by two motions of the Lungs, viz. dilatation and contraction. When they are dilated, they receive in Air, and this is termed in≈øpiration; but when they are contracted, they expel or drive forth the Air, which is called expiration.

While the Air is drawn in in in≈øpiration, a double benefit accrews to the Bea≈øt: Fir≈øt his Heart and Bloud are thereby cooled; whence we ≈øee that the hotter he is, the more frequently he draws his breath, that the bloud may be the more fanned by the cool Air. Secondly, hereby the vital flame is continued; for as an ordinary Fire is extingui≈øhed by withdrawing the Air from it, ≈øo does the Animal die when it is denied Air to breathe in. To the≈øe benefits of in≈øpiration may be added, that when the Lungs are heaved up by the Air drawn in, their ≈øub≈øtance is rarefied, ≈øo that there is granted a freer circulation of the bloud through them.

The Air having performed the≈øe offices, by its ≈øtay in the Lungs it becomes hot, and ≈øo can be of no further u≈øe for cooling the Heart and Bloud; and its nitrous particles are con≈øumed by the vital flame that feeds upon them, and therefore it becomes nece≈ø≈øary to expel it, that there may
be room for new and fre≈øh Air to be drawn in for the u≈øes afore≈øaid. So that this drawing in and expelling the Air ≈øucceed one another by turns, and an≈øwer to the ≈øy≈øtole and dia≈øtole of the Heart; onely this motion of the Lungs is partly voluntary and partly natural, but that of the Heart wholly natural.

But neither is expiration or breathing forth without its particular u≈øes; for by it are vented or voided the ≈ømoaky or ≈øooty ≈øteams or excrements of the Heart and arterial Bloud, (which excrements are brought from the Heart through the pneumonick Artery with the bloud:) al≈øo the thin and thick excrements of the Lungs gathered in the branches of the Wind-pipe are by this motion of expiration, (heighten'd into a cough) brought into the one great trunk thereof, through which as through a Reed it is driven by the force of the Air up to the Mouth and No≈øe, to be by them voided.

Of what nature the motion of the Lungs is, and by what Mu≈øcles of the Brea≈øt it is a≈ø≈øi≈øted, the Reader may inform him≈øelf in the fourth Chapter of this Book that treats of the Midriff, who≈øe motion corre≈øponds to this of the Lungs.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Neck.

argument.p: The contained Parts of the Neck. Of the Larynx. Its figure. Its ≈øub≈øtance. Five Cartilages. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its Kernels. The Pharynx.

div.p: HAVING now fini≈øhed my Di≈øcour≈øe of the two Lower Venters, order of Di≈ø≈øection requires that I ≈øhould a≈øcend to the third and uppermo≈øt Venter, and treat of the Head and Animal Faculty; but I will fir≈øt ≈øpeak to tho≈øe Parts which lead me thither, and tho≈øe are the Parts of the Neck.
The Neck is called in Latin Collum, √† colle, from an hillock; for it ari≈øeth out of the Body as an hill doth out of the re≈øt of the Earth.
It comprehends the di≈øtance between the Head and Brea≈øt, and its Parts are containing, or contained: as for the former, they are ≈øuch as are found in the other Parts of the Body; but

The Parts contained are peculiar to it ≈øelf, and are the≈øe: the Gullet, the Wind-pipe, the Vertebrae, or Joints of the Neck, and its Mu≈øcles. Of the≈øe two latter we ≈øhall di≈øcour≈øe in the Fourth and Fifth Books; and of the two former, we treated of one in the Fir≈øt Book, as belonging to the Stomach, and of the other in this as pertaining to the Lungs. But becau≈øe the uppermo≈øt parts of both the≈øe next to the Throat are di≈øtingui≈øh'd from the re≈øt by peculiar names and have particular u≈øes, we ≈øhall treat of them in this Chapter. Now the top of the Wind-pipe is called Larynx, and of the Gullet, Pharynx.

The Larynx or Throttle is ≈øituated, as hath been ≈øaid, at the upper part of the Neck, adjoining to the root of the Tongue. It is in Humane Bodies the in≈øtrument of the Voice, and in what≈øoever other Creatures, of that noi≈øe which they make, by what name ≈øoever it be di≈øtingui≈øhed, as particularly of the neighing of an Hor≈øe.

Its figure is round and almo≈øt circular, onely bunching a little out on the fore≈øide, and depre≈ø≈øed as much on the back-part next to the Gullet, for the Gullets better and more ≈øecure pa≈ø≈øage, and that the meat in ≈øwallowing might not be hindred from de≈øcending by it.

It is framed of five Cartilages or Gri≈øtles, the fir≈øt of which is called Scutiformis or Buckler-like, becau≈øe it re≈øembles a Shield or Buckler, being hollow within and bunching without. In Humane Bodies (in Men more e≈øpecially, for Women have it not ≈øo far ≈øticking out as Men) this bunching out is by ≈øome Anatomi≈øts termed Adam's Apple, from an old Tradition that a part of the fatal Apple abode ≈øticking in Adam's Throat in that place.

The next or ≈øecond Gri≈øtle of the Larynx is called Annularis from the re≈øemblance it hath to a Turki≈øh Ring, wherewith they arm their Thumb when they ≈øhoot. This Gri≈øtle is round, and incompa≈ø≈øeth the whole Larynx.

The third and fourth, becau≈øe as they are joined together they re≈øemble the neck of an Ewer, are called Guttales. The≈øe two Gri≈øtles many times pa≈øs for one, becau≈øe they have but one skin proper to them both, and untill that skin be removed they are not to be parted. The≈øe two form the glottis or little tongue, being a chink of that ≈øhape.

The fifth is termed Epiglottis becau≈øe it is placed above the glottis or chink. The ≈øub≈øtance of this is ≈øoft, and its ≈øhape like an Ivy-leaf. Its u≈øe is to hinder the falling down of any thing that may be offen≈øive to the Wind-pipe, when the Creature doth ≈øwallow either his meat or drink.
The≈øe Cartilages are moved by ≈øeveral pairs of Mu≈øcles, which ≈øhall be de≈øcribed in the Fourth Book.

div.p: The Ve≈ø≈øels of the Larynx are of all ≈øorts. Veins are derived to it from the external Jugulars; Arteries from the large branch of the Carotides; Its Nerves it hath from the recurrent Nerves of the (eighth, commonly reckoned for the) ≈øixth pair, which are called in tho≈øe Creatures which have voices, vocales.

There are al≈øo two ≈øorts of Kernels belonging to it. One pair is called Ton≈øillae, which are placed at the ≈øides of the ∆≤vula, and at the upper part of the Larynx. The≈øe are tho≈øe which in Humane Bodies are called the Almonds of the Ears, and are of this u≈øe, viz. to ≈øeparate that flegmatick humour from the bloud that makes the ≈ølaver; which humour ≈øerves to moi≈øten it, and al≈øo the Gullet, that by their glibne≈øs or ≈ølipperine≈øs they may the better ≈øerve for their re≈øpective u≈øes.

The other pair of Kernels are placed contrary to the former, namely at the lower end of the Larynx, in number two, one on each ≈øide of the Buckler-like Gri≈øtle. In Hor≈øes they are much larger than the former, and by them large branches of the external jugular Veins and Arteries do run. The≈øe are tho≈øe Kernels under the Throat or between the Jaws of an Hor≈øe that one may plainly feel at any time, but more e≈øpecially when an Hor≈øe has the Glanders, for in ≈øuch they are much ≈øwelled.

The Pharynx (or top of the Gullet) is ≈øo called from a Greek word that ≈øignifies to carry, becau≈øe it conveys the meat and drink from the Mouth toward the Stomach. It is ≈øomewhat more fle≈øhy than the re≈øt of the Gullet, and reaches up, behind, to the ∆≤vula, on the ≈øides to the Ton≈øils, and on the fore-part to the Epiglottis. It has ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles by the help of which it performs its motion, of which we ≈øhall treat in the Fourth Book. Its u≈øe is to receive the meat when it is chewed, and gra≈øping it on every ≈øide by contracting it ≈øelf, to ≈øqueeze it down the Gullet, by which it de≈øcends to the Stomach.
Thus much of the Parts of the Neck, which brings me to

div.head: THE ANATOMY OF AN HORSE. BOOK III. Of the Head.
CHAP. I. Of the Head and Animal Parts contained therein.

argument.p: The common containing Parts of the Head. The proper containing Parts. The Mu≈øcles. The Pericranium. The Perio≈øteum. Dura meninx. Its connexion The falx. Its Sinus's. Tenuis meninx. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. The u≈øe of the Meninges.

div.p: HAVING fini≈øhed the de≈øcription of the two Lower Venters, which are two of the principal Parts of the Body; I come now in the next place to betake my ≈øelf to the la≈øt principal Part which is the Head, being the ≈øeat of the Animal Faculty, as the two lower are of the Vital and Natural.

In di≈ø≈øecting of this Part I ≈øhall follow the ≈øame method as in the two former, examining its Parts in order, as they offer them≈øelves to our ≈øight in di≈ø≈øection, fir≈øt dividing it into parts to that intent.

But before we begin to divide it, I think it will not be ami≈øs to ≈øpeak ≈øomething of its ≈øupereminency over all the other Parts; for in re≈øpect that it is the ≈øeat of the Sen≈øes, it is lookt upon by Anatomi≈øts to be the chief Man≈øion-hou≈øe of the Animal Soul; and Sen≈øe is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to every living Creature, that without it, it is not far from being without life. And as the Head in this regard is the mo≈øt principal Part, ≈øo is it accordingly ≈øituated in the uppermo≈øt place, above all the other Parts of the
Body, for this rea≈øon, viz. that the Animal ≈øpirits as from a fountain might ≈øpring from thence, and communicate ≈øen≈øe and motion down to all Parts of the Body: but for the Eyes ≈øake more e≈øpecially has it this high ≈øituation, for thereby two conveniencies accrue to the ≈øen≈øe of ≈øeeing; fir≈øt, the Eyes being placed as in a Watch-tower, can di≈øcover things at the greater di≈øtance, and thereby prevent many dangers which might otherwi≈øe come unawares: and in the next place by being placed ≈øo near the fountain of Animal ≈øpirits, the optick Nerves, which are of a ≈øoft ≈øub≈øtance, and could not therefore endure a long pa≈ø≈øage, are ≈øecured from breaking.

As to the figure or ≈øhape of the Head, I will omit ≈øpeaking of that, ≈øince it is ≈øo vi≈øible and ≈øo common to be ≈øeen. And though ≈øomething might be ≈øpoken as to the true and mo≈øt natural ≈øhape of an Hor≈øe's Head, yet that being already de≈øcribed by other Authours, and may by me (if God ≈øhall ≈øo long ≈øpare my life) be treated of more at large in another Book which I de≈øign to ≈øet forth of the ≈øeveral Cures performed by me, by ≈øuch means and methods as I have experimented ≈øince I came to under≈øtand Anatomy; I ≈øhall wave it at this time, and ≈øpeak no more of the Head in general, but proceed to treat of its Parts.
The Parts of the Head, (as of the other two Venters before di≈øcour≈øed of) may be di≈øtingui≈øhed into Parts containing and contained. The containing are either common or proper; of which in order.

Fir≈øt then of its common containing Parts; the fir≈øt of which is the Cuticle with its hairs, of which we have ≈øufficiently treated in the fir≈øt Chapter of the Fir≈øt Book; the next is the cutis or True skin, al≈øo the Fat and fle≈øhy Pannicle, of all which we have treated at large in the five fir≈øt Chapters of the Fir≈øt Book, whither the Reader may plea≈øe to turn back for his better information.
The proper containing Parts of the Head are five, namely the Mu≈øcles, the Pericranium, the Perio≈øteum, the Skull, and the Membranes or Meninges contained within it.
To the Mu≈øcles we will ≈øpeak in the next Book which is of the Mu≈øcles,as being the mo≈øt proper place.

The fle≈øhy Pannicle or membrana carno≈øa together with the other common inve≈øting Parts above it being removed, the Pericranium next appears, which is a thin, white and very ≈øen≈øible Membrane ≈øpread over the whole Skull, adhering immediately to the Perio≈øteum every-where, ≈øaving where the temporal Mu≈øcles on each ≈øide come between them. There are many ≈ølender Fibres that pa≈øs from this Membrane through the ≈øutures or ≈øeams of the Skull, which are knit to the cra≈ø≈øa meninx or outer skin, which cloaths the Brain on the in≈øide of the Scull; whence ≈øome are of opinion that the Pericranium has its ri≈øe from it. Whether that be ≈øo or no, the≈øe Fibres however ≈øerve to ≈øtay the dura mater in its place, whereby it hinders the Brain which it inve≈øts from being cla≈øh'd again≈øt the ruggid Skull in violent concu≈ø≈øions of the Head.

The next inve≈øting Part is the Perio≈øteum, which is a Skin of much alike ≈øub≈øtance with the Pericranium, onely thinner. It is of the ≈øame nature with that Membrane that inve≈øts all the Bones in the whole Body, excepting the Teeth which are bare. From this Membrane it is that the Skull as well as all other bones are ≈øen≈øible, for of them≈øelves they are ≈øen≈øle≈øs Parts. It ≈øticks very clo≈øe to the Skull, and it, as well as the Pericranium, has Arteries from the external Carotides, and Veins from the external Jugulars.

We ≈øhould in the next place ≈øpeak to the Bones of the Head, or the ≈øeveral Bones of the Skull di≈øtingui≈øhed by ≈øeveral ≈øutures; but I omit them al≈øo here, and ≈øhall ≈øpeak to them in their proper place, (viz. in the Fifth Book) and proceed to the Parts within the Skull, the fir≈øt of which is the dura meninx, that is, the hard Skin or Membrane, called likewi≈øe cra≈ø≈øa meninx, to di≈øtingui≈øh it from the thinner that lies next under it, and immediately cloaths the Brain.

This hard or thick Membrane is called by many Authours dura mater or the hard mother, becau≈øe they conceive that mo≈øt of the Skins of the whole Body do ≈øpring from it, and therefore it is e≈øteemed as their mother.

Its figure and amplitude an≈øwer to the Bones of the Skull, by rea≈øon it inve≈øteth all its cavities. It is knit, and that very ≈øtrongly, to the bottom of the Skull, to its proce≈ø≈øes, and to the circles of its holes, from whence it cannot ea≈øily be removed. It is ≈øu≈øpended al≈øo by the Fibres above-≈øpoken of that come through the ≈øutures of the Skull from the Pericranium, as likewi≈øe by the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels that penetrate the Skull and are in≈øerted into this Membrane. By which Ve≈ø≈øels it is in like manner fa≈øtened to the Skin under it called the pia mater, and in ≈øeveral places to the Brain it ≈øelf. It con≈øi≈øts of two Skins, as the Peritonaeum of the Lowe≈øt Venter, and the Pleura of the middle do. In its upper part it is doubled, and its duplicature divides the Brain into two parts, the right and left. This duplicature being in the hinder part broad, and growing narrower ≈øtill as it inclines to the fore-part, I mean towards the No≈øe, is by Phy≈øicians called falx or the ≈øickle, becau≈øe in a Man's Head which is pretty round, it makes almo≈øt an half circle, as a ≈øickle does. We may retain the ≈øame name for it in an Hor≈øe, though le≈øs properly, as differing ≈øomewhat in ≈øhape.

In this reduplication there are ≈øeveral cavities or hollowne≈ø≈øes, commonly called by the Latin name ≈øinus, which are accounted receptacles of abounding bloud and ≈øpirits; by Galen they are called the Ventricles of the dura mater, by others ci≈øterns of bloud. The highe≈øt of the≈øe, and al≈øo the longe≈øt, doth run all along the top or upper part of the falx from the No≈øe length-ways of the Head towards the Noll, where it is divided into ≈øeveral branches, two of which de≈øcend downwards to the bottom of the occiput, and a third runs to the glandula pinealis.

Into the≈øe hollowne≈ø≈øes or ≈øinus's the mouths of the Veins and Arteries are ≈øaid to open, the Arteries pouring bloud into them, and the Veins receiving it from them again, as hath been ob≈øerved in the di≈ø≈øecting the Heads of living Creatures, for in the long or uppermo≈øt ≈øinus hath been ≈øeen a ≈øtrong beating or pul≈øe occa≈øioned by the bloud that is di≈øcharged into it by the Arteries.

The other Membrane or Skin which inve≈øts the Brain is called tenuis meninx from its thinne≈øs, and pia mater or tender mother from its immediate covering or clo≈øe ≈øticking to the Brain, imbracing it as a Mother does her Infant. It is ≈øpread over all the cortical or outer part of the Brain, in≈øinuating it ≈øelf into all its windings, as al≈øo into tho≈øe of the cerebellum and medulla oblongata, and ties all their proce≈ø≈øes and parts to one another, that they cannot be di≈øplaced or bear hard upon one another. And whereever it goes, the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels run along it, and are di≈øper≈øed out of it into the Parts that it cloaths.

This Skin is very thin, and of a mo≈øt exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe, yea this and the dura mater ≈øeem to be the in≈øtruments of all ≈øen≈øation. For as ≈øen≈øe is
communicated to every part immediately by the Nerves, ≈øo the nervous Fibres are more probably propagated from the≈øe Membranes that cloath the Nerves, than from the medullar Part it ≈øelf of the Nerve which is derived from the medulla oblongata and ≈øpinal marrow, which of them≈øelves have little or no ≈øen≈øe, but onely by virtue of the≈øe Membranes that inve≈øt them.

It is furni≈øhed with very many Arteries and Veins, mo≈øt of which are exceeding ≈ømall, but in number infinite, interwoven one with another in the manner of a Net. The Arteries do ≈øpring from the Carotides and Cervical Arteries, and the Veins from the jugular Veins.

The u≈øe of the≈øe two Membranes that inve≈øt the Brain is to ≈øu≈øtain the Ve≈ø≈øels that enter into it, to cloath and defend it from the hardne≈øs of the Parts that environ it, to keep it in its due form and ≈øituation (for of it ≈øelf it would run all about, it is of ≈øo ≈øoft a con≈øi≈øtency) and la≈øtly to afford a coat to all the Nerves, not onely to tho≈øe that ≈øpring within the Skull, but to all tho≈øe al≈øo that ari≈øe out of the Back-bone, for the≈øe two Membranes are propagated all along it, inve≈øting its pith, (called the ≈øpinal marrow) out of which tho≈øe Nerves ≈øpring.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Brain in general.

argument.p: The excellency of the Brain. That an Hor≈øe hath a Brain.

div.p:
BEING come to treat of the Brain, it ≈øhall not be ami≈øs, if before I ≈øpeak of its ≈øeveral Parts, I ≈øay ≈øomething as to its excellency, and the eminent offices it performs for the benefit of the Animal. All Authours agree that it is one of the mo≈øt noble Parts of the whole Body, ranked for its dignity even with the Heart it ≈øelf. And indeed, as I have intimated in the foregoing Chapter, its ≈øituation ≈øheweth plainly as much, it being placed in the highe≈øt part of all the Body, and there fenced about as it were with ≈øtrong walls on every ≈øide, to ≈øecure it from outward injuries. In it are contained the Animal Faculties, viz. tho≈øe of Sen≈øe and Motion. The former of the≈øe two Faculties ≈øits in it as in a Throne of Maje≈øty, beholding the forms of all things under her feet, having all the Organs and In≈øtruments of the Sen≈øes attending Her, at her command. For fir≈øt the Eyes are placed near her, that as Spies or Centinels watching day and night they may di≈øcover the Enemy. The Ears al≈øo are ≈øeated near her, at her command to be turned this way or that way, to li≈øten to any dangers that are approaching, that ≈øo they may be avoided. Likewi≈øe the In≈øtruments of Smelling and Ta≈øting are near her, that at her command tho≈øe Foods that are profitable and nece≈ø≈øary may be received, and that unplea≈øant or hurtfull Food may be rejected. And as the Faculty of Sen≈øation hath the forementioned Mini≈øters or In≈øtruments placed near her for the execution of her offices; ≈øo hath the motive Faculty a dominion extended to the furthe≈øt limits of the Body, of which every Limb and Member is perfectly at her beck, to move this way or that way as ≈øhe directs. I ≈øay, both the≈øe noble Faculties have their ≈øeat in the Brain;
for it is not a private or particular Organ of Sen≈øe, but an univer≈øal one; nor doth the motive Faculty exert it ≈øelf in the Brain it ≈øelf, which is incapable of voluntary motion; but that motion which it has, is natural, and that not owing to it ≈øelf, but to the Arteries that are di≈øper≈øed in it, for the beating of the≈øe makes it ≈øeem to widen, and contract it ≈øelf, as hath been ob≈øerved in Wounds of the Heads of both Men and Bea≈øts. This motion, I ≈øay, is communicated to it from the Arteries, and in its dilatation it receives arterial bloud by the Carotid Arteries, and in its contraction it forces that Bloud into the Veins, and the Animal Spirits into the Nerves, by which they are carried into all Parts of the Body, and with them the moving power is imparted; for without ≈øuch influence from the brain an Animal would be like a Log, it would be able neither to move nor feel, or rather it would cea≈øe to be an Animal, and become a dead Carca≈øe.

How ab≈øurd and ridiculous a thing is it then for any Man that hath any Brain him≈øelf, to imagine a Hor≈øe to have none? yet ≈øuch Men I have my ≈øelf met withall, yea I know ≈øeveral which to this day will not be convinced of that erroneous opinion by any arguments whatever. Neither will they take the pains to in≈øpect the Parts, to ≈øatisfy them≈øelves of the contrary, but will ≈øtill continue in their fal≈øe received opinion, merely taken from a ≈øilly ob≈øervation they have made when they have ≈øeen Hor≈øes and Oxen knocked on the Head, where they ≈øee the Skull broken and nothing under it, but a few hard and dry Bones, without any marrowy ≈øub≈øtance: I ≈øay from this ob≈øervation they draw their conclu≈øion, that a Hor≈øe hath no Brain. I much wonder how any ≈øuch Dolt can have the confidence to take upon him the name of a Farrier, and pretend to cure he knows not what. Such Per≈øons I would de≈øire onely when they ≈øee another Hor≈øe knockt on the Head, that they prevail with them that doe it, (or otherwi≈øe when any Hor≈øe is dead) to ≈øtrike him a blow or two with the ≈øame force above the u≈øual place between the Ears or a very little lower, and they ≈øhall then be ≈øoon convinced that he hath a Brain, (though not ≈øo large by much as a Man hath, con≈øidering the different bulk of their Bodies.) And when they are convinced of that, I hope they will take pains to be ≈øatisfied in the other Parts of the Body by ≈øearching into them, as by the≈øe my Labours they are directed; ≈øo ≈øhall they improve them≈øelves in their profe≈ø≈øions, and I have the wi≈øhed end of my pains, which I have taken to advance them.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the ≈øeveral Parts of the Brain, viz. that which is ≈øtrictly called the Brain, the Cerebellum or After-brain, and the Spinal Marrow.

argument.p: The Parts of the Brain. The manner of ≈øawing the Skull a≈øunder. The ≈øub≈øtance and divi≈øion of the Brain, (≈øtrictly ≈øo called.) Its action. The Cerebellum. Its Parts.

div.p: IF we take the Brain in a large ≈øignification, it comprehends all that marrowy ≈øub≈øtance that is found in the cavity of the Skull: yet for di≈øtinction's ≈øake it is by all Authours divided into three parts; fir≈øt, the fore-part, being the large≈øt, is called the Brain; ≈øecondly, the middle part is called Cerebellum, the Brainlet or After-brain; and la≈øtly, the hindmo≈øt and lowermo≈øt is termed Medulla oblongata, being that part of the Spinal Marrow which is within the Skull.

Now to find out the≈øe ≈øeveral Parts we mu≈øt divide the Skull with a Saw for that purpo≈øe, beginning almo≈øt as far back as the Noll-bone, or indeed quite as far, dividing the hole of the Noll-bone in the middle, and ≈øo go with your Saw fir≈øt along one ≈øide of the Head a little above the auditory pa≈ø≈øage till you come to the Fore-head a little below the Eyes (or ju≈øt even with them;) where being come, and having ≈øawed onely ju≈øt through the Skull, (for you mu≈øt have a care that your Saw do not pierce the Brain, for that will hinder your ≈øeeing the Parts of it) then cro≈øs the Fore-head with your Saw and pa≈øs along the other ≈øide till you come to the hole of the Noll-bone again: by doing which you will loo≈øen the upper part of the Skull, which with care you mu≈øt take off, that you break not the dura mater or Skin next under it, for that Skin is fa≈øtened to it in ≈øeveral places. When you have removed that piece of the Skull, then remove the Skin al≈øo by parting it lengthways down the middle, whereby you ≈øhall plainly ≈øee the Brain with its convolutions or folds, al≈øo the After-brain with its wormlike proce≈ø≈øes, &c. in ≈øuch manner as they are repre≈øented in the following Table.

div.p: Of the≈øe ≈øeveral Parts of the Brain we ≈øhall ≈øpeak in their order, and fir≈øt of that which is ≈øtrictly ≈øo called. It is of a marrowy ≈øub≈øtance, but not equally ≈øo, for the upper part of it u≈øes to be called its cortex or bark, being of a more dusky colour; whereas the inner or lower part is more white, and is particularly called the marrow or pith of the Brain. It is divided into two parts, a right and a left, by a Membrane that runs length-ways of the Head, from the Fore-head to the Noll; but this divi≈øion de≈øcends no deeper into the Brain than the A≈øh-coloured part of it reaches. The Skin which divides it, is called falx or the ≈øickle, of which I have already ≈øpoken in the fir≈øt Chapter.

The action of the Brain is to elaborate the Animal Spirits, which from it are tran≈ømitted to the Medulla oblongata, and from thence into the Nerves, for the ≈øen≈øation and motion of the whole Body, as has been more fully ≈øhewn in the two foregoing Chapters.

The ≈øecond part of the Brain, called the After-brain, is ≈øituated in the back-part of the Skull next the Noll-bone, onely parted from the Brain on its upper part by the pia mater or undermo≈øt Skin.

This differeth not much from the Brain either in colour or ≈øub≈øtance, but onely in its convolutions or foldings: for the Brain ob≈øerveth no order in its winding, but the Brainlet doth, for all its folds are circular, being extended one over another like plates, and each is kept apart from other by the pia mater that inve≈øts each of them ≈øeverally.

It is framed of four Parts, whereof two are lateral, (or on each ≈øide) the right and the left; and the≈øe are ≈øpherical, or round like a Globe: The other two are in the middle betwixt the≈øe, ≈øtanding before and behind; and the≈øe are made up of ≈øeveral orbicular Portions in ≈øimilitude like the Worms which are found in rotten Timber, and are from thence called Worm-like Proce≈ø≈øes.
The u≈øe of the Brainlet or After-brain is the ≈øame as of the Brain.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Spinal Marrow contained within and without the Skull.

argument.p: The Spinal Marrow. Its ≈øub≈øtance. Its ri≈øe. Its figure. Its Membranes. Its u≈øe. The number of Nerves ≈øpringing from it.

div.p: THAT part of the Spinal Marrow that is within the Brain, is termed particularly medulla oblongata, and is the third part of the Brain, being of an uniform, white and compact ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øomething harder than either the Brain or After-brain.

It ari≈øes out of the Brain and Brainlet, and that from ≈øix roots; two of which ≈øpring at the upper and fore-part of the Brain, and are called corpora ≈øtriata, the ≈øtreaked or chamfered Bodies, being onely the ends of its two Thighs; the other four ari≈øe lower and more backward, by which it adheres to the Brainlet, and are tho≈øe protuberances or jettings out that are called Nates and Te≈øtes, its Buttocks and Te≈øticles.

Its figure (after its ri≈øe) is long and round, being thicker near its beginning than afterwards. Its length within the Skull is about two inches, beginning towards the fore-part of the Head, and reaching to the Noll, whence it is lengthned and continued down the Chine as far as the Dock. That part of it which is contained in the Chine, we commonly call in Hor≈øes the pith of the Back.

Within the Skull it is clad onely with two Membranes; but without, it is covered with three. The fir≈øt of which it hath from the inner Skin of the Brain or pia mater; this immediately covers it. The ≈øecond it hath from the upper Skin of the Brain or dura mater; this is next to and covereth the former. And the third is ≈øaid to ≈øpring from a ≈øtrong Ligament which binds together the fore-part of the Rack-bones, covering both the former, and is very ≈øtrong.

Now the u≈øe of the Spinal Marrow is to be the original of all the Nerves, which from it (as from a Fountain) like ≈ømall Rivulets convey to all Parts of the Body the Animal Spirits. For although the Brain in common ≈øpeech be accounted the original of the Nerves; that is to be under≈øtood in a large ≈øen≈øe, when all the three Parts of the Brain are included in that one general appellation: But when the Brain comes to be divided into Parts, which are di≈øtingui≈øh'd by particular names, then are both the Brain and Brainlet thrown out of the office of being the original of the Nerves. For ocular In≈øpection doth te≈øtify, that it is from that part of the Spinal Marrow contained within the Skull, from which all the Nerves of the Brain do ≈øpring; as likewi≈øe from that part of the Spinal Marrow without the Skull, called the Pith or Marrow of the Back, that all the other Nerves of the whole Body do ari≈øe. Which large and far di≈øtant origination of the Nerves is very nece≈ø≈øary; for it would not have been ≈øafe (in con≈øideration of the length of the way) that all the Nerves ≈øhould be carried from the Brain to the inferior or lower Parts; and therefore it is wi≈øely provided by Nature, that from the Marrow or Pith of the back tho≈øe Nerves ≈øhould ≈øpring which furni≈øh the Parts ≈øo remote from the Brain.

As for the number of Nerves which ≈øpring from the Spinal Marrow without the Skull, they are in a Hor≈øe thirty ≈øeven pair, according to the number of Joints or vertebrae from the Noll-bone or the going out of the Marrow from the head, to the ≈øetting on of the tail; for out of the holes or perforations in every Bone do pa≈øs a pair of Nerves. Therefore there being ≈øo many Bones, there are ≈øo many pair of Nerves that ≈øpring from the Spinal Marrow. And from the medulla oblongata or that part of the Spinal Marrow that is within the Skull, there ≈øpring nine pair, as ≈øhall be further ≈øhewed hereafter.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Parts of the Cerebrum, or Brain properly ≈øo called, viz. the Rete mirabile, Glandula pituitaria, Infundibulum, the Ventricles of the Brain, the Corpus callo≈øum, plexus choroides, Nates, Te≈øtes, Penis or Glandula pinealis.

argument.p: The Rete mirabile. Why ≈øo called. Its u≈øe. The manner of taking out the Brain, and in what order the Parts appear. Glandula pituitaria. From whence the Snot is ≈øeparated in the Glanders. No ≈øuch Di≈øea≈øe as the mourning of the Chine. The Infundibulum or Funnel. Corpora ≈øtriata, Nates, and Te≈øtes. The Pine-apple Gland. Its u≈øe. The Ventricles. The manner of di≈øcovering them. Their u≈øes.

div.p: HAVING given a ≈øhort de≈øcription of the Cerebrum, (or Brain properly ≈øo called) the Cerebellum, and Spinal Marrow; we now return to the Cerebrum, to take a more exact view of its ≈øeveral Parts; and we ≈øhall begin with the Rete mirabile or wonderfull Net.

This Net is framed of innumerable twigs of Arteries which ≈øpring from the large≈øt branches of the Carotid and Cervical Arteries, which pa≈øs into the Skull by proper holes in the Bones of the Temples. This Net is far more di≈øcernable in Oxen and Hor≈øes than in other le≈ø≈øer Animals.

It is called the wonderfull Net by rea≈øon of its ≈øtructure, the Arteries of which it is compo≈øed cro≈ø≈øing one another like the threds of a Net, or rather as if ≈øeveral Nets were ≈øpread one over another. It is di≈øper≈øed all over the bottom of the Brain both without and within the dura mater, ≈øome of the ≈ømalle≈øt ≈øhoots of it branching into the pituitary Glandule.

The u≈øe of this Net is ≈øaid to be for the preparing of the Bloud and Vital Spirits to make Animal Spirits of. For which purpo≈øe in the twinings and windings of the≈øe ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels they are a long time detained, for the better elaboration and preparation of them, and le≈øt they might ru≈øh into the Brain in too full a ≈øtream, and thereby over≈ølow and di≈øturb the Animal Faculty.

To ≈øee this wonderfull Net, as al≈øo the other Parts of the bottom or under-≈øide of the Brain, you mu≈øt (after having ≈øawn the Skull a≈øunder, as is ≈øhewed in the foregoing Chapter) with a pair of ≈øharp Pincers pinch off by little and little the ≈øides of the remaining part of the Skull, all round, untill you come as near the bottom as you can; and you mu≈øt then with as much care as po≈ø≈øible lift up the Brain, beginning at the fore-part of it, where the Bone of the Fore-head a little ≈øeparates it. After you have lifted it a little way up, there will come in ≈øight the mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes together with their nervous Filaments or Threds that
pa≈øs through the Sieve-like Bone, hanging at them; which being loo≈øened and the Brain farther pulled up, the next thing that appeareth are the branches of the Carotid Arteries, which having penetrated the Skull are carried to the Brain; which being cut off and the Brain yet a little farther turned up, the unition or coming together, and the going out of the Optick Nerves are to be ≈øeen; the Trunks of which if you likewi≈øe cut off, there are other Arteries (al≈øo branches of the Carotides) to be ≈øeen, coming in through the Bones of the Temples: which Arteries (as I have already ≈øhewed) are (with ≈øome ≈ømall Veins joined with them) tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels which make up the Rete mirabile or wonderfull Net, di≈øcour≈øed of at the beginning of this Chapter.

After you have cut in ≈øunder the≈øe Arteries al≈øo, then you may by lifting up the Brain ≈øtill a little higher, perceive the moving Nerves of the Eyes (for they come next to view) and after them the other pairs of Nerves follow in order, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that one pair of them being cut off and the Brain with its Appendices or Proce≈ø≈øes more lifted up, the next is ≈øtill more plainly di≈øcerned by the carefull Anatomi≈øt. In which method and order all the Nerves, to which I ≈øhall particularly ≈øpeak in a convenient place, (I mean the Nerves ari≈øing within the Skull) and al≈øo the Arteries, as well the Carotid as Vertebral, being at length cut off, the whole frame of the Brain may be taken out of the Skull.

div.p:
After you have thus taken out the Brain and viewed all its Parts as they appear before you di≈ø≈øect it, you will at the very middle of its bottom, a little above the uniting of the Optick Nerves, within the hard Skin or dura mater, (for that is in the next place to be taken off and removed, otherwi≈øe it will hide all other Parts from you; but that Skin being removed in the place afore≈øaid, I ≈øay) you will find a ≈ømall round Kernel, in compa≈øs about the bigne≈øs of a Groat, and ≈øomething flat and round. Its ≈øeat is in a little hole made for that purpo≈øe at the very bottom of the Skull, in a Bone called the wedge-like Bone. This will be more plainly ≈øeen if you take the Brain out and leave the dura mater behind; for then you ≈øee it in its natural po≈øition, as the letter B in Fig. 2. of the foregoing Table ≈øhews it: but if you take the dura mater out, this comes out with it. This Kernel is called Glandula pituitaria, the ≈ønotty or flegmey Kernel, from its office, which is to receive the ≈ønotty Excrements of the Brain from the Infundibulum or Funnel, and afterward to tran≈ømit or convey them away, as ≈øome Authors ≈øay, into the Palate, from thence to be avoided by the Mouth or No≈øe. But others will have it, that it is ≈øent into the Jugular Veins by two ≈ømall ducts or pa≈ø≈øages, one on each ≈øide, being branches of one Trunk that begins at the bottom of the ≈øaid Gland, and is divided into two, after it has penetrated the wedge-like Bone. Which pa≈ø≈øages they have found out by injecting Liquors of ≈øeveral colours with a ≈øyringe into them, for they have ob≈øerved the ≈øaid Liquors to pa≈øs into the Veins, but none to come to either the Palate or No≈øe. By which Experiment they conclude, that whatever ≈øerum or wheyi≈øh or flegmatick Humour i≈ø≈øues out of the Ventricles of the Brain through the Funnel, di≈øtils not upon the Palate, but is poured again into the Bloud and mixed with it. Whence we may gather that the Rheum or Snot which i≈ø≈øueth ≈øo plentifully out of the No≈øes of Hor≈øes that have great Colds, and al≈øo of glander'd Hor≈øes, falls not (as I have my ≈øelf ≈øometimes thought) from the Brain, but is ≈øeparated out of the Arteries from the Bloud by the Glands or Kernels of the upper part and in≈øide of the No≈øe. Which we may the rather believe, when we ob≈øerve that other Glands are ≈øwell'd with Rheum at the ≈øame time, as particularly the Kernels under the Hor≈øe's Jaws; which is one of the certaine≈øt ≈øigns we have of a Hor≈øe's inclining to the Glanders. And this may ≈øerve to convict of errour all our ancient Authors who did hold, (and our Practitioners who at this day do hold) that the Glanders proceed from a defect and wa≈øting in the Brain; and that all that ≈ønotty matter comes from thence which i≈ø≈øues out of the No≈øe. Which were it ≈øo, all the Brain in the Hor≈øe's Head would not be ≈øufficient to ≈øupply it with matter for three daies, according to the quantity that I have ≈øeen come from one in that time. It is therefore a very fal≈øe opinion, taken up merely upon
gue≈øs, without in≈øpecting into the Parts, that our Practitioners do commonly entertain concerning this Di≈øea≈øe.

Neither is there ≈øuch a Di≈øea≈øe as the mourning of the Chine,as they do to this day hold; for it is impo≈ø≈øible any Creature ≈øhould continue ≈øo long alive as till all his Brain be ≈øo far wa≈øted by this Di≈øea≈øe, that it comes to reach the Spinal Marrow without the Skull, which is that I ≈øuppo≈øe they call the Chine.

But this Di≈øea≈øe, by them called the mourning of the Chine, is di≈øtingui≈øhed into a different Di≈øea≈øe from the former from the Matter's altering its colour; for it is generally ob≈øerved that after the Hor≈øe hath had this Di≈øea≈øe running on him for ≈øome time, the corrupt Matter or Snot changes by degrees from an indifferent white to a more dull colour, inclining at fir≈øt to a little reddi≈øh, but after a longer time, e≈øpecially when the Hor≈øe begins to grow towards his end, it will be very black and very nau≈øeous both to ≈øee and ≈ømell.

From this alteration of the colour, as I have ≈øaid, I do believe they give the Di≈øea≈øe this proper and di≈øtingui≈øhing name of mourning of the Chine; whereas it is onely a greater degree of one and the ≈øame Di≈øea≈øe, in which the Chine is not at all affected, at lea≈øt no more than any other Part of the Body, all of which langui≈øhes away by this inveterate Di≈øtemper. By what ≈øteps it proceeds, and how the Matter comes to alter its colour, I will give you my opinion.

The ma≈øs of Bloud being depraved either by unwhol≈øome Food, or by great Colds, or la≈øtly by infection from the Air and from other Hor≈øes (for this Di≈øtemper is catching) this flegmatick Matter collected in it is ≈øpued out of the ends of the Arteries in the upper part of the No≈øtrils, about the ≈øpongie Bones chiefly; for in an Hor≈øe there is little of this Matter comes out of the Mouth, but it ≈øtill de≈øcends by the No≈øtrils. This Humour, I ≈øay, di≈øtilling out of the Arteries by the ≈øpongie Bones continually, doth in proce≈øs of time ≈øo fill the ≈øaid Bones with filthy Matter, that like a Sink or Chanel being choaked up with filth, there is not ≈øo free a pa≈ø≈øage for the Humour, as when the Di≈øea≈øe fir≈øt began; ≈øo that the Matter by that means is there ≈øtayed, and by its continuance there it acquires ≈øo bad a quality that it corrodes and cankers tho≈øe Bones, and indeed ulcerates and gangrenes all the pa≈ø≈øages of the No≈øtrils, till it have mortified and con≈øum'd them (as happens ≈øometimes to Venereal Per≈øons) and at length de≈øtroy'd the Bea≈øt: for indeed it is ≈øeldom or never curable when it is once come truly to be a Canker.

Now by the foulne≈øs of the≈øe Bones (as I have ≈øaid) that Matter or Snot which doth de≈øcend by the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages, (which indeed doth at length drivel down in a greater quantity than before, by rea≈øon of the pa≈ø≈øages being widened from the Parts being gnawn a≈øunder by the cankered Humour; I ≈øay that Matter or Snot which doth de≈øcend after this) is of a contrary colour to what it u≈øed to be, for it is become more black and wateri≈øh, mixed with a little Red, and hath a very ill ≈ømell: but this alteration happens not from the Matter's flowing from a new Part, but is cau≈øed by rea≈øon of the foulne≈øs of the Parts through which it pa≈ø≈øeth, for from thence it hath its dye in a great degree.

Not but that there is yet another cau≈øe of it, which is the greater foulne≈øs of the Bloud: for as the beginning of the Di≈øtemper did proceed from the corruption or depravation of the Bloud, which was become as it were degenerate from its ≈øpirituous, bal≈øamick and volatili≈øed condition, into a
flat and vappid ≈øtate, like to dead Wine; ≈øo in proce≈øs of time for want of the Spirits to quicken it, and cau≈øe the fermentations nece≈ø≈øary in the proper places of the Body, where the excrementitious parts of the bloud ≈øhould be thrown off, (there being ≈øeveral Bowels of the Body appointed to ≈øeparate, and ≈øome that have Receptacles to receive the ≈øame) I ≈øay, for want of the≈øe Spirits to cau≈øe a fermentation whereby the excrementitious parts of the Bloud ≈øhould be thrown off, ≈øuch Excrements are collected every day in greater quantity, and acquire a greater degree of malignity, being hardly any part of them di≈øcharged any other way but this, which is preternatural, and mo≈øt times becomes de≈øtructive to the Bea≈øt, after the Di≈øea≈øe hath arrived to this height.

Thus have I given you my opinion concerning this Di≈øtemper, which though it be new, will I hope to the intelligent Reader appear to be truer than that of our Ancient or Modern Practitioners, few of whom (I may affirm without boa≈øting) have made ≈øo diligent an inquiry into this Di≈øtemper as I with great pains and charge have done; for if they had, they would with great ea≈øe ≈øee them≈øelves in an error, and no more believe that there is or can be ≈øuch a Di≈øea≈øe as the mourning of the Chine. But enough of this, (though I hope it will not be deemed to be from the purpo≈øe:) I ≈øhall therefore return from whence I have digre≈ø≈øed, and de≈øcribe the remaining Parts of the Brain.

Having examined ≈øufficiently the Rete mirabile or wonderfull Net, as al≈øo the Pituitary Gland, if you then remove the dura mater quite from the Brain at the ba≈øis or bottom of it, there will appear the head of the Spinal Marrow, ≈øo much as is contained within the Skull, of which we have treated in a foregoing Chapter. There may be al≈øo plainly ≈øeen the ri≈øe of the ≈øeveral conjugations or pairs of Nerves, of which we will treat at large in a convenient place; al≈øo the bottom of the Cerebel or After-brain, as the next Table doth demon≈øtrate to you.

After the≈øe you may take a plain view of the end of the Infundibulum or Funnel, (a cavity ≈øo called) which end reaches (before di≈ø≈øection) to the Pituitary Gland, upon which it pours the flegmatick Excrements of the Brain, as hath been already ≈øhewed.

This Funnel is ≈øo called from its ≈øhape; for above, the head thereof is large; but the lower part, is a long and ≈øtrait Pipe. By ≈øome Authors it is called Pelvis the Ba≈øin. Its beginning is ≈øaid to be on the fore-part of the third Ventricle, by ≈øome ≈øo called, but I could never in a Hor≈øe ≈øee more than two that I could properly call Ventricles, between which two this Funnel is ≈øeated, and into which they do empty them≈øelves, di≈øcharging their ≈øerous or wateri≈øh moi≈øture into it. This Funnel I have often found near filled with a thicki≈øh Flegm; and Doctor Willis ≈øays that in an Hor≈øe's Brain he has ob≈øerved it wider than a Goo≈øe-quill, and full of a clear Water.

Next come we to ≈øpeak to tho≈øe Parts of the Brain that lie hid, and cannot well be ≈øeen without di≈ø≈øecting of it; and fir≈øt of the Buttocks and Stones. The≈øe are four orbicular Prominences or round Bodies jetting out of the medulla oblongata (or head of the Spinal Marrow) of which the two fir≈øt, namely the Buttocks, are large≈øt, and the latter (viz. the Stones) ≈øeem to be onely accre≈øcences to them. The Buttocks ≈øtand lowermo≈øt, and adhere to the Brainlet; (as do al≈øo the Stones.) They are larger than in a Man, and look of a fle≈øhy colour while they are cloathed with the pia mater; but that being removed, they appear
yellowi≈øh, and of a different colour from the re≈øt of the Marrow. But of the≈øe we di≈øcour≈øed before at the beginning of the fourth Chapter; as al≈øo of the corpora ≈øtriata or utmo≈øt ends of the medulla oblongata, that adhere to the Brain properly ≈øo called.

The≈øe four Prominences are by Doctor Willis compared to Mole-hills, and are therefore by him ≈øo called. They may be plainly ≈øeen if you but lift up the hinder part of the Brain after you have ≈øeparated it from the After-brain, turning it as far back as you can without breaking it.

Between the≈øe four Prominences, or rather between the two lower of them, to wit the Buttocks, there is placed a certain Glandule or Kernel, which goes by the name of glandula pinealis, or Pine-kernel Glandule, from the re≈øemblance it is ≈øaid to have with the Kernel of a Pine-apple. It is al≈øo called the Yard or Prick of the Brain, from its being placed ≈øo near the Buttocks and Stones, as al≈øo becau≈øe it re≈øembleth a Man's Yard. This Gland as al≈øo the Buttocks and Te≈øticles before-≈øpoken of are repre≈øented in the next Table.

Concerning the u≈øe of this Glandule there are great di≈øputes among the Learned; but I ≈øub≈øcribe to Bartholin's opinion, who believeth its u≈øe to be the ≈øame with that of other Kernels, which is to ≈øeparate the Lympha from the Arterial Bloud.

There is as it were a chink between the Buttocks near this Glandule, which I think fit to mention, becau≈øe mo≈øt Authours ≈øpeak of it. Some give it the name of Anus or Ar≈øe, others call it Vulva; but why they have impo≈øed ≈øuch names as the≈øe upon the≈øe Parts, I cannot judge, nor is it worth the while to inquire, ≈øeeing they have no other foundation but fancy: however, ≈øince they are known by the≈øe names, I did think it fit not to pa≈øs them by, finding them as plainly to be ≈øeen and as ea≈øie to be found in Hor≈øes as Anatomi≈øts find them in Humane Brains.

I come in the next place to ≈øpeak to the Ventricles of the Brain, which are by ≈øome accounted four, by others three; but if di≈ø≈øection be made by beginning from beneath, there will appear onely two: and indeed I could never find more; for that which is called the third, I cannot think to be one, but rather a portion of the other two joined together. Nay, ≈øome Authours will have it that there is but one, being onely divided at the beginning, but at the end they unite into and become one common Cavity, as any one that will diligently trace them may ob≈øerve.

To ≈øee the≈øe Ventricles you mu≈øt cut the whole ≈øub≈øtance of the Brain in≈øunder in or as near the middle as you can gue≈øs, dividing the upper from the lower ≈øide, whereby you will di≈øcover them in the middle of the Brain of that ≈øhape as the fir≈øt Figure of the following Table repre≈øents them in: for there they are repre≈øented to the life, as much of them I mean, as can be ≈øeen without farther di≈ø≈øection; and appear to be of a ≈øemicircular or Half-moon ≈øhape. But if you cut the Brain further, and ≈øo follow their Cavities lightly with a Probe forwards down towards the No≈øe (for there they ≈øink deep into the callous body, or white inner part of the Brain) you will trace them as far as the mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes; and if backwards, you will find them to de≈øcend as far as the ba≈øis or bottom of the Brain; and then if you will take a view of them when you have laid them ≈øo far bare both ways, you will find them to re≈øemble in ≈øhape in Hor≈øe-≈øhoe.

Now the u≈øes of the≈øe Ventricles according to the divers opinions of Authours are many, but I will follow the mo≈øt Modern in this point.
Fir≈øt then they are framed for the more ea≈øie pa≈ø≈øage of the Bloud; for along their ≈øides do pa≈øs many branches of the Bloud-carrying Ve≈ø≈øels, which could not ≈øo conveniently be conveyed through the ≈øub≈øtance of the Brain, le≈øt being compre≈ø≈øed by the great weight of it, the pa≈ø≈øage of the Bloud ≈øhould have been ob≈øtructed, whereas now it hath a free pa≈ø≈øage.

Another u≈øe of them is, to ≈øerve for the reception of the ≈øerous or wheyie excrement of the Bloud that is ≈øeparated from it by the glandulous Skin that inve≈øts them, and by the glandula pituitaria; which ≈øerous Humour i≈ø≈øuing out of the Arteries, is ≈øuckt up again by branches of the Jugular Veins, and is by them returned with the Bloud to the Heart.

In the Membrane that cloaths the≈øe Ventricles there is a contexture of ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels of both Veins and Arteries, which is called plexus Choroides. The Ve≈ø≈øels that make up this plexus, are little branches of the Carotid Arteries, and ≈øome of the internal Jugular Veins interwoven with them. The Skin wherein the≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels are ≈øo interwoven has a great many ≈ømall Kernels ≈øticking in it, which as I have already ≈øaid, ≈øeparate the ≈øerous Matter from the Bloud.

In the Anatomical Di≈øcour≈øes of Humane Brains there are ≈øeveral other Parts of the Brain con≈øidered, as the fornix, the corpus callo≈øum, the ≈øeptum lucidum and the like, all which are as di≈øcernible in the Brains of Hor≈øes as in Men, and might therefore as largely be di≈øcour≈øed of: but it being not very material to treat of them, I will for brevity ≈øake but in a manner name them.

Fir≈øt then, that which is called the corpus callo≈øum, is the white ≈øub≈øtance of the Brain, plainly ≈øeen when you cut the Brain a≈øunder in the middle to ≈øee its Ventricles; for then you may view its white ≈øub≈øtance which makes the middle part of the Brain; the out≈øide of it being of an A≈øh-colour, and going by the name of cortex, or the bark.
The ≈øeptum lucidum is onely the Partition that divides the two Ventricles above-de≈øcribed, ≈øome taking it to be a reduplication of the pia mater, and others a portion of the Brain.

The Fornix or Vault is a kind of an Arch that ≈øtands between the Brain and the medulla oblongata. It is of a ≈øub≈øtance like the corpus callo≈øum, and is of a triangular figure. Its u≈øe is to bear up the upper part of the Brain, that its weight may not pre≈øs upon the ≈øubjacent Parts.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Action of the Brain, and the exerci≈øes of the Animal Faculty by the Nerves and Fibres.

argument.p: The action of the Brain. What the Animal Spirits are made of. How the Animal Spirits enter into the Nerves; And how into the Fibres. Whence the Fibres ari≈øe. They can move by the Spirit implanted in them.

div.p: HAVING hitherto ≈øpoken of the ≈øtructure of the Brain, and di≈øcour≈øed of all its Parts; I come in the next place to ≈øpeak of its Action, in general, and to ≈øhew, according to the opinion of our mo≈øt Learned and Modern Authours, how the Animal Faculty exerts it ≈øelf.

It is generally agreed that the proper action of the Brain (taken in a large ≈øen≈øe) is the elaborating of Animal Spirits; which Spirits are conveyed from it by the Nerves into the ≈øeveral Parts of the Body for the performing of the Animal actions or motions; for all voluntary motions are performed by the help of the≈øe Spirits.

The≈øe Spirits are made out of the Vital Spirits and Arterial Bloud, as out of their proper matter. And the place wherein, or the principal in≈øtrument that elaborates them, is not the Ve≈ø≈øels, but the very ≈øub≈øtance of the Brain, into who≈øe parenchyma or marrowy ≈øub≈øtance the Bloud and Vital Spirits are extrava≈øated.

Now concerning the manner how this Work is performed there are great controver≈øies among≈øt the Learned, and many arguments urged by each, which will be too tedious here to recite: I will therefore give you onely the opinion of a late Worthy Authour as delivered in his own words.

The Heart, ≈øays he, is like the primum mobile of the Body, to which the motion of all the Humours that have once pa≈øt it, is owing. This by its ≈øy≈øtole impells the Bloud as into all other Parts, ≈øo into the Brain, by the ≈øeveral branches of the Carotides, who≈øe innumerable twigs run partly through the outer cortex or greyi≈øh part of the Brain, and partly into the inner medullar or white ≈øub≈øtance of it. The≈øe twigs of Arteries ≈øpring partly from the Plexus Choroides and Rete mirabile, and partly from the Carotides them≈øelves immediately. The ≈øuperfluous ≈øerum of the Bloud is ≈øeparated by the Glands before de≈øcribed;
and that Bloud which is not elaborated into Animal Spirits, is returned again to the Heart by the Veins. But tho≈øe particles that are fit and proper to be converted into them, are extrava≈øated into the very parenchyma of the Brain, or at lea≈øt are di≈øtributed through it by invi≈øible capillaries, in which being perfected into Spirits, the≈øe by the help of the Fibres or Filaments which the inner part or ≈øub≈øtance of the Brain chiefly con≈øi≈øts of, are conveyed into the Corpora ≈øtriata (or other Proce≈ø≈øes of the medulla oblongata that adhere to the Brain) which con≈øi≈øt of the like Filaments, and by them to the Nerves, who≈øe inner ≈øub≈øtance is fibrous like the medulla from whence they ≈øpring. And the rea≈øon of this ≈øucce≈ø≈øive motion from one to another, is the pul≈øe of the Heart, whereby that which comes behind always drives forward what is before. Whence (≈øays my Authour) the true cau≈øe of an Apoplexy (wherein motion and ≈øen≈øe are almo≈øt quite aboli≈øhed) is from the ob≈øtruction or compre≈ø≈øion of the Arteries of the Brain: whereby both little Bloud and Vital Spirits can be conveyed thither to make Animal Spirit of; and al≈øo when it is made, it is not impelled out of the Brain along the Fibres into the Nerves, to enable them to perform their functions. The≈øe are the words of that worthy Authour concerning this Work.

It remains now to inquire how the≈øe Spirits, after they are thus elaborated, do perpetually flow from the Brain through the pa≈ø≈øages of the Nerves, and how they enter and fill the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Fibres of which the moving and ≈øen≈øitive Parts con≈øi≈øt.

That the Brain and Cerebel are the fir≈øt fountain of the Animal Spirits I have in my foregoing Di≈øcour≈øe already ≈øhewed; from whence they flow along the Nerves as by ≈øo many rivulets unto differing and di≈øtant Parts; till at length they pa≈øs out of the mo≈øt capillary Nerves into the ≈ømall Fibres interwoven in the Membranes, the mu≈øculous Fle≈øh, and other Parts, and la≈øt of all into the tendons of the Mu≈øcles, making them the organs of Sen≈øe and Motion: in which Parts becoming more fixed, they are called the implanted Spirits, attending their office when≈øoever the Nerves with their influent Spirits bring from the Brain the in≈øtinct for performing the ≈øame.

Now concerning the≈øe nervous Fibres in their ≈øeveral Parts, which are the immediate in≈øtruments of the Animal Faculty, we ought to inquire from whence they have their ri≈øe: It is plain they do not ari≈øe immediately from the Head, or any of its marrowy Parts; neither can we rea≈øonably judge them to ≈øpring from the Nerves, becau≈øe the Fibres in mo≈øt Parts do much exceed the bulk or bigne≈øs of the Nerve that is brought to them, as may be ea≈øily ≈øeen by the tendon of every Mu≈øcle, which being made up of united Fibres, is ob≈øerved to be far greater than the Nerve that is in≈øerted into the Mu≈øcle: ≈øo that it is unlikely they ≈øhould be onely continued portions of the Nerves divided or jagged into fine threds, as ≈øome have imagined; and it is more probable that they are ≈øpermatick and primigenial Parts, that is, that the rudiments of them were drawn in the fir≈øt formation of the Parts of the Embryo in the Womb, as well and as ≈øoon as the Nerves them≈øelves; unle≈øs one would with Doctor Willis except the Fibres of the ≈øanguineous Parts, which he thinks to be bred ≈øecondarily of the Bloud and nervous Juice flowing into tho≈øe Parts.

One thing further we mu≈øt note concerning the≈øe Fibres, that they are enabled to perform their motion, not onely from the Animal Spirits that flow by the Nerves at the in≈øtant of ≈øuch motion, but al≈øo from the Spirits that are ≈øtored up in the Fibres them≈øelves; of which any one may ≈øatisfy him≈øelf in ob≈øerving an Animal newly killed when its Skin is taken off; for when life is peri≈øhed, and all the force of the Spirits flowing in through the Nerves hath quite cea≈øed, yet the Spirits implanted in the≈øe Fibres breaking forth from the Mu≈øcles ≈øtill move and ≈øhake them, and force them into ≈øeveral convul≈øions and trembling motions. This I have not onely ≈øeen my ≈øelf in ≈øeveral Hor≈øes I have cau≈øed to be killed on purpo≈øe to di≈ø≈øect, but have al≈øo ≈øhewed it to ≈øeveral Spectators who have been very much plea≈øed at the ob≈øervation, and at the variety of their motions.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the ≈øeveral pair of Nerves ari≈øing from within the Skull, particularly of the fir≈øt, ≈øecond and third pair.

argument.p: The fir≈øt pair of Nerves, viz. the Smelling. The ≈øecond pair, or Optick Nerves. The third pair, or Eye-movers.

div.p: HAVING ≈øufficiently treated of the Brain and Animal Faculty or Spirits, it is fit that in the next place I ≈øhould come to ≈øpeak of the Nerves, beginning according to the order of di≈ø≈øection with tho≈øe that ari≈øe immediately from the Brain, which I find to be of the ≈øame number in Hor≈øes as Dr. Willis hath ob≈øerved them to be in Humane Bodies, viz. nine pair. I will therefore ob≈øerve the ≈øame method, and begin as the ≈øaid Learned Doctor hath done, with the ≈ømelling Nerves fir≈øt, becau≈øe they are the foremo≈øt, and therefore do fir≈øt appear in di≈ø≈øection.

The≈øe Nerves are called the mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes,becau≈øe they are round at their end like a Pap. They take their ri≈øe from the ≈øhanks of the medulla oblongata betwixt the corpora ≈øtriata or chamfered Bodies, and the chambers of the Optick Nerves; from whence running under the bottom of the Brain they do in their cour≈øe by degrees increa≈øe, and become broader and larger, and at length reach as far as the Sieve-like Bone that is ≈øeated at the top of the No≈øtrils. During all which way they are ≈øoft and marrowy, (being hollow within and pretty full of moi≈øture) but being arrived at this Bone, they receive a new covering or coat from the dura mater, (being clad before onely with the pia mater) with which they are divided into many little Fibres or Filaments like little ≈øtrings, which do many of them pa≈øs through the holes of the Sieve-like Bone into the cavities of the No≈øtrils, where they are di≈øtributed on every ≈øide, entring into the Membranes that cover tho≈øe Parts. The≈øe Fibres or Filaments which do thus proceed from the before-named Proce≈ø≈øes, are believed to be the true organs of Smelling, and of Sen≈øation al≈øo. From whence it is that tho≈øe Per≈øons that do not accu≈øtom them≈øelves to draw ≈ønu≈øh up their No≈øes, are upon the lea≈øt ≈øcent of it provoked to ≈øneeze: which is occa≈øioned by the Powder's a≈øcending up the No≈øe and re≈øting upon the tender Membranes thereof, wherein the little Fibres of the ≈ømelling
Nerves being di≈øper≈øed, are immediatly irritated or provoked into a convul≈øive motion, which is that we call ≈øneezing. It was an old opinion that the Snivel was milked as it were out of the Ventricles of the Brain by the≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes; but having above in the fifth Chapter ≈øhewn other Ve≈ø≈øels which di≈øcharge that flegmatick matter into the No≈øe, namely the Arteries, it ≈øeems more probable that the≈øe Mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes have a nobler u≈øe, namely that we have a≈øcribed unto them, to be the in≈øtruments of ≈ømelling. And therefore they are larger in Hor≈øes and all ≈øorts of Cattle than in Men, becau≈øe it was nece≈ø≈øary their Smell ≈øhould be very exqui≈øite, ≈øeeing they can di≈øtingui≈øh of the whol≈øomne≈øs or hurtfulne≈øs of their Food by that Sen≈øe onely.

div.p: Next come we to the ≈øecond conjugation or pair of Nerves, and tho≈øe are the Optick or Seeing Nerves; ≈øo called, either becau≈øe they carry the vi≈øive Spirits to the Eyes, or becau≈øe they convey the repre≈øentations of vi≈øible things from the Eyes to the Brain.

The≈øe ari≈øe a little behind the former out of the medulla oblongata, and having proceeded a while with a certain compa≈øs, they are united above the ≈øaddle of os ≈øphenoides, and that with a total confu≈øion and mingling of their ≈øub≈øtances, as far as by the naked Eye I could ever di≈øcern in all Hor≈øes that I have di≈ø≈øected; though ≈øome Authours ≈øay that in Humane Bodies they do unite indeed, but that it is onely by contact, without confounding their Fibres with one another.

The≈øe Nerves after they are thus united, do ≈øoon after again ≈øeparate, and go out of the Skull into the centre of the Eyes, three of who≈øe coats are made out of the ≈øub≈øtance of the≈øe Nerves being dilated.

At their ri≈øe and a pretty way in their progre≈øs they are very ≈øoft, being covered onely with the pia mater; but as ≈øoon as they reach the dura mater; they are covered with it al≈øo, and thereby become ≈øtronger and harder. This outmo≈øt Membrane it is which doth con≈øtitute that coat of the Eye called the horney Coat or ≈øclerotica; and from the inner or pia mater doth proceed the next Coat or Skin of the Eye called uvea or Grape like, from its colour; and la≈øtly the marrowy ≈øub≈øtance of the Nerve doth make the third Coat called Retina or Net-like.

The Sen≈øe of Seeing like that of Smelling is by Doctor Willis ≈øaid to be performed not ≈øo much by the help of the Nerve, as of the Fibres which are interwoven with the Organ; namely, ≈øaith he, the little Fibres in the Coats of the Eyes, and e≈øpecially tho≈øe that are in≈øerted into the cornea or ≈øclerotick Coat, and di≈øpo≈øed after the manner of a Net, do receive the impre≈ø≈øion of the vi≈øible ≈øpecies, and by repre≈øenting the image of the thing ≈øo as it is offered without, cau≈øe ≈øight: but it is the office of the Nerve it ≈øelf to tran≈ømit inwardly, as it were by the pa≈ø≈øage of an Optick Tube, that image or ≈øen≈øible ≈øpecies, and to carry it to the common ≈øen≈øory.
The next pair are the Eye-movers, which are by Ancient Authours accounted the ≈øecond pair, but do by our Modern Authours go for the third pair.

The≈øe take their beginning from the ba≈øis or bottom of the medulla oblongata behind the Funnel, from whence they proceed forwards by the ≈øides of the Optick Nerves. At their ri≈øe they are united, whence is a rea≈øon drawn that when one Eye is moved toward any object, the other is directed al≈øo towards the ≈øame.

They are ≈ømaller, yet much harder than the former, and as was ≈øaid, run along by their ≈øides untill they come to the os cuneiforme or Wedge-like Bone; where, as the Optick Nerves pa≈ø≈øed through the fir≈øt, ≈øo the≈øe pa≈øs through the ≈øecond hole of that Bone, and ≈øo on untill they come to the Mu≈øcles of the Eyes, into ≈øeveral if not all of which they ≈øend a twig or ≈ømall branch, which is in each Mu≈øcle ≈øubdivided into innumerable other ≈ømaller ones, by which the Animal Spirits are conveyed into the Fibres of the Mu≈øcles, and by con≈øequence the ≈øeveral motions of the Eye come to be performed, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed at large in a more convenient place, when I come to treat of the Mu≈øcles of the Eyes in the next Book.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the fourth and fifth pair of Nerves that ari≈øe within the Skull.

argument.p: The fourth pair called Pathetick. The fifth pair. The rea≈øon of blu≈øhing.

div.p: THE fourth pair of Nerves do ari≈øe contrary to all other: for whereas the re≈øt do take their ri≈øe from the bottom or ≈øides of the oblong Marrow, the≈øe have their beginning at the top of it, behind tho≈øe round bunchings out of the Brain called Nates and Te≈øtes, (of which we have already treated where we de≈øcribed the Parts of the Brain.) From whence bending a little forwards by the ≈øides of the ≈øaid oblong Marrow, they are immediately hid by the dura mater, under which they run for ≈øome time, untill they come to that hole of the Skull, where the other Nerves de≈øigned for the Eyes do pa≈øs out, which the≈øe accompany, but do not unite with, and at length terminate in the Trochlear Mu≈øcles of the Eyes.

This pair of Nerves are by Doctor Willis called the Pathetick Nerves, becau≈øe, ≈øays he, their office is to move the Eyes pathetically, according to the force of the pa≈ø≈øions and in≈øtincts of Nature, delivered and remanded from the Brain to the After-brain, and on the contrary from this to that, through the Nates and Te≈øtes and their Medullar Proce≈ø≈øes. For, ≈øaith that Learned Anatomi≈øt, ≈øeeing that by the diver≈øe impul≈øe and undulation of the Animal Spirit's dwelling in this by-path, there happen certain mutual commerces between the Brain and Praecordia (the Cerebel mediating between either, from who≈øe Ring-like Proce≈øs he will have the Nerves of the Praecordia to ari≈øe;) it is nece≈ø≈øary that the≈øe Nerves that are rooted in the middle way, ≈øhould be ≈øtruck upon by every march or remove of the Spirits going this way or that way, whereby the motions of the Eyes mu≈øt needs follow the affections of tho≈øe Parts. With the≈øe Nerves, (≈øaith he) all perfect Animals are furni≈øhed, there being none but are obnoxious to anger, love, hatred, and other Affections, as may be di≈øcovered in every little Creature, but much more in this which we are a di≈øcour≈øing of, there being none the a≈øpect and ge≈øture of who≈øe Eyes do ≈øhew them more than a Hor≈øe's do.

Next come we to treat of the fifth pair, concerning the ri≈øe of which there are ≈øeveral di≈øputes among≈øt Authours, (Doctor Willis, particularly, affirming that they ≈øpring from the Ring-like Proce≈øs of the Cerebel:) but if their original be ≈øtrictly inquired into, I cannot find, in an Hor≈øe, (however it may be in Humane Brains) but that they do take their beginning as the others do, I mean from the oblong Marrow, onely a little below the former pair.

The≈øe con≈øi≈øt of very many Fibres gathered together, ≈øome of which are ≈øoft, and ≈øome hard; ≈øo that they ≈øeem not to be ≈øo much one ≈øingle pair of Nerves, as a collection of many ≈ømall Nerves into one bundle, ≈øome of which are de≈øigned for one u≈øe and ≈øome for another, being for that purpo≈øe di≈øtributed into ≈øeveral Parts remote one from another; in which they ≈øerve, in ≈øome for motion, in others for ≈øen≈øe: from whence it is, ≈øaith Doctor Willis, that there is that ≈øympathy and con≈øent of
actions in tho≈øe ≈øeveral Parts to which the≈øe Nerves are di≈øtributed. As for in≈øtance, ≈øeeing ≈øome twigs go to the Eyes, others to the Palate of the Mouth, No≈øe, &c. therefore when we ≈øee or ≈ømell what plea≈øes our Palate, our Mouth waters, as we commonly phra≈øe it.

But that it may be better under≈øtood what and how many Parts have con≈øent by means of the≈øe Nerves, it will be convenient to di≈øcover their divi≈øion, progre≈øs and different in≈øertion. Their Trunks, beginning or ari≈øing out of the oblong Marrow, as hath been ≈øhewed, are divided each of them into two notable branches, the fir≈øt whereof tending ≈øtreight downwards, and going out of the Skull by their proper holes, are in their de≈øcent towards the lower Jaw, (for who≈øe Parts, ≈øaith my Authour, they are chiefly de≈øign'd) divided into many le≈ø≈øer branches, which provide for the Temporal Mu≈øcles, as al≈øo for the Mu≈øcles of the Face and Cheeks. From the≈øe branches al≈øo there go twigs or little ≈øhoots into the Lips, Gums, roots of the Teeth, Jaws, Throat, and to the farther end of the Palate, and al≈øo to the Tongue.

The other branches of this pair of Nerves are called the ≈øuperiour or uppermo≈øt branches, being larger than the other, and do thus run their cour≈øe. After their divi≈øion from the former they go ≈øtreight forward for a little ≈øpace under the dura mater nigh the ≈øide of the Bone called the Turkey chair, and over again≈øt the glandula pituitaria ≈øend little twigs to the Trunk of the Carotides, that makes the wonderfull Net: then they are inoculated into the Nerves of the ≈øixth pair, and from thence ≈øend back ≈øometimes one, ≈øometimes two ≈øhoots a-piece, which being united with two other ≈ølips turned back from the Nerves of the ≈øixth pair, do con≈øtitute the root or fir≈øt trunk of the interco≈øtal pair of Nerves, reckoned for the ninth pair, of which more ≈øhall be ≈øpoken by and by in the tenth Chapter.

After they have ≈øent out the ≈ølips for the root of the Interco≈øtal Nerve, the≈øe ≈øame great branches of the fifth pair are again divided each into two notable branches; the le≈ø≈øer and upper of which tends towards the globe of the Eye, and being again divided ≈øends forth two other, the fir≈øt of which is parted into two more, that go, one, to the No≈øe, and the other to the Eye-lids; and the ≈øecond into four or five ≈ølips, that are mo≈øtly ≈øpent on the Eye-lids, but partly on the Coats of the Eye and its Glands.

The ≈øecond or greater branch of the ≈øecond divi≈øion of the≈øe Nerves, being carried towards the orbit of the Eye, is again divided into two new branches: the lower of the≈øe being bent downwards, and cleaving it ≈øelf into many ≈øhoots, is be≈øtowed on the Palate and upper region of the Jaws; the other, being the higher, is carried beyond the orbit of the Eye, and pa≈ø≈øeth through a proper hole of the upper Jaw with the Vein and Artery which it twi≈øts about, and ≈øends many ≈ølips to the Mu≈øcles of the Cheeks, Lips, No≈øe, and roots of the upper Teeth.

From this pair of Nerves being di≈øtributed to ≈øo many Parts, I ≈øay, may the con≈øent of tho≈øe Parts one with another be learned: and particularly this is worthy ob≈øervation, That ≈øeeing they twi≈øt about the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels that go to the Cheeks, &c. hence it is, that when in Men and Women the Animal Spirits are di≈øturbed by the imagination of ≈øome uncomely thing; as if they took care to hide the Face, they enter the≈øe Nerves di≈øorderly, whereby their twigs that embrace the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels do compre≈øs and pull them, ≈øo that the Bloud comes to flow too impetuou≈øly into the Cheeks, &c. by the Arteries, and is detained there for ≈øome time
by ≈øtraitning the Veins. But ≈øuch ob≈øervations belong more to an Anatomi≈øt of Humane Bodies to which they are proper, and therefore I ≈øhall return from this digre≈ø≈øion, which yet, I hope, will not be unplea≈øant to the inqui≈øitive Reader.
