div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the ≈øixth and ≈øeventh pair of Nerves ari≈øing within the Skull.

argument.p: The ≈øixth pair. The ≈øeventh pair, or Auditory Nerves.

div.p: THOSE Nerves which are by Doctor Willis reckoned for the ≈øixth pair, are in the next place to be ≈øpoken to. The≈øe take their beginning ju≈øt by the fifth, and being for a little time hid under the dura mater, go at length out of the ≈øame hole of the Skull with the before-named fourth and fifth pairs, and are carried each with a ≈øingle Trunk nigh to the Sockets of the Eyes; but ≈øo, that near the ≈øide of the Turky-chair-bone they are inoculated with the ≈øecond or greater branches of the fifth pair. Whence they ≈øend back ≈øometimes one, ≈øometimes two twigs, which being united with the fir≈øt or recurring branches of the fifth pair, as was noted in the foregoing Chapter, do con≈øtitute the beginning of the Interco≈øtal Nerves. Afterward going a little forwards, each of them near the Orbit or Socket of the Eye, is divided into two branches; one of which is in≈øerted into the Abducent Mu≈øcle of the Eye (or the Mu≈øcle that draws the Eye outward) which is ≈øeated in its outer corner; and the other being ≈øplit into very many Fibres is be≈øtowed on the ≈øeventh Mu≈øcle of the Eye, which is ≈øaid to be proper onely to Brutes. Whether Men do wholly want them, let others examine; however, in the Animal we are treating of, they are very con≈øpicuous and mo≈øt ea≈øie to be found, concerning who≈øe u≈øe I will ≈øpeak when I come to a proper place for that purpo≈øe.

Next are the ≈øeventh pair to be examined, which by the Ancients (and by all untill Dr. Willis altered the account) were reckoned for the fifth pair. The≈øe are employed about the Sen≈øe of Hearing, and are therefore called the Auditory Nerves. They take their ri≈øe in Humane Bodies (according to Doctor Willis) out of the lower ≈øide of the Annular or ringy protuberance of the Cerebel; but I am ≈øure they do not ≈øo in Hor≈øes, in whom I have always found them to ari≈øe from the ≈øides of the oblong Marrow.

They have each of them two Proce≈ø≈øes, one ≈øoft and the other harder; which di≈øtinction of them makes many be of the opinion that they are indeed two pair of Nerves, though u≈øually they are accounted but for one.

The ≈øofte≈øt of the≈øe two Proce≈ø≈øes is properly called the Auditory Nerve, the which is carried through an hole of os Petro≈øum (or the craggy Bone) into the Cells of the Ear, which it cloaths with a mo≈øt thin Membrane, and by which the ≈øounds are conveyed to the common Sen≈øory.

The harder part or proce≈øs of the Nerve is ≈øaid to conduce more to Motion than Sen≈øe; which pa≈ø≈øing out al≈øo through its proper hole in the afore≈øaid Bone doth immediately receive a twig from the eighth or wandring pair; after which it is ≈øtreight divided into two branches; the fir≈øt of which tending downward is be≈øtowed on the Mu≈øcles of the Tongue and the Bone Hyoides; the other winding about the auditory pa≈ø≈øage and bending more upwards, is divided into three Shoots; the fir≈øt of which an≈øwering to the Nerve of the former divi≈øion, be≈øtows certain
≈ølips on the Mu≈øcles of the Lips, Mouth, Face and No≈øe, and ≈øo actuates ≈øome of the outward organs of the Voice, as the former doth ≈øome of the inner. The ≈øecond of the≈øe Shoots being divided into many other le≈ø≈øer, is ≈øent into the Mu≈øcles of the Forehead, as al≈øo to the Eye-lids. And the third or la≈øt of them doth run towards and ≈øpreads it ≈øelf into the Mu≈øcles of the Ears. Whence upon any unu≈øual and a≈øtoni≈øhing ≈øound the Ear is by a natural in≈øtinct prickt up, to li≈øten to it the more attentively, and at the ≈øame time the Spirits flowing by other branches of this Nerve into the Mu≈øcles of the Eye-lids, cau≈øe them to be drawn as far a≈øunder as is po≈ø≈øible, that the Bea≈øt may have the clearer view of any threatning danger; which po≈øture of the Eyes we call ≈øtaring.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the eighth and ninth pair of Nerves.

argument.p: The eighth or wandring pair. The ninth or interco≈øtal pair.

div.p: THE next pair of Nerves we are to treat of are the eighth, (commonly reckoned for the ≈øixth) otherwi≈øe called the wandring pair, from their being di≈øtributed into many Parts, wandring as it were not onely through the Head and Neck, but through many of the inferiour Parts of the Body both in the Che≈øt and Paunch, furni≈øhing them with nerves branching from them.

The≈øe Nerves do al≈øo ari≈øe out of the oblong Marrow a little below the Auditory Nerves. Their root or beginning con≈øi≈øts of many Fibres, ≈øome of which are ≈ømaller and ≈øome thicker, to which is added a notable Fibre or rather Nerve, much greater than the re≈øt, coming from the Spinal Marrow of the Neck, which is joined with them and wrapped about with one and the ≈øame Coat taken from the dura mater, as if they were but one Nerve. They continue to be thus united till they have pa≈øt without the Skull, after which they are di≈øper≈øed to ≈øeveral Parts. The Acce≈ø≈øory Nerve is di≈øtributed to the Mu≈øcles of the Neck and Shoulders; and one notable Fibre of the eighth pair joins it ≈øelf on each ≈øide to the harder Proce≈øs of the Auditory or ≈øeventh pair, as al≈øo two others run to the Mu≈øcles of the Gullet and Neck. But the re≈øt of the Fibres of the wandring pair continue together, going forward in one Trunk; and in≈øtead of the other companion lately parted from them (I mean the Spinal or Acce≈ø≈øory Nerve) they entertain a new one, which is the Interco≈øtal, or Nerve of the ninth pair.

In this place where the ≈øaid Interco≈øtal Nerve is united with this Nerve of the eighth pair, there is made a notable Plexus, (that is, the Trunk of the Nerve in that place ≈øwells into a kind of tumour, re≈øembling the joint or knot of a Cane.) For as the Interco≈øtal Nerve is received into it, ≈øo out of it there ≈øprings a con≈øiderable branch, which being carried towards the Throttle is divided into three twigs; the fir≈øt of which is ≈øtretched out into the ≈øphincter of the Gullet; the ≈øecond being hid under the Shield-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle, di≈øtributes its Shoots to the upper Mu≈øcles of the Throttle, and particularly to the Mu≈øcle by which the Chink of the
Throttle is ≈øhut up. The third of the≈øe ≈øhoots or twigs going al≈øo under the Shield-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle, meets the top of the Recurring Nerve and is united with the ≈øame.

Below the afore≈øaid inoculating of the Interco≈øtal with the wandring pair, which makes that Plexus before named, the Trunk of this latter goes ≈øtreight down by the ≈øides of the a≈øcending Carotid Artery, on which it be≈øtows ≈øome ≈ølips, and at the bottom of the Neck it ≈øends out another twig into the Recurrent Nerve, but this it does onely on the left ≈øide.

From hence the Trunk of the wandring pair de≈øcends without any noted branchings till it comes over again≈øt the fir≈øt or ≈øecond Rib, where out of a ≈øecond Plexus many ≈øhoots and numerous Fibres are ≈øent forth towards the Heart and its appendages, but not altogether in the ≈øame manner on both ≈øides. Doctor Willis ≈øays, many more branches are ≈øent from this pair towards the Heart in Bea≈øts than in Men; for in the≈øe latter there are a great many twigs ≈øent thereto from the Interco≈øtal pair, whereas there are very few in Brutes; ≈øo that in both, the plenty of the one ≈øupplies the defect of the other.

There is (≈øaith the ≈øame Authour) one notable difference worthy of note, of the two Recurrent Nerves that ≈øpring out of the Trunk of this eighth pair, viz. that that on the right ≈øide ari≈øes out of it higher, and winds about the Axillar Artery; whereas that on the left ≈øprings much lower therefrom, and twi≈øting about the de≈øcending Trunk of the Aorta, returns back from thence, and a≈øcends upwards where in its progre≈øs it ≈øends forth ≈øhoots to divers Parts.

And that ob≈øervation of the ≈øaid Doctor is worthy to be taken notice of, viz. That the Nerves that pa≈øs towards the Heart of Brutes are much fewer in number than tho≈øe in Men, of which (as al≈øo of their proceeding chiefly from the wandring pair) he gives this ingenious rea≈øon; That ≈øeeing Bea≈øts want prudence, and are not much liable to various and divers pa≈ø≈øions, it was not therefore nece≈ø≈øary that there ≈øhould be two ways of deriving the Spirits from the Brain to the Praecordia, namely one to bring Spirits to maintain the exerci≈øe of the vital function, and the other to mini≈øter to the impre≈ø≈øions of the affections; but it is ≈øufficient that all the Spirits, for what≈øoever office they are de≈øtin'd, ≈øhould be conveyed thither by one and the ≈øame path.

Over again≈øt the Heart, the Trunk of the wandring pair ≈øends forth many notable branches on either hand, which pa≈ø≈øing to the Lungs, are di≈øtributed through their whole ≈øub≈øtance along with the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels and branches of the Wind-pipe, which they climb upon and twi≈øt about: and as it de≈øcends by the ≈øides of the Wind-pipe, it di≈øtributes al≈øo many ≈ølips into the Coats of the Gullet. After the≈øe branches have grown out of the≈øe Nerves, then is each Trunk, as it de≈øcends by the Gullet, divided into an outer and inner branch: but pre≈øently the outer branches unite with the outer, and the inner with the inner; and being ≈øo united, the former de≈øcends by the out≈øide of the orifice of the Stomach to its bottom, where it di≈øper≈øes it ≈øelf; and the latter de≈øcending by the in≈øide of the orifice of the Stomach, turns back there, and creeps along its upper part. To what other Parts the twigs of this eighth or wandring pair are extended, the Reader may learn in the de≈øcription of the Parts them≈øelves, in treating of which we have con≈øtantly ob≈øerv'd to ≈øhew from whence their Nerves were derived.

After the wandring or eighth pair, by order of di≈ø≈øection the ninth and la≈øt pair of Nerves that ≈øpring from within the Skull are to be ≈øpoken to. Concerning the ri≈øe of which pair, there are various opinions; for ≈øome there be that will have them onely branches of the wandring pair, and that they take their beginning from them: but that opinion is rejected, ≈øince it is now made very apparent that they have another original, of which the often before-cited Doctor Willis was the fir≈øt di≈øcoverer, whom I may be bold to follow, ≈øince none have given, nor 'tis probable can give a better account of them than that Learned man, who ≈øaith that the beginnings, (as al≈øo the different Trunks in the progre≈øs) of the≈øe Interco≈øtal Nerves are ea≈øily di≈øtingui≈øhed from the former, notwith≈øtanding they do often communicate or join together by branches ≈øent forth from one to the other.

But though they owe not their original to the wandring pair, and much le≈øs are to be reputed as branches of them, yet have they no proper root of their own, but do borrow their original from two or three recurring branches of the fifth and ≈øixth pairs near their origine, growing out of them as a Shrub upon another Tree or Shrub.

The≈øe Nerves thus con≈øtituted do afterward run out of the Skull by their proper holes, and pre≈øently on each ≈øide form a Plexus near that of the wandring pair, into which two Nervous Proce≈ø≈øes out of the fir≈øt vertebral pair are in≈øerted, and out of which there goes one twig or ≈ølip into the Sphincter of the Gullet, and another into the Plexus afore≈øaid of the wandring pair. Whence de≈øcending by the vertebrae of the Neck, by that time they arrive at its middle, they have each another greater Plexus, into which a large Nerve from a neighbouring vertebral pair is in≈øerted, and from which proceed ≈øome twigs that uniting with others of the wandring pair are di≈øtributed all about the Praecordia, (that is, to the Heart and Lungs) as al≈øo one ≈øingle one a little lower. 'Tis true, Doctor Willis affirms that this Plexus la≈øt ≈øpoken of is proper to Man onely; but ≈øince I find ≈øo little difference in the other Parts between a Man and the Animal I am treating of, I ≈øu≈øpend my belief whether this Plexus may not be found in him al≈øo, though I have not been yet ≈øo diligent as to make any exact inquiry into it.

This Plexus is called the Plexus cervicalis, becau≈øe it is formed in the Neck; whence the Trunks of this Interco≈øtal pair de≈øcending by the Claviculae or Chanel-bones into the Che≈øt, as ≈øoon as they have arrived at the ≈øecond Rib, each of them receives three or four branches from the Vertebral Nerves next above, whereby is made another notable Plexus, commonly called the Interco≈øtal. From whence as its Trunks pa≈øs down by the roots of the Ribs, in every one of their Inter≈øtices, and even as low as the Os ≈øacrum from every jointing of the Vertebrae each Trunk receives a Vertebral Nerve.

As ≈øoon as they are de≈øcended out of the Cavity of the Che≈øt, and are come over again≈øt the bottom of the Stomach, they ≈øend forth on each ≈øide a notable branch, each of which tending towards the Me≈øentery makes its chief Plexus's, being in number ≈øeven, viz. five large ones which are upper, and two le≈øs that are lower. For each branch is pre≈øently divided into two other, and every one forms one Plexus, which make four; and the fifth is in the middle of the≈øe, being the large≈øt: and the≈øe are the five upper.

The two lower Plexus are framed of two branches that ≈øpring from the Trunks de≈øcended as far as the lower part of the Loyns, and are di≈øtingui≈øhed by the names of Plexus infimus, and minimus, (i. e. the lowe≈øt, and the lea≈øt) which two Plexus do furni≈øh ≈øeveral Parts of the Lower Belly with Nerves.

La≈øtly, When this Interco≈øtal pair have de≈øcended as low as the Os ≈øacrum, and have furni≈øhed in their cour≈øe the ≈øeveral Parts of the Lower Belly with Nerves, they bend towards one another and ≈øeem to be knit together by two or three Proce≈ø≈øes, and at length each of them ends in ≈ømall Fibres which are di≈øtributed into the Sphincter Mu≈øcle of the Ar≈øe.

Thus have I given a de≈øcription of the ≈øeveral pairs of Nerves ari≈øing within the Skull, in de≈øcribing of which I mu≈øt own my ≈øelf obliged to ≈øeveral worthy Authours, who≈øe Doctrine I have been forced much to follow and relie on in this particular, having not as yet made a thorow in≈øpection into the≈øe mo≈øt curious In≈øtruments of the Animal Faculty my ≈øelf: the chiefe≈øt of which Authours and whom I have mo≈øt followed, is that accurate Tracer of them, Doctor Willis, to whom all that have treated of the≈øe Parts ≈øince him, have been ≈øo much beholding. But onely where he a≈ø≈øigns ≈øome differences betwixt the cour≈øe of the Nerves in Men, and all Brutes in general, I cannot ea≈øily acquie≈øce in his opinion in relation to a Hor≈øe, the frame of who≈øe Body comes almo≈øt in all re≈øpects ≈øo near to that of a Man's; however, till I have made a more exact ≈øcrutiny, I ≈øhall forbear contradiction.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Nerves ari≈øing from the Spinal Marrow, while it is in the Vertebrae of the Neck.

argument.p: Thirty ≈øeven pair of Nerves ≈øpring out of the Spinal Marrow. The fir≈øt pair of the Neck. The ≈øecond. The third and fourth. The fifth. The ≈øixth. The Acce≈ø≈øory Nerve, that a≈øcends to the Brain, and unites with the wandring pair.

div.p: HAVING treated of the ≈øeveral Conjugations or Pairs of Nerves which take their beginning from that part of the Spinal Marrow contained within the Skull, the u≈øual and mo≈øt natural method requires me next to proceed to tho≈øe that ≈øpring from that part of it that is contained in the Vertebrae of the Neck and Chine without the Skull.

We ob≈øerved in a Chapter above, that in its whole progre≈øs from the Skull to the Rump-bones there ≈øpring from it thirty ≈øeven pair of Nerves. Particularly, while it is in the Neck, there ari≈øe out of it ≈øeven pair; while it is in the Back, ≈øeventeen pair; while it is in the Loyns, ≈øeven pair; and while it is in the Os ≈øacrum, ≈øix pair: for as was noted before, ≈øuch is the number of the Joints in the Rack-bone, betwixt every of which a pair of Nerves i≈ø≈øues. Of all which we will treat briefly in order.

The fir≈øt pair of the Neck, though it be commonly reckoned among the pairs of the Spine or Rack-bone, becau≈øe it comes out from between the fir≈øt Vertebra and the Skull; yet if we con≈øider its ri≈øe, it ought rather to be reputed the tenth pair of the Brain; for it ri≈øes with many Fibres from the Spinal Marrow while it is yet within the Skull, but pre≈øently after its ri≈øe tends backwards or downwards (whereas all the re≈øt that ari≈øe within the Skull go forwards.) This pair is chiefly be≈øtowed on the Mu≈øcles of the Neck.
The ≈øecond pair comes out between the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Vertebrae of the Neck, and is be≈øtowed upon the Neck, Head and Face.

The third and fourth pair come forth of the holes that are between the ≈øecond and third, and the third and fourth Vertebrae, and are ≈øpread into the Mu≈øcles of the Cheeks, as al≈øo into the Mu≈øcles that are common to the Head and Neck.

The fifth ≈øpringeth forth between the fourth and fifth Vertebrae. A twig from each Nerve of this pair, being joined with the like twigs of the fourth and ≈øixth, do make that remarkable Nerve that goes to the Midriff, and is called Nervus Phrenicus. The other branches of this fifth pair are di≈øtributed ≈øome of them backward and ≈øome forward into ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles; ≈øome of which do bow the Head; other twigs run toward the Fore-legs, and are di≈øtributed into ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles about the Shoulders.

The ≈øixth pair cometh out under the fifth Vertebra, and hath, as the re≈øt, ≈øeveral branches; ≈øome of which go to the Mu≈øcles of the Fore-legs, and ≈øome to the Mu≈øcles of the Neck; but one particular twig helps to
make up the Trunk of the Nervus Phrenicus, joining it ≈øelf with the afore≈øaid twigs of the fourth and fifth pairs.

The ≈øeventh pair cometh out of the hole common to the ≈øixth and ≈øeventh Vertebrae, which joining with the foregoing pair, viz. the ≈øixth of the Neck, and likewi≈øe with the two following, viz. the two fir≈øt of the Che≈øt, is di≈øper≈øed into ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles of both the Shoulders, al≈øo to the Neck and Cheeks.

About where this ≈øeventh pair of Nerves ari≈øes, there ≈øprings another, found out by Doctor Willis, and by him called Nervus ad par vagum acce≈ø≈øorius, which a≈øcends up by the ≈øides of the Spinal Marrow (growing in its cour≈øe thicker and thicker) untill it reach up to the Skull, during which way it continues in one body without ≈øending any branches to any Part. When it has entred the Skull, it then joins it ≈øelf with the Fibres of the eighth pair of the Brain called the wandring pair, with which it takes its progre≈øs out of the Skull, but pre≈øently after ≈øeparates from them, and is di≈øper≈øed into the Mu≈øcles of the Neck and Shoulders, as was ≈øhewed before in the foregoing Chapter, while we di≈øcour≈øed of the wandring pair.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of tho≈øe Nerves that ari≈øe out of the Spinal Marrow whil≈øt it is in the Vertebrae of the Back, Loyns, and Os ≈øacrum.

argument.p: The fir≈øt pair of the Back. The ≈øecond pair. The remaining fifteen pair. The fir≈øt pair of the Loyns. The ≈øecond pair. The third pair. The remaining four pair. The fir≈øt pair of Os ≈øacrum. The remaining five pair. How the Nerves ≈øpring out of the Spinal Marrow.

div.p: FROM the Marrow of the Back proceed ≈øeventeen pair of Nerves, there being in an Hor≈øe ≈øo many Spondyls or Back-bones; which number exceeds that of the Joints of the Back in Humane Bodies, there being in them but twelve, and ≈øo accordingly they have no more than twelve pair of Nerves from the Marrow within the Back.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe pairs ≈øpringeth out of the hole which is common to the la≈øt Vertebra of the Neck and the fir≈øt of the Che≈øt: Each of them (as are likewi≈øe all the following) is pre≈øently divided into two branches, of which the formore is larger than the hinder. The formore joineth it ≈øelf with the two la≈øt of the Neck, and ≈øo goeth the greate≈øt part of it to the Fore-legs; onely one little twig that ari≈øeth out of it before ≈øuch conjunction, is be≈øtowed upon ≈øome of the Mu≈øcles of the Brea≈øt and Neck; and the ≈ømaller which is the hinder, is be≈øtowed upon the Mu≈øcles ≈øeated on the Back.

The ≈øecond pair ≈øprings out between the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Vertebrae of the Che≈øt, who≈øe formore branch being united with the fir≈øt of the Che≈øt, together with it is joined with the ≈øixth and ≈øeventh of the Neck, which all together make one Plexus, out of which proceed mo≈øt of the Nerves that are in≈øerted into the Mu≈øcles of the Shoulders and Fore-legs. But before the afore≈øaid formore branch unite with the foregoing, it ≈øends forth a twig to the Interco≈øtal Nerve (or Nerve of the ninth pair) de≈øcending
down the Thorax or Che≈øt, as al≈øo do all the re≈øt of the remaining fifteen pair.

That branch of this pair which is called the hinder branch, hath the ≈øame di≈øtribution with the hinder of the foregoing pair, and therefore I will omit ≈øpeaking particularly of it: Neither do I think it nece≈ø≈øary to treat of every particular of the remaining pairs that proceed from the Marrow of the Back; fir≈øt, becau≈øe my de≈øign is to be as brief as po≈ø≈øible both in the≈øe and all other Parts, that I may not make my Volume ≈øwell too big; and in the next place, the remaining pairs coming out of the ≈øeveral holes betwixt the jointings of the other Bones of the Back as the≈øe already ≈øpoken of do out of the former, it would be but repeating almo≈øt the ≈øame things over again ≈øo to de≈øcribe particularly every pair. I will therefore onely ≈øpeak thus much of them in general, that after they are come out of their ≈øeveral holes of the Vertebrae, they do each of them immediately divide them≈øelves into two branches, whereof the formore (being, as hath been ≈øaid, the larger) ≈øends one twig to the Interco≈øtal Nerve, and the remainder of it is be≈øtowed on the Mu≈øcles between the Ribs, called the Interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles, both external and internal, and a few twigs al≈øo upon the other Mu≈øcles of the Che≈øt that lie upon the Ribs; and la≈øtly, a twig or two on the obliquely de≈øcending Mu≈øcles of the Lower Belly. The hinder and le≈ø≈øer branches pre≈øently upon the divi≈øion bend backward to the Spine, and are ≈øpent upon the Mu≈øcles and Skin of the Back.

Next come we to ≈øpeak to tho≈øe Nerves that ≈øpring from that part of the Spinal Marrow that is contained within the Vertebrae of the Loyns, which are in number ≈øeven pair according to the number of Bones in that Part. The fir≈øt of which cometh out between the fir≈øt Vertebra of the Loyns and the la≈øt of the Back. Each of them, like tho≈øe of the Back, is pre≈øently divided into two branches; the formore of which is be≈øtowed upon the fle≈øhy part of the Midriff, e≈øpecially its two Proce≈ø≈øes, and partly on the Mu≈øcle P≈øoas; and the hinder of them is in≈øerted into the Mu≈øculus longi≈ø≈øimus or longe≈øt Mu≈øcle of the Back.

The ≈øecond pair come out between the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Vertebrae of the Loyns under the Mu≈øcle P≈øoas; the formore of who≈øe branches is be≈øtowed upon the Mu≈øcle that fills up the Cavity of Os Ileum or Haunch-bone (which Mu≈øcle is the ≈øecond bender of the Thigh) al≈øo a twig of it is ≈øent to the Mu≈øculus fa≈øcialis, and to other neighbouring Parts. The hinder branch pa≈ø≈øeth into the Buttock Mu≈øcles, and doth lo≈øe it ≈øelf in the bodies of tho≈øe Mu≈øcles.

The third pair of the≈øe Nerves of the Loyns come forth between the ≈øecond and third Vertebrae of the Loyns, from under the Mu≈øcle P≈øoas, as the former did. The fore branch is di≈øper≈øed down the hinder Leg to the Cambrel or Hock, furni≈øhing ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles about tho≈øe Parts with Nerves. The hinder branch is bent back and di≈øper≈øed through the Mu≈øcles of the Loyns, ≈øupplying them with Nerves.

The other four pair of the≈øe Nerves of the Loyns, like the former, come forth from between the other four Vertebrae of the Loyns. Their fore branches are di≈øper≈øed into mo≈øt of the Mu≈øcles of the Buttocks and hinder legs; al≈øo ≈øome twigs are ≈øent from them to the Mu≈øcles that rai≈øe the Yard, ≈øome others to the neck of the Bladder; and in Mares ≈øome twigs are ≈øent to the Matrix or Womb. And the hinder branches are carried backward, and are be≈øtowed upon ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles of the Back.

In the next place I come to treat of the remaining Conjugations or pairs of Nerves that ≈øpring from the Spinal Marrow, which are tho≈øe that come forth of the holes of Os ≈øacrum, and are in number ≈øix pair, there being in the ≈øaid Bone ≈øix Vertebrae, with pretty wide holes for the coming forth of the Nerves.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe pair i≈ø≈øueth out between the la≈øt Vertebra of the Loyns and the fir≈øt of Os ≈øacrum in the ≈øame manner as tho≈øe that ≈øpring out of the Vertebrae of the Loyns, and like them is divided into two branches; the foremo≈øt of which is a great part of it mixed with tho≈øe other of the Loyns, and with them runs down to the hinder Legs, ≈øupplying ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles of tho≈øe Parts with Nerves. And the hinder furni≈øheth the bigge≈øt Buttock-mu≈øcle and other Parts thereabouts with Nerves.

This pair of Nerves, as I have ≈øaid, come out ≈øide-ways like the Nerves of the Loyns, and are divided like them afterwards into a fore and a hinder branch; but the other five pair come out before and behind; but before they go out of the Bone, they are on each ≈øide double, and on each ≈øide one Nerve goes into the fore-parts and the other into the hinder. Tho≈øe that go into the hinder-parts are di≈øper≈øed as tho≈øe of the Loyns were, that is, into the Mu≈øcles that lie upon the Os ≈øacrum, and Ileum; but tho≈øe that go into the fore-parts are di≈øper≈øed into ≈øome Mu≈øcles on the fore-part of the Thigh; al≈øo ≈øome twigs of them are ≈øent to the Cods, the Bladder, and to the Mu≈øcles of the Fundament.

div.p:
Thus have I given a brief de≈øcription of the ≈øeveral Conjugations or Pairs of Nerves that ≈øpring from the Spinal Marrow, ≈øhewing where they ari≈øe, which way they pa≈øs, and to what Parts they run; which
may be of great u≈øe to our Practitioners, if they will but take the pains to inquire into this part of Anatomy; for by under≈øtanding the beginning or ri≈øe of the Nerve that furni≈øheth an affected Part, one may learn where to apply the Remedy. As for in≈øtance; When from any outward cau≈øe, as from a fall, ≈øtroke, brui≈øe or any other accident, any Part hath lo≈øt either Sen≈øe or Motion or both; or from any inward cau≈øe a Pal≈øie happens, by which the u≈øe of ≈øome particular Limb is taken away; it would conduce very much to the cure if the ri≈øe of the Nerves of ≈øuch Part were known by the undertaker of the cure of tho≈øe Affections; for the Medicine is to be applied always to the beginning or ri≈øe of that Nerve that pa≈ø≈øes to that Part, or as near to it as is po≈ø≈øible.

I ≈øhould here put an end to this di≈øcour≈øe of the Spinal Nerves, if it were not convenient to add a word of the manner how they ari≈øe out of the Marrow, which is very accurately de≈øcribed thus by Doctor Willis.

On each ≈øide of the Spinal Marrow, near its outer edge four or five Fibres ari≈øe in its upper ≈øide, and as many in its lower: both which companies penetrate fir≈øt the pia mater or inmo≈øt Coat of the Spinal Marrow, and then the dura mater or middle Coat, (which is as it were a common ca≈øe to them all) with di≈øtinct Fibres: but afterwards as both companies of Fibres are to pa≈øs through the third Membrane (for the Spinal Marrow has three) they meet together, and being inve≈øted with the Coat they borrowed from the ≈øecond Membrane, they become as it were one Trunk: which Trunk pa≈ø≈øing out of the jointing of the Vertebrae, is again divided into ≈øeveral Nerves de≈øign'd for ≈øundry Parts. After this manner in the whole tract of the Spinal Marrow have the ≈øeveral vertebral Nerves their origine; and in tho≈øe places where the brachial (or fore-leg) and crural Nerves pa≈øs out, the Spinal Marrow encrea≈øes both in thickne≈øs and breadth, and the nervous Fibres are larger. All which that it may be the better apprehended, I have thought good to annex the following Figure from Him, onely encrea≈øing the number of the pairs of Nerves as they are found to be in an Hor≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Eye-lids, Eyes and their ≈øeveral Parts, viz. their Coats and Humours.

argument.p: The Eyes, their name. Their number. Their figure. Their Parts. The Eye-lids. 1. The Tunicles of the Eyes. Adnata. 2. Sclerotica. 3. Choroides. 4. Retina. The Humours of the Eyes. The watery Humour. The Cry≈øtalline. The Gla≈ø≈øey.

div.p: THE Eyes are termed in Latin Oculi, from the word occludo to ≈øhut, or from occulto to hide, becau≈øe they are hid by the ≈øhutting of the Eye-lids. They are the Organs or In≈øtruments of Sight, con≈øi≈øting of many Parts, viz. of Humours, Membranes, &c.

Their number is by all People known to be two, and that for the ≈øecurity and perfection of ≈øight; that if one be defective, or ≈øhould by accident be lo≈øt, the other may ≈øupply its place and office, though not altogether ≈øo perfectly.

The Eye alone, when its Mu≈øcles, and the Nerves and Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels that enter into it, are removed, is of a round figure, both that it might move the better, and al≈øo that it might the better receive the vi≈øible Rays.

Adjoining unto the Eyes are the Eye-lids, which contain them as it were, and ≈øerve as a ≈øafeguard or cover to pre≈øerve them from external injuries: United with them are the Fat and Mu≈øcles: and la≈øtly the Parts that con≈øtitute the Eye it ≈øelf are the Membranes, Humours, and Ve≈ø≈øels.

The Eye-lids do ≈øerve as Curtains to the Eyes, by which du≈øt, Flies, or any thing el≈øe that might annoy them, is kept out. They are made up of the Skin, the membrana Carno≈øa or fle≈øhy Pannicle, and Mu≈øcles; but both the Mu≈øcles and fle≈øhy Pannicle are in the≈øe Parts very thin. On the in≈øide next the Eye they are lined with a Membrane that is propagated from the Pericranium, which is very ≈ømooth, that it may move glibly upon the Eye. The extremities or edges of the Eye-lids are hard and gri≈øtly, partly to ≈øtrengthen them, and partly that they may meet the more exactly, and not fall one over the other. And thus much ≈øhall ≈øuffice for the outward or containing Parts of the Eyes, viz. the Eye-lids.

As for the Mu≈øcles, we ≈øhall defer ≈øpeaking of them till the next Book. And as to the Fat, it differs not from that which is intermixed among the Mu≈øcles in other Parts, and ≈øerves here to keep the hinder-part of the Eye and parts adjoining moi≈øt, that the Eye may move the more glibly in its Socket.

We ≈øhall therefore next proceed to the Eye it ≈øelf, and de≈øcribe the Parts of which it con≈øi≈øts, and fir≈øt its Tunicles or Coats, the fir≈øt or outmo≈øt of which is a common Coat, ari≈øing from the Pericranium, and is ≈øpread over all the white of the Eye. By this is the Eye kept firmly within its Socket or Orbit. It is of exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe, and hath many ≈ømall Arteries and Veins creeping through it, which are very di≈øcernible when there is any inflammation in that Part. It is called Adnata.

This Adnata being removed, the proper Tunicles or Coats do appear, being in number three; the fir≈øt of which from its hardne≈øs is called ≈øclerotica. This ari≈øes from the dura mater, or (which is all one) from the outmo≈øt Coat of the Optick Nerve. It is ≈øomewhat hard, and opaque on its back≈øide; but on its fore-part, becau≈øe it is tran≈øparent like an Horn, it lo≈øes its name of ≈øclerotica which it had from its hardne≈øs, and is called tunica cornea or horney Coat from its clearne≈øs.

The ≈øecond proper Coat lieth next under this, and goeth by the name of Choroides, becau≈øe it re≈øembles that Membrane that inwraps the Foal in the Womb, called Chorion. As the former did ari≈øe from the dura mater, ≈øo doth this from the pia mater, (or if you will, from the inner Coat of the Optick Nerve.) All over the back-part of the Eye, this Coat on its in≈øide is blacki≈øh, that the Idea's received in might appear the more illu≈øtrious.

This Coat is perforated before as wide as the pupilla or ≈øight of the Eye is in compa≈øs, to permit the rays of vi≈øible Species to pa≈øs in to the cry≈øtalline Humour. Which fore-part, becau≈øe ≈øo much of it as is from under the white is ≈øomewhat of the colour of a Grape, is called uvea: by which name the fore-part of this Coat is di≈øtingui≈øhed from its hinder-part, as the former was by the name of cornea, from ≈øclerotica; which I thought fit to take notice of in this place, that the Reader might not take the four names for four ≈øeveral Coats, when they are but two, and ≈øo might go about to find what indeed there is not.

From the circumference of the uvea, where its duplicated Membrane bends it ≈øelf back to the cry≈øtalline Humour, there is formed a Ligament called ligamentum Ciliare, becau≈øe it con≈øi≈øts of ≈ølender Filaments or Fibres like the hairs that grow upon the Eye-lids in Humane Bodies, running like ≈øo many black lines from the circumference of the uvea to the ≈øides of the cry≈øtalline Humour; which Humour they encompa≈øs, and widen or con≈øtringe it as there is occa≈øion, by contracting or opening the perforation of the uvea.
The third or inmo≈øt proper Tunicle of the Eye is called Retina or the Net-fa≈øhioned Coat, becau≈øe it encompa≈ø≈øes the vitreous or gla≈ø≈øey Humour like a Net.

This Coat is made of the medullar ≈øub≈øtance of the Optick Nerve, being very thin, and rather of a dark than light≈øom colour, mixed with an ob≈øcure redne≈øs. Its figure is ≈øemicircular, round on its out≈øide, and hollow within, containing in it the vitreous Humour, and receiving into its bo≈øom the cry≈øtalline Humour al≈øo, having its Fibres extended as far as the ligamentum Ciliare, to which the≈øe Fibres afford animal Spirits for the continuance of its motion. It is ob≈øerved that if this Coat be taken and put into warm Water, ≈øhaking it a little to wa≈øh off the mucous or ≈ønotty matter that cleaves to it, and then be held up to the light, the Fibres or Filaments will appear very numerous like the threads of the fine≈øt Lawn.

Having done with the Tunicles or Coats of the Eyes, I come next to ≈øpeak of the Humours contained within tho≈øe Coats, which are in number three, that is the Aqueus or watery, the Vitreus or gla≈ø≈øey, and the Cry≈øtalline: of which the la≈øt for its u≈øe is the mo≈øt noble, and is placed almo≈øt in the centre of the Eyes.

Of the≈øe Humours the Aqueus or watery is outermo≈øt, being thin and fluxive like Water, from whence it hath its name. It fills up that ≈øpace that is betwixt the horney or outmo≈øt Coat and the cry≈øtalline Humour in the fore-part of the Eye. It is ob≈øerved in Men, that if any clotted and coloured bits or motes ≈øwim in this Humour, the ≈øhapes of ≈øeveral In≈øects, as Gnats, Flies, Spiders and the like, will ≈øeem to be flying before their Eyes, as hath been oft declared by Men who have had this Affection. I am therefore apt to believe that many Hor≈øes are not without ≈øuch kind of congealed bits floating in this Humour, that without any evident or external cau≈øe to occa≈øion it, are much given to ≈øtart, e≈øpecially with their Head; the repre≈øentation of the afore≈øaid In≈øects moving before the cry≈øtalline Humour, which makes them fear ≈øomething or other is ≈øtill flying into their Eye.

Yea it is in Humane Bodies farther ob≈øerved, that oft times ≈øeveral of the≈øe coloured Particles in the watery Humour do gather together, and unite ≈øo clo≈øe, that they grow as it were into a skin or film, ≈øpreading before the ≈øight of the Eye, which cau≈øes an ab≈øolute blindne≈øs, and is that Di≈øea≈øe which Phy≈øicians call a Cataract; which Di≈øea≈øe the Animal we are treating of is much ≈øubject to, though we have not ≈øo proper a term for it as this is.

The next Humour is the Cry≈øtalline, which is ≈øo called from its exceeding bright and ≈øhining colour, being as tran≈øparent as Cry≈øtal; It is it ≈øelf of no di≈øtingui≈øhable colour, that it might receive the Idea's of all colours.

It is placed betwixt the watery and gla≈ø≈øey Humours, but not exactly in the middle or centre of the Eye, but rather towards its fore-part. It is inclo≈øed in the bo≈øom, as it were, of the gla≈ø≈øey Humour, and is flatti≈øh on the fore-≈øide, but rounder behind.

This Humour is believed to be the primary or chief in≈øtrument of the ≈øight, becau≈øe it collects or receives the rayes of vi≈øible things; though the tunica Retina doth afterwards ≈øtop them by its dark body, and communicate them to the common Sen≈øory by the Optick Nerve.

The third and la≈øt of the Humours of the Eye is the Vitreus or gla≈ø≈øey, ≈øo called becau≈øe in colour it is like to molten gla≈øs. This is not of ≈øo thick a con≈øi≈øtence as the cry≈øtalline; but it much exceeds both it and the watery in quantity. It is round in its hinder part but plane before, onely it has a little hollowne≈øs in the middle wherein the cry≈øtalline Humour is placed as in a mold or ca≈øe. It fills up all the hinder part of the globe of the Eye, as al≈øo ≈øome part of the ≈øides.

The u≈øes of this Humour are ≈øaid to be, fir≈øt, to nouri≈øh the cry≈øtalline Humour, as Galen conceived; next, that the vi≈øible ≈øpecies received into the cry≈øtalline Humour might not be reflected, or return defiled by dark and coloured tinctures, whereby the ≈øight ≈øhould be di≈øturbed; but that they might have a free pa≈ø≈øage through it to the Retina.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Ears and their ≈øeveral Parts.

argument.p: The Auricle. Its Parts. Its u≈øe. The inward Ear. Its Parts. The Dium. Four little Bones. The Hammer. The Anvil. The Stirrop. The orbicular Bone. The u≈øe of the≈øe Bones. The Cavities of the Ear. Concha. Fene≈øtra ovalis. Fene≈øtra rotunda. The Labyrinth. Cochlea.

div.p: THE Ears (which according to order we come now to ≈øpeak to) are the in≈øtruments of Hearing, framed by Nature with no le≈øs Art than the Eyes; yea ≈øo full of intricate Meanders they are, and con≈øi≈øt of ≈øo many Parts, that they will be very hard to be deciphered. Notwith≈øtanding I will endeavour to give what ≈øatisfaction I can, by what I have learned by In≈øpection, as well as by the Writings of the mo≈øt accurate Anatomi≈øts.

Fir≈øt then the Parts of the Ear are either Outward or Inward. The outward part is called Auricula, which is onely an adjuvant or a≈ø≈øi≈øting in≈øtrument of Hearing, collecting in its hollowne≈øs ≈øome part of the Air that is the vehicle of the ≈øound, as it is pa≈ø≈øing by.

The Parts whereof the outward Ear is framed, are either proper, or common. The common are the Scarf skin, the true Skin, and membrana nervea, or nervous Membrane. The proper are the Mu≈øcles, Veins, Arteries, Nerves, and the Gri≈øtle. Of the Mu≈øcles we ≈øhall ≈øpeak in their proper place, viz. in the next Book that treats of the Mu≈øcles. The Veins of the Ear are branched to it from the external Jugular Vein; the Arteries from the Carotid Arteries; and the Nerves from the ≈øecond pair of the Neck being joined with the harder Proce≈øs of the ≈øeventh pair. As to the Gri≈øtle of which for the greate≈øt part it con≈øi≈øts, that is a ≈øub≈øtance that is fitte≈øt for this place; for if it had been bony, the Ear would both have been immoveable,
and ≈øo could not have turned it ≈øelf toward the ≈øound, as we ≈øee the Hor≈øe can now move it; and al≈øo it would have been in continual danger of being broken off: and if it had been fle≈øhy or membranous onely, the Hor≈øe's Ears would have flap'd down like Hounds Ears, which would have been a great deformity.

The u≈øes of this outward Ear are, fir≈øt, to ≈øerve for an ornament to the Head; ≈øecondly to receive, or at lea≈øt to help to receive the ≈øounds; for fir≈øt, it gathereth them being di≈øper≈øed in the Air; ≈øecondly, it doth moderate the fiercene≈øs of their motion, ≈øo that they come gently to the Tympanum, or Drum, and beat moderately again≈øt it.
The internal or inward Ear hath al≈øo ≈øundry Parts, contained in the Os petro≈øum, as the outward Ear is fa≈øten'd upon it.
The≈øe Parts are fir≈øt the Drum with its Cord and Mu≈øcles; ≈øecondly, four little Bones; thirdly, its Cavities with the implanted Air; and la≈øtly, its Ve≈ø≈øels.

The Drum, called Tympanum, is a nervous, round and tran≈øparent Membrane, of mo≈øt exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe, ari≈øing from the ≈øofter proce≈øs of the Auditory Nerve expanded. It is exceeding dry, that it might give the better Echo to the ≈øound. It is al≈øo ≈øtrong, that it ≈øhould the better endure outward harms or injuries. It hath a Cord behind it for ≈øtrengthning and ≈øtretching of it, even as the Military Drum hath. As for its Mu≈øcles, we ≈øhall de≈øcribe them in the next Book.

Within the Membrane of this Tympanum or Drum there is an internal Cavity, called Concha, in which are ≈øeveral little dry Bones, which have in them no Marrow, nor are covered with any Membrane or perio≈øteum: yet at their ends where they are joined together, they are bound with a ≈ømall Ligament, proceeding from the before mentioned Cord of the Drum.

The≈øe little Bones are four in number; the fir≈øt of which is called malleolus, that is, a little Hammer. This Hammer hath a round head, which by a loo≈øe Ligament is jointed into the Cavity of the ≈øecond little Bone that is called the Anvil; which head is continued into a ≈ømall neck, that reacheth beyond the middle of the Drum and adhereth to it. About its middle it hath two Proce≈ø≈øes, the one of which, being ≈øhorter, hath the tendon of the internal Mu≈øcle in≈øerted into it; and the other, being longer, hath the tendon of the external, the Drum intervening.
The next of the≈øe little Bones is by Anatomi≈øts called Incus, the Anvil, having one head and two feet, being therefore more like to one of the grinding Double-teeth than to an Anvil.

The head of this is indifferent thick, having in the top of it a little ≈ømooth hollowne≈øs, which receives the knob or head of the Hammer. The ≈ømaller foot of the Anvil is tied to the top of the Stirrop by a loo≈øe but firm Ligament, but the thicker foot re≈øteth upon the Os ≈øquamo≈øum, or ≈øcaly Bone.

The third is called the Stirrop, having a perforation in the middle, and is fixed before or rather round that pa≈ø≈øage that is called the oval Window, by which ≈øounds pa≈øs out of the fir≈øt Cavity into the ≈øecond called the Labyrinth. Which Cavities are wrought by Nature in the Rocky-bone, and contain in them the inbred Air. Now as the cry≈øtalline Humour of the Eye is the chief in≈øtrument of the Sight, in re≈øpect of the reception of vi≈øible Images or Forms; ≈øo is this inbred Air of the Ear, the chief in≈øtrument which receiveth the forms of Sounds, although there be another more noble Organ which judgeth of them, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewn by and by.

The figure of this Bone is in Hor≈øes triangular, very like the Greek Letter Œî, (but in Men it is repre≈øented to be of ≈øomewhat another ≈øhape) which Letter is like ≈øuch a Stirrop as we often ≈øee in old Hangings (not ≈øuch Stirrops as are u≈øed now-a-daies) from its ≈øimilitude unto which I ≈øuppo≈øe it hath its name.
The upper part of this Stirrop is ≈ømall, as you may ≈øee by the figure of it, upon which the longe≈øt foot of the Anvil ≈øtands.
The fourth and la≈øt of the≈øe little Bones of the Ear was not long ≈øince found out by a diligent Anatomi≈øt, named Franc. Sylvius, till who≈øe time there were but three Bones of the Ear reckoned.
This Bone from its round ≈øhape is called orbiculare. It is tied by a ≈ølender Ligament to the ≈øide of the Stirrop, in that part where the Stirrop is fa≈øtned to the Anvil.

The u≈øe of the≈øe four Bones is not, that by hitting one again≈øt another they ≈øhould produce a ≈øound, but fir≈øt, to defend the Membrane of the Tympanum or Drum, le≈øt it ≈øhould be torn and beat inwards by the violent ≈øhaking of the outward Air again≈øt it, in loud ≈øounds, ≈øuch as Thunder, or the noi≈øe of great Guns and the like.

Secondly, They are a≈ø≈øi≈øting to the Sen≈øe of Hearing on this manner: The external Air beats again≈øt the Drum, which is driven again≈øt the Hammer, and this ≈øtrikes upon the Anvil, as the Anvil bears again≈øt the Stirrop; which as it does, more ≈øtrongly or weakly, ≈øo does the Stirrop open the oval Window more or le≈øs, and proportionably the ≈øound appears to the common Sen≈øory, louder, or lower.

We come in the next place to ≈øpeak of the Caverns or Cavities, by ≈øome called Dens, which are formed in the mid≈øt of the Os petro≈øum or Rockey-bone where it bunches out mo≈øt, and are three in number.

The fir≈øt of them is to be ≈øeen as ≈øoon as the Membrane of the Drum is taken away, and is called Concha, from its re≈øemblance to the ≈øhell of a Taber. Others call it the Ba≈øin, and ≈øome the Den. It has its fir≈øt denomination, (which is that which it is mo≈øt commonly known by) not ≈øo much from its ≈øhape, as from its u≈øe; for when the Membrane is ≈øtruck upon by any outward ≈øound, the Echo is made in this Cavity, even as it is in the hollow of a Taber, or in our common Drum when the Parchment is beat upon; for in all the≈øe the ≈øound is principally occa≈øion'd by the Air included in the Cavity.

Nature hath placed in this Cavity divers In≈øtruments; as fir≈øt, ≈øome ≈øerving for pul≈øation, ≈øuch are the four Bones, the Cord and the Mu≈øcles, (of all which before.) Secondly, others for conduction into the other Cavities; ≈øuch are two perforations or little holes, commonly called Windows. And la≈øtly, a third ≈øort for Expurgation; ≈øuch are the pa≈ø≈øages which lead, one into the Palate, and another into the No≈øtrils, by the help of which the pituitous Matter which is collected in this Cavity is di≈øcharged.

The fir≈øt of the perforations being the upper and larger, has added to it the Epithet Oval, alluding to its figure. This opens inwards or backwards, and that with a pretty wide mouth, into the Labyrinth; but is kept ≈øhut next the Concha by the ba≈øis of the Stirrop, when ≈øound cea≈øes. The other being the le≈øs and lower, is of a round ≈øhape (and therefore ≈øtyled Rotunda.) This is always open having no covering, and is divided by the Os ≈øquamo≈øum into two Pipes, one of which tends to the Cochlea, the other into the Labyrinth.

The ≈øecond of the≈øe Cavities of the inward Ear is (from its windings and turnings) called Labyrinthus, the Labyrinth. If one con≈øider it in its whole dimen≈øion it is round, and much le≈øs than the former. Its windings are circular, yet the circles run not quite round the Cavity, but come as much ≈øhort of an intire circle as the Gri≈øtles of the Wind-pipe in the Throat do, or rather more, ≈øo that they are commonly termed ≈øemicircular. Their u≈øe is to modulate the ≈øounds ≈øo as they may be lei≈øurely communicated to the Auditory Nerve which is di≈øper≈øed through the Membrane that inve≈øts this Cavity, or rather makes it. It has three pretty wide holes, two opening into it, and one out of it. The two that open into it, are the oval and round holes, mentioned in the foregoing Paragraph. By the≈øe the internal agitated Air pa≈ø≈øes out of the Concha into the Labyrinth. That which opens out of it is that which pa≈ø≈øes towards the third Cavity called Cochlea, into which the afore≈øaid Air pa≈ø≈øes further by it out of the Labyrinth. Be≈øides the≈øe there are four other very ≈ømall holes for the ingre≈øs of the nervous Fibres that are in≈øerted into the Membrane that cloaths this Cavity.

The third and la≈øt inner Cavity is called Cochlea or the Snail-≈øhell, from the re≈øemblance it hath with that Shell, e≈øpecially in its Spiral winding; which, if you take off the upper part of the Bone, will plainly appear.

This Cavity is far le≈øs than the former two, being indifferent long but crooked. Into this endeth one Pipe from the round hole of the fir≈øt Cavity, and another from the ≈øecond, ju≈øt now mentioned.

It is inve≈øted, as the other Cavities are, with a ≈øoft and thin Membrane (after the ≈øame manner as the ≈øockets of the Teeth are) into which (as into that of the Labyrinth) the ≈ølender Fibres of the Auditory Nerve do enter, and that through three or four ≈øeveral holes which are all very ≈ømall.

It is filled with the internal inbred Air as well as the former, by which the Echo is made to the impul≈øe of the external Air upon the Tympanum that is the vehicle of the ≈øound: And the Auditory Nerve being in≈øerted into the Membrane that cloaths the Cavities, is affected therewith, whereby it comes to be communicated to the original of the Nerves where the common Sen≈øory is ≈øeated, that judgeth and di≈øtingui≈øheth of them.

Into the≈øe three Cavities that make up the Internal Ear, are the ≈øame Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels di≈øtributed as to the External: The Nerves are al≈øo from the ≈øame conjugation, namely the ≈øeventh pair; onely whereas the harder Proce≈øs of the Nerve goes to the External Ear, it is the ≈øofter that comes to the Internal.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the No≈øe, Lips and Mouth.

argument.p: The external Parts of the No≈øe. The Skin. Bones and Gri≈øtles. Ve≈ø≈øels. The internal Parts. The nervous Membrane. The mu≈øcular Membrane. Spongy Fle≈øh. Sieve-like Bone. The u≈øes of the No≈øe. The Lips. Their ≈øub≈øtance. Their u≈øe. The Mouth. The Parts containing. The Parts contained. The Gums. The Palate. The Uvula. Its u≈øe. The falling of it a Di≈øtemper incident to Hor≈øes as well as Men. The Tongue. Its Membranes. Its ≈øub≈øtance. Its Ve≈ø≈øels. Its u≈øes. The ≈øalival Ducts. The u≈øe of the Slaver.

div.p: HAVING de≈øcribed all the Organs of Seeing and Hearing, we come in the next place to the third outward Sen≈øe which is the Smelling, of which the No≈øe being the In≈øtrument, we are now to enter upon its de≈øcription.
As therefore the Ear is divided into an External or outward, and an Internal or inward part; ≈øo will we divide the No≈øe, it being made of the like parts.
The External Parts are the Skin, the Mu≈øcles and Gri≈øtles, Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts, as al≈øo many Bones, and tho≈øe di≈øtingui≈øhed or divided by ≈øeveral Sutures.

The Skin wherewith the No≈øe is covered is thin, and without any fat under it, for beauty ≈øake; for if there had been any fat naturally in this place, it might have been collected to that quantity or bulk, as to have become a great deformity to the Creature: for which rea≈øon Nature hath ≈øo ordered it, that in this place the Skin ≈øticketh ≈øo fa≈øt to the Mu≈øcles and Gri≈øtles, that it is not ea≈øie to part it from them without renting.

The Bones which make the Cavities of the No≈øe are ≈øome proper, and ≈øome common: of which hereafter in the Fifth Book of the Bones. The Gri≈øtles are five in number, of which we ≈øhall al≈øo di≈øcour≈øe in the ≈øame Book.

The Ve≈ø≈øels of the No≈øe are, Veins from the Jugular Veins, and Arteries from the Carotides; al≈øo Nerves from the third pair of the Brain, which ≈øend to each ≈øide of the No≈øe one branch, (be≈øides the olfactory Nerves or fir≈øt pair, called the Mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes.)

As to the Internal Parts of the No≈øe, we ≈øhall begin fir≈øt with the Coat or Skin which compa≈ø≈øeth the whole capacity of the No≈øtrils. This Coat is ≈øaid to ari≈øe from that Skin of the Brain which is called the dura mater; and is not peculiar to this Part alone, but is as well common to the Mouth, Palate, Tongue, Larynx, &c. as to the No≈øtrils; onely in the No≈øtrils it is thinner and of exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe; for any thing blown up the No≈øe that is of a biting nature, ≈øo irritates it, as immediately to cau≈øe the Hor≈øe to ≈øneeze. This Skin hath on its back-≈øide abundance of little Glands or Kernels, in which the Rheum is ≈øeparated that runs out by the No≈øe.
There is al≈øo another Skin belonging to the in≈øide of the No≈øe called the mu≈øcular Membrane, which is ≈øaid to draw together or contract the No≈øtrils.
In the upper part of the No≈øtrils there is a red fle≈øhy ≈øpongious ≈øub≈øtance, with which the ≈øpongy Bones are filled up.

There are al≈øo ≈øeated at the upper end of the No≈øe next to the Brain over both No≈øtrils a Bone which from its likene≈øs to a Sieve, (by rea≈øon of the innumerable little perforations or holes that are in it) is called Os cribriforme or Sieve‚ñ™like Bone. In the in≈øide of this Bone are ≈øeared tho≈øe two productions of the Brain called prece≈ø≈øus mammillares, which are the
true In≈øtruments of Smelling, and are therefore better called the Smelling-nerves. There pa≈øs from them through the holes of this Sieve-like Bone many little Strings or Fibres, which are di≈øper≈øed into all the inward capacity of the No≈øe, ≈øerving there to be the immediate Organs of Smelling, but the Scents are communicated to the common Sen≈øory of the Brain by the afore≈øaid Mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes.

The principal u≈øe of the No≈øe is for Smelling, which is performed in this manner. The No≈øtrils are adjuvant In≈øtruments of Smelling even as the External Ear is of Hearing. For as the Ear gathereth the ≈øounds that fly in the Air; ≈øo when ≈ømells exhale out of odoriferous Bodies into the Air, the Hor≈øe by taking in his breath at his No≈øe, (which he for the mo≈øt part does, and not in at his Mouth as we often do) the ≈øcents accompanying the Air a≈øcend up the No≈øtrils to the top of their Cavity, and ≈øo to the before-named Sieve-like Bone, where affecting the little Fibres of the Olfactory Nerves that come, as hath been ≈øaid, from the Mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes through tho≈øe little holes, tho≈øe Fibres communicate their ≈øen≈øation to the Proce≈ø≈øes, and the≈øe convey it to the original of the Nerves or common Sen≈øory, by which it is di≈øtingui≈øhed.

Inferiour u≈øes of the No≈øe are, fir≈øt, to take in the breath by; and next, to ≈øerve as a common Shore or Sink for the di≈øcharge and evacuation of the ≈øuperfluous flegmatick Humours of the Bloud.

In the next place we come to treat of the Lips (or the external Parts of the Mouth) which are two in number, one upper and the other lower. The≈øe are framed of a ≈øoft fle≈øhy fungous ≈øub≈øtance, as al≈øo of ≈øome proper Mu≈øcles covered with the hairy Skin on the out≈øide of them, but on the in≈øide they are covered with a Membrane common to the Mouth and Stomach.

The u≈øes of the Lips are fir≈øt to gather the Hay or Oats or other Food into the Mouth; ≈øecondly to retain, or help to retain it, while it is chewing; thirdly, they ≈øerve to keep the Gums and Teeth from external Injuries.
Within the Lips is the Mouth, who≈øe Parts are either containing or contained, that is, either tho≈øe that make the Mouth, or ≈øuch as are contained in it.

The Parts whereof the Mouth is made, are of two ≈øorts, ≈øome fle≈øhy, others bony. The fle≈øhy Parts are the Lips, of which we have already ≈øpoken; al≈øo the Mu≈øcles of the Cheeks and lower Jaw. The bony are the upper and nether Jaws, with the Teeth fixed in them.

All the≈øe Parts (as al≈øo the whole inward capacity of the Mouth) except the Teeth, are lined with a thick Membrane or Skin, which in the Palate is rugged and knotty as it were, by rea≈øon of the many little Glands on the back-≈øide of it, by which part of the Slaver is ≈øeparated into the Mouth; and this Membrane reduplicated maketh the ∆≤vula, as ≈øome think; though others more probably hold, that it is of a peculiar ≈øub≈øtance.
The Parts contained within the Mouth are divers. As fir≈øt the Teeth and the Bone Hyoides at the root of the Tongue; of both which we ≈øhall treat in the Book of the Bones.
Be≈øides the≈øe there are the Gums, the Palate, the ∆≤vula, the Almonds, the Tongue, and the Mu≈øcles that ≈øerve to move it.
The Gums being in number two, are made up of a hard fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance, de≈øtitute of motion, that ≈øo the Teeth might be better fa≈øtned in their Sockets.

The Palate is the upper part of the Mouth, and is called by that name, from its being as it were fenced or paled in with Teeth. It extends from the back-part of the Mouth to the Fore-teeth, but is not ≈øo much hollowed in an Hor≈øe as in Humane Skulls. It hath in it ≈øome eighteen ≈øteps or bars which reach from the in≈øide of the Fore-teeth to the very farther end of the Mouth. It con≈øi≈øts of Bones, of a peculiar glandulous Fle≈øh, and a thick Coat; which Coat is full of little perforations or holes for the Slaver that is ≈øeparated in the little Glands (above-mentioned) to di≈øtill through into the Mouth.

The ∆≤vula is a red, fungous and longi≈øh kind of a Kernel ≈øeated in the inward or backer-part of the Palate, where the No≈øtrils open into the Mouth, hanging directly downward with a ≈ømall but blunti≈øh end ju≈øt over the chink of the Larynx.

The u≈øe of this ∆≤vula is ≈øaid to be, fir≈øt, to moderate the coldne≈øs of the Air drawn in by the Lungs. This is Bartholin's opinion, who ≈øays further, that from this u≈øe of it it comes to pa≈øs, that ≈øuch Per≈øons as want it, die Phthi≈øical. Whether that be ≈øo or no I cannot tell: but the main u≈øe of it in an Hor≈øe I take to be, ≈øecondly, to hinder the Water, when he drinks, from pa≈ø≈øing out of his Mouth into his No≈øtrils.

This Kernel is very nece≈ø≈øary to be known by all profe≈ø≈øed Farriers, for ≈øuch knowledge might have contributed to the pre≈øervation of many Hor≈øes which for want of it have been lo≈øt. Such are tho≈øe which by rea≈øon of Humours too much flowing to this Kernel have had it ≈øo much di≈øtended, that it hath hung down into the Throat to that degree, that the Hor≈øe hath not been able to ≈øwallow, there being no pa≈ø≈øage left for the Meat to go down; but when he has chew'd it and endeavours to ≈øwallow it, in≈øtead of its going down the Gullet into his Stomach, it comes out at his No≈øe; whereby it comes to pa≈øs that although the Hor≈øe have never ≈øo good a Stomach, yet for all that he comes to ≈øtarve to death with hunger.

This my ≈øelf have been ≈øometimes an Eye-witne≈øs of, and have oftener heard of it by others; but could never ≈øee nor hear of any of them, that had any help for this Di≈øtemper; their endeavours proving ≈øtill un≈øucce≈øsfull by their not well under≈øtanding either the Di≈øtemper, or the Part affected.

This ≈øwelling of the ∆≤vula in Men is called by Phy≈øicians Ca≈øus ∆≤vulae; and by the Vulgar, the falling down of the Palate of the Mouth. It is a Di≈øtemper that commonly comes upon taking ≈øome great cold; but is very ordinarily cured not by Phy≈øicians onely, but by every old Woman, who knows that by holding Pepper or Ginger or the like again≈øt it, the Rheum is thereby drained out of it, and it contracts it ≈øelf to its due and natural bulk, whereby the Party is ≈øpeedily relieved. How far ≈øuch Medicines might contribute to the cure in Hor≈øes, I ≈øhall forbear in this place to give my opinion, becau≈øe as I have already ≈øaid, I do by God's a≈ø≈øi≈øtance de≈øign to publi≈øh a Book of Cures by it ≈øelf, but was willing in the fir≈øt place to teach my Practitioner the frame and u≈øe of the Parts, and to hint ≈øome of tho≈øe Di≈øea≈øes they are incident to, which we have lea≈øt under≈øtood: and by that time the Ingenious Student is come to under≈øtand them, I ≈øhall I hope be ready to publi≈øh a new and certainer way of curing them than has hitherto been practi≈øed.

Next we come to ≈øpeak of the Tongue and its Parts. It is called in Latin, Lingua, √† lingendo, from Licking. It is in figure long, broad and
thick, e≈øpecially towards the root. It is covered with two Skins; the outward, cloathing onely its upper part, which in an Hor≈øe is almo≈øt as ≈ømooth as in Men, though it is much rougher in Oxen, and the like. This Membrane is very porous.

The inward Skin covers the whole Tongue, the lower ≈øide as well as the upper, and is thin and ≈øoft, having many Teat-like Protuberances bunching out of it, which are in≈øerted into the pores or holes of the outward Coat.

Concerning the ≈øub≈øtance of the Tongue there is diver≈øity of opinions; for ≈øome would have it of a glandulous, others a mu≈øculous ≈øub≈øtance; and ≈øome, that it has a peculiar ≈øub≈øtance: to which opinion I mo≈øt incline, becau≈øe I do not find in any Part of the Body a ≈øub≈øtance like it.

It hath Ve≈ø≈øels of all ≈øorts; Veins from an inward branch of the external Jugular; Arteries from the Carotid Arteries; and Nerves of two kinds, one from the fifth and another from the eighth pair of the Brain.

The Tongue hath at its root ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles, by which all its motions are performed, of which we will ≈øpeak in the next Book. And be≈øides the Mu≈øcles, there is al≈øo at the root of the Tongue a con≈øiderable quantity of Fat, with which the Mu≈øcles are interlarded as it were.

The u≈øes of the Tongue are, fir≈øt, to ta≈øte the Food that is offered, whereby (as well as by the ≈ømell) the Hor≈øe di≈øtingui≈øheth whether it be good and whol≈øom for him or not; and in the next place it helpeth the chewing of the Meat, by to≈ø≈øing it to and fro, and after it is chewed, it a≈ø≈øi≈øteth in turning it down to the Stomach.

There is to be found out by di≈ø≈øection underneath the root of the Tongue a large Kernel, from whence two Pipes, called ≈øalival Ducts, do ≈øpring, one from the fore, and the other from the hinder-part of it: The≈øe two at a ≈ømall di≈øtance from the Gland unite into one, which runs pretty ≈øtreight forward under the Tongue toward the Chin: but in the middle way, as Doctor Wharton affirms, there are other pretty remarkable Glands (in an Hor≈øe) that ≈øtand on each ≈øide this Duct, and di≈øcharge them≈øelves into it. When it is come near the Chin at the Bridle of the Tongue, it ends into other ≈ømall Glands, through which it pours into the Mouth part of the Slaver that keeps it continually moi≈øt.

Be≈øides this Duct there are two others of the ≈øame u≈øe, which do ari≈øe out of the Kernels below the root of the Ear, (called Parotides) and run on the out≈øide of the Jaw-bone to the middle of that Mu≈øcle of the Cheek that is called Buccinator, where they open into the Cavity of the Mouth, into which they di≈øcharge the before-named Liquor, which in the≈øe and the other Glands of the Mouth is ≈øeparated from the Bloud.

Now we mu≈øt under≈øtand, this Slaver (or Saliva) is not merely an Humour excrementitious, as that is which is ≈øeparated in ≈øeveral Kernels in other Parts of the Body, as particularly in the Guts; for this is of great u≈øe, not onely in that it continually moi≈øtens the Mouth, as al≈øo the Hay and Oats whil≈øt they are in chewing; but being ≈øwallow'd down with the Meats, it doth further the fermentation and concoction of them in the Stomach, whither part of this Juice al≈øo goes with every mor≈øel. It is of the ≈øame nature with that which in Men we call the Spittle, and of the ≈øame u≈øe.

And here it may not be ami≈øs to recite a ≈øtory I have read of a Per≈øon that had one of the≈øe external ≈øalival Ducts wounded, becau≈øe I have ob≈øerved (the la≈øt Spring at Greenwich) the ≈øame accident happen to an Hor≈øe, with the ≈øame ≈øymptom. The Story is thus: A Noble-man being
wounded in the middle of the Cheek with having a Gla≈øs thrown at him; the Wound was quickly almo≈øt clo≈øed, but in the middle of it, through a little hole, there lei≈øurely di≈øtilled out of it for a long time a watery and clear Liquor, which for all that ever the Surgeon could doe, hindred the intire clo≈øing up of the Wound for almo≈øt two years. This Liquor did di≈øtill out of the ≈øalival Duct, which was not then found out; but at la≈øt an actual Cautery being applied to the end of the Duct, the Liquor was by that means ≈øtopt, and the Wound pre≈øently healed. The Hor≈øe that I ≈øaw had a clear watery Humour running in like manner out of the ≈øide of his Cheek, but in that quantity, that in a few hours time (e≈øpecially in the time next after his drinking) it would make his Manger all a float. A Farrier had him under cure there, and my opinion being ask'd, I advis'd to ≈øear it, but he that had him in hand not knowing the occa≈øion of this flux of Humour, thought rowelling of him would ≈øerve; but what he did to him, I had no opportunity ≈øince to inform my ≈øelf.

Now ≈øeeing a like ca≈øe to this may happen, that my Practitioner may under≈øtand where to apply his Cautery (or red-hot Iron) for the ≈øtanching of the Liquor, I have thought it convenient to annex a Scheme of each of the≈øe ≈øalival Ducts; that under the Tongue being found out by Doctor Wharton, and the other ari≈øing from the Parotides and running on the out≈øide the Gums, by one Steno, a Dane.

div.p: Having now gone through the fir≈øt divi≈øion of the Body, which is into three Venters or Regions, wherein I have principally treated of the Parts contained in them; it now remains that I examine the Parts wherewith the Venters them≈øelves are made up, laying each apart by them≈øelves, that their natures, differences and figures may better appear. The Parts of this nature are the Fle≈øh and Bones, of which two it will be mo≈øt proper to begin with the Fle≈øh, both becau≈øe it maketh the greate≈øt part of the bulk of the Body, and al≈øo becau≈øe of its quick tendency towards putrefaction, whereas the Bones are of a durable nature, and ≈øo no inconvenience will happen upon deferring the examination of them to the la≈øt.
