div.head: THE ANATOMY OF AN HORSE. BOOK IV. Of the Mu≈øcles.
CHAP. I. Containeth a de≈øcription of the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Fle≈øh, and an Apology for not expre≈ø≈øing the Mu≈øcles ≈øo particularly in Figures as I have done other Parts of the Body.
div.p: IN the Fir≈øt Book Chap. 6. treating of the Mu≈øcles of the Belly, I affirmed that all the fle≈øhy Parts of the Body are mu≈øcular; which mu≈øt be under≈øtood not of all Fle≈øh in general, but onely of Fle≈øh properly ≈øo called. For there are four kinds of Fle≈øh: Fir≈øt, that which is properly ≈øo called, ≈øuch as is that of the Mu≈øcles; ≈øecondly, that of the Bowels, as of the Liver and Spleen, and the like; thirdly, that of the Glands or Kernels; and fourthly, membranous Fle≈øh, ≈øuch as is that of the Stomach, Guts, &c.

The Fle≈øh of the Mu≈øcles is ≈øoft and ruddy, con≈øi≈øting of Fibres and coagulated or curdled Bloud, called a Parenchyma. For the Bloud in its circulation as it pa≈ø≈øeth out of the Arteries into the Veins, is extrava≈øated out of the Arteries into the very fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance, out of which it is not
≈øo clearly imbibed or drunk up by the Veins, but that ≈øome particles of it adhere to the fle≈øhy Fibres, and fill up their inter≈øtices, that is, the empty ≈øpaces between one and another: which Bloud congealing and fixing there, does, I ≈øay, together with the Fibres con≈øtitute that ≈øub≈øtance which we properly call Fle≈øh.

As to the other Parts that ≈øerve to con≈øtitute a Mu≈øcle, as al≈øo of its u≈øe, and the rea≈øon of their ≈øundry denominations, I di≈øcour≈øed ≈øo fully in the above-mentioned ≈øixth Chapter of the Fir≈øt Book, that I ≈øhall not need to add any thing to the ≈øame purpo≈øe here: onely I think my ≈øelf in this place obliged to give the Reader the rea≈øons, why I have not repre≈øented the Mu≈øcles in Figures particularly, as I have done other Parts of the Body, nor dare be ≈øo confident of my exactne≈øs in the de≈øcription of them; for

Fir≈øt, The Mu≈øcles are ≈øo numerous, that to have expre≈øt them all in Figures would have made this Volume at lea≈øt half as dear again as it is; as may be gue≈øt by the number of Copper-plates (in Folio) that Mr. Brown has repre≈øented the Mu≈øcles of an Humane Body upon; for they are near fourty, and the≈øe of an Hor≈øe mu≈øt have required rather more than fewer.

Secondly, Though ≈øome knowledge of the Mu≈øcles, e≈øpecially the external ones, is nece≈ø≈øary that one may know in Tumours which way to make inci≈øion (that is, lengthways of the Mu≈øcle and not acro≈øs, for fear of rendring it u≈øele≈øs by cutting its nervous Fibres a≈øunder) yet to be ≈øo very exact in the knowledg of all of them, is matter rather of commendable curio≈øity than real u≈øefulne≈øs.

But thirdly, The chief rea≈øon is (for I will confe≈øs it) that I have not had the opportunity my ≈øelf to rai≈øe and in≈øpect every particular Mu≈øcle, ≈øo that I mu≈øt have delineated ≈øeveral of them by gue≈øs and upon tru≈øt, whereby I ≈øhould both have betrayed my own importune vanity, and have led my Reader 'tis like into ≈øeveral Errours. Neither probably may my verbal de≈øcription of them be truly exact as to tho≈øe which I have not my ≈øelf viewed: though ≈øeeing in tho≈øe that I have in≈øpected, I have found ≈øo great a ≈øimilitude between the Mu≈øcles of an Hor≈øe and tho≈øe of a Man, I hope I ≈øhall not be much wide of the truth, if I pre≈øume of the ≈øame Analogy or likene≈øs in tho≈øe that I have not in≈øpected.

Now as to the likene≈øs of a Man's and an Hor≈øe's Mu≈øcles the Reader may be pretty well ≈øatisfied if he compare tho≈øe of an Hor≈øe's Belly (delineated with the autop≈øie or ≈øelf-view of the Graver) expre≈øt at the end of the ≈øixth Chapter of the Fir≈øt Book, with tho≈øe of a Man's: or take but a pro≈øpect of the next following Figure which repre≈øents an Hor≈øe, ≈øeveral of who≈øe Mu≈øcles I have pre≈øerved, and after having rai≈øed them, placed them in their ≈øeveral places again, the Hor≈øe ≈øtanding up in a Pre≈øs with them on, ju≈øt in the ≈øame po≈øture as he appears in the Figure.

To the≈øe rea≈øons I might add the impo≈ø≈øibility that mo≈øt of my Profe≈ø≈øion ≈øhould ever attain to an exact knowledge of them; ≈øo that this Book being principally de≈øigned for their u≈øe, I ≈øhould have been at a great deal of co≈øt and more pains to no great purpo≈øe. Now the difficulty lies in this, That mo≈øt of the names of the Mu≈øcles being originally Greek, and ≈øeveral of them ≈øuch as can no way aptly or intelligibly be rendred into Engli≈øh; and con≈øidering the mean education of mo≈øt Farriers, that few of them under≈øtand ≈øo much as Latin; I ≈øay con≈øidering the≈øe things, 'tis impo≈ø≈øible to de≈øcribe them to their capacity, and therefore I have contented my
≈øelf with a more ≈øuperficial and ≈øuccinct de≈øcription of them. And though for my own part I may without vain-glory pretend to a more liberal education than mo≈øt of my Profe≈ø≈øion, ≈øo that the Cramp-names (as we call them) of the Mu≈øcles are no ≈øuch hindrance nor di≈øcouragement to me as they will be I fear to mo≈øt others; yet I hope no curious and ingenious Anatomi≈øt, that knows how much time and pains is nece≈ø≈øary to be ≈øpent upon the exact examination of any one Part, will think me ≈øluggi≈øh and ≈øupine, that I have not in tho≈øe few years that I have applied my ≈øelf to this ≈øtudy, attained as yet to the full knowledge of all the Parts of this Bea≈øt that I anatomize. And as on the one hand I hope I may my ≈øelf attain to greater skill in this Art than I have yet arrived at; ≈øo on the other hand I would not be guilty of the vanity of thinking to monopolize it, but ≈øhall both de≈øire and hope that others will make up what I ≈øhall leave imperfect. But thus much I hope may ≈øerve for mine Apology with all ingenuous Men, I ≈øhall therefore return from whence I have digre≈ø≈øed.

A ≈øecond ≈øort of Fle≈øh is that of the Bowels, as of the Liver, Spleen and Kidneys, who≈øe ≈øub≈øtance hath been held to be for the greate≈øt part parenchymous, or to con≈øi≈øt of an affu≈øion of Bloud congealed about the Ve≈ø≈øels; though latter Anatomi≈øts do affirm them to be for the greate≈øt part glandulous. And to the≈øe hath u≈øed to be reckoned the Heart; but that is of a ≈øub≈øtance far different from the≈øe, as being truly mu≈øcular, and may therefore more properly be ranked with the Mu≈øcles, though it be of a more hard and compact frame than them al≈øo.

A third kind of Fle≈øh is that of the Glands, ≈øuch as the Thymus, which by ≈øome is called the Sweet-bread, and is ≈øituated near the Collar-bone ju≈øt within the Che≈øt, of which we have already treated in the Second Book. Of this ≈øort of glandulous Fle≈øh likewi≈øe are the Parotides or Kernels below the Ears, al≈øo the Ton≈øils (commonly called the Almonds of the Ears) very many Glands in the Me≈øentery and other Parts of the Body; to which may be added the Pancreas ≈øeated in the Lower Belly, which is commonly known by the name of the Sweet-bread.

Now the Glands being ≈øpermatical Parts, their parenchyma or fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance is not ≈øanguineous or bloudy, as that of the two former kinds of Fle≈øh; but ≈øpermatical, compo≈øed out of the very fir≈øt rudiments of the embryo or conception. And though the Glands are many times encrea≈øed in bulk, as particularly in Humane Bodies affected with the King's-Evil, and in Hor≈øes which upon taking great Colds have the Ton≈øils or Almonds of the Ears, and al≈øo the Parotides or Kernels below the Ears, ≈øo ≈øwelled and ≈øore, that the Hor≈øe will not be able to ≈øwallow his Drink, or at lea≈øt not to hold down his Head to take it, but mu≈øt be forced to have it given him in a Pail held up as high as the Manger; yet I ≈øay, the encrea≈øe of the≈øe Kernels happens not upon any extraordinary afflux of Bloud flowing to tho≈øe Parts, but by a flegmatick Humour falling upon them, and when the Di≈øtemper is cured they return again to their former ≈ømallne≈øs, being according to Nature incapable of that growth that is natural and proper to the Parts called ≈øanguineous. To this ≈øort of Fle≈øh (≈øay ≈øome Authours) may the Brain be reduced.

The la≈øt ≈øort of Fle≈øh is that which is called Membranous, ≈øuch is that of the middle Coat of the Gullet, Stomach, Guts, Womb and Bladder. For though the inmo≈øt and outermo≈øt Coats be purely nervous or membranous, yet the middle con≈øi≈øts of two ranks of Fibres and a Parenchyma
that adheres to them, which is di≈øcoverable particularly in the Guts, when they are ≈øcraped by Men that make ≈øtrings for mu≈øical In≈øtruments, for then you may perceive a great deal of ≈ølimy ≈øtuff to be ≈øcraped off them, which is this Parenchyma: For that they lo≈øe no part of their membranous or fibrous ≈øub≈øtance is evident, in that their ≈øtrength is rather increa≈øed than dimini≈øhed by ≈øuch ≈øcraping. This Coat notwith≈øtanding it is mu≈øcular, yet its Parenchyma differs in many regards from that of the ≈øanguineous Mu≈øcles, particularly in that it is ≈øpermatical as was ≈øaid before of the Glands.

Now the Parts that con≈øi≈øt of the≈øe three latter ≈øorts of Fle≈øh are all de≈øcribed in their proper places; but tho≈øe that con≈øi≈øt of the fir≈øt ≈øort, which as I have ≈øaid, is mo≈øt properly ≈øo called, I intend to treat of in this Book which containeth the Doctrine of the Mu≈øcles.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Eye-lids.

argument.p: The Eye-lids have three pair of Mu≈øcles. One pair to open them; and Two to ≈øhut them. The Forehead Mu≈øcles.

div.p: HAving in the ≈øixth Chapter of the Fir≈øt Book ≈øpoken of the ≈øeveral Parts of which a Mu≈øcle is compounded, and al≈øo of the differences and actions of them; as likewi≈øe of what u≈øe they are in general; (to which Chapter I refer the Reader) My propo≈øed method requires that I ≈øhould now come to ≈øpeak to every particular of them, beginning with tho≈øe of the Lower Belly: but having in the before-cited Chapter of the Fir≈øt Book treated particularly of them, I will in this place pa≈øs them by, de≈øiring the Reader to con≈øult the ≈øaid Chapter for his ≈øatisfaction; for I love not to be tedious with repetitions.
The next Mu≈øcles then that we come to ≈øpeak to according to order, are the Mu≈øcles of the Eye-lids, which are in number three to each Eye.
The fir≈øt of the≈øe is called Rectus or Aperiens, from its office, which is to lift up or open the Eye-lid.

This is ≈øeated in the upper part of the orbit of the Eye, and ≈øpringeth with a ≈ølender but fle≈øhy beginning from the ≈øame place as the Elevator of the Eye doth, (which is at the hole which the Optick Nerve pa≈ø≈øes through into the orbit) and holds the ≈øame cour≈øe with it, being of the ≈øame figure and ≈øub≈øtance, that is, fle≈øhy; till at la≈øt parting from it, with a pretty broad but thin Tendon, it is in≈øerted into the Gri≈øtle at the edge of the upper Eye-lid, where it ≈øerves (as hath been ≈øaid) to open the Eye-lid by lifting it up.

The two other Mu≈øcles of the Eye-lid are called Shutters, and otherwi≈øe ≈øemicircular, becau≈øe each runs the length of one Eye-lid: though there are ≈øome that call them circular or orbicular, ≈øuppo≈øing them to be but one Mu≈øcle which compa≈ø≈øes the Eye-lid round as with a circle. But in Bodies that are very mu≈øculous or fle≈øhy, they have by curious Anatomi≈øts been plainly di≈øcovered to be two, and that the rather, becau≈øe each receives di≈øtinct Nerves from different places. They lie betwixt the carnous Membrane and the inner ≈ømooth Skin that lines the Eye-lids.

That which draweth down or ≈øhutteth the upper Lid is larger, and ari≈øeth from the inner corner of the Eye, from whence it pa≈ø≈øeth acro≈øs, though with a kind of an oblique line, towards the outward corner, growing pre≈øently fle≈øhy and broad, ≈øo that it filleth up all the ≈øpace betwixt the Eye-brow and the lowe≈øt edge of the Eye-lid, and ≈øo at la≈øt is in≈øerted into the outward corner of the Eye.

The le≈ø≈øer of the≈øe two is that which moveth the lower Lid in order to ≈øhut it. This is rather membranous than fle≈øhy at its origin, (being al≈øo very thin) and takes its ri≈øe at the inner corner of the Eye with a ≈øharp beginning as the former did: whence being carried overthwart, it proceeds to the middle of the Eye-lid, where it becomes ≈øomething fle≈øhy, and continues its cour≈øe to the outward corner, which it turns about, and a≈øcending a little to the upper Eye-lid, is with an indifferent broad end in≈øerted into it.

There is another pair of Mu≈øcles which though not belonging properly to the Eye-lids, yet ≈øeem to contribute ≈øomething to their motion upward or opening, which therefore may rea≈øonably be de≈øcribed in this place, and tho≈øe are the mu≈øculi frontales, or Fore-head Mu≈øcles. The≈øe ari≈øe from the Skull near the coronal Suture, and de≈øcend with ≈øtreight Fibres to the Eye-brows, where they terminate. By the help of the≈øe Mu≈øcles the Skin of the Fore-head to which they clo≈øely ≈øtick is contracted or wrinkled, and ≈øo by con≈øequence the upper Eye-lid's a little drawn upward.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Eye.

argument.p: The Eyes have ≈øeven pair of Mu≈øcles. Their ri≈øe and in≈øertion. Whence they have their names. Attollens and Deprimens. Adducens. Abducens. The upper oblique Mu≈øcle. The lower oblique Mu≈øcle. The orbicular Mu≈øcle. The manner of rai≈øing the Mu≈øcles of the Eye.

div.p: TO the moving of each Eye of an Hor≈øe do belong ≈øeven Mu≈øcles; though in Humane Bodies there are accounted but ≈øix, becau≈øe the circular or ≈øu≈øpending Mu≈øcle is ≈øaid in them to be wanting.

Of the≈øe ≈øeven, four are ≈øtreight, two oblique or ≈ølanting, and the other circular or round. The ≈øtreight ≈øerve to move the Eyes upwards and downwards, to the right hand and to the left. The oblique move them obliquely; and the circular or round one keeps the Eye ≈øu≈øpended up in its place.

The≈øe Mu≈øcles have all their ri≈øe from one and the ≈øame place; they have al≈øo the ≈øame progre≈øs and ≈øtructure, and their termination is alike: for they do all ari≈øe from the Membrane that inve≈øts the Orbit of the Eye near the hole where the Optick Nerve pa≈ø≈øeth from the Brain into the ≈øaid Orbit, touching one another at their beginning; but they immediately ≈øeparate, and in their cour≈øe become ≈øtill more and more bulky and fle≈øhy till their middle, which is round and buncheth out with a kind of a belly; but as they grow toward their ends or terminations they degenerate from their fle≈øhy into a thin membranous ≈øub≈øtance, which is in≈øerted into the horney Coat of the Eye, encompa≈ø≈øing it as far as it is white.

The≈øe Mu≈øcles have their ≈øeveral appellations or names from the ≈øeveral motions they perform; as fir≈øt, The fir≈øt of the ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles, from its office of pulling up the Eye, is called Attollens: The ≈øecond is called Deprimens, becau≈øe it is an Antagoni≈øt to the former, for as that pulls the Eye up, ≈øo this by a contrary motion pulls it down again. From which offices they have al≈øo in Men other two names given them by Anatomi≈øts: the fir≈øt is called the proud, becau≈øe when the Eye is pulled up, a Per≈øon looks high and lofty or proud: and on the contrary when the Eye is pulled down by the other Mu≈øcle, he looks with a contrary countenance, ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive and humble, for which rea≈øon this ≈øecond Mu≈øcle is called humilis or the humble Mu≈øcle.

The next, being the third ≈øtreight Mu≈øcle, is called Adducens, becau≈øe it pulleth the Eye towards the No≈øe. It is otherwi≈øe called Bibitorius, becau≈øe it performs that motion of drawing the Eye to the No≈øe when we drink, for then we commonly look into the Pot or Gla≈øs that is before our No≈øe.
The fourth ≈øtreight Mu≈øcle is called Abducens or Indignatorius, from its office of drawing the Eye to the outer corner, which turn or a≈øpect of the Eye betokens anger or ≈øcorn.

Now the≈øe four Mu≈øcles have the≈øe four ≈øeveral motions, when they work ≈øeverally; but when they all four work together, they have but one action, which is to keep the Eye ≈øteady and fixt, which Phy≈øicians call a tonick motion: but in Bea≈øts that have the ≈øu≈øpending Mu≈øcle, the tonick motion is performed mainly, if not altogether, by that Mu≈øcle. You have the≈øe four, as al≈øo the three other lively repre≈øented to you in the twenty fifth Table of the Third Book, p. 123.

The next are the oblique Mu≈øcles, being as hath been ≈øaid, in number two pair, which from their rolling the Eye about are called circumagentes. The fir≈øt of them is called obliquus major vel ≈øuperior (or the uppermo≈øt and large≈øt oblique Mu≈øcle) being longer than the other, but rather ≈ølenderer. It ≈øpringeth from the upper but inner part of the Orbit of the Eye by the hole where the Optick Nerve comes through, (as do all the re≈øt.) From hence it pa≈ø≈øeth ≈øtreight to the upper part of the inner corner of the Eye, where it endeth in a ≈ømall round Tendon, which pa≈ø≈øeth through a tran≈øver≈øe Cartilage or Gri≈øtle there placed, called Trochlea (or the Pully) and thence continueth its cour≈øe ≈ølantingly along the upper part of the Eye, till at la≈øt it is in≈øerted into the outmo≈øt Skin of the Eye between the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles Attollens and Abducens. This rolleth the Eye towards its inner corner.

The ≈øecond oblique Mu≈øcle is called obliquus minor ≈øive inferior, or the le≈øs and lower oblique Mu≈øcle, being ≈øhorter than the other, though rather thicker. This ≈øpringeth from a chink which is in the lower part of the Orbit of the Eye, beginning with a fle≈øhy head, from whence it a≈øcends with a ≈ølanting cour≈øe towards the outward corner of the Eye, about which it turns, and then ends in a ≈øhort roundi≈øh and nervous Tendon, which meets with the Tendon of the other oblique Mu≈øcle, and ≈øeeming to unite with it, is in≈øerted in the ≈øame place. This rolls the Eye towards its outer corner.

The ≈øeventh Mu≈øcle is called the orbicular or round; likewi≈øe Mu≈øculus ≈øu≈øpen≈øorius, the ≈øu≈øpen≈øory Mu≈øcle; and la≈øtly, becau≈øe it is onely found in Brutes, it hath the name given it of ≈øeptimus Brutorum, the Brute's ≈øeventh Mu≈øcle. It is ≈øhort and fle≈øhy, encompa≈ø≈øing the Optick Nerve,
and is in≈øerted into the hinder part of the Cornea. You have the figure of it in the afore-mentioned twenty fifth Table of the Third Book, wherein it is removed from one Eye, but in the other it is plainly repre≈øented in ≈øitu. The u≈øe of this Mu≈øcle, as hath been ≈øaid, is to ≈øu≈øtain the Eye, le≈øt by looking continually down toward the ground, it ≈øhould hang too much outward; and by it al≈øo the tonick motion is performed.

Having di≈øcour≈øed of the≈øe ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles and of their ≈øeveral actions and u≈øes, I think it very nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øet down the manner of rai≈øing them, that he that will take the pains to examine them in the Creature it ≈øelf, may the better find them, without violating of them unawares, whereby he will lo≈øe his labour, and mi≈øs of ≈øatisfaction in the inquiry after them.

You mu≈øt then, after the taking the Eye and all its appurtenances clear out of the Orbit (if you will make your di≈ø≈øection that way; but if you will take the pains to remove the Bones of the Orbit and not cut the Eye out, it will be much better, for then you are ≈øure to ≈øee the Mu≈øcles in their natural ≈øituation: but whether you remove the Bones, or take the Eye out, you mu≈øt I ≈øay) make your di≈ø≈øection on this manner: Fir≈øt, you mu≈øt with a pair of Sci≈ø≈øers cut off the Fat and the Skins before you rai≈øe any of the Mu≈øcles, making them as clean as you can. Then begin with them in order thus: fir≈øt rai≈øe the larger or upper oblique Mu≈øcle, then the le≈ø≈øer or lower oblique; then the four ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles: but you mu≈øt onely rai≈øe the larger oblique Mu≈øcle and not remove it, untill you have ≈øeen and removed the other five; for when the others are removed, you will the plainer perceive how the Tendon of the ≈øaid Mu≈øcle pa≈ø≈øeth through the Pully, that is ≈øeated in the inner corner of the Eye.

After you have had a full view of the≈øe Mu≈øcles before-named, then mind the la≈øt and ≈øeventh Mu≈øcle, which ≈øtill encompa≈ø≈øeth the Optick Nerve, reaching from the place where the other Mu≈øcles had their ri≈øe, quite down to the hinder hemi≈øphere of the Eye.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Mu≈øcles of the No≈øe.

argument.p: The fir≈øt pair of Abducent Mu≈øcles. The ≈øecond pair. The fir≈øt pair of Adducent Mu≈øcles. The ≈øecond pair.

div.p: THE No≈øe of an Hor≈øe ≈øo far as it is gri≈øtly, is moved ≈øeveral ways, which motions are performed by the≈øe following Mu≈øcles. Fir≈øt it is drawn together to ≈øhut the No≈øtrils by the Adducent or Claudent Mu≈øcles: and ≈øecondly it is drawn a≈øunder to open the No≈øtrils by the Abducent or Aperient Mu≈øcles. And to the performing each motion there belong two pair of Mu≈øcles; ≈øo that in all there are eight Mu≈øcles that belong to the No≈øe. I ≈øhall de≈øcribe the two latter pair fir≈øt, whereof

The fir≈øt pair ari≈øes from the upper Jaw-bone, near the fir≈øt proper pair of the Lips, and is in≈øerted partly into the lower part of the Alae, or gri≈øtly circumference of the No≈øtrils, and partly into the upper part of the upper Lip.

The other pair begins at the top of the No≈øe near the Eye, with an acute and fle≈øhy beginning, whence de≈øcending ≈øomewhat ≈ølantingly, and in its pa≈ø≈øage lying upon each ≈øide of the No≈øe, it doth at la≈øt end at the Alae, as the other pair did, but with a broader and fle≈øhier end. Each of the≈øe Mu≈øcles being narrow at the beginning, and ending broad, is in ≈øhape triangular or three-≈øquare, like the Greek Letter Œî delta, from whence it is called by ≈øome deltoides. The u≈øe of this pair, as al≈øo of the former, is to draw the gri≈øtly circumference or wings of the No≈øtrils upwards, and ≈øo to widen and open them.

The other two pair are called the Adducent or clo≈øing Mu≈øcles; the fir≈øt pair of which is external, ari≈øing about the root of the Gri≈øtle, and a≈øcending cro≈øs-ways to the ridg or tip of the No≈øe, into which it is in≈øerted. This pair is more fle≈øhy than the other, though indeed there is not much Fle≈øh in any of the Mu≈øcles of the No≈øe, and therefore it will require a very accurate Anatomi≈øt to rai≈øe any of them, and to di≈øtingui≈øh them.

The ≈øecond pair of the clo≈øing Mu≈øcles are internal, and are hid in the Cavity of the No≈øtrils under the inner Coat that cloaths them. The≈øe are not ≈øo fle≈øhy as the former. They ari≈øe from the end of the Bone of the No≈øe, and ≈øpreading into a kind of membranous ≈øub≈øtance, they de≈øcend to the gri≈øtly circumference of the No≈øtrils where they terminate.

The fir≈øt pair of the≈øe Mu≈øcles being contracted depre≈øs the Alae or Gri≈øtles of the No≈øe, and the latter pair draw them inwards, and ≈øo clo≈øe the No≈øtrils; to which motion the orbicular or round Mu≈øcle of the upper Lip is a≈ø≈øi≈øtant, for by its drawing the upper Lip downwards, it doth at the ≈øame time con≈øtringe or ≈øtraiten the No≈øtrils.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Lips and Cheeks.

argument.p: The fir≈øt common Mu≈øcle, called the four≈øquare Mu≈øcle. The ≈øecond common Mu≈øcle, called the Trumpeter. The fir≈øt proper pair of Mu≈øcles of the Lips, called par Attollens. The ≈øecond pair, called par Abducens. The third pair, called Zugomaticum. The fourth pair, called Deprimens. The fifth pair, called Obliqu√® detrahens. The odd Mu≈øcle, called Orbicularis.

div.p: TO the Lips do belong ≈øeveral pair of Mu≈øcles, ≈øome of which are proper to the Lips alone, and others are common both to the Cheeks and Lips.

The common are on each ≈øide of the Face two. The fir≈øt of which is called detrahens quadratus, or the four-≈øquare drawers a≈øide of the Cheeks and Lips. This ≈øhews more like a Skin than a Mu≈øcle, being broad and thin, onely it is interlaced with fle≈øhy Fibres, which makes it to be accounted a Mu≈øcle.

It ari≈øes from one of the Vertebres of the Neck on its out≈øide, as al≈øo from the Shoulder-blade, the Collar-bone and Brea≈øt-bone, from whence it a≈øcends with oblique or ≈ølanting Fibres up to the Chin, Lips, and root of the No≈øe; which Parts it draws downwards with a ≈ølanting motion.

The ≈øecond common Mu≈øcle of the Cheeks and Lips, is called in Humane Bodies Buccinator the Trumpeter, becau≈øe in blowing a Trumpet the main ≈øtre≈øs lies upon this Mu≈øcle; though others derive that name from Bucca the Cheek, becau≈øe it is the mo≈øt con≈øiderable Mu≈øcle of it,
and on this account it may retain the ≈øame name in an Hor≈øe: or it may be called the Contracter, from its action, which is to contract the Cheek.

It ≈øprings from almo≈øt the whole length of the upper Jaw-bone, and is in≈øerted into the whole length of the lower, at the root of the Gums. It is thin and membranous, and interlaced with divers Fibres running ≈øundry ways; and hath the inner Coat of the Mouth ≈øo clo≈øely and firmly adhering to it, that it is ≈øcarce ≈øeparable from it. This Mu≈øcle is ≈øeated under the upper part of the former, and is ≈øpread over the whole dimen≈øion of the Cheek.

Its u≈øe in Hor≈øes and other Brutes is to be as a Hand to help the Mouth in its chewing motion; for as the Meat in chewing falls on the out≈øide of the Teeth, betwixt them and the Cheek, this Mu≈øcle helps to turn it over the Teeth again, that it may be ≈øufficiently broken and ground, and made thereby the readier for concoction when it is turned down to the Stomach.
Be≈øides this office of a≈ø≈øi≈øting in chewing, it doth ≈øerve al≈øo at other times upon any occa≈øion to move the Cheeks and Lips.

Next come we to the Mu≈øcles that are proper to the Lips onely, and tho≈øe are by Anatomi≈øts accounted five pair and one odd one. The fir≈øt of them is called par Attollens, or Lifters up of the Lip. This pair ≈øpring from the upper Jaw, where it makes the hollow of the Cheek. At their ri≈øe they are broad and fle≈øhy, from thence pa≈ø≈øing down obliquely along the Cheeks, each of them is in≈øerted into its own ≈øide of the upper Lip, near the No≈øe. The u≈øe of the≈øe Mu≈øcles, if they both of them act together, is to draw the upper Lip directly upwards and outwards; but if onely one acts, then is but one ≈øide of the Lip drawn upward obliquely. You may plainly ≈øee the≈øe Mu≈øcles work, if you take notice of a Ston'd Hor≈øe after he hath ≈ømelt to a Mare; for then he will mo≈øt times hold up his Head in the Air, and turn up his upper Lip till he hath almo≈øt turned it in≈øide outwards. And the like you may ≈øee many Hor≈øes doe, if you onely let them ≈ømell to another Hor≈øe's Dung.

The ≈øecond pair is called Abducens, the Drawers of the Lip on one ≈øide. This ari≈øes at the Cavity that is under the Os jugale with a fle≈øhy and round beginning, which is cover'd with ≈øome Fat, e≈øpecially in fat Hor≈øes; from whence they run down on each ≈øide to the middle of the upper Lip, into which they are in≈øerted with a ≈øtrong round Tendon. The≈øe jointly move the Lips upwards and outwards as the former did, a≈ø≈øi≈øting them in their motion; and when either of them acts ≈øingly, then it a≈ø≈øi≈øts the action of one of the former that is on its own ≈øide, and helps to draw the Lip upwards of one ≈øide.

The third pair is called by Riolanus, Zugomaticum or Jugale, from its ri≈øe, which is outwardly from the proce≈øs of the Os jugale. At their beginning they are fle≈øhy and ≈øomewhat round, and running downward a little overthwart the Cheeks they reach at la≈øt to the ≈øides of the upper Lip, where they are in≈øerted near the corner of the Mouth. The u≈øe of this pair is to draw the Lip upwards ≈øideways.

The fourth pair is called Deprimens, or the Drawers down of the lower Lip. The≈øe ari≈øe fle≈øhy and broad from the lowermo≈øt and outwardmo≈øt part of the Lower Mandible; from whence each marches obliquely to the under Lip, into which they are in≈øerted about the middle of it. The u≈øe of this pair is to draw the under Lip downwards and ≈øomewhat outwards.
So that it joineth in the ≈øame action with the fir≈øt pair of the common Mu≈øcles called Detrahens quadratus.

The fifth pair is called Obliqu√® detrahens, from their office, which is to draw the lower Lip obliquely downwards and outwards. They take their beginning from the ≈øides of the lower Jaw, where they ri≈øe with a fle≈øhy and broad head; from whence they a≈øcend upwards, growing in their pa≈ø≈øage ≈øomething narrower, and are each in≈øerted into the corners of the lower Lip. The u≈øe of this pair is, as hath been ≈øaid, to draw the lower Lip obliquely downwards and outwards.

In the next place we come to the odd Mu≈øcle, called Orbicularis, or orbicular, becau≈øe it goes round the circuit of both the Lips. It is al≈øo called Con≈øtringens, becau≈øe it ≈øerves as it were for a Sphincter Mu≈øcle to pur≈øe up or contract the Lips. Be≈øides the≈øe names it has in Men that of O≈øculatorius, the Ki≈ø≈øing Mu≈øcle, becau≈øe it contracts or draws the Lips together in ki≈ø≈øing. It ≈øticks very clo≈øe to the Skin of the Lips, and makes up the greate≈øt part of their ≈øub≈øtance.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Mu≈øcles of the lower Jaw.

argument.p: The fir≈øt pair of Mu≈øcles called the Temporal. The ≈øecond pair, called Deprimens. The third pair, called Ma≈ø≈øeteres. The fourth pair, called Pterygoideum externum. The fifth pair, called Pterygoideum internum.

div.p: THE upper Jaw being immoveable hath no Mu≈øcles, there being no occa≈øion for them where there is no motion, which is their onely u≈øe. But the lower Jaw which hath motions of divers ≈øorts, doth require divers ≈øorts of Mu≈øcles to perform them. Now the≈øe Mu≈øcles are in number five pair.

The fir≈øt pair of the≈øe Mu≈øcles is called the Temporal, becau≈øe they are ≈øeated upon the Temples. They ≈øpring on each ≈øide from the Bones of the Brow or Fore-head, the Synciput, Temples and Wedge-like Bone. They are the ≈øtronge≈øt and large≈øt of all the five pair. Their beginning is fle≈øhy, large and ≈øemicircular, their in≈øide lying upon the Perio≈øteum, and their out≈øide covered with the Pericranium. They de≈øcend under the Os jugale to the acute Proce≈øs of the lower Jaw, into which they are in≈øerted by a ≈øhort but very ≈øtrong Tendon. The≈øe Mu≈øcles with great force pull up the lower Jaw, and ≈øo ≈øhut the Mouth.

The ≈øecond pair hath the name of Deprimens, becau≈øe they pull down the Jaw. They are al≈øo from their ≈øhape, having as it were two bellies, called biventre. The≈øe being a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the quadrati, which were de≈øcribed in the foregoing Chapter (being one of the pairs that are common to the Cheeks and Lips) pull down the Jaw, and ≈øo open the Mouth. They ari≈øe with a broad and nervous beginning from the Proce≈øs of the Temple-bone called Styloides, and ≈øuddenly becoming round, fle≈øhy and ≈ømall, they pa≈øs downwards, and in their middle where they come to the flexure of the lower Jaw-bone, they lo≈øe their fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance and degenerate into a nervous and round Tendon, and then becoming fle≈øhy again they are in≈øerted into the inner ≈øide of the lower Jaw at the middle or fore-part of it.

The third pair is called Ma≈ø≈øeteres, becau≈øe they are very a≈ø≈øi≈øtant in the office of chewing, by moving the Jaw to the right and left ≈øide. Each hath two beginnings: the fir≈øt is large, ≈øtrong and nervous, ari≈øing from that Suture where the fourth and fir≈øt Bone of the upper Jaw are joined; the other beginning is fle≈øhy, ≈øpringing from the Os jugale. They are firmly and largely in≈øerted into the out≈øide of the lower Jaw. The≈øe Mu≈øcles, by rea≈øon of their diver≈øity of Fibres, move the nether Jaw both forwards, backwards and to the ≈øides, and ≈øo in a manner circularly.

The fourth pair are called Pterygoideum externum, as if they re≈øembled a pair of Wings. The≈øe like the former have al≈øo a double beginning, partly nervous, and partly fle≈øhy. They ≈øpring partly from the upper and outward ≈øide of the Wing-like Proce≈øs of the Wedge-like Bone, and partly from the rough and ≈øharp line of the ≈øame Bone, from whence they march down with ≈øtreight Fibres, becoming in their cour≈øe larger and thicker, till they come to the lateral part of the lower Jaw, into who≈øe in≈øide they are in≈øerted with a ≈øtrong Tendon. The u≈øe of this pair of Mu≈øcles is to open the Jaw and move it forward, which appeareth when the Teeth of the lower Jaw are ≈øtretched farther out than tho≈øe of the upper.

The fifth and la≈øt pair of Mu≈øcles of the lower Jaw are called Pterygoideum internum. The≈øe ari≈øe with a nervous beginning from the inner ≈øide or cavity of the Wedge-like Bone, at its wing-like Proce≈øs; then becoming fle≈øhy, large and thick, they march down with a ≈øtreight pa≈ø≈øage to the inner and hinder part of the lower Jaw, where they are in≈øerted by a nervous, broad and ≈øtrong Tendon. The u≈øe of the≈øe Mu≈øcles is to draw the Jaw towards its head or backwards; and al≈øo to help the Temporal Mu≈øcle to draw the Jaw up.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Ear.

argument.p: The External Ear hath four Mu≈øcles. 1. The lifter up of the Ear. 2. The puller back of the Ear. 3. Adducens Aurem. 4. Abducens Aurem. 1. The Inward Ear hath two. The External. 2. The Internal.

div.p:
THE Mu≈øcles of the Ears in Brutes (e≈øpecially ≈øuch as have large Ears, as Hor≈øes, A≈ø≈øes, Oxen, Hares, &c.) differ much in magnitude from tho≈øe of Men, in whom they are ≈øo very ≈ømall, that Galen calls them, the lineaments of Mu≈øcles. The rea≈øon of which is, that in Man the Ears are mo≈øt commonly immoveable, (though there have been ≈øome that could move them) and therefore to have large Mu≈øcles were needle≈øs; and yet to have none at all, would look like a defect in the mo≈øt perfect of all Animals. But though Man cannot move his Ears, yet is that no prejudice to his hearing; for the want of that motion is recompenced by the ea≈øie and ≈øpeedy motions of his Head, whereby he can turn it on every ≈øide to receive the ≈øounds; whereas four-footed Bea≈øts, that have the motions of their Heads not ≈øo nimble, have need to have their Ears always moveable every way, to receive the ≈øounds from every ≈øide: and their moveablene≈øs has al≈øo a further u≈øe, to wit, to drive away
Flies and other In≈øects that are trouble≈øome to the Bea≈øt, which Men can doe with their Hands.

The Ear we divided, in the former Book, into the Outward and Inward. The Outward (of which we have been di≈øcour≈øing thus far in this Chapter) has four Mu≈øcles; and the≈øe are tho≈øe which are ≈øo much larger in Brutes than Men. The Inward Ear has two, which are of a proportionable largene≈øs in both.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe we come to treat of is the fir≈øt of the Outward Ear, which goes by the name of Attollens Aurem, the lifter or puller up of the Ear. This ari≈øes at the out≈øide of the Frontal or Forehead Mu≈øcle, and at its ri≈øe is thin and membranous; from whence being carried over the Temporal Mu≈øcle, and growing in its cour≈øe ≈øomething narrower, it doth at la≈øt in≈øert it ≈øelf into the upper part of the Ear, moving it upwards and forwards.

The ≈øecond is called Detrahens Aurem, or the puller back of the Ear. This Mu≈øcle ari≈øes from the Mammillary Proce≈øs with a fle≈øhy, broad and fibrous head; and ≈øo growing narrower in its progre≈øs is at length in≈øerted into the root of the Gri≈øtle of the Ear, ≈øometimes by two, ≈øometimes by three Tendons. The u≈øe of this Mu≈øcle is to draw the Ear backwards and ≈øomewhat upwards.

The third is called Adducens Aurem, by which the Ear is drawn forwards and ≈øomewhat downwards. This is ≈øaid to be but a part of the mu≈øculus quadratus before ≈øpoken of in the fifth Chapter of this Book, being one of the common Mu≈øcles of the Cheeks and Lips. This Mu≈øcle a≈øcending with its Fibres is implanted into the lower ≈øide of the root of the Ear.

The fourth is called Abducens Aurem, becau≈øe it draws or pulls the Ear backwards. This takes its beginning at the Occiput or back-part of the Head from the Coat that cloaths tho≈øe Mu≈øcles that belong to that part, where it is at fir≈øt ≈øomething narrow, but afterward waxing broader it is carried tran≈øver≈øly to the hinder part of the Ear, into which it is in≈øerted. This a≈ø≈øi≈øts the ≈øecond in its action, having ≈øometimes two, and ≈øometimes three Tendons as that has.

The next are the two Mu≈øcles of the Inner Ear (called Auris, as the Outward Ear is called Auricula) the fir≈øt of which is called Externus Tympani Auris, or the external Mu≈øcle of the Drum of the Ear, becau≈øe it moves the Membrane of the Ear ≈øo called upwards and outwards. This is thin but broad at its ri≈øe, which is from the upper part of the pa≈ø≈øage of the Ear; then becoming narrower it grows into a very fine and ≈ømall Tendon, which is carried on the out≈øide of the Tympanum till it arrive at its centre or middle into which it is in≈øerted, where on the in≈øide of this Tympanum the little Bone called the Hammer ≈øticketh, which with the Membrane or Tympanum this Mu≈øcle draweth a little outward and upward. This Mu≈øcle as al≈øo the next are very ≈ømall, there being ≈øcarce any in the whole Body again ≈øo ≈ømall as they are; and therefore it will require great skill to rai≈øe them without violating of them. To prevent which the undertaker is to open with great care the Os petro≈øum which is to be done on that ≈øide which is next to the Temples, taking out the pieces of Bones by degrees that the≈øe Mu≈øcles may receive no prejudice. It is left to the di≈øcretion of the Di≈ø≈øector whether he will remove the Bones with a Chi≈ø≈øel, or Saw, or by filing, ≈øo he doe it carefully.

The ≈øecond is called Internus, and hath its origination from the bottom of the Os cuneiforme or Wedge-like Bone, there where it is joined with the Proce≈ø≈øus petro≈øus. It is ≈øeated inwardly in the Cavity of the Os petro≈øum, being fle≈øhy at its beginning, yet thin and ≈ømall: at its middle it is divided into two very ≈ømall and very thin Tendons, whereof one is in≈øerted into the upper Proce≈øs of the Malleus or Hammer, and the other into the neck of it. The u≈øe of this Mu≈øcle, alone, is to draw the head of the Hammer obliquely forwards, and al≈øo to draw it ≈øomewhat inwards: but when the≈øe two act both together, they move the Tympanum with its ≈ømall Bones upwards and downwards, which is done when the Hor≈øe would carefully li≈øten or harken to any approaching noi≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Tongue.

argument.p: The Tongue hath five pair of proper Mu≈øcles. 2. Hyp≈øiloglo≈ø≈øum. 3. Myloglo≈ø≈øum. 4. Ceratoglo≈ø≈øum. 5. Styloglo≈ø≈øum.

div.p: THE Tongue in Brutes hath but two principal u≈øes, viz. to ta≈øte the Food, and to rowl it up and down the Mouth: but in Men it has a third u≈øe, which is to be the main in≈øtrument of Speech. Yet notwith≈øtanding there are as many Mu≈øcles that belong to it in Brutes as there do in Men; for in ≈øome regard it has a further u≈øe in them than in Men, ≈øeeing it does not onely ta≈øte and rowl about the Meat, but it ≈øerves al≈øo to gather it into the Mouth; for that they doe with their Tongue, becau≈øe they have not the help of Hands as we have. Wherefore that the Tongue might perform all the≈øe offices, it was nece≈ø≈øary it ≈øhould be furni≈øhed with variety of Mu≈øcles, to make it capable of being moved every way, outward and inward, upward and downward, and ≈øideways. And le≈øt in undergoing the≈øe motions it ≈øhould be made to reach farther than is nece≈ø≈øary, Nature hath re≈øtrained it with a ≈øtrong Ligament underneath, which in Men is called the Fraenum or Bridle of the Tongue.
The Tongue therefore hath five pair of Mu≈øcles proper to it ≈øelf, be≈øides tho≈øe that are common to it and the Os hyoides, of which in the following Chapter.

The fir≈øt pair proper to it is called Genioglo≈ø≈øum (or the Chin-tongue pair) ≈øo called becau≈øe their ri≈øe is from the Chin, and their in≈øertion into the Tongue. This name is proper enough in Men who have Chins, but agrees not ≈øo well with them in Hor≈øes (or other Brutes) in whom we call all that part below the Teeth, the lower Jaw, not di≈øtingui≈øhing any part of it by the name of the Chin. But notwith≈øtanding I ≈øhall de≈øcribe them by that name, becau≈øe it would be too tedious and too bold an undertaking for me to invent new names for this as well as for others that are in Brutes as improperly called by ≈øuch names as this pair is; leaving ≈øuch an attempt to tho≈øe that have both more lei≈øure, and that make a greater figure in the Anatomical Province.

This pair ari≈øe from the ruggedne≈øs which is in the middle of the lower Jaw before, in the inner and lower part of it. In their progre≈øs they are ≈øaid to have ≈øeveral ≈øuch in≈øcriptions as the ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles of the
Paunch have, as if each con≈øi≈øted of ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles; however that be, they reach to the middle of the Tongue where they are in≈øerted into its lower ≈øide. Their u≈øe is to move the Tongue forwards, towards the Foreteeth, and many times out of the Mouth, that is, when the Bea≈øt gathers in his Meat.

The ≈øecond pair is called Hyp≈øiloglo≈ø≈øum, (which word ≈øhould be writ without an H, ≈øeeing they have this name becau≈øe they ri≈øe from the bottom of the Os hyoides, which is otherwi≈øe called Yp≈øiloides,) from its re≈øembling in ≈øhape the Greek Letter v (Yp≈øilon.) They end in the middle of the Tongue, and have an action contrary to the former; for as tho≈øe mov'd the Tongue outward, ≈øo the≈øe move it ≈øtreight inward or backward.

The third pair is called Myloglo≈ø≈øum, from the places of its ri≈øe and in≈øertion; for they ari≈øe from the inner part of the lower Jaw, at the roots of the farthe≈øt grinding Teeth, and are in≈øerted into the Ligament by which the Tongue is tied to the fauces or Jaws. If this pair work together, they draw the Tongue downwards; but if onely one of them work, then it draws the Tongue obliquely to its own ≈øide.

The fourth pair is called Ceratoglo≈ø≈øum, becau≈øe they ari≈øe from the horns of the Os hyoides, and reaching from thence to the ≈øides of the Tongue are there in≈øerted into it. If one of the≈øe work alone, it draws the Tongue a≈ølant to either the right or left ≈øide; but if both work together, they draw the Tongue downwards and inwards.

The fifth and la≈øt pair of Mu≈øcles proper to the Tongue are called Styloglo≈ø≈øum, becau≈øe they ari≈øe from the Styloides (or Pen-like) Proce≈øs of the Temple-bones, being fle≈øhy at their beginning, though very ≈ømall and ≈øharp; but afterwards becoming broader and thicker, they run to the ≈øides of the Tongue, into which they are in≈øerted about the middle of its length. If either of the≈øe Mu≈øcles move ≈øingly, the Tongue is drawn to the right, or left ≈øide; but if both act together, they pull the Tongue upwards and inwards.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Bone of the Tongue, called Os hyoides.

argument.p: The Os hyoides hath four pair. 1. Sternohyoideum. 2. Geniohyoideum. 3. Coracohyoideum. 4. Styloceratohyoideum.

div.p: THE Mu≈øcles of the Cheeks and Tongue ≈øerving to to≈øs the Meat to and again in the Mouth, and tho≈øe of the lower Jaw helping to chew or grind it; after it is ≈øufficiently minced, it wants afterward to be ≈øwallowed and to be tran≈ømitted into the Stomach. Now none of the fore≈øaid Mu≈øcles contribute any thing thereto, therefore it was nece≈ø≈øary there ≈øhould be others appropriated thereto, which by moving diver≈øly the root of the Tongue might make way for the mor≈øel to de≈øcend into the Gullet. Such are tho≈øe that are common to the Tongue and the Bone called hyoides that is fa≈øten'd to its root or ba≈øis, which are in number four pair.

The fir≈øt pair is called Sternohyoideum, becau≈øe they ≈øpring from the upper but inner part of the Sternum or Brea≈øt-bone (with a broad and fle≈øhy beginning) and a≈øcending under the Skin of the Neck by the Wind-pipe (≈øtill keeping the ≈øame largene≈øs and ≈øub≈øtance) are at length in≈øerted into the root or bottom of the Os hyoides, which they move downward and backward.

The ≈øecond pair is oppo≈øite to the former, and is called Geniohyoideum. The≈øe are large, ≈øhort and fle≈øhy all over, and ari≈øe with Fibres of a divers cour≈øe, from the in≈øide of the fore-part of the lower Jaw (called in Men the Chin) and are in≈øerted into the middle part of the Bone hyoides, which they draw ≈øtreight upwards and a little forwards.

The third pair is called Coracohyoideum. The≈øe are ≈ølender, but ≈øtrong, and long; yea con≈øidering the ≈ølenderne≈øs of them, they are the longe≈øt Mu≈øcles of the whole Body. They ari≈øe out of the Proce≈øs called Coracoides at the upper end of the Shoulder-blade near the Neck, and run obliquely upward under the fir≈øt pair of Mu≈øcles of the Head called Ma≈øtoideum, where they lo≈øe their fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance, as giving way to the other that are more worthy and con≈øiderable than them≈øelves, and degenerate each into a nervous and round Tendon for ≈øome time; but ≈øo ≈øoon as they are pa≈øt the≈øe Mu≈øcles, they become mu≈øculous again, and ≈øo continue till they reach to the Os hyoides, into who≈øe horns they are in≈øerted. The≈øe becau≈øe of their two bellies are by ≈øome called Diga≈øtricks. Their u≈øe is to pull the Os hyoides obliquely downwards.

The fourth and la≈øt pair of Mu≈øcles of the Os hyoides is called Styloceratohyoideum. The≈øe ari≈øe from the root of the Appendix or Proce≈øs called Styloides, and end in the horns of Os hyoides. They move the Bone obliquely upwards.

I hope the Engli≈øh Reader will pardon me for not tran≈ølating the names of the≈øe Mu≈øcles, for it is impo≈ø≈øible for any Man to doe it, ≈øeeing our Engli≈øh Tongue is not capable of ≈øuch compo≈øitions as the Greek admits of, from whence the≈øe names are borrowed: but he will ≈øee the rea≈øons of the names, if he ob≈øerve but the parts from whence the Mu≈øcles are ≈øaid to ri≈øe, and into which they are in≈øerted, in the de≈øcription of them.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Larynx or Throttle.

argument.p: The Larynx hath two pair of common Mu≈øeles, viz. 1. Sternothyreoideum. 2. Hyothyreoideum. 1 and four pair proper ones and an odd one, viz. Cricothyreoideum. 2. Cricoarytaenoideum po≈øticum. 3. Cricoarytaenoideum laterale. 4. Thyreoarytaenoideum. 5. The Mu≈øcle Arytaenoides.

div.p: THE Larynx in Mankind is the main in≈øtrument in modulating or forming the Voice, ≈øo as to make the tone high or low, &c. And though few Bea≈øts can alter their tones with that variety that a Man can, yet have they the ≈øame number of Mu≈øcles to move the ≈øeveral Gri≈øtles whereof the Larynx is compo≈øed. Now its Mu≈øcles are either proper, or common. The common are tho≈øe that are implanted into the Larynx, but ari≈øe not therefrom; and the proper are tho≈øe that both ari≈øe and end in the Larynx. The common are four, and the proper nine.

The fir≈øt of the common pair is called Sternothyreoideum, and by ≈øome Bronchium, or the Weazand-mu≈øcles. The≈øe ari≈øe with a fle≈øhy and broad beginning from the upper and inner part of the Sternum or Brea≈øt-bone at the very Throat, a≈øcending with right or ≈øtreight Fibres up by the ≈øides of the Wind-pipe, continuing the ≈øame largene≈øs and ≈øub≈øtance till they reach to the Cartilago thyreoides, or Shield-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle, into which they are in≈øerted. Their u≈øe is to draw down the ≈øaid Gri≈øtle, and ≈øo to widen the Chink as ≈øome Authours think; though others are of opinion that ≈øuch drawing of it down, ≈øerves to ≈øtraiten the Chink.

The ≈øecond pair is called Hyothyreoideum. The≈øe ari≈øe from the lower ≈øide of the Bone hyoides, having a broad and fle≈øhy beginning; from whence de≈øcending with ≈øtreight Fibres they are in≈øerted into the Cartilago thyreoides; by lifting which upwards they are ≈øaid to ≈øtraiten the Chink of the Larynx; though ≈øome on the contrary affirm that they widen it.

Next come we to the proper Mu≈øcles of the Larynx, the fir≈øt pair of which is called Cricothyreoideum anticum, becau≈øe they take their beginning from the fore-part of the Ring-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle called Cricoides, and proceed obliquely to the Shield-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle or Thyreoides, into who≈øe ≈øides they are implanted. The u≈øe of this pair of Mu≈øcles is to move the Shield-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle or Thyreoides obliquely downwards, and by that means to open the glottis or Chink of the Larynx.

The ≈øecond of the proper pairs of Mu≈øcles of the Larynx are called Cricoarytaenoideum po≈øticum. The≈øe contrary to the former ari≈øe from the lower and back-part of the Ring-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle, and running upward with ≈øtreight Fibres are in≈øerted with a nervous end into the lower ≈øide of the Arytaenoides or Ewer-like Gri≈øtle, which it pulls upward and backward, and thereby opens and widens the Larynx.

The third pair is called Cricoarytaenoideum laterale, becau≈øe they are ≈øeated at the ≈øides of the former pair. They ari≈øe from the ≈øides of the Anulary or Ring-fa≈øhioned Cartilage ≈øomewhat ≈ølender; from whence proceeding directly upwards, and becoming more large and fle≈øhy, they come to the Arytaenoides, into the ≈øides of which they are implanted in that part that the foregoing pair did not cover. The u≈øe of this pair is to open the Larynx by drawing the Gri≈øtles obliquely a≈øide.

The fourth pair is called Thyreoarytaenoideum. The≈øe are the large≈øt and ≈øtronge≈øt of all the proper Mu≈øcles of the Larynx, yea almo≈øt equal to all the re≈øt put together. They ari≈øe clo≈øe one to the other from the inner hollow and middle part of the Thyreoides or Shield-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle, who≈øe inner Cavity they fill through the whole length of it, and with oblique Fibres they a≈øcend upward, growing narrower in their a≈øcent, till they come to their in≈øertion into the ≈øides of the Ewer-like Gri≈øtle. The≈øe are the Mu≈øcles that are principally affected in Humane Bodies when they are in the greate≈øt danger from that Di≈øea≈øe called the Squinancy or Quin≈øie. For when the≈øe Mu≈øcles are inflamed, they ≈øwell inwards into the Throttle, and make the Cavity thereof ≈øo ≈øtrait, that the Patient cannot fetch his breath, but is ≈øtrangled.

The fifth and la≈øt is reckoned but for one ≈øingle Mu≈øcle, and is called Arytaenoides, al≈øo Claudens ≈øecundum, or the ≈øecond Shutting-mu≈øcle. They take their ri≈øe from the hinder line of the Ewer-like Gri≈øtle or Arytaenoides from whence it hath its name. It is very ≈ømall but fle≈øhy, and running with tran≈øver≈øe Fibres, it is in≈øerted into the ≈øides of the ≈øame Gri≈øtle, which it helps to con≈øtringe or draw both its ≈øides together, and ≈øo ≈øtraitens the Throttle.

The Epiglottis or Throat-flap, that covers the Chink of the Larynx has no di≈øcernible Mu≈øcles in Man, nor I believe in an Hor≈øe: but in Cattle, Sheep, &c. that chew the Cud, it is ≈øaid to have evident ones; ≈øome of which ≈øpring from the Os hyoides, and are in≈øerted into the ba≈øis of the Epiglottis, which they lift up; and others are placed between the Coat and Gri≈øtle of the Epiglottis, helping it to ≈øhut the Larynx.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Uvula and Throat.

argument.p: The Uvula hath two Mu≈øcles. 1. Pterygo≈øtaphilinus externus. 2. Pterygo≈øtaphilinus internus. The Pharynx hath ≈øeven Mu≈øcles. 1. Par Sphenopharyngaeum. 2. Cephalopharyngaeum. 3. Stylopharyngaeum. 4. The Mu≈øcle Oe≈øophagiaeus. Two pair of Mu≈øcles lately found out by Doctor Croune, viz. Pterygo-palatini, and Spheno-palatini.

div.p: THE ∆≤vula is ≈øaid to have two Mu≈øcles to hold it up, one of which is called Pterygo≈øtaphilinus externus. This ≈øpringeth from the upper Jaw a little beyond the furthermo≈øt Grinder, and is in≈øerted into the ∆≤vula.

The ≈øecond is called Pterygo≈øtaphilinus internus. This proceeds from the lower part of the inner Wing of the Proce≈øs Pterygoides (or Winglike) and is in≈øerted in like manner as the former into the ∆≤vula.

This is the de≈øcription that Anatomi≈øts commonly give of the≈øe two Mu≈øcles; but it may be que≈øtion'd whether they are any more than imaginary ones; for ≈øeeing the ∆≤vula has no apparent voluntary motion, it ≈øeems to have no occa≈øion for any Mu≈øcles.

Next to the Mu≈øcles of the ∆≤vula come tho≈øe of the Throat (or the beginning of the Gullet called Pharynx) to be treated of, to which belong ≈øeven Mu≈øcles, that is, three pair and a Sphincter. The fir≈øt of the pairs is called Sphenopharyngaeum. The≈øe ari≈øe thin and nervous from the Appendix of the Wedgelike-bone, de≈øcending by the inward Cavity of its
Wing-like Proce≈ø≈øes, and are in≈øerted into the lateral parts of the Palate and Pharynx, which they widen in ≈øwallowing.

The next pair is called Cephalopharyngaeum. The≈øe ≈øpring from that part where the Head is joined to the fir≈øt Vertebra of the Neck, from whence they de≈øcend to the Pharynx, into which they are ≈øpread with a large plexus of Fibres, which ≈øeemeth to make its Membrane. The action of this pair is contrary to the former; for as tho≈øe widen the Pharynx to let the nouri≈øhment de≈øcend into the Gullet, ≈øo the≈øe ≈øtraiten it when the Food is pa≈øt by it, and thereby ≈øqueeze the Food down the Gullet.

The third pair is called Stylopharyngaeum. The≈øe ari≈øe with a ≈ømall beginning from the inner part of the Styloides Proce≈øs of the Temple-bone, and de≈øcending with a thin body are in≈øerted into the ≈øides of the Pharynx which they dilate or widen.

The la≈øt of the≈øe Mu≈øcles is that which hath no fellow, and is called Oe≈øophagiaeus, or the Sphincter of the Gullet. This ari≈øes at one ≈øide of the Thyreoides, or Shield-fa≈øhioned Gri≈øtle, and is in≈øerted into the other ≈øide of the ≈øame, wholly encompa≈ø≈øing in its cour≈øe both the fore and back part of the Gullet, in the ≈øame manner as the Sphincters of the Anus and Bladder do tho≈øe Parts, ≈øerving here for the ≈øame u≈øe, viz. to draw or pur≈øe in the mouth of the Gullet, as tho≈øe do the Ar≈øe and Bladder. Now though I have the warrant of ≈øeveral Authours in de≈øcribing of this Mu≈øcle la≈øt of the ≈øeven, yet there be others that treat fir≈øt of it, and reckon it the fir≈øt Mu≈øcle of the Throat, ≈øaying, that if you fir≈øt rai≈øe this, the two next before-mentioned pairs, namely, the Stylopharyngaeum and the Cephalopharyngaeum, may be the better found.

Having done with the Mu≈øcles of the ∆≤vula and Throat, as al≈øo with all the Mu≈øcles of the inward and outward Parts of the Mouth and Chaps, according as they are treated of by the Ancient and Modern Anatomizers of the≈øe Parts; it remains now that I ≈øhould de≈øcend to the Mu≈øcles of the Head and Neck, and ≈øo to the inferiour Parts; but before I depart quite from hence, I think it nece≈ø≈øary to give the Reader an account of two pair of Mu≈øcles more, which belong to the Palate of the Mouth, never treated of by any Anatomi≈øt yet, ≈øave Mr. Brown, who in his Book of the Mu≈øcles lately ≈øet forth, gives the fir≈øt account of them, at the de≈øire of the di≈øcoverer of them, which was the mo≈øt ingenious Doctor Croune now living, and at this time Lecturer at Chirurgeons Hall in London.
This worthy and learned Di≈øcoverer hath given them the≈øe names following; the fir≈øt he calls Mu≈øculi Pterygo-palatini, and the other Sphenopalatini.

This de≈øcription hath he al≈øo given of them, viz. The fir≈øt or Pterygo-palatini are ≈øeated in the lower part of the Cavity of the Wing-like Proce≈ø≈øes of the Wedge-like Bone, and terminate about the Glandula palati with their Tendons, which run upon part of the fore-mentioned Proce≈ø≈øes, as on two Trochleae or Pullies. The u≈øe of this pair is to depre≈øs the before-named Gland of the Palate and the ∆≤vula.

The latter of them, which he calls Spheno-palatini, have an u≈øe contrary to the former, viz. to lift up the fore-mentioned Gland and ∆≤vula. Their ri≈øe is from the Os ≈øphenoides or Wedge-like Bone, and their in≈øertion (with a broader Tendon than the former) into the ≈øides of the before-mentioned Gland and ∆≤vula. It is believed from the ≈øituation and action of this la≈øt pair of Mu≈øcles, that when the Rheum that had ≈øwelled the
Gland and relaxt the ∆≤vula, is drained away, the≈øe Mu≈øcles help to reduce the ∆≤vula to its proper and natural ≈øituation; though to me it ≈øeems, that its own contracting of it ≈øelf is ≈øufficient.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Head.

argument.p: The Head hath eight pair of proper Mu≈øcles. 1. Ma≈øtoideum. 2. Splenium. 3. Complexum. 4. Parvum & cra≈ø≈øum. 5. Rectum majus. 6. Rectum minus. 7. Obliquum ≈øuperius. 8. Obliquum inferius.

div.p: THE Mu≈øcles of the Head are either proper or common. The common are tho≈øe which primarily move the Neck, and the Head onely ≈øecondarily, of which in the next Chapter; for according to order the proper are fir≈øt to be ≈øpoken to, and the≈øe are they that move the Head onely, the Neck at that time remaining unmoved, the number of which are ≈øixteen, or eight pair.

The fir≈øt pair is called Ma≈øtoideum (which pair ≈øome Authours indeed reckon for the eighth or la≈øt pair, and the Splenium for the fir≈øt; but being willing to follow the more modern Writers I will begin with the Ma≈øtoideum and reckon them for the fir≈øt pair.)

The≈øe are ≈øeated in the fore-part of the Neck, having each a double beginning; one of which is from the Brea≈øt-bone, being altogether nervous, and the other from the Collar-bone, which is fle≈øhy. From the≈øe originals they a≈øcend obliquely upwards by the Neck, till they come to the hinder part of the Head, viz. to the Mammillary Proce≈øs of the Temple-bone, into which each is in≈øerted by a round and fle≈øhy Tendon. If both the≈øe Mu≈øcles work together, then they bend the Head right forward or downward; but if one onely works, then that draws the Head a little to one ≈øide. Of all the eight pair there are onely this that bend the Head ≈øtreight forward, and that are placed in the fore-part of the Neck; for all the re≈øt are ≈øeated behind towards the Mane, and do either pull the Head back, or el≈øe to one ≈øide.

The ≈øecond pair (or fir≈øt pullers back of the Head) is called Splenium. The≈øe are long and thick, ari≈øing from the five uppermo≈øt Vertebrae of the Che≈øt and five lowermo≈øt of the Neck, with a nervous beginning; from whence a≈øcending to the hinder part of the Head, they there end with a broad and fle≈øhy Tendon. The u≈øe of the≈øe, if both of them act together, is to draw the Head directly backward; but if either of them act ≈øingly, then it draws the Head a little to one ≈øide.

The third pair, (being the ≈øecond puller back of the Head) is called Complexum or Trigeminum, becau≈øe each Mu≈øcle ≈øeems to con≈øi≈øt of three, for it ari≈øes with three heads; one of which is from the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈øs of the fourth and fifth Vertebrae of the Che≈øt; the ≈øecond from the fir≈øt and ≈øecond of the ≈øame, and the third from the ridge of the ≈øeventh Vertebra of the Neck: all which uniting into one body, the Mu≈øcles a≈øcend upward as far as to the Occiput or Noll-bone, (in their cour≈øe becoming fle≈øhy and broad) and are in≈øerted into the ≈øaid Noll-bone, at the root of the Mammillary Proce≈øs, ≈øometimes by one, and ≈øometimes by a triple Tendon.

The third puller back of the Head, or fourth pair, is called parvum & cra≈ø≈øum, becau≈øe they are ≈ømall and thick. The≈øe are ≈øituated under the former, ari≈øing from the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the ≈øix uppermo≈øt Vertebrae of the Neck, with a nervous beginning; but afterward becoming fle≈øhy, they are carried obliquely upward, and are in≈øerted into the hindermo≈øt root of the Proce≈ø≈øus Mammillaris. Their u≈øe is, if they act both together, to bring the Head lightly backwards; and if but one act, then to bring it backward to one ≈øide.

The fifth pair is called Rectum majus or the greater right pair, being ≈ømall, fle≈øhy and ≈ølender, and ari≈øing from the tip of the Spine or ridge of the ≈øecond Vertebra of the Neck, where they touch one another; but pre≈øently part, and a≈øcending both upward, end with a round Tendon in the middle of the Noll-bone or Occiput. The action of this pair is the ≈øame as of the former.

The ≈øixth pair (being the fifth of the pullers back) is called Rectum minus, or the le≈ø≈øer right pair. Their ≈øituation is ju≈øt under the former pair, as it were concealed, and are of the like ≈øub≈øtance, form and progre≈øs. They ari≈øe clo≈øe together from the back-part of the fir≈øt Vertebra of the Neck where the Bone ≈øhould have ended in a Spine, but that Spine is wanting becau≈øe it would have offended the former pair of Mu≈øcles that ≈øpring from the ≈øecond Vertebra and march over this. Pre≈øently after their original they part, and a≈øcend upwards, and on either ≈øide are implanted into the Noll-bone. The u≈øe of the≈øe is to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the motion of the two foregoing pair. Now the rea≈øon why there are ≈øo many Mu≈øcles appointed to move the Head backward, and but one pair forward, is becau≈øe the Head by rea≈øon of its great bulk and weight, is prone enough of it ≈øelf to incline forward or downward; but it requireth a great force to move it upward or backward.

The ≈øeventh pair is called Obliquum ≈øuperius, or the upper Oblique pair. The≈øe are ≈øeated under the right or ≈øtreight pairs, and are like them in form and ≈øub≈øtance. They are ≈ømall, ari≈øing out of the middle of the Occiput at the out≈øide of the ≈øtreight pairs, from whence they de≈øcend downwards, and are in≈øerted into the tips of the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the fir≈øt Vertebra of the Neck, the right-hand Mu≈øcle into the right Proce≈øs, and the left into the left. The u≈øe of the≈øe, if they both act together, is to nodd the Head gently directly backwards.

The eighth pair is called Obliquum inferius, or the lower Oblique pair. The≈øe ari≈øe from the Spine or ridge of the ≈øecond Vertebra of the Neck, from whence running obliquely upwards, they end at the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the fir≈øt Vertebra of the Neck. They are longi≈øh, round and fle≈øhy, and make (as do al≈øo the former) a Triangle of equal ≈øides.

The u≈øe of this pair is to move the Head as it were ≈øemicircularly, (for it cannot be moved quite round) the fir≈øt Vertebra turning upon the Tooth-like Proce≈øs of the ≈øecond: but this motion is performed, when one of them onely acts at a time; for if both of them move or act together, then they either keep the Head ≈øteady (as ≈øome Authours conceive) or el≈øe draw it a very little backwards.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Neck.

argument.p: The Mu≈øcles common to the Head and Neck are four pair. 1. Spinatum. 2. Tran≈øver≈øale. 3. Longum. 4. Scalenum.

div.p: THE Head is not onely moved by its proper Mu≈øcles mentioned in the la≈øt Chapter, primarily; but ≈øecondarily al≈øo by other Mu≈øcles belonging to the Neck, which are in number eight, on each ≈øide four, by the help of which the Neck is ≈øometimes bent forward, other times extended backward; it is al≈øo ≈øometimes drawn to one ≈øide, and ≈øometimes to the other: but there are more Mu≈øcles to draw it backwards than either forwards or to one ≈øide, becau≈øe the labour is greater by rea≈øon of the weight of the Head and Neck (as was ≈øaid in the former Chapter.) There are therefore two pair of Mu≈øcles to bend the Neck backward, namely the fir≈øt and ≈øecond, which do al≈øo draw it a little obliquely; and the third and fourth pair draw it both forward and to one ≈øide, as both act together, or but one of each pair at a time.

The fir≈øt pair of the≈øe is called Spinatum, becau≈øe they are ≈øeated among≈øt the Spines of the Vertebrae. They ari≈øe from the roots of the Spines of the ≈øeven uppermo≈øt Vertebrae of the Che≈øt, and five lowermo≈øt of the Neck, being ≈øeparated from one another onely by the tips of the Spines, and are in≈øerted into the whole lower ≈øide of the Spine of the ≈øecond Vertebra of the Neck. They bend the Neck backward, or a little obliquely. Some think that they have no original from the Spines of the Neck, but that they onely adhere to them in their pa≈ø≈øage.

The next pair is called Tran≈øver≈øale, becau≈øe they both ri≈øe from and are in≈øerted into the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the Vertebrae. They take their beginning from the roots of the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the ≈øix uppermo≈øt Vertebrae of the Che≈øt; from whence a≈øcending by degrees they become ≈øtronger and thicker, and are in≈øerted into the out≈øides of all the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the Neck-bones. The u≈øe of this pair, as al≈øo of the former, is as hath been ≈øaid, to pull or draw the Neck directly backwards; but if one Mu≈øcle of either pair work alone, it pulls the Neck with an oblique motion.

The third is called Longum, or the Long pair. The≈øe lie hid under the Oe≈øophagus or Gullet, wherefore they are by ≈øome called the Undergullet-lurkers. They ari≈øe with a thin and ≈øharp but fle≈øhy beginning from the body of the fifth and ≈øixth Vertebrae of the Back, and as they a≈øcend upwards, are knit to the ≈øides of all the Vertebrae, till they come to the fir≈øt or highe≈øt of the Neck, where each touching other they are both in≈øerted into its Proce≈øs. The u≈øe of this pair, when they work together, is to bend the Neck directly forward, and withall to incline the Head; but if one of them act alone, then is the Neck drawn towards that ≈øide on which the Mu≈øcle moveth.

The fourth and la≈øt pair of the Mu≈øcles of the Neck is called Scalenum or Triangulare. The≈øe by ≈øome Authours are accounted as the eighth pair of the Che≈øt. They are ≈øeated on the ≈øides of the Neck inclining rather to the fore than hinder part of it. They take their beginning from the fir≈øt Rib, ari≈øing fle≈øhy and large, and are in≈øerted into the in≈øide of all
the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the Vertebrae of the Neck. Their u≈øe is the ≈øame with the foregoing pair. They are ob≈øerved to be perforated or to have holes through them, by which Veins, Arteries and Nerves do pa≈øs out of the Body into the Fore-legs.
