argument.p: There are four pair of Mu≈øcles that widen the Che≈øt. 1. Subclavium. 2. Serratum majus Anticum. 3. Serratum po≈øticum ≈øuperius. 4. Serratum po≈øticum inferius. Two pair that contract the Brea≈øt. 1. Par Triangulare. 2. Sacrolumbum. Cervicale de≈øcendens.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Brea≈øt.
div.p: HAving di≈øpatched the Mu≈øcles of the Head and Neck, we come in the next place to ≈øpeak to tho≈øe of the Che≈øt or Thorax, in which are contained the principal In≈øtruments of Life, the Heart and Lungs. Now the Lungs being the principal organs of Re≈øpiration, and wanting Mu≈øcles whereby to dilate or contract them≈øelves, it was nece≈ø≈øary they ≈øhould receive a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from the Che≈øt in which they are included, by the dilatation or contraction whereof, they might be al≈øo dilated and contracted. To which end the Che≈øt is furni≈øhed with ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles, ≈øome of which contract it in Expiration, that is, when the Hor≈øe lets forth his breath, and others dilate it in In≈øpiration, when he receives in his breath.

Of the Dilaters or tho≈øe that widen the Che≈øt there are four pair, be≈øides the ≈øixteen pair of the External Interco≈øtals, there being (as is already ≈øaid in Chap. 2. of the Second Book where I largely treated of them) between each Rib two Mu≈øcles, an External and an Internal one. Now there being in number ≈øeventeen Ribs, reckoning a Rib for the extreme part both toward the Neck and toward the Flank, there mu≈øt be one pair of Mu≈øcles fewer than there are Ribs, of which tho≈øe that are ≈øeated externally, ≈øerve all as one Mu≈øcle to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the widening or dilating the Che≈øt, and tho≈øe that are ≈øeated internally (lying under the former) a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the contraction of it. For a more full de≈øcription of the≈øe Mu≈øcles you may plea≈øe to turn back to the afore-cited Chapter.

The fir≈øt pair of the dilating or widening Mu≈øcles is called Subclavium,from their ≈øituation, which is under the Collar-bone called Clavicula, for they fill up that ≈øpace that is between the Clavicle and the fir≈øt Rib. The≈øe ari≈øe fle≈øhy from the inner and lower part of the Clavicle or Collarbone, which is next to the Rib, and running obliquely or ≈ølanting forward, are implanted into the fir≈øt Rib near the Brea≈øt-bone with a fle≈øhy end. The action of this pair of Mu≈øcles is to draw the fir≈øt Rib upwards and outwards, by which motion the cavity of the Che≈øt is widened.

The next or ≈øecond pair of the Dilaters is called Serratum majus Anticum, or the greater and foremo≈øt Saw-like pair, ≈øo called partly from their ≈øituation and magnitude, and partly from the figure of their Tendons which re≈øemble the teeth of a Saw. They ari≈øe from the in≈øide of the Shoulderblade and the two upper Ribs, and are in≈øerted into the lower five Trueribs and two upper ba≈øtard or Short-ribs, before they end into Gri≈øtles; ≈øo that its breadth takes up a great part of the ≈øide of the Che≈øt, and it is al≈øo very fle≈øhy. The u≈øe of this pair of Mu≈øcles is to draw the Ribs outwards and upwards, and ≈øo to dilate or widen the Che≈øt, which it doth more e≈øpecially in great and violent ≈øtrainings.

The third proper pair of the Mu≈øcles of the Che≈øt is called the upper backward Saw-pair, or Serratum po≈øticum ≈øuperius. They are ≈øeated on the Back under the Mu≈øcle called Rhomboides or the fourth Mu≈øcle of the Shoulder-blade, betwixt both the Blades, and above the fir≈øt pair of the
Head. They ≈øpring membranous from the Spines of the three lower Rack-bones of the Neck and the fir≈øt of the Back, and are in≈øerted into the Inter≈øtices of three or four of the upper Ribs. Their u≈øe is the ≈øame as of the former, viz. to draw the Ribs upward, whereby the Che≈øt is dilated, and the inner Cavity thereof inlarged.

The fourth is called Serratum po≈øticum inferius, the lower backward Saw-pair. The≈øe are ≈øeated almo≈øt in the middle of the Back, under the broad Mu≈øcle that is the fir≈øt of the Depre≈ø≈øors of the Shoulder. They ari≈øe from the Spines of the three lowe≈øt Vertebrae of the Back and of the fir≈øt of the Loins, with a membranous, nervous and broad beginning; afterwards they pa≈øs with an overthwart line cro≈øs the Mu≈øcles of the Back, and being increa≈øed with fle≈øhy Fibres are in≈øerted into three or four of the lower ≈øhort Ribs before they turn into Gri≈øtles. Their u≈øe is to draw the three or four lowe≈øt Ribs outwards, and ≈øo to dilate or widen the lower part of the Che≈øt.

Be≈øides the four pair already named there is yet another Mu≈øcle that a≈ø≈øi≈øts the≈øe in the motion of widening the Che≈øt in In≈øpiration, which is the Diaphragma or Midriff, of which I have already ≈øpoken in its proper place, namely in the fourth Chapter of the Second Book; I ≈øhall therefore omit ≈øpeaking of it any farther here.

Next come we to treat of the Mu≈øcles that contract or ≈øtraiten the Che≈øt in Expiration or letting forth the breath. The fir≈øt pair of the≈øe is called par Triangulare, or triangled pair, though they make not a perfect triangle, becau≈øe they con≈øi≈øt of two long ≈øides and one ≈øhort one. The≈øe ari≈øe from the middle line of the Brea≈øt-bone on the in≈øide of it, (for their ≈øeat is within the Cavity of the Che≈øt, under the Brea≈øt-bone) being little and ≈ølender, and are in≈øerted into the bony ends of the third, fourth, fifth and ≈øixth True-ribs (where they are fa≈øtned to the Gri≈øtles.) The u≈øe of this pair is to draw the Ribs toward the Brea≈øt-bone, and thereby to ≈øtraiten the Che≈øt in Expiration.

The next is called Sacrolumbum from their ri≈øe, which is from the Os ≈øacrum and from the Spine or ridge of the Lumbi or Loins. They are ≈øeated under the Serratum po≈øticum inferius, and creeping upwards mix them≈øelves with the long Mu≈øcle of the Back, and al≈øo fa≈øten them≈øelves to the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the Racks of the Loins as far as to the lowe≈øt Rack of the Che≈øt, from whence a≈øcending up to the Ribs, they are in≈øerted into the lower ≈øide of them all by a particular Tendon about three or four fingers breadth from the ridge of the Back. The u≈øe of this pair according to Ve≈ølingius, is to contract the Che≈øt; but Spigelius and al≈øo Bartholinus do believe that becau≈øe it grows out of the ≈øame beginning with the long Mu≈øcle of the Back, therefore it extends and rai≈øes up the Che≈øt as that doth.

There is another pair oppo≈øite to this de≈øcribed by Diemerbroeck, a diligent Anatomi≈øt, who hath given them the name of Cervicale de≈øcendens. The≈øe, ≈øays he, do ≈øpring from the third, fourth, fifth, ≈øixth and ≈øeventh Vertebrae of the Neek, and are in≈øerted into the upper ≈øide of each Rib, as the Sacrolumbum is into the Lower; and ≈øays, that this pair by pulling the Ribs upwards in In≈øpiration widen the Che≈øt, as the other by drawing them down in Expiration ≈øtraiten it.

To the Mu≈øcles already ≈øpoken of, which do contract the Che≈øt, do belong the ≈øixteen Internal Interco≈øtal Mu≈øcles: For as the External ones a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Wideners or Dilaters of the Che≈øt in their motions, ≈øo do the
Internal al≈øo a≈ø≈øi≈øt the≈øe contracting Mu≈øcles in the drawing together of the Che≈øt, and do all act together as one Mu≈øcle, as the others do; for they pa≈øs obliquely from the lower to the upper Ribs, as the others did from the upper to the lower, their Fibres running contrary to or acro≈øs the former. All the≈øe Mu≈øcles are ≈øaid, ≈øecondarily, to be a≈ø≈øi≈øted in their motion by the Abdominal Mu≈øcles, as al≈øo by the Mu≈øcles of the Shoulderblade and Fore-legs.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Back and Loins.

argument.p: The Mu≈øcles of the Back have but one motion. Four pair of the Back and Loins. 1. Mu≈øculi longi≈ø≈øimi. 2. Par Quadratum. 3. Sacri. 4. Par Semi≈øpinatum. The di≈øtemper called a ≈øway'd Back is oftner an affection of the≈øe Mu≈øcles, than any di≈ølocation in the Vertebrae.

div.p: THE Mu≈øcles of the Back, as al≈øo of the whole Spine, are ≈øo diver≈øly and intricately intermixed and knit together, that ≈øome Anatomi≈øts have divided them into more, others into fewer, and that by rea≈øon of the infinite originals of the Fibres and the multitude of their in≈øertions, all which the admirable wi≈øedom of Nature thought fit to mingle and knit one within another, that they might the better and with the more ≈øtrength ≈øu≈øtain and accompli≈øh tho≈øe ≈øtrong and violent actions to which they are de≈øign'd, and al≈øo with more ea≈øe and ≈øafety bear ≈øuch extraordinary heavy weights, as this noble Animal, the ≈øubject of my Di≈øcour≈øe, doth continually undergo. For if power united be the ≈øtronger, (as the common ≈øaying is) then certainly if many Mu≈øcles con≈øpire together unto one motion, they will be better able to perform it.

Now that there are not more than one apparent motion performed by the Mu≈øcles of the Back of an Hor≈øe is plain, which motion is by the help of the Back-bones to rai≈øe up and ≈øu≈øpend as it were the whole bulk of the Body, and to bear al≈øo great weights many times upon it: I ≈øay this is the main, if not the onely motion performed by the≈øe Mu≈øcles; for the Bodies of Hor≈øes cannot be turned backwards and forwards, to the ≈øides, and almo≈øt ≈øemicircularly, as the Backs of Men are, as may be ≈øeen in Dancers, Tumblers and the like.

Again, the≈øe Mu≈øcles though they are by later Anatomi≈øts divided into ≈øeveral pairs, yet the Ancients (as Galen for one) were of opinion, that ≈øeeing they cannot be by any means truly ≈øeparated, either there mu≈øt be ≈øo many pair as there are Rack-bones, or el≈øe (which is more likely) that there is but one onely pair, offering tendinous di≈øtributions to all the Vertebrae of the Back. And ≈øays Galen, If one of this pair work alone, the Spine is inclined towards that ≈øide, be it the right or left; but if they both work together, the Spine is bended to neither hand, but pulled ≈øtreight backward, or rather the Spines are held in their ≈øeveral proper places. And, adds he, whereas almo≈øt all Mu≈øcles have their Antagoni≈øts, that are the Authours of a contrary action to theirs, yet the≈øe Mu≈øcles of the Spine (if you except the bending Mu≈øcles of the Neck) have no Antagoni≈øts or Oppo≈øites.

Neither are the≈øe Mu≈øcles of the Back proper to the Back alone,but common to the Loins al≈øo, being reckoned their ≈øecond pair, of which I
will fir≈øt treat though it be contrary to the cu≈øtom of Anatomi≈øts to doe ≈øo This pair then goes by the name of Ma≈øculi longi≈ø≈øimi, ≈øo called from their extraordinary length, as being the longe≈øt Mu≈øcles (and al≈øo the ≈øtronge≈øt) in the whole Body. For they ari≈øe from the Os ≈øacrum, and Ileium or Haunch-bone, and pa≈ø≈øing along by the Spine or ridge of the Loins, Back and Neck, they reach as far as to the Proce≈ø≈øus Mammillares, or Mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes of the Temple-bones. They are almo≈øt confounded with the Sacrolumbum and Semi≈øpinatum in their march through the Loins, whence by ≈øome tho≈øe are taken to be parts of this pair: but as ≈øoon as this pair arrives at the Back, it parts with tho≈øe, and appears to be di≈øtinct from them. Their u≈øe is (if they act together) directly to extend the Back and Loins; but if one onely work, then is the Spine inclined on one ≈øide, for their Fibres are oblique or ≈ølanting.

The next pair goes by the name of Quadratum or the Square pair, from their Figure; for whil≈øt they are in their natural ≈øituation they both of them together make a four-≈øquare figure, though when they are ≈øeparated they are each of a triangular ≈øhape. They ari≈øe broad, thick and fle≈øhy from the backward and upper Cavity of the Haunch-bone, and from the inner and upper ≈øide of Os ≈øacrum, and remaining fle≈øhy in their whole cour≈øe, they are in≈øerted into all the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the Vertebrae of the Loins as far as the lowe≈øt Rib. Their u≈øe is to bend the Racks of the Loins with a right motion forward or downward; but if one of them work alone, it draws the Loins to one ≈øide a little downward.

The next are the Mu≈øcles called Sacri, or holy Mu≈øcles, from their ri≈øe, which is from the Os ≈øacrum. They ≈øpring with an acute original from that part of the ≈øaid Bone where the Spine is fa≈øtned to the Haunchbones. After their original they grow broad by degrees, and though they end not till they come to the Spine of the lowe≈øt Vertebra of the Thorax, yet in their progre≈øs they are in≈øerted into ≈øeveral of the Spines and oblique Proce≈ø≈øes of the Vertebrae of the Loins, their Fibres running obliquely or with a ≈ølanting line upwards and inwards. The u≈øe of this pair, if one work alone, is to pull the Body a little on one ≈øide, but if both act or work together, they extend that part of the Spine to which they are fa≈øtned.

The la≈øt pair is called Semi≈øpinatum. The≈øe ari≈øe with a nervous original or beginning from all the Spines or Ridges of the Os ≈øacrum and the Loins, and are in≈øerted into the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the Vertebrae of the Loins and ≈øome of the lowermo≈øt of the Che≈øt. The≈øe with the former pair do fill up the di≈øtances between the Spines, where they touch one another, nothing coming between them to ≈øeparate them from one another, but a membranous Ligament i≈ø≈øuing from the upper Spine. The u≈øe of this pair is to join the Spines together, and to extend or erect that part of the Back to which they grow. Now if all the≈øe Mu≈øcles of the Back and Loins work together, the whole Back is extended, or in a manner drawn backwards: but if the Mu≈øcles of one ≈øide work alone, the Body is inclined to that ≈øide.

The≈øe Mu≈øcles are apt to have their tone and ≈øtrength violated by ≈øeveral accidents, as by over-great Loads, by a ≈øudden Gold taken by pulling off the Saddle after hard riding before the Hor≈øe be quite cold, and the like; whereby the Mu≈øcles become benumbed and relaxed, and ≈øo are in a manner deprived of both ≈øen≈øe and motion; by which means the
Hor≈øe becomes u≈øele≈øs, being ≈øo far from being able to carry Burthens or to perform any other ≈øervice for his Ma≈øter, that when he is up he can hardly ≈øerve him≈øelf, I mean, ≈øtand to eat his Meat; or if down, not able to ri≈øe without help. This al≈øo often happens to old and lean Hor≈øes, in whom by rea≈øon of the weakne≈øs of their Bodies, as al≈øo becau≈øe they abound with flegmatick Humours, the≈øe Mu≈øcles are ≈øo relaxt that they are ≈øcarce able to ≈øupport the weight of their own Bodies, much le≈øs other Burthens. And in this ca≈øe I think nothing more proper than good ≈øtore of ≈øtrengthening Food, to ≈øupport and nouri≈øh their in≈øide, whereby they may gain ≈øtrength, and withall to apply ≈øome ≈øtrengthening Pla≈øter to the out≈øide at the ≈øame time.

But to recover tho≈øe that come by this affection by great Colds taken as is above-mentioned, it will be the be≈øt way to give them warm, ≈øtrengthening and comfortable Medicines inwardly, and al≈øo to apply fir≈øt ≈øome warm Sheep-skins pretty often renewed, and at the ≈øame time to anoint the Loins with ≈øome ≈øovereign Ointments or Oyles outwardly; or if this will not doe, then to ≈øweat him in a Dunghill, and after he comes out, to apply to the Loins a ≈øtrengthening Charge or Pla≈øter.

I thought my ≈øelf a little obliged in this place to inlarge upon this account, to undeceive many of our Profe≈ø≈øors, who take all Di≈øtempers in this kind to be as one, concluding ≈øtill that all Hor≈øes thus affected, are either ≈øtrained in the Kidneys or ≈øwayed, as we call it, in the Back; when indeed the≈øe Mu≈øcles are either benumbed by cold as afore≈øaid, or by ≈øtrains gotten by carrying over-great weights or burthens, they are di≈øtended to that degree, that for ≈øome time they lo≈øe the ≈øtrength and vigor they u≈øed to perform their motions with; this, I ≈øay, is often the true cau≈øe of the debility and weakne≈øs of the Back.

Not that I will deny that there is any ≈øuch malady as a ≈øwayed Back, for I have my ≈øelf by di≈ø≈øection ≈øeen in a Hor≈øe that was knocked on the Head, (being not curable of this Di≈øtemper) not onely all the mu≈øcular Parts as it were brui≈øed, and many of their inter≈øpaces filled with a kind of a congealed Humour or Matter, but al≈øo found a kind of di≈ølocation in that part where the Os ≈øacrum or lowe≈øt Vertebra of the Loins are joined, and a deal of congealed Matter ≈øettled about tho≈øe Parts. But ≈øuch a ≈øtrain is ≈øeldom curable, or if ever, not without great charge and long keeping. What I have therefore ≈øaid upon this account is to let our Profe≈ø≈øors know, that mo≈øt of tho≈øe affections which they call ≈øway'd Backs are onely di≈øtempers of the Mu≈øcles, and therefore ea≈øily cured if ≈øoon taken in hand: but tho≈øe which have broken Backs, (which we commonly under≈øtand by ≈øwayed Backs) are ≈øeldom curable. And thus much ≈øhall ≈øuffice as to this ≈øort of di≈øcour≈øe in this place; it remains now that I return to my former di≈øcour≈øe, and de≈øcribe the remaining part of the Mu≈øcles, of which tho≈øe of the Anus, Bladder, and Genitals both in Hor≈øes and Mares come next to be ≈øpoken to.

argument.p: The Sphincter Mu≈øcle of the Anus. Two Levators. The Sphincter of the Bladder.

div.p: AHor≈øe being a Creature made for ≈øervice, it was fit that he ≈øhould void his Excrements at his own conveniency and choice, and not perpetually; As therefore Nature hath provided Mu≈øcles about the Mouth and Chaps for the receiving, chewing and ≈øwallowing of the Food, ≈øo at the end of the Guts and at the outlet of the Urine there are Mu≈øcles ≈øet as Porters to interclude the pa≈ø≈øage, that nothing might go out but by the Hor≈øe's own accord; whereas were it not for the≈øe Mu≈øcles, his Excrements would come from him continually and involuntarily, as I have ≈øeen to happen in ≈øuch Hor≈øes who≈øe Sphincter Mu≈øcle hath by ≈øome accident or extraordinary weakne≈øs been violated. Neither hath Nature onely provided Mu≈øcles for the keeping of the Excrements in, I mean till ≈øuch time as it is nece≈ø≈øary they ≈øhould be let forth; but others al≈øo as in≈øtruments to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the voiding or letting of them forth. For the former purpo≈øe is appointed one Mu≈øcle at the Anus called the Sphincter, and for the latter, two, called Levators.

The Sphincter is a fle≈øhy Mu≈øcle ≈øeated at the very end of the Ar≈øegut, the which it incompa≈ø≈øeth round like a Ring, to which it may fitly be re≈øembled. It is rather knit to than ari≈øes from the lower Vertebrae of the Os ≈øacrum, being round and broad, and furni≈øhed with tran≈øver≈øe or overthwart Fibres, or indeed orbicular ones. This Mu≈øcle is much thicker above or inwards, than below or at the Fundament, where it adheres ≈øo firmly to the Skin, that it is not ea≈øie to ≈øeparate it from it. Its u≈øe we have mentioned in the former Paragraph.

The other two are called the Levators or litters up of the Fundament.The≈øe are ≈ømall, broad and nervous, ari≈øing from the Ligaments of the Hip-bones and Os ≈øacrum, from whence pa≈ø≈øing by the ≈øides of the ≈øtreight or Ar≈øe-gut they adhere to it, and are in≈øerted into the upper part of the Sphincter. A portion of them al≈øo grows to the root of the Yard, and in Mares to the neck of the Matrix. Their u≈øe is to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Abdominal Mu≈øcles in the expul≈øion of the Excrements, which they doe by lifting up the Fundament. They al≈øo help to keep the Fundament from falling out, which ≈øometimes happens when they are too much relaxt.

To the Bladder doth al≈øo belong a Mu≈øcle called a Sphincter, which is ≈øeated in the beginning of its neck, the which it compa≈ø≈øeth round. It is furni≈øhed with orbicular Fibres as the Sphincter of the Fundament is, and is of the ≈øame u≈øe; for it con≈øtringes or pur≈øes up the neck of the Bladder (as that doth the Anus) that the Urine may not pa≈øs out without a ≈øpontaneous relaxing of this Mu≈øcle. In Mares it is ≈øeated at the very end of the Bladder, viz. at the hole where the neck of the Bladder opens into the Vagina.

The Mu≈øcles of the Tard are in number four (or two pair) of which we have already treated in the Fir≈øt Book at Chapter 20. of which the fir≈øt pair are called the Erectores or Lifters up of the Yard, and the other
Dilatantes, Wideners, and by ≈øome they are called Acceleratores or Ha≈øtners. I thought fit in this place onely to name them, referring the Reader to the above-named Chapter for his farther ≈øatisfaction; as al≈øo to the ≈øaid Book at Chap. 22. for the de≈øcription of the Mu≈øcles of the Te≈øticles called the Crema≈øter Mu≈øcles, by which the Te≈øticles are ≈øu≈øpended. The Reader may al≈øo be ≈øatisfied in the ≈øame Book at Chap. 27. concerning the Mu≈øcles of the Clitoris in Mares, which are two pair, as the Yard of a Hor≈øe, to which it is re≈øembled, hath; for I ≈øhall not in≈øi≈øt upon them in this place neither.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Scapula or Shoulder-blade.

argument.p: The Shoulder-blade hath four pair. 1. Cucullares. 2. Levatores. 3. Serratum minus Anticum. 4. Rhomboides.

div.p: HAving ≈øufficiently treated of the Mu≈øcles of the three Venters, it remains that I de≈øcend now to treat of tho≈øe of the Limbs, beginning fir≈øt with the formo≈øt of them, the fir≈øt of which ≈øhall be tho≈øe that move the Shoulder-blade.

The Shoulder-blade is ob≈øerved to have four motions, viz. forward, backward, upward and downward, which motions are performed by four pair of proper Mu≈øcles. The fir≈øt pair are ≈øeated betwixt the two Shoulder-blades, covering the top of the Withers. They are called Cucullares from the re≈øemblance they have with a Monk's Hood or Cowl. Their fir≈øt original is fle≈øhy and thin, which they take from the Occiput or hinder part of the Head; but as they de≈øcend down the Neck they have other membranous beginnings from five of the Spines thereof, yea and from eight or nine of the uppermo≈øt of the Che≈øt: but they pre≈øently begin to be ≈øtraitned as they de≈øcend towards the Shoulder-blades, into who≈øe whole ≈øpine or ridge they are implanted, as likewi≈øe into the Shoulder-bone and broader part of the Collar-bone. This pair of Mu≈øcles, becau≈øe of their divers originals, from whence they have ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Fibres, are ≈øaid to perform ≈øeveral motions; as when the upper part of the Mu≈øcle that ari≈øes from the Occiput is contracted, then is the Shoulder-blade lifted obliquely upward, that part being furni≈øhed with oblique Fibres; and when that part which ≈øprings from the Withers is contracted, then it is pull'd ≈øtreight thitherward.

The ≈øecond pair are called Levatores, the Lifters or Heavers; and by ≈øome (in Men) Patientiae Mu≈øculi. The≈øe are ≈øituated above the Collarbone, taking their beginning from the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the fir≈øt, ≈øecond, third and fourth Vertebrae of the Neck; which beginnings being united in the middle (or thereabouts) of the length of the Mu≈øcles, they are at la≈øt in≈øerted into the Shoulder-blades at their fore corner. The u≈øe of the≈øe Mu≈øcles is to draw the Blades upward and forward.

The third pair is called Serratum minus Anticum or the le≈ø≈øer fore Sawpair.The≈øe lie under the Pectoral Mu≈øcles, and ≈øpring from the four uppermo≈øt Ribs before they become gri≈øtly, by four fle≈øhy portions repre≈øenting
the teeth of a Saw; from whence they pa≈øs ≈øomewhat ≈ølantingly to the Shoulder-blade, into who≈øe Proce≈øs (called its Anchor-like Proce≈øs) it is in≈øerted with a broad (partly fle≈øhy and partly nervous) Tendon. The u≈øe of this pair is to move the Shoulder-blades forward to the Che≈øt.

The fourth and la≈øt pair is called Rhomboides. The≈øe are ≈øeated under the Cucullares, being thin, broad and four-≈øquare. They ≈øpring fle≈øhy from the hinder Proce≈ø≈øes or Spines of the three lowe≈øt Rack-bones of the Neck, and as many of the uppermo≈øt of the Che≈øt, and continuing fle≈øhy to their very in≈øertion they are implanted into the ba≈øis of the Blades. Their u≈øe is to draw the Blade ≈øomewhat upward and backward, couching it to the Back.

Note, that ≈øeeing a Hor≈øe and all four-footed Bea≈øts go prone, whereas Man walks erect or upright, the motions of the Mu≈øcles might, and ought in ≈øtrictne≈øs, to be explained diver≈øly in them from what they are in him: As for example, Tho≈øe which are ≈øaid in Man to move the Part upward, viz. toward the Head, ought in a four-footed Bea≈øt to be ≈øaid to move it forward; and tho≈øe which move it backward in Man, move it upward in the other, becau≈øe of the different po≈øture of their Bodies: and the ≈øame might be ≈øaid as to their motions forward and backward. But ≈øeeing many of the Mu≈øcles have their names from their offices in Men, it would make but a confu≈øion and a great impropriety in their appellations to explain their motions by other termes in Brutes. And therefore the Reader is de≈øired to ob≈øerve, That when we ≈øay a Part is moved upward, we mean towards the Head; when downward, toward the Tail; when backward, toward the Back; and when forward, we under≈øtand it toward the Brea≈øt or Belly.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Shoulder.

argument.p: Each Shoulder hath nine Mu≈øcles, viz. fir≈øt, two Erectors. 1 Deltoides. 2 Supra≈øpinatus. 1 Secondly, two Depre≈ø≈øors. Lati≈ø≈øimus. 2 Rotundus major. 1 Thirdly, two Pullers forward. Pectoralis. 2 Coracoideus. 1 Fourthly, three Pullers backward. Infra≈øpinatus. 2 Sub≈øcapularis. 3 Rotundus minor.

div.p: THAT which I call the Shoulder is that Part or Bone that reaches from the top or pitch of the Shoulder (and is joynted into the Shoulder-blade) to the next Joint which we call the Elbow; which it is nece≈ø≈øary to intimate for di≈øtinction ≈øake, becau≈øe the Shoulder-blade and this part are commonly both under≈øtood by the name of the Shoulder. Having adverti≈øed this, pa≈øs we now to its Mu≈øcles.

The motions of the Shoulders are five, viz. backwards, forwards, upwards, downwards and circularly. To perform which each hath nine Mu≈øcles, of which there are two that move it upward, namely the Deltoides and Supra≈øpinatus; and of the≈øe we ≈øhall treat in the fir≈øt place.

The fir≈øt is called Deltoides from its figure, which re≈øembles the ≈øhape of the Greek Letter Œî delta. It is fle≈øhy and (as you may ≈øee) triangular, ari≈øing from the mid≈øt of the Clavicle or Collar-bone, the top of the Shoulder, and the whole ridge of the Shoulder-blade, and is extended as far as to the middle of the Shoulder-bone, where it is in≈øerted. This Mu≈øcle is ob≈øerved to have divers ≈øorts of Fibres; ≈øome of which run obliquely
downwards, ≈øuch are tho≈øe on the fore-part; others run obliquely forward, which are tho≈øe on the back-part of it; and a third ≈øort, which are placed in the middle, run directly toward the Fore-leg: Wherefore (≈øays my Authour) when the Fibres of the fore-part are contracted, the Shoulder is lifted upward and forward towards the Hor≈øe's No≈øe; if the middle Fibres be contracted, the Shoulder is lifted directly towards his Back; and if the hinder Fibres be contracted, then is the Shoulder carried obliquely backward: ≈øo that this Mu≈øcle is ≈øaid not onely to rai≈øe up the Shoulder (which is indeed its chiefe≈øt u≈øe) but helps al≈øo to perform other motions as well as that.

The ≈øecond Erector or Lifter up of the Shoulder is called Supra≈øpinatus by ≈øome, but by others Super≈øcapularis ≈øuperior, or the upper Blade-rider,becau≈øe it is ≈øeated uppermo≈øt upon the Shoulder-blade, and filleth up all that cavity which is between its ≈øpine and upper edge. It ari≈øes from the ≈øpine of the Blade with a long and fle≈øhy beginning, and pa≈ø≈øing over the jointing of the Scapula with the Shoulder-bone by a broad and ≈øtrong Tendon, is in≈øerted into the neck of the ≈øaid Shoulder-bone. This Mu≈øcle is by ≈øome Authours thought not onely to lift up the Shoulder (which is its principal u≈øe, as being one of the Erectors) but al≈øo to help to turn it a little round.

The Depre≈ø≈øors or Pullers down of the Shoulder are al≈øo two, namely Lati≈ø≈øimus and Rotundus major. The Lati≈ø≈øimus is ≈øo called from its breadth and largene≈øs, for with its fellow it covereth almo≈øt the whole Back. It goeth al≈øo by the name of Ani-≈øcalptor, or Scratch-ar≈øe Mu≈øcle (in Men.) It ri≈øes with a membranous and broad beginning from the tops of all the ≈øpines of the Rack-bones that are betwixt the ≈øixth Vertebra of the Che≈øt and the middle of Os ≈øacrum, as al≈øo from the upper part of Os ileum or Haunch-bone: from thence a≈øcending upward untill it come to that part of the Back where the Ribs begin to bend backward, there it becomes more fle≈øhy, and is carried over the lower or hinder corner of the Shoulder-blade, at which place it begins to grow narrower but continues fle≈øhy: and at length by a broad and ≈øtrong Tendon it is in≈øerted below the upper head of the Shoulder-bone lengthways, on the in≈øide, betwixt the Pectoral and Round Mu≈øcles, there being a ≈øpace left betwixt them for that purpo≈øe. This draws the Shoulder downward or toward the Tail, though a little obliquely backward.

The ≈øecond Puller down of the Shoulder (or its fourth Mu≈øcle) is called Rotundus major, or the greater Round Mu≈øcle. It takes its beginning from the whole lower Co≈øta or Rib of the Shoulder-blade, and is in≈øerted into the upper and inner part of the Shoulder-bone with a ≈øhort but broad, ≈øtrong and nervous Tendon. The u≈øe of this is the ≈øame with the former, viz. to pull the Shoulder downward.

The two pair of Mu≈øcles that pull the Shoulder forward are called, the one by the name of Pectoralis, and the other Coracoideus. The Pectoralis is ≈øo called from its ≈øituation, which is upon the fore-≈øide of the Brea≈øt. It hath a very large and for the greate≈øt part membranous beginning, which it takes from divers parts: for its upper part ari≈øes from the middle of the Collar-bone on that ≈øide next the Brea≈øt; its middle, from the whole length of the Brea≈øt-bone and the ends of the Gri≈øtles of the Ribs that end in it; and its lower part ≈øprings from the Gri≈øtles of the ≈øixth, ≈øeventh and eighth Ribs. After it hath taken the≈øe beginnings, it pre≈øently becomes fle≈øhy and thick, and running towards the Shoulder is at
length in≈øerted into the Shoulder-bone with a ≈øhort, but broad, finewy and ≈øtrong Tendon a little below its head, betwixt the Mu≈øcle Deltoides, and that which is called Biceps. The office of this Mu≈øcle is, when it contracteth it ≈øelf equally, to move the Shoulder equally and directly forward or toward the Brea≈øt, inclining to neither hand: but if all its Fibres be not equally contracted, (for by rea≈øon of its divers beginnings it hath al≈øo divers ≈øorts of Fibres, ≈øome running with a ≈ølanting line from above downwards, others with the like ≈ølanting line from below upward, and tho≈øe betwixt the≈øe running ≈øtreight; wherefore I ≈øay, if all the≈øe Fibres be not equally contracted, but ≈øome work, and others not) then are other motions performed by this Mu≈øcle, as the Shoulder drawn more upward or downward, as the different Fibres work.

Coracoideus is by Bartholin accounted the ninth Mu≈øcle of the Shoulder (which, ≈øays he, was fir≈øt ob≈øerved by Arantius and Placentinus) but we do after the more modern Authours reckon it for the ≈øixth, and ≈øecond drawer forward of it. It hath its name Coracoideus from its beginning, which is from the Proce≈ø≈øus Coracoides of the Scapula; from whence it reaches to the middle of the Shoulder-bone where it terminates. Its u≈øe is (as ≈øay the di≈øcoverers of it) to draw the Shoulder to the Proce≈øs of the Blade-bone, or forward upon the Brea≈øt.
The Shoulder is moved al≈øo backward by three Mu≈øcles, which are Infra≈øpinatus, Sub≈øcapularis or Immer≈øus, and Rotundus minor.

That which is reckoned the fir≈øt of the≈øe, is the Infra≈øpinatus, by ≈øome called Supra≈øcapularis inferior. It is ≈øeated upon the Shoulder-blade and fills up all that ≈øpace which is betwixt the ridge or ≈øpine of the Scapula and its lower edge, even as the Supra≈øcapularis ≈øuperior fills up the upper ≈øpace. It ari≈øes fle≈øhy from the ba≈øis of the Blade below the ridge of it, becoming narrower in its progre≈øs as the Blade-bone grows narrower, and is in≈øerted by a broad and ≈øhort Tendon into the fourth Ligament of the Shoulder-bone.

The ≈øecond Puller or Drawer back of the Shoulder is the Sub≈øcapularis,the Under-blade-lurker, or Immer≈øus the drowned Mu≈øcle, becau≈øe it is ≈øeated under the Blade-bone betwixt the Ribs and it. Very fle≈øhy it is, ari≈øing ≈øo from the inner part of the ba≈øis of the Blade; in figure it is triangular, like the Bone, growing narrower or ≈øtraiter by degrees as it de≈øcends, and is in≈øerted into one of the Ligaments of the Shoulder.

The next being the third and la≈øt of the Drawers back of the Shoulder is called Rotundus minor, the le≈ø≈øer Round Mu≈øcle, from its figure. It ari≈øes from the lowe≈øt corner of the Scapula, and is implanted into the neck of the Shoulder-bone.
As for the circular motion of the Shoulder, that is not performed by any one Mu≈øcle, but by ≈øeveral of the≈øe already named, acting ≈øucce≈ø≈øively one after another.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the Mu≈øcles that move the Fore-leg and Foot.

argument.p: How far the Fore-leg of an Hor≈øe an≈øwers in its Parts to the Arm of a Man. 1. Two Mu≈øcles bend the Cubit. Biceps. 2. Brachiaeus internus. 1. Two al≈øo extend it. Longus. 2. Brevis. 1. Two Mu≈øcles bend the Shank. Cubitaeus internus. 2. Radiaeus internus. 1. Two al≈øo extend it. Cubitaeus externus. 2. Radiaeus extrnus. The Pa≈øterns and Coffin-joint are bended by two Mu≈øcles. 1. Sublimis. 2. Profundus. 1 They are extended by one, viz. Exten≈øor magnus.

div.p: THAT part of the Leg which reaches from the Elbow to that which we call the Knee, an≈øwers to that part in Humane Bodies which reaches from the Elbow to the Wri≈øt. Onely in an Hor≈øe there is but one Bone in this ≈øpace (which we ≈øhall call the Cubit-bone) whereas in Men there are two going by two di≈øtinct names, one of which being the greater is called Cubitus or the Cubit, and the other ∆≤lna or the Ell. But as for that part which we call the Knee, it agrees more exactly with the Wri≈øt in Men, and might more properly be called ≈øo: For examining the Part to ≈øee of what it is compounded, I find it made up of two ranges of little Bones as the Wri≈øt of a Man is, and not like the Knee of a Man; which con≈øi≈øts of one little round Bone (called the Knee-pan) fa≈øtned between the Jointings of the lower head of the Thigh-bone and the heads of the tibia and fibula: for that Bone is exactly found in the Hind-leg of a Hor≈øe in that Joint we call the Stifle, which is indeed the Knee, as ≈øhall be proved in a convenient place. And as the Knee of a Hor≈øe is like the Wri≈øt of a Man, ≈øo is that Bone below it, (or indeed three Bones, for the Bone which we call the Shank or Shin, hath two ≈ømall Bones fa≈øtned to it running by its ≈øides down almo≈øt all its length till within two or three inches of the great Pa≈øtern; I ≈øay that as the Knee is that part which is the Wri≈øt in Man, ≈øo is this part between the Knee and great Pa≈øtern) an≈øwerable to the Metacarpium, that is, to that ≈øpace which reaches from the Wri≈øt to the ≈øetting on of the Fingers. Onely in Man there are five Bones, and in an Hor≈øe but three. So likewi≈øe does the great Pa≈øtern corre≈øpond to the fir≈øt Joint of the Finger; the little Pa≈øtern to the ≈øecond Joint; and the Coffin-joint on which the Hoof grows, to that Joint of the Finger on which the Nail grows.

By this you may ≈øee that the≈øe Parts of an Hor≈øe come very near the like Parts of a Man, the number of Bones and Mu≈øcles of the Fingers onely excepted. For a Hor≈øe is ≈øolidipes, or whole-footed, ≈øo that the whole of it is nece≈ø≈øarily moved at one time, and therefore has no need of that variety of Mu≈øcles that a Man's Hand is endowed withall. An Hor≈øe's Fore-feet are of no other u≈øe than to go upon, any more than his Hinder-feet; whereas the Hand of a Man is ordained for other u≈øes, and is therefore accordingly ≈øhaped, and divided into more Parts, to wit four Fingers and a Thumb, all which have their peculiar Mu≈øcles to enable them to perform tho≈øe motions to which they are de≈øigned. Whence the number of the Mu≈øcles come to differ greatly. Now we ≈øhall take no notice of tho≈øe that a Man has more than an Hor≈øe, but ≈øhall onely treat of tho≈øe that are to be found to move the Joints of an Hor≈øe already mentioned, viz. the Cubit-bone, the Shank, the two Pa≈øterns, and the Coffin-joint.

Fir≈øt, the Cubit is either bended, or extended. Of the Benders there are two; the fir≈øt of which is called Biceps, from its double beginning; for it hath two heads, the fir≈øt being outward, tendinous and round, ari≈øeth
from the upper brim of the hollowne≈øs of the Shoulder-blade; the ≈øecond head is broader, and is framed partly of a Tendon and partly of Fle≈øh: this ari≈øes from the Proce≈ø≈øus Anchoriformis or Anchor-like Proce≈øs of the Scapula; then de≈øcending by the inner head of the Shoulder-bone, it meeteth with the former head, and becometh a ≈øtrong fle≈øhy Mu≈øcle, running down the in≈øide of the Cubit-bone to the Knee, where it is in≈øerted. This bends the Cubit forwards and ≈øomewhat inwards.

The ≈øecond Bender is from its ≈øituation in Humane Bodies (being placed as the former is, upon the in≈øide of the Arm in them, and of the Leg in Hor≈øes; I ≈øay from its ≈øituation it is) called Brachiaeus Internus. This lies inwardly under the Biceps, and is ≈øomething ≈øhorter than it, but of a fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance like it. It takes its beginning near the end of that Mu≈øcle of the Shoulder called Deltoides, about the middle of the Shoulder-bone, to which it is firmly fa≈øtned: after which it runs its cour≈øe as the former, and is in≈øerted into the fore≈øide of the Cubit-bone a little above the Knee, a≈ø≈øi≈øting the motion of the former.

There are al≈øo two Mu≈øcles to extend the Cubit,which lie on its outer and hinder ≈øide. The fir≈øt of them from its length is called Longus. This ari≈øes with a ≈øtrong and broad original, partly nervous and partly fle≈øhy (which ≈øome make to be two heads) from the lower Rib of the Blade-bone, after which it de≈øcends on the hinder ≈øide of the Shoulder-bone, and al≈øo of the Cubit-bone, and is in≈øerted into its out≈øide ju≈øt at the Knee. This draws the Cubit backwards and ≈øomewhat outwards, and thereby extends it or ≈øtretches it out ≈øtreight.

The ≈øecond Extender of the Cubit is called Brevis from its ≈øhortne≈øs.It ari≈øes from the hinder-part of the neck of the Shoulder-bone, and holding the ≈øame cour≈øe as the former, is in≈øerted into the lower end of the Cubit-bone at the ≈øame place with the former, and a≈ø≈øi≈øts its motion.

Be≈øides the≈øe there are ≈øaid by ≈øome Anatomi≈øts to be two more Extending Mu≈øcles, viz. one called Brachiaeus Externus from its being placed on the out≈øide of the Arm in Men. But this is by Spigelius looked upon to be the ≈øecond head of the Long Mu≈øcle, becau≈øe it grows into one Mu≈øcle with it, and has the ≈øame in≈øertion with both it and the Short one.

The other is called Anconaeus, being a ≈ømall-bodied Mu≈øcle, ari≈øing from the lower and back-part of the Shoulder-bone, and is in≈øerted into the Cubit an inch or two below the Elbow. But ≈øome make this to be but a part of the Short Mu≈øcle.

As for the other Bone of this Joint in Men, called Radius, that al≈øo has its Mu≈øcles, which ≈øerve to turn the Arm and Hand round: But ≈øeeing there is no ≈øuch Bone in an Hor≈øe, as neither any ≈øuch motion of an Hor≈øe's Leg, it cannot be expected there ≈øhould be found any Mu≈øcles in him an≈øwerable to the other, as to this part.
Pa≈øs we on therefore to the next Joint commonly called the Shank, but which truly an≈øwers to the Metacarp, or back of the hand in Men. And this like the Cubit is either bended or extended.

To bend it there are two Mu≈øcles; of which the fir≈øt is called Cubitaeus internus. This ari≈øeth from the inner knob of the Shoulder-bone, and de≈øcending along the in≈øide of the Cubit, is implanted into the inner and hinder ≈øides of the top of the Shank.
The ≈øecond is called Radiaeus internus in Men, though very improperly in an Hor≈øe, ≈øeeing he has no Radius. This has the ≈øame ri≈øe, progre≈øs and in≈øertion with the former.

There are al≈øo two Mu≈øcles to extend it; the fir≈øt of which is called Cubitaeus externus. This ≈øprings from the outer knob of the Shoulder-bone, and de≈øcending down the Cubit, is in≈øerted into the outer and fore≈øide of the head of the Shank.
The ≈øecond of the Extenders is called Radiaeus externus (improperly as to an Hor≈øe, as was noted before.) This has the ≈øame ri≈øe, progre≈øs and in≈øertion with its fellow.

The next Joint is the great Pa≈øtern which an≈øwers to the fir≈øt Joint of the Finger in a Man's Hand, as the little Pa≈øtern an≈øwers to the ≈øecond Joint, and the Coffin-joint to the la≈øt on which the Nail grows. All the≈øe are either bended or extended as the former Joints were. But before we de≈øcribe tho≈øe Mu≈øcles that perform the≈øe actions, there is one other to be treated of that is called in Man Palmaris, from its being ≈øpread over the Palm of the Hand; but in an Hor≈øe its Tendon is ≈øpread over the Sole of the Foot, whence the name of Plantaris would better agree to it. This ≈øprings fle≈øhy from the inner knob of the Shoulder-bone, but pre≈øently grows into a ≈ølender Tendon which de≈øcends to the Sole of the Foot as afore≈øaid.

The Pa≈øterns and Coffin-joint are bended by two Mu≈øcles; the fir≈øt of which is called Sublimis, (I ≈øuppo≈øe becau≈øe it ri≈øes high up.) It ≈øprings from the inner knob of the Shoulder-bone, and is in≈øerted into the Pa≈øterns.
The ≈øecond is named Profundus. This ari≈øes from the upper part of the Cubit-bone, and is in≈øerted into the Coffin-joint.

They are extended by one very con≈øiderable Mu≈øcle, called Exten≈øor magnus. This ≈øprings from the outer knob of the Shoulder-bone, and its Tendon is in≈øerted into the fore and outer ≈øide of the Pa≈øterns and Coffin-joint. Some reckon this to be two Mu≈øcles.

There are ≈øeveral other proper Mu≈øcles that belong to the Fingers in Men, ≈øome to one and ≈øome to another, as al≈øo others that move them laterally, or to and from one another, which it were from our purpo≈øe here to mention, as not being to be found in an Hor≈øe. Though I dare not affirm po≈øitively that there are no more than I have here de≈øcribed; for I am apt to ≈øu≈øpect the contrary from the multitude of Tendons that de≈øcend into the Coffin-joint: however the≈øe that I have mention'd are the mo≈øt con≈øiderable and plainly di≈øcoverable; and rather than encrea≈øe their number at a venture, I will be content that this Chapter be reputed imperfect.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Thigh.

argument.p: 1. The Benders of the Thigh are three. P≈øoas. 2. Iliacus internus. 3. Pectineus. 1. The Extenders are al≈øo three. Glutaeus major. 2. Glutaeus medius. 3. Glutaeus minor. One Mover of the Thigh inward, viz. Triceps or Quadriceps. Four Mu≈øcles move the Thigh outward, called Quadrigemini. Al≈øo the Deltoides of the Thigh. 1 The Thigh is turned a little about by two Mu≈øcles. viz. Obturator internus. 2. Obturator externus.

div.p: BY the Thigh we mean that part which is betwixt the Joint of the Huckle or Whirle-bone, and that which is called the Stifle; which con≈øi≈øteth of one large and long Bone, going by the name of the Thigh-bone, or Femur. This Bone hath a round head which is jointed into the round Cavity of the Hip-bone, ≈øo that it admits of all kinds of motions, whence it hath a multitude of Mu≈øcles to perform the≈øe motions; ≈øome of which move the Thigh forwards, whereby it is bended; ≈øome move it backwards, and thereby extend it: a third ≈øort bend it inward, as when a Hor≈øe rubs the contrary Leg with his Foot, which is often ≈øeen upon any itching or pricking humour affecting that Part: a fourth ≈øort move it outwards; and a fifth obliquely about. But fir≈øt of the Benders forwards, which are accounted to be three in number.

The fir≈øt of which is called P≈øoas or Lumbaris. This is almo≈øt round,thick and livid, and lieth in the inner part of the Abdomen, upon the Vertebrae of the Loins. It ari≈øes fle≈øhy from the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of the two lowe≈øt Vertebrae of the Che≈øt and two or three uppermo≈øt of the Loins; from whence de≈øcending by the in≈øide of Os ileum, at length it ends in a ≈øtrong and round Tendon, which is in≈øerted on the fore≈øide of the upper part of the le≈ø≈øer head of the Thigh-bone. The u≈øe of this is, ≈øtrongly to draw the Thigh upward, and ≈øomewhat inward. Upon this Mu≈øcle the Kidneys are placed, near that part of it where its Nerve enters into it; which in Men is the cau≈øe of that ≈øtupor or numbne≈øs that is felt in the Thigh by tho≈øe that are troubled with the Stone in the Kidneys, on that ≈øide that the Stone is on.

The ≈øecond Bender forward is called Iliacus internus, or the inward Haunch Mu≈øcle. It ≈øpringeth with a ≈ølender and fle≈øhy beginning from the in≈øide of the Haunch-bone, and being joined by its Tendon to the former Mu≈øcle, is in≈øerted with a round Tendon into the le≈ø≈øer head or Rotator of the Thigh-bone. The u≈øe of this is the ≈øame with the fir≈øt, which is, to lift the Thigh up and ≈øo to bend it forward; yet it doth not move it ≈øo much inward as the P≈øoas doth.

The third is called Pectineus, ari≈øing broad and fle≈øhy from the line of the Share-bone near its Gri≈øtle, and is implanted into the in≈øide of the lower end of the Thigh-bone with a broad and large Tendon. Its u≈øe is to draw the Thigh upward and inward. This is the Mu≈øcle that in Men helps to lay one Thigh over the other in ≈øitting.

Note, that both this la≈øt foregoing, and all the following Mu≈øcles ≈øave the two la≈øt, are in≈øerted at the lower end of the Thigh-bone, ju≈øt above the Stifle; whereas in Men they are mo≈øt of them if not all in≈øerted into its upper part, viz. either into its neck, or into one or other of the two knobs jetting out at the lower end of the neck, (called the great and little Trochanters.) What may be the rea≈øon of this different in≈øertion is not ea≈øie to gue≈øs, unle≈øs it be the ≈øhortne≈øs of the Thigh-bone, which in an Hor≈øe is not half ≈øo long as it is in a tall Man: ≈øo that an Hor≈øe's Mu≈øcles
being ≈øo plump and bulky upon his Buttocks, it was nece≈ø≈øary they ≈øhould have ≈øome con≈øiderable ≈øpace to grow ≈ølenderer in and to become tendinous; and therefore they are extended as far as the Stifle which an≈øwers to the Knee in Man.

Next come we to the Mu≈øcles that bend back and ≈øo extend the Thigh,(as when an Hor≈øe ≈øtretches him≈øelf) which motion is al≈øo performed by three Mu≈øcles. The fir≈øt of which is called Glutaeus externus, or the outwardmo≈øt Buttock Mu≈øcle; in Men it is al≈øo called Glutaeus major, the greate≈øt Buttock Mu≈øcle; but in an Hor≈øe it is not ≈øo, for in them the middlemo≈øt is the large≈øt. This ≈øpringeth with a very fle≈øhy beginning from the Crupper, from the Spine or ridge of the Haunch-bone, and from the Os ≈øacrum. Afterward de≈øcending a little obliquely and riding over the Joint of the Huckle-bone, it at length grows narrower and more ≈ølender, and ≈øo endeth into a ≈øtrong and broad Tendon, which is in≈øerted into the inner part of the Thigh-bone ju≈øt above the Stifle, yea it ≈øeems to reach as far as to the top of the Tibia. Its u≈øe is to draw the Thigh backward and ≈øo to extend it, as al≈øo to enable the Hor≈øe to go backward.

The next or ≈øecond is called Glutaeus medius, or the middle Buttock Mu≈øcle. This in Man (becau≈øe of his going erect) lieth quite under the former, and is ≈øo hid by it, that unle≈øs the former be fir≈øt removed, it cannot be ≈øeen. But in Hor≈øes it is larger than the former, and lieth ≈øide by ≈øide with it, as doth the next al≈øo, and they are both to be ≈øeen without removing the fir≈øt, as may be plainly ob≈øerved by the following Figure. It ari≈øes with a fle≈øhy and broad beginning, a little higher than the fir≈øt, from the Spine of the Haunch-bone on the fore-part of it, and from thence de≈øcends ≈øomewhat obliquely over the Joint of the Hip as far as to the lower end of the Thigh-bone, into the outer ≈øide of which it is in≈øerted with a broad, ≈øtrong and membranous Tendon. Its u≈øe is to extend the Thigh and to draw it outward and backward, as when the Hor≈øe ≈øtands to ≈øtale.

The third and la≈øt of the Extenders is called Glutaeus minor, or le≈ø≈øer Buttock Mu≈øcle. This in a Hor≈øe ari≈øes equal in height with the former at the Spine of the Haunch-bone. At its beginning it is round, ≈øharp and fle≈øhy; but in its cour≈øe it becomes more broad, de≈øcending with an oblique line by the ≈øide of the ≈øecond Mu≈øcle, and is in≈øerted at the lower end of the Thigh-bone, rather towards its fore-≈øide. This a≈ø≈øi≈øts the action of the former, drawing the Thigh outward and backward.

The Thigh is drawn to the in≈øide by the Mu≈øcle Triceps, or Quadriceps, for it goes by both names, becau≈øe ≈øome affirm it to have four, and others but three beginnings. This Mu≈øcle is looked upon to be the thicke≈øt of all the Mu≈øcles of the whole Body, being furni≈øhed with great variety of Fibres.
The fir≈øt of its beginnings is from the upper part of the Share-bone, where it ari≈øes with a nervous head, and de≈øcending is in≈øerted into the in≈øide of the lower end of the Thigh-bone.
The ≈øecond part of it ari≈øes from the lower ≈øide of the ≈øame Bone, being fle≈øhy and broad, and is in≈øerted into the in≈øide of the Thigh-bone, a little higher up than the former.

The third head of this Mu≈øcle ari≈øes with a fle≈øhy and ≈øometimes nervous beginning from the whole lower part of the Coxendix, round about the circumference of its wide hole; and is in≈øerted near the la≈øt.

The fourth head ≈øprings with a nervous and fle≈øhy beginning from the tip of the Coxendix, and afterward running along the in≈øide of the Thigh, endeth into a round Tendon, which joining with the Tendon of the fir≈øt part of this Mu≈øcle is in≈øerted into the lower end of the Thigh-bone with it.

The Thigh is al≈øo turned outward, which motion is performed by four ≈ømall Mu≈øcles called Quadrigemini, all which are placed one by another upon the out≈øide of the articulation of the Thigh. The fir≈øt of them is from its ≈øituation called Iliacus externus, and from its figure, Pyriformis or Pear-like Mu≈øcle. This is longer than any of the re≈øt of them, ari≈øing round from the lower and outer part of Os ≈øacrum; thence it runneth downward upon the back≈øide of the great Rotator, and is implanted into the out≈øide of the lower end of the Thigh-bone.
The ≈øecond and third of the≈øe Mu≈øcles do want particular names; but both of them ari≈øe from the knob of Os i≈øchium, near one another, and are in≈øerted with the fir≈øt.

The fourth and la≈øt is called Quadrigeminus quadratus. It is more fle≈øhy and broad than the re≈øt, ari≈øing from the inner part of the knob of the I≈øchium, lying ≈øome two or three inches di≈øtant from the third, and endeth with the former.

To the≈øe mu≈øt be added that Mu≈øcle which we have named the Deltoides of the Thigh, not finding any in Humane Bodies to an≈øwer to it,≈øo as to borrow a name from thence. It ≈øprings (as you may ≈øee plain in the foregoing Figure) from the out≈øide of the tip of the Ileum, with a ≈øharp beginning; but pre≈øently enlarging it ≈øelf, becomes three-≈øquare, and is in≈øerted with a broad membranous Tendon into the out≈øide of the Thigh-bone, from which in≈øertion it appears torn off in the Figure. By its ≈øituation it ≈øeems to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the action of the Quadrigemini.

The Thigh is turned about obliquely by two Mu≈øcles called Obturatores,or Stoppers, becau≈øe they fill up the wide hole between the Os pubis and Hip-bone. The fir≈øt is called Obturator internus. This ari≈øeth from the inner circumference of the hole before ≈øpoken of, and pa≈ø≈øing over-thwart the end of the Hip-bone, is in≈øerted into the Cavity of the great Rotator.

The other is called Obturator externus, the outward Filler. This ari≈øes out of the external circumference of the above-named hole with a fle≈øhy and broad beginning, and winding about the neck of the Thigh-bone turneth into a ≈øtrong and large Tendon which is implanted into the Cavity of the great Rotator with the former.

And thus much for the Mu≈øcles of the Thigh, which for order ≈øake I have according to the cu≈øtom of Anatomi≈øts fir≈øt treated of; but it is nece≈ø≈øary that we make our di≈ø≈øection in the Leg fir≈øt, to remove tho≈øe Mu≈øcles; for we cannot ≈øo ea≈øily nor conveniently rai≈øe nor ≈øhew the≈øe of the Thigh, untill tho≈øe of the Leg be removed, becau≈øe the heads of ≈øome of them lie upon the Mu≈øcles of the Thigh.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Mu≈øcles of the Tibia or Leg.

argument.p: 1. The Leg is extended by ≈øive Mu≈øcles. Membrano≈øus. 2. Longus. 3. Rectus. 4. Va≈øtus externus. 5. Va≈øtus internus. 1. Four Mu≈øcles bend the Leg. Biceps. 2. Semimembrano≈øus. 3. Seminervo≈øus. 4. Gracilis. 1 One moves it obliquely, viz. Poplitaeus.

div.p: THE Mu≈øcles of the Tibia or Leg are of the ≈øame number in Hor≈øes as in Men, (like as the Mu≈øcles of mo≈øt other Parts are) the in≈øertion of ≈øome of them onely excepted. Which difference ≈øprings from hence, that this Bone of the Leg which in a Hor≈øe is but one main Bone ≈øupported on each ≈øide with another ≈ølender immoveable one for ≈øtrength, as al≈øo for the ≈øafer pa≈ø≈øage of the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles between them, (which I ≈øuppo≈øe to be the onely u≈øe of them, as not being moveable; I ≈øay this Bone which in a Hor≈øe is but one) is in a Man two, going by two different names, viz. the one by that of Tibia, and the other, by that of Fibula, and ≈øome of the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles are in≈øerted into one of them, and ≈øome into the other. But otherwi≈øe ≈øo far as I have had opportunity to examine them, I have found them to have the ≈øame original, ≈øub≈øtance, figure and cour≈øe in a Hor≈øe as in Man; and therefore I ≈øhall proceed to treat of them after the ≈øame method as I have done of all the re≈øt, forbearing to ≈øpeak any further of the difference (in a Man and an Hor≈øe) between the Parts that are moved by the Mu≈øcles to be treated of in this and the following Chapter, untill I come to the Book of the Bones, where I ≈øhall ≈øhew at large the ≈øimilitude between them, and that the difference is not ≈øo much as it may be believed to be.

The Leg hath three motions allowed it, viz. bended, extended, and moved obliquely outwards. All the Extenders are placed on the fore-part of the Thigh, of which the fir≈øt is called Membrano≈øus. This Mu≈øcle is by Bartholin called the Abductor, as if its u≈øe were to move the Leg obliquely outwards; but that office is by other Anatomi≈øts ≈øince him a≈øcribed to the Poplitaeus, and this ≈øaid to extend the Leg. It ari≈øeth fle≈øhy from the upper part of Os ileum on the out≈øide, and near the great Proce≈øs of the Thigh-bone it becomes broad and nervou≈øly membranous, wherefore it is called Fa≈øcia lata, the broad Swadling-band, for it enwrappeth almo≈øt all the Mu≈øcles of the Thigh within it ≈øelf; and being come as low as the Knee in Humane Bodies, and that Joint we call the Stifle in Hor≈øes, (which exactly an≈øwers to the other, even as far as to the little round Bone between the two Bones of the Femur and Tibia, called the Patella or Knee-pan) I ≈øay when it is come as low as the Stifle (over which it cro≈ø≈øes) it is at la≈øt in≈øerted into the fore-≈øide of the Tibia or Bone of the Leg. Its u≈øe is, as hath been ≈øaid, to extend the Leg directly; or as ≈øome Authours will have it, ≈øomewhat to abduce it or draw it obliquely outwards.

The ≈øecond Extender is called Longus, and Sartorius or Sutorius, from its u≈øe in tho≈øe Men that ≈øit cro≈øs-legg'd at work, as Shoomakers and Tailors. It ari≈øes ≈øharp and nervous from the upper and fore-part of the appendix of Os ileum, and as it pa≈ø≈øes obliquely down the in≈øide of the Thigh, it becomes more fle≈øhy and broad, continuing ≈øo till it come to the in≈øide of the Leg a little below the Stifle, where it ends in a broad Tendon, and is in≈øerted into the Bone of the Leg or Tibia. The u≈øe of this
Mu≈øcle is not onely to extend the Leg, but al≈øo to draw it inwards, wherefore it is by ≈øome Authours reckoned for one of the Benders of the Leg.

The third, from its ≈øtreight cour≈øe, is called Rectus, the Streight Mu≈øcle. This takes its beginning from the lower brim of the Haunch-bone, and pa≈ø≈øing with a fle≈øhy and round belly ≈øtreight down the fore-≈øide of the Thigh untill it come to the Stifle, it there turns into a ≈øtrong and broad Tendon, which adhering to the Patella de≈øcends over it, and is implanted into the fore-≈øide of the upper part of the Shank.

The fourth is called Va≈øtus externus, becau≈øe of its great fle≈øhy bulk,and becau≈øe it de≈øcends on the out≈øide of the Streight Mu≈øcle. It ari≈øes broad and nervous from the root of the great Rotator or Trochanter, cleaving clo≈øe to the outward part of the Thigh-bone all along its cour≈øe, untill it come to the Stifle, where it becomes membranous and broad, and uniting with the Tendon of the Streight Mu≈øcle or Rectus, is in≈øerted into the ≈øame place with it, but on its out≈øide.

The fifth is called Va≈øtus internus, running on the in≈øide of the Rectus.It ari≈øes from the root of the le≈ø≈øer Trochanter and from the neck of the Thigh-bone with a nervous beginning, and afterwards growing fle≈øhy de≈øcends down the Thigh-bone, ≈øticking clo≈øe to it, till it come to the Stifle, over which it pa≈ø≈øeth, and afterward unites its ≈øelf with the former two, and takes its in≈øertion in the ≈øame place of the Tibia as they do.

It is worth the Di≈ø≈øectour's taking notice of the≈øe three la≈øt Mu≈øcles, how they be joined all in one ju≈øt at their cro≈ø≈øing the Stifle, where they make one broad and very ≈øtrong Tendon, which ≈øpreads over and involves the Patella or little Bone of the Stifle, and ties it ≈øo fa≈øt in its place upon the jointing of the Thigh-bone with the Tibia, that it is very ≈øeldom di≈øplaced, or indeed never. For although by di≈øtentions or ≈øtrains we often have this Part affected; yet never did I ≈øee an ab≈øolute di≈ølocation in it. The Patella indeed may be (and often is) wrenched either to one ≈øide or the other as the accident may happen, but it is immediately reduced to its place again by this compound ligamentous Tendon, which like a Spring retracts it ≈øelf into its former Station, and the Bone to which it is knit, al≈øo. So that, that malady which is commonly taken for a di≈ølocation of this Bone, ≈øeems rather to be from Bloud extrava≈øated out of the Capillary Ve≈ø≈øels, which by great di≈øtentions many times may be broken; which Bloud lieth congealing and putrifying in the ≈øpaces between the Membranes and Mu≈øcles, affecting the ≈øen≈øible neighbouring Parts, which puts the Hor≈øe to that great pain we ob≈øerve him to have on ≈øuch accidents. Now the means we u≈øe to remove this pain is by chafing the Part with penetrating Oils, which commonly effect the cure, if they be u≈øed pre≈øently before the Bloud be too much congealed: But if the pain be not removed by this means, we are fain to open the Skin by way of an I≈ø≈øue, blowing in wind to ≈øeparate the ≈øeveral Skins one from another, and ≈øo make way for the congealed Matter the better to come forth; which done, the pain is removed, and the affection quite taken away, and the Hor≈øe mo≈øt times goes again as well as ever. Whereas ≈øhould this Bone be di≈øplac'd, as it is by many Farriers thought to be, this way of proceeding ≈øeems ≈øo far from contributing to the cure, that by laying the Skins open there is rather given more liberty for the Bone to remove out of its place, than any a≈ø≈øi≈øtance afforded toward the re≈øtoring it again. But
≈øo much by way of digre≈ø≈øion to inform our Profe≈ø≈øours in this point; I ≈øhall now proceed to de≈øcribe the remaining Mu≈øcles, the next of which are the Benders of the Leg.

The≈øe are in number four; the fir≈øt of which (according to Bartholin) is called Biceps, though by other Authours it is reckoned the la≈øt and fifth, ≈øuppo≈øing that there are five of the≈øe Mu≈øcles. It ari≈øes ≈øharp and nervous from the appendix of the Coxendix, and being carried on the out≈øide of the Thigh, it doth about its middle become fle≈øhy, as if it begun there with a ≈øecond head; from whence de≈øcending it groweth in its cour≈øe more thick and outwardly nervous, untill it becomes a ≈øtrong Tendon, which is in≈øerted into the outer ≈øide, (but ≈øomewhat backward) of the appendix of the Tibia. The u≈øe of this Mu≈øcle is to bend the Leg by pulling it backward.

The next, according to the before-named Bartholin, is the Semimembrano≈øus, which by others is reputed the fourth Bender. It takes its beginning from the knob of the Coxendix as the former doth, with a ≈ømall, membranous head, from whence it runneth down the back-part of the Thigh, till it come to the Leg-bone, into which it is in≈øerted with a round Tendon behind, in that place which in Man is called the Ham.

The third (according to the ≈øame Authour) is the Seminervo≈øus, ≈øo called from its ≈øub≈øtance, it being partly nervous and partly fle≈øhy, as the former was partly fle≈øhy and partly membranous. This ari≈øes ≈ømall and nervous from the ≈øame knob of the Coxendix as the former two did; from whence de≈øcending obliquely by the back and inner part of the Thigh (in which cour≈øe it becomes fle≈øhy) its Tendon reaches towards the middle of the Leg-bone, into who≈øe inner and backer part it is in≈øerted.

The fourth is called Gracilis, the ≈ølender Mu≈øcle. This by ≈øome Authours is accounted for the ≈øecond Bender of the Leg, but I ≈øhall after the method of the before-named Authour rank it for the fourth and la≈øt. It ari≈øes with a large and nervous beginning from the middle of the Share-bone ju≈øt at its jointing, from whence it runs down the in≈øide of the Thigh untill it comes to the Tibia or Leg-bone, into who≈øe in≈øide it is in≈øerted with a round Tendon near the former.

Note, that ≈øome of the≈øe Mu≈øcles being placed more outward and others more inward; if they all work together, they draw the Leg directly backward; but if one be contracted alone, then it doth bend the Leg a little either to this or that ≈øide, according as the Mu≈øcle is placed, as well as draw it backward.

There is another Mu≈øcle who≈øe u≈øe is to move the Leg obliquely; its name is Poplitaeus. It takes its ri≈øe broad and nervous from the outer head of the Thigh-bone, and afterward becoming fle≈øhy runs with a ≈ølanting line down the Thigh to the back and inward part of the upper knob of the Tibia, where it is in≈øerted.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of the Mu≈øcles that move the lower part of the Leg, and the Foot.

argument.p: The In≈øtep-bone is bended by two Mu≈øcles. 1. Tibiaeus anticus. 2. Peronaeus anticus. It is extended by three. 1. Ga≈øtrocnemius externus. 2. Ga≈øtrocnemius internus. 3. Plantaris. The Tendons of the≈øe three Mu≈øcles make the magna Chorda. 1. It is moved ≈øideways by two. Tibialis po≈øticus. 2. Peronaeus po≈øticus. 1. The Pa≈øterns and Coffin-joint are bended by two Mu≈øcles. Flexor longus. 2. Flexor brevis. 1. They are extended al≈øo by two. Exten≈øor longus. 2. Exten≈øor brevis.

div.p: BY the lower part of the Leg is to be under≈øtood that Bone which is below the Hock or Hough, reaching from thence to the great Pa≈øtern; which Bone an≈øwers to tho≈øe five in Humane Bodies that make the In≈øtep. Likewi≈øe the great Pa≈øtern and little Pa≈øtern an≈øwer to the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Joints of the Toes in Men; and la≈øtly that which is called the Coffin-joint on which the Hoof grows, is an≈øwerable to the la≈øt joint of the Toes on which the Nails are placed. Onely the difference is, that a Man becau≈øe of his going upright, treadeth upon the whole ≈øpace from the Heel to the Toes; and his Foot is al≈øo divided into five Toes, each con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeveral Joints, that by ≈øpreading them≈øelves and gra≈øping clo≈øely on what he treads upon, they may keep him the more firmly erect. Whereas a Hor≈øe and other four-footed Bea≈øts having four Feet upon the ground, have no need of ≈øo broad nor large a Foot, and do therefore go as it were upon Tip-toes, their Heels reaching as high up the Leg as to the Hock, which indeed is the Heel of the Hor≈øe, as a very eminent and learned Phy≈øician who did me the honour to take a view of my Skeleton, intimated to me. For make but any Quadruped, as a Dog or the like, ≈øtand upright, lifting up his Fore-feet, and you may ob≈øerve all that part of his Leg from the Hough downwards to lie upon the ground as a Man's Foot does; yea ≈øome, as Coneys, &c. in their ordinary gate tread upon all that ≈øpace: onely ≈øuch Creatures have their Feet cleft into Toes, whereas a Hor≈øe is whole-footed, and thence ari≈øes a difference as to the number of the Mu≈øcles of the Foot.

Note, that the Mu≈øcles which move each Bone have onely their In≈øertions into that Bone they are to move, and that they take their ri≈øe from the Bone or ≈øome other Part (immediately or mediately) above it, as may be ob≈øerved by the foregoing di≈øcour≈øe of the Mu≈øcles of the Thigh and Leg. Thus tho≈øe Mu≈øcles that move the Thigh, take their original from either the Hip-bone, Share-bone, or Os ≈øacrum, all of which are above it; likewi≈øe tho≈øe that move the Leg, ari≈øe from the Hip or Share-bones, or el≈øe from the Head or ≈øome other part of the Thigh-bone which is the Joint above it; and thus la≈øtly do the Mu≈øcles that are to move all that part of the Leg or Foot which is below the Hock, ≈øpring from and lie upon the Parts above the Hock, ≈øave the Flexor brevis and Ten≈øor brevis, and the Plantaris which is at the Sole of the Foot (which cannot properly be called a Mu≈øcle neither, for it is very little or not at all carnous, but rather ligamentous) for otherwi≈øe onely the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles reach hither, and are in≈øerted ≈øome into one Joint, ≈øome into another.

The Foot is bended, extended, and moved (a little) to either ≈øide,according to the motion of the In≈øtep-bone (for ≈øo we ≈øhall call it for di≈øtinctions ≈øake.) Fir≈øt, it is bended when it is drawn upwards and forward. To perform which motion there are two Mu≈øcles a≈ø≈øi≈øting: the fir≈øt of which is called Tibiaeus anticus or the forward Leg-mu≈øcle, ≈øo
named from the ≈øituation of it, which is upon the fore-part of the Leg-bone towards its outer ≈øide. It ari≈øes ≈øharp and fle≈øhy from the upper appendix of the Leg-bone, cleaving clo≈øe to it all along as it de≈øcends, and towards the bottom of it, it turneth by degrees to a Tendon, which pa≈ø≈øing under the Gri≈øtle that compa≈ø≈øeth about the next Joint or Hock, is divided into two or more Tendons that are in≈øerted into the fore≈øide of the In≈øtep-bone, which (together with the re≈øt of the Foot) it moves forward and upward.

The next is called Peronaeus anticus, becau≈øe it ari≈øes in Man from that Bone of the Leg that is called Perone or Fibula, and therefore it is improperly ≈øo called in an Hor≈øe that wants that Bone, and in whom it ≈øprings from the upper appendix of the Tibia, and de≈øcending downwards with a fle≈øhy body till it come almo≈øt to the bottom of this Bone, it turneth into a Tendon as the former did, which Tendon pa≈ø≈øeth down by the out≈øide of the Hock, and is in≈øerted into the out≈øide of the In≈øtep-bone, which with the re≈øt of the Foot it moves forward and ≈øomewhat outward.

The Foot is al≈øo Extended, that is, when the In≈øtep-bone is drawn backwards, which motion is performed by three Mu≈øcles: of which the fir≈øt is called Gemellus externus, or Ga≈øtrocnemius externus. This in Men makes the greate≈øt part of the Calf of the Leg. It takes its ri≈øe broad and fle≈øhy from the inner head of the Thigh-bone at the lower end of it, and al≈øo from the outward head of the ≈øame Bone, for it hath a double beginning; which two heads de≈øcending for a while apart, they begin to be united into one about the middle of the Leg-bone, after which they both turn into one entire, broad, ≈øtrong and nervous Tendon, which unites with the Tendon of the following Mu≈øcle called Ga≈øtrocnemius internus, and both are in≈øerted into the Heel-bone.

The ≈øecond Extender of the Foot is called Ga≈øtrocnemius internus. This Mu≈øcle lyeth ≈øomething under the former, ari≈øing from the hinder-part of the upper end of the Leg-bone with a ≈øtrong, nervous beginning, and growing tendinous toward the lower end of the Bone unites with the Tendon of the foregoing, and is in≈øerted into the Heel-bone with it as afore≈øaid.

The third and la≈øt is called Plantaris, or the Mu≈øcle of the Soal or Tread. This ari≈øes fle≈øhy, round and ≈ølender between the former two, taking its beginning from the back-part of the lower head of the Thigh-bone. After it hath de≈øcended a little way down the Leg-bone it becomes a ≈ølender round Tendon, which running between the Tendons of the former two and joining very clo≈øely with them de≈øcends down to the Heel-bone, where it leaves them and proceeds along the back-part of the In≈øtep-bone and the two Pa≈øterns, and terminates within the Foot, ≈øpreading all about the bottom of it, making that Part which is called the Soal of the Foot in Men, and in Hor≈øes that Part that lieth next under the Soal, and is plain to be ≈øeen when we have drawn the Soal of the Foot out.

It is the Tendons of the≈øe three Mu≈øcles that make that ≈øtrong and thick Tendon by which Butchers hang up their Meat,which by rea≈øon of its greatne≈øs and ≈øingular ≈øtrength is called Chorda magna. It is al≈øo this Tendon running down the back-part of the Leg, which we call the back Sinew, which being affected either by a ≈øtrain or brui≈øe or other accident, cau≈øes ≈øo great a pain, by rea≈øon of the ≈øen≈øiblene≈øs of the Tendon. When it is hurt, the Hor≈øe many times falls exceeding lame, though ≈øuch
accidents are not ≈øo dangerous to life in Hor≈øes as they are ≈øaid to be in Men; for we make no difficulty in curing them, e≈øpecially if pre≈øently taken in hand, but Chirurgeons do mo≈øt times conclude Wounds of this Part in Men to be very dangerous by rea≈øon of their frequent falling into convul≈øions thereupon.

The Foot is al≈øo moved ≈øomewhat ≈øideways, viz. inward and outward,by two Mu≈øcles. The fir≈øt of which is called Tibialis po≈øticus. This ≈øpringeth from the upper end of the Leg-bone, from whence it de≈øcends among the before-named hinder Mu≈øcles till it come to the In≈øtep-joint, where it becomes tendinous, and from thence runs down the inner ≈øide of the In≈øtep-bone and Pa≈øterns, till it come to the Soal of the Foot, into which it is in≈øerted. Its u≈øe is to move the Foot obliquely inward.

The ≈øecond is called Peronaeus po≈øticus (improperly in an Hor≈øe.) It ari≈øes from the upper and hinder-part of the Leg-bone by a nervous and ≈øtrong beginning, from whence it de≈øcends all along the out≈øide of the Bone cleaving firmly to it, untill it reach its middle, where it becomes tendinous, and de≈øcends with the Tendon of the Peronaeus anticus on the out≈øide of the In≈øtep-joint or Hock, but is not joined with it; for it continues its cour≈øe further untill it reach the Foot, into the bottom of which it is implanted. This moves the Foot contrary to the former, viz. obliquely outward.

The Pa≈øterns and Coffin-joint are likewi≈øe bended, or extended by their proper Mu≈øcles. The Benders are two, of which the fir≈øt is called Flexor longus, or the Long Bender. This ari≈øes from the upper and hinder-part of the Leg-bone, about the middle whereof it becometh tendinous, and de≈øcends on the inner ≈øide of the Hough down the In≈øtep-bone and Pa≈øterns into the Coffin-joint.

The ≈øecond is called Flexor brevis, the Short Bender. It ≈øprings from the in≈øide of the Heel-bone a little below the Hock, and has the ≈øame in≈øertion with the former. The≈øe bend the Pa≈øterns and Coffin-joint by drawing them backward.

The Extenders are al≈øo two. The fir≈øt is called Longus Ten≈øor, or the Long Extender. It ari≈øes from the fore and inner ≈øide of the Shank ju≈øt under the Stifle, and de≈øcends on the fore-≈øide of that Bone, the In≈øtep-bone and the Pa≈øterns, and is in≈øerted into the fore and upper part of the Coffin-joint.

The ≈øecond ari≈øeth from the fore-part of the annular Ligament that binds about the In≈øtep-joint, and de≈øcending under the former has the ≈øame in≈øertion. The≈øe two extend the Pa≈øterns and Coffin-joint by drawing them forward.

Thus I am come to the end of the Treati≈øe of the Mu≈øcles, in de≈øcribing of any of which if I have erred, I hope the Apology with which I prefaced this fourth Book will obtain my excu≈øe with all ingenuous Men: and as for the moro≈øe and carping, I ≈øhall take it as a favour from them, if in≈øtead of railing at random, they will take the pains to demon≈øtrate my mi≈øtakes.

div.head: THE ANATOMY OF AN HORSE. BOOK V. Of the Bones.
CHAP. I. Of the nature, definition, differences and parts of Bones.

argument.p: The definition of a Bone. The material and efficient cau≈øes of a Bone. Their differences. Their Parts. How many Bones of the Head.

div.p: THE Bones are by a learned and ancient Philo≈øopher compared to the Carka≈øe of a Ship, to which the re≈øt of the Parts are fa≈øtned and whereupon they are ≈øu≈øtained. The≈øe afford ≈øtability, ≈øtreightne≈øs and form to each Part and to the whole. The knowledge of them is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary; for without it we mu≈øt needs be ignorant of the originals and in≈øertions of the Mu≈øcles; and upon fractures or di≈ølocations of them, it were very unlikely that any ≈øhould ≈øet them right again without the knowledge of their ≈øhapes, and the manner of their jointing one with another.

A Bone is ≈øaid to be a ≈øimilar Part, the drie≈øt and colde≈øt of all the re≈øt, made of the mo≈øt earthy and tartareous part of the Seed in the Womb, (i. e. of the Humour in the Ovum or Conception) and is nouri≈øhed with the like particles of Bloud after the birth, and moi≈øtned with the Marrow contained in it.

In which de≈øcription the word [Seed] is to be interpreted as we have intimated,and not of the Male and Female's Seed mixed together in the Womb, as the Ancients conceived; for it is certain that the Female hath no true Seed, and that the Male's being onely an active principle of generation, affords nothing of matter to the Parts of the Foetus, but onely impregnates the Ovum, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed more at large when I come to ≈øpeak to the Generation of Animals. Thus the Male's Seed is no material cau≈øe at all of the Bones, but onely a remote efficient cau≈øe of them as it is of other Parts of the Body; of all which the pla≈øtick or formative power that is ≈øeated in the Ovum it ≈øelf, is the immediate efficient.

As to the differences of Bones, they are many, as being divided or di≈øtingui≈øhed ≈øeveral ways. And fir≈øt from their hardne≈øs, or ≈øoftne≈øs: thus the lower parts of the Temple-bones are called Petro≈øa, ≈øtony Bones, and ≈øuch are al≈øo the Bones of the Teeth. Others are in re≈øpect to the≈øe, ≈øoft; ≈øuch are the ≈øpongy Bones of the No≈øe, and tho≈øe which are called appendices to any Bone. And la≈øtly of a mean ≈øub≈øtance between the≈øe may be reckoned all the re≈øt of the Bones.
They are again divided or di≈øtingui≈øhed by their magnitude; thus ≈øome are e≈øteemed great, ≈øome little, and ≈øome of a moderate ≈øize betwixt both.

Al≈øo they are divided by their figure; ≈øome being plain, ≈øome round; ≈øome have three ≈øides, others four; ≈øome are like a Boat, ≈øome a Cup; ≈øome like a Hammer, an Anvil, or a Stirrop, ≈øuch are the Auditory Bones.
They are al≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhed from their ≈øituation, connexion, cavity, ≈øen≈øe, and upon ≈øeveral other con≈øiderations, which it would be tedious further to pro≈øecute.

Again, the Bones are many of them divided into three parts; fir≈øt, that part whereof the body of the Bone con≈øi≈øteth; ≈øecondly, the part that groweth to the Bone; thirdly, the bunching part of the Bone: of which the fir≈øt hath no proper name belonging to it, but is called by the name of the whole Bone; the ≈øecond being that part that groweth to the Bone is properly called Epiphy≈øis, the Appendage; and that part that bunches out beyond the plain ≈øurface, is called Apophy≈øis, or the Proce≈øs.

In relation to this di≈øcour≈øe of the Bones we ≈øhall divide the Body into three Parts, viz. the Head, the Trunk and the Limbs. By the Head is implied both Head and Neck. The fir≈øt and uppermo≈øt Part of the Head is the Skull, called Cranium, becau≈øe it is as it were Cranos an Helmet to the Brain. It is compounded of ≈øeveral Bones to the number of fifteen or ≈øeventeen in Humane Bodies, ≈øay mo≈øt Anatomi≈øts, that is, in all, as well little as big; for of the large ones there are but nine, three of which are common to the Skull with the upper Jaw-bone, which are the Wedge-like Bone or cuneiforme, the Yoke-bone, and ≈øpongio≈øum, the ≈øpongy or Sieve-like Bone. The other ≈øix are proper Bones and make up the Skull it ≈øelf; and tho≈øe are the Fore-head Bone, the Noll-bone, the two Bones of the Synciput, and the two Temple-bones, in which la≈øt are contained (in each of them) three ≈ømall Bones, of which we have already treated where we ≈øpoke of the Parts of the Ear in the third Book at Chap. 14. namely the Hammer, the Anvil and the Stirrup, all which make up the ≈øaid number of fifteen Bones of the Skull; to which if we add the lately found-out Bone of the Ear, called the orbicular Bone, there will be ≈øeventeen. Now the larger Bones are divided or di≈øtingui≈øhed by
≈øeveral Seams called Sutures, and both Bones and Sutures are of the ≈øame number in this Animal we are treating of as in Men, as may be ≈øeen by the following Figure.
