div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Sutures or Seams of the Head.

argument.p: A Suture what, and of how many kinds. The Sutures are proper or common. The proper are true or fal≈øe. 1. True Sutures are The Coronal. 2. The Lambdoidal. 3. The Sagittal. The fal≈øe Sutures are two. The common Sutures are 1. Frontalis. 2. Cunciformis. 3. Cribro≈øa. The u≈øe of the Sutures.

div.p: A Suture is the connexion of one Bone of the Head to another, of which there are two ≈øorts: the one is plain and linear, like two boards glewed or ≈øtones cemented together; the other indented like the teeth of two Saws put tooth within tooth.

Of the≈øe Sutures ≈øome are proper to the Skull alone, and ≈øome are common to it with the upper Jaw. The proper Sutures are again double, that is to ≈øay, true or fal≈øe. Of the former ≈øort are tho≈øe Saw-like ones before-named, which are three in number, viz. Coronal, Lambdoidal and Sagittal; and of the latter are the plain ones, which ≈øome reckon to be more, ≈øome fewer.

The fir≈øt of the Saw-like ones is called in Humane Skulls Coronalis or the Crown-Suture, becau≈øe the Ancients were wont to wear their Crowns or Garlands in that place. This Suture, as in Men, ≈øo likewi≈øe in a Hor≈øe runs overthwart the Skull above the Fore-head, reaching from the Temple-bone of one ≈øide to the Temple-bone on the other, joining the Os frontis or Fore-head-bone to the Synciput or Bone of the fore-part of the Head.

The ≈øecond is called Lambdoides or Lambdoidal Suture, as re≈øembling in its dimen≈øion the Greek letter Œõ lambda. This is ≈øeated on the back-part of the Head, being oppo≈øite to the former, beginning at the bottom of the Occiput, from whence it a≈øcends obliquely to either Ear in Men, but in a Hor≈øe ≈øomething above the Ear, running with a more ≈ølanting line. It joins the Bone of the Occiput to the Bones of the Synciput and Temples.

The third runs not overthwart the Head as the two former, but lengthways of it, reaching in Humane Skulls from the top or middle of the Lambdoidal to the middle of the Coronal Suture onely; but in Hor≈øes it reaches further (as it does in Children) cro≈ø≈øing the Coronal Suture, and runs afterward down the Fore-head-bone to the No≈øe. This is not ≈øo Saw-like in Hor≈øes Skulls as the other two are, as may be ≈øeen by the foregoing Figure. It is the la≈øt of the true or Saw-like Sutures, and hath the name of Sagittal, from its ≈øtreightne≈øs, its cour≈øe being ≈øtreight like an Arrow.

Next come we to the fal≈øe, counterfeit or ba≈øtard proper Sutures, which are tho≈øe that re≈øemble a Line onely, and are not Saw-like at all. The≈øe are in number two; the fir≈øt of which pa≈ø≈øeth from the Root of the Proce≈ø≈øus mammillaris upwards with a circular Duct, and pa≈ø≈øeth downwards again towards the bottom of the Ear, after it hath compa≈ø≈øed in the Temple-bone. By this Seam are the Bones of the Synciput, Occiput and Sphenoides joined with the Temple-bones.

The ≈øecond of the ba≈øtard proper Sutures runs obliquely downwards, ari≈øing from the ≈øide or rather top of the former, and runs down toward the Socket of the Eye, to the beginning of the fir≈øt common Suture.
The common Sutures are tho≈øe that belong not to the Skull alone, but are common to it with the Wedge-like Bone and the upper Jaw. Of which the≈øe that follow are the mo≈øt remarkable.
Fir≈øt, the Frontalis, by which the outer Proce≈øs of the Fore-head-bone is joined with the fir≈øt Bone of the upper Jaw.
The ≈øecond is that which is called Cuneiformis or Wedge-like, by which the Wedge-like-bone is joined with the fir≈øt Bone of the upper Jaw.
The third is called Cribro≈øa, which is common to the Wedge-like-bone, and the ≈øeptum or partition of the No≈øe.

Now the u≈øes of the≈øe Sutures or Seams are, fir≈øt, to be vents of the Brain, through which the impure and ≈øooty excrements might exhale or evaporate; ≈øecondly, to help to ≈øtay the Brain from tottering, and its parts from being mi≈øplaced in violent motions, by giving way to the Fibres that pa≈øs through them from the Dura mater within, to the Pericranium without the Skull, by which Fibres the ≈øaid dura mater and al≈øo the Brain it ≈øelf (which is wrapt within it) is kept ≈øu≈øpended as it were, that ≈øo the hardne≈øs of the Skull might not offend it by pre≈ø≈øing again≈øt it, nor the Brains own weight bear too hard upon the bottom of the Skull, which it would be apt to do were it not for its being thus born up or ≈øu≈øpended by the≈øe Fibres that tie the Dura mater to the out≈øide of the Skull.
The≈øe Sutures were al≈øo made for the ingre≈øs and egre≈øs of the Ve≈ø≈øels, for the life and nouri≈øhment of the Parts contained within the Skull.

La≈øtly, that if at any time the Head ≈øhould happen to be broken, the fracture might not run through the whole Skull, but ≈øtay at the end of the fractured Bone; whereas were it not for the≈øe Seams, it would like an earthen Pot with one knock or fall be in danger of being ≈øhivered all in pieces, which it is not now ≈øo apt to do, for the crack will not ≈øo ea≈øily pa≈øs over a Seam as it would run along an intire bone.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the proper Bones of the Skull.

argument.p: The Bones of the Skull are proper or common. The proper are ≈øix. 1. The Fore-head-bone. Its Cavities. Its Holes. Its Proce≈ø≈øes. 2 The Bones of the Synciput. Their connexion. Their ≈øhape, ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øurface and holes. 3 The Os occipitis. Its ≈øhape and connexion. Its Sinus. Its Proce≈ø≈øes and Holes. 4 The Temple-bones. Their connexion. Their figure. Their ≈øub≈øtance. Their Sinus. Their Proce≈ø≈øes. 5 Os petro≈øum. Its Holes, and Cavities.

div.p: THE Bones of the Skull are of two ≈øorts, proper and common. Of the fir≈øt in this Chapter; and of the latter in the next.

The proper are in number ≈øix; one of the Fore-head, another of the hinder-part of the Head or Occiput, two of the Crown, and two of the Temples, all which are divided or di≈øtingui≈øhed from one another by the before-named Sutures.

The Fore-head-bone, called Os frontis, is ≈øeated before, and maketh the fore-part of the Skull, both above and a little below the Orbit of the Eyes. It is bounded before by the Coronal and fir≈øt common Suture, on the ≈øides by the Temporal Bones, and on the in≈øide by the ≈øpongy Bones.

Betwixt the Laminae or Scales of this Bone at the top of the No≈øe there is a large (or rather double) Cavity, from whence two holes pa≈øs to the No≈øtrils, di≈øtingui≈øhed by many bony Fibres and ≈ømall Scales, which are encompa≈ø≈øed with a green Membrane, and contain a ≈øoft medullar, or as it were an oylie body.

The u≈øes a≈øcribed to the≈øe Cavities are various: as fir≈øt, to prepare the air that is drawn in by the No≈øtrils, for the generation of animal Spirits; ≈øecondly, to keep for ≈øome time the odoriferous air whereby ≈ømells may be more lei≈øurably perceived; thirdly, ≈øome think that they ≈øerve for the collection of flegmatick Excrements; and others, la≈øtly, that they a≈ø≈øi≈øt or promote the ≈øhrilne≈øs or echo of the Voice. I will not determine of the truth of any of the≈øe opinions; but ≈øhall onely ob≈øerve this further, that the≈øe Cavities are much larger in an Hor≈øe than they are in a Man, even the difference of the bulk of their Bodies con≈øidered.

Be≈øides the≈øe Cavities there is al≈øo a Den or Sinus made of a double Scale; one of which being outermo≈øt maketh the upper (inward) part of the Orbit of the Eye, and is plain; the other maketh the Cavity above the Eyes on either ≈øide, and is not plain, but hath in≈øcriptions an≈øwerable to the winding convolutions of the Brain, who≈øe bunchingout portions it receives.

This Fore-head-bone hath al≈øo two Holes in the middle part of the Eye-brow, which go to the Orbit of the Eye, by which the fir≈øt branch of the Nerve of the fifth conjugation of the Brain goeth to the Mu≈øcle of the Fore-head.
It hath al≈øo four Proce≈ø≈øes, two of which are ≈øeated at the greater corner of the Eye, and other two at its le≈ø≈øer, all helping to make the upper part of the Orbit.

Next come we to the Bones of the Synciput or fore-part of the Head, which are in number two, being joined before with the Bone of the Forehead by the Coronal Suture, with the Os occipitis behind, by the Lambdoidal Suture, on each ≈øide to the Temple-bones by the ≈øcaly Sutures, and to the Wedge-like-bone by one of the common Sutures. They are al≈øo joyned together, or one to another, in the middle or top of the Head (lengthways) by a Suture common to them both, called the Sagittal Suture.

Their figure is almo≈øt four-≈øquare; their ≈øub≈øtance thinner than that of the other Bones, yet con≈øi≈øt of two plates, ≈øave in their lower edges, where they are joined to the Temple-bones. On the out≈øide they are ≈ømooth, but on the in≈øide uneven, having ≈øeveral ≈øhallow Cavities or Dens by the ≈øides of the Sagittal Suture, to which the Dura mater firmly grows; as al≈øo many long and winding in≈øcriptions or furrows for the Ve≈ø≈øels which run from the internal Jugulars through the ≈øaid Dura mater to the Brain. They have likewi≈øe ≈øeveral perforations or little holes, ≈øome of which indeed penetrate but one Plate, which are for the entrance and exit of the Ve≈ø≈øels that run between the Plates; but mo≈øt run quite through them, and are made for ≈ømall Veins and Arteries to pa≈øs both from within outwards, and from without inwards.

Next is the Os occipitis, or Noll-bone, which makes the hinder and lower part of the Head, and the middle part al≈øo of the ba≈øis of the Skull. It is of a very hard ≈øub≈øtance, harder than any Bone of the Skull be≈øides, (except the Os petro≈øum of the Temple-bones) being thicker at the bottom where it is without fle≈øh, and where the two Sinus of the Dura
mater are joined. At the ≈øides of the great perforation (through which the Spinal Marrow de≈øcends) it is ≈øomewhat thin and without any Cavities or ≈ømall Dens in it; but that its thinne≈øs here might be no prejudice to it, from the edge of this perforation there a≈øcends on the in≈øide a large Proce≈øs or Prominence running along to its top, to ≈øtrengthen it and arm it again≈øt any accidents that might happen by blows, &c. This Prominence it is that di≈øtingui≈øhes the two Protuberances of the Cerebellum.

This Bone is in ≈øhape five-corner'd, by two of which corners it is joined in its upper part to the Bones of the Synciput by the Lambdoidal Suture; by two other in its fore-≈øides to the Temple-bones by one of the counterfeit Sutures; and by its fifth corner to the Os cuneiforme, or Wedgelike Bone.

It hath in it ≈øeveral Sinus's or Chanels, of which ≈øome are on the in≈øide,and others on the out≈øide of it. Of tho≈øe on the in≈øide there are two which are pretty large, ordained for the receiving the protuberances or bunchings out of the Cerebellum or After-brain. The others on the in≈øide are ≈øome to receive the protuberances of the Brain it ≈øelf; others to receive the two Sinus's of the Dura mater, that they might not be compre≈ø≈øed by the Bones of the Skull; and the re≈øt are for the like u≈øes. The two that are on the out≈øide of this Bone, are in its lower part by the ≈øides of the great perforation, of a ≈øemicircular ≈øhape.

This Bone hath al≈øo ≈øeveral Proce≈ø≈øes, four of which being clad with a glib Gri≈øtle are received into ≈øo many Sinus's of the fir≈øt Vertebra of the Neck. But that is the mo≈øt con≈øiderable which I mentioned before, and ≈øerves to ≈øtrengthen the Bone. It has Holes to the number of five; the fir≈øt is in the mid≈øt of the bottom of the Noll, which is the large≈øt of all the inward holes of the Head, being in ≈øhape round and ≈øomewhat long, through which the Medulla oblongata or Spinal Marrow pa≈ø≈øeth out of the Skull into the Cavity of the Vertebrae of the Neck. The other four are le≈øs by far, and are made for the tran≈øition of ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels.

The Temple-bones come next to be treated of, which are ≈øeated on the ≈øides of the Skull and reach to the bottom of the Ears. They are joyned on their upper part to the out≈øide of the Bones of the Crown by the Suture called Squamo≈øa, or Scale-like. In their fore-part they are joined to the fir≈øt Bone of the upper Jaw, by its fir≈øt Proce≈øs; and their hinder-part is joined to the Os occipitis, by one of the counterfeit Sutures.

The figure of the Temple-bone is in its upper part ample, equal and ≈øemicircular; but below, it is very ≈øhapele≈øs, like to a rude, rugged and unequal Rock, from whence as al≈øo from its hardne≈øs it hath its name of Petro≈øum, or the Rocky-bone.

The ≈øub≈øtance of this Bone is al≈øo full of variety; for at its bottom it is thick and rugged; but as it a≈øcends, by degrees it grows much thinner, and at its top is ≈øo thin that it is almo≈øt tran≈øparent, (e≈øpecially where it gives way to the Temporal Mu≈øcle) and like a Scale lies upon the lower edge of the Bone of the Synciput, which Bone in its de≈øcent under the Temple-bone is al≈øo attenuated.

The Temple-bones have each of them two Sinus or Cavities. The outer of the≈øe is much larger than the other, being lined with a Cartilage or Gri≈øtle, ≈øeated betwixt the Auditory pa≈ø≈øage and the Proce≈øs of the Yoke-bone. It is of an indifferent length, running as it were tran≈øver≈øly or overthwart, and has the longer Proce≈øs or the head of the lower Jaw in≈øerted or articulated into it. The other Cavity is inward at the back≈øide
of the Proce≈øs of the Yoke-bone, and is common to the Temple-bone with the Noll-bone.

By the≈øe Sinus or Cavities there ≈øtands a ≈øharp and longi≈øh, and (in Hor≈øes) pretty thick (but in Men far more long and ≈ølender) Appendix, from its ≈øhape in Humane Bodies called Os ≈øtyloides, the Pen-like Bone. Be≈øides which there are al≈øo three Proce≈ø≈øes; two of which are external, and one internal.
The fir≈øt external is blunt, thick and ≈øhort, (≈øaid to be ≈øomewhat hollow within) tending downwards, in ≈øhape ≈øomething like to the Nipple of a Cow, from whence it is called Mammillaris.

The ≈øecond of the outward Proce≈ø≈øes runs forward from the hole of the Ear to the Proce≈øs of the fir≈øt Bone of the upper Jaw, both of them framing the Os jugale, or Yoke-bone. For the≈øe two Proce≈ø≈øes, one of the Temple-bone and the other of the fir≈øt Bone of the upper Jaw, being joined by an oblong Suture do make the fa≈øhion (as it were) of a Bridge, or of an Oxes Yoke, from whence that Bone hath its name, and of which we ≈øhall treat further in the next Chapter.

The third Proce≈øs, which is internal, is that which is called the Rocky-bone. It is pretty long, jetting out to the in≈øide of the bottom of the Skull, within which it hath two holes, through one of which an Artery, and through the other the Auditory Nerve pa≈øs to the inner Cavities of the Ear, which are three in number, namely the Tympanum or Drum, the Labyrinthus or Labyrinth, and the Cochlea, or Snail-≈øhell. On the out≈øide of the Skull this Proce≈øs has three perforations or holes. The fir≈øt and large≈øt of which is called meatus Auditorius, or the hole of hearing. The ≈øecond is narrow, ≈øhort and oblique, near to the fir≈øt, by the fir≈øt hole of the Wedge-like Bone. Through this the Jugular Vein enters into the inner Cavities of the Skull. The third hole is ≈øeated betwixt the Proce≈ø≈øus mammillaris and the Styloides or Pen-like Appendix, ending into that pa≈ø≈øage that goes from the Ear to the Mouth. As to the little Bones that lie hid in the Cavities of this Proce≈øs, by ancient Anatomi≈øts they were reckoned to be but three, but there is by modern Authours added a fourth; and they are commonly known by the≈øe following names, viz. Incus, Malleus, Stapes, and Os orbiculare, of all which I have already treated in the fourteenth Chapter of the Third Book, where they are al≈øo lively repre≈øented in Figures, to which place I refer the Reader for his further ≈øatisfaction; having not mentioned them in this place, but that they make up the number of the proper Bones of the Skull.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Bones common to the Skull and upper Jaw.

argument.p: 1 The Wedgelike Bone. Its ≈øituation. Its Proce≈ø≈øes. Its Cavities. Its Holes. 2 The Sievelike Bone. Its ≈øituation and connexion. Its Parts. Its ∆≤≈øe. 3 Os jugale.

div.p: HAving hitherto treated of the Bones proper to the Skull onely, I come now to treat of tho≈øe which are common to it with the upper Jaw; and the≈øe are in number three, namely, the Os ≈øphenoides or cuneiforme, the Os cribriforme, and the Os jugale.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe is the Sphenoides, or Wedge-like Bone, ≈øo called from its ≈øituation, which is betwixt the Bones of the Skull and the upper Jaw, and not from the likene≈øs of its figure to that of a Wedge, as ≈øome do believe. It is joined before to the Fore-head-bone, and behind to the Os occipitis. At the ≈øides it doth a good part of it join to the Os petro≈øum. Above, it is joined to the fir≈øt, fourth and ≈øixth Bones of the upper Jaw; and below, to the Bones of the Palate of the Mouth.

It hath ≈øeveral Proce≈ø≈øes, of which ≈øome are external, and ≈øome internal. The internal are four, ≈øtanding out like four feet of a Table or Chair, which (taking in the ≈øpace between them) form the Sella Turcica. The external are al≈øo four, of which the two formo≈øt are contiguous to the upper Jaw, and are called the Wing-like Proce≈ø≈øes, from the re≈øemblance they have to Bats-wings; for they are thick in ≈øome places, and yet end into a notable thinne≈øs, almo≈øt as thin and ≈øharp as the edge of a Knife. The two hinder are ≈øtretched out toward the Styloides Proce≈ø≈øes of the Temple-bones.
This Bone hath ≈øeveral Cavities or hollowne≈ø≈øes; two of which are common with it and the Temple-bones, and the Bones of the Synciput.

It hath al≈øo many perforations or little Holes to the number of ≈øeven on each ≈øide. One of which being round gives a pa≈ø≈øage to the Optick Nerve toward the Eye. The re≈øt are penetrated ≈øome by one, ≈øome by ≈øeveral pairs of Nerves; others by the Carotid Arteries and Jugular Veins; and others again by both Nerves and Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels.

The next common Bone of the Head and upper Jaw is the Os cribriforme, ≈øo called from the ≈øeveral or indeed innumerable little holes in it, which make it like a Sieve, through which holes the ≈ømells do pa≈øs to the Mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes, or Olfactory Nerves. It is ≈øituated in the fore-part of the Skull, between or a little below the Sockets of the Eyes, under the middle ba≈øis of the Fore-head-bone, and at the upper part of the No≈øtrils. It is joined by a plain or ≈øimple line to the Fore-head-bone, the ≈øecond Bone of the upper Jaw, and to the Os cuneiforme.

This Bone is by ≈øome divided into four parts; of which the fir≈øt is a Proce≈øs in the upper and middle part of it, which is long and triangular, ending in a ≈øharp point, whence it is called Cri≈øta galli, or the Cock's Comb. This runs in betwixt the Mammillary Proce≈ø≈øes dividing them one from the other. To its ≈øharp point the Sinus of the Falx adhereth.

The ≈øecond part of this Bone is that which mo≈øt properly is called Os cribriforme, being perforated all over like a Sieve, ≈øome of which holes are ≈øtreight and ≈øome oblique. They are ob≈øerved to be much larger in
Dogs than in any other Animal (allowing for the proportion of their Bodies) which is ≈øuppo≈øed the rea≈øon why their ≈ømell is more exqui≈øite than that of any other Creature.

The third part is a Proce≈øs in its lower or under ≈øide oppo≈øite to the upper Proce≈øs; which part divideth the upper part of the No≈øe into two No≈øtrils, whence it is called ≈øeptum Na≈øi, the Partition-bone of the No≈øe.

The fourth and la≈øt part of this Bone is compared to a Sponge or Pumice-≈øtone, being porous and full of ≈ømall cavities, which are filled with a ≈øpongie fle≈øh; and from this part the whole Bone is by ≈øome called Os ≈øpongio≈øum. For the names of cribriforme and ≈øpongio≈øum are confounded one with the other, being either of them given indifferently to the whole Bone. But if we will con≈øider the ≈øpongio≈øum onely as a part of the cribriforme, then we mu≈øt ≈øay, that it is that part of it that is ≈øeated ju≈øt at the top of the No≈øtrils. Some make two Bones of it, affixing one at the top of each No≈øtril, and call them in the plural number O≈ø≈øa ≈øpongio≈øa.

The u≈øe a≈øcribed to the Os cribriforme by mo≈øt Anatomi≈øts hath been to di≈øcharge through its pores or holes flegmatick excrements from the Brain into the No≈øe, but he that ≈øhall examine them, will find that its holes are ≈øo filled either with the ≈øpongie fle≈øh before-named, or el≈øe with the Fibres of the ≈ømelling Nerves pa≈ø≈øing through them to the in≈øide of the No≈øtrils, that there is no pa≈ø≈øage left for any humour by them. What we therefore account their true u≈øe to be, the Reader may be informed, if he plea≈øe to turn back to the fifteenth Chapter of the Third Book, where we treated of the No≈øe, and de≈øcribed its u≈øes: adding to what is there ≈øaid of it, that it makes up the inner corner of the Orbit of the Eye.

The third and la≈øt Bone common to the Skull and upper Jaw is called Os jugale, or the Yoke-bone. This is ≈øeated on each ≈øide of the Hor≈øe's Face between the meatus of the Ear or Auditory pa≈ø≈øage, and the fir≈øt Bone of the upper Jaw; being framed of two Bones, one of which is a Proce≈øs of the Temple-bone that is carried from the meatus Auditorius, and is the hinder of them; and the other Bone being the foremore is a Proce≈øs of the fir≈øt Bone of the upper Jaw, and which maketh the lower ≈øide of the le≈ø≈øer or outer corner of the Eye. The≈øe two are joined by a ≈ølanting or oblique Suture, and being ≈øo joined do con≈øtitute this Bone called Os jugale. Over this Bone runs the Tendon of the Temporal-mu≈øcle, and al≈øo the Tendon of the Ma≈ø≈øeter or Chewing-mu≈øcle, as they pa≈øs to the lower Jaw.

Some make but two common Bones of the Skull and upper Jaw, not reckoning this for any particular Bone, ≈øeeing (as has been ≈øaid) it is formed onely of the two Proce≈ø≈øes of the Temple and upper Jaw-bone. But ≈øeeing it is di≈øtingui≈øhed from the others by a particular name (though not of any peculiar ≈øub≈øtance) I thought it not ab≈øurd to reckon it for a third common Bone.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Jaw-bones and their Parts.

argument.p: The Bones of the upper Jaw. 1. Zygomaticum. 2. Lachrymale. 3. Innominatum. 4. Os malae, or Cheek-bone. Its connexion. Its Holes. 5. The No≈øebone. Its connexion. 6. The Palate-bone. The lower Jaw-bone. Its Proce≈ø≈øes and Sinus's. Its Cavities and Holes. The Sockets of the Teeth.

div.p: THE Bones of the upper and lower Jaws come next to be ≈øpoken to, with the fir≈øt of which we will begin.

This Jaw hath Bones of two ≈øorts, the one proper to it ≈øelf, and the other common to it and the Skull. The common Bones are the Wedge-like and Sieve-like Bones, and the Os jugale, of which we have already treated in the foregoing Chapter. I ≈øhall therefore proceed to treat of the Bones proper to the upper Jaw onely, which make the lower ≈øide of the Orbit of the Eye, the No≈øe, Cheeks and Roof of the Mouth.

The Bones that con≈øtitute all the≈øe Parts are twelve in number, on each ≈øide of the Face ≈øix; the fir≈øt of which is called Zygomaticum, becau≈øe by its Proce≈øs it makes up the greate≈øt part of the Os jugale. This is ≈øeated at, and maketh, the lower part of the outer corner of the Eye.

The next is a round, little, brittle and thin Bone, ≈øeated in the inner corner of the Eye, called Os lachrymale, becau≈øe it has a hole in it through which the ≈øerous humour that makes the tears in Men doth i≈ø≈øue. Upon this hole the little Kernel called caruncula Lachrymalis re≈øteth, that hindreth the continual gleeting of the fore≈øaid humour. There is al≈øo in the lower part of this Bone another hole which goes to the cavity of the No≈øtril, through which doth pa≈øs a branch of the fifth pair of Nerves to the inner Skin of the No≈øe.

The third is ≈øeated in the inner ≈øide of the Eye, and within is continued with the fungous Bones of the No≈øtrils. It is broad, and ≈øomewhat quadrangular or four-corner'd, al≈øo thin and tran≈øparent, like the Scale of a Fi≈øh. On its out≈øide it is ≈ømooth, but within rugged and unequal, becau≈øe of the Scales that cleave unto it. It is joined to four Bones, viz. to the Fore-head-bone, to the Wedge-like Bone, to the ≈øecond Bone of the Jaw, (viz. the next foregoing) and al≈øo to the fourth, or next following. It is not known by any peculiar name; I have therefore made bold to call it Os innominatum.

The fourth Bone is called Os malae, the Cheek-bone, becau≈øe it maketh up the greate≈øt part of the Cheek, as al≈øo of the Palate. It likewi≈øe contains the upper Teeth in its cavities or caverns. It is much larger than any other Bone of the upper Jaw, and is circum≈øcribed with many Sutures; for not to mention the Teeth that are inarticulated into it, it abutteth upon or is joined to ≈øeveral Bones. In the fir≈øt place it is joined above, on the ≈øide next the No≈øe, to the Bone of the Fore-head; below, to the Wedge-like Bone, and the Bone of the Palate of the Mouth; before, to the Os lachrymale, and to the fifth Bone that makes the upper part of the No≈øe, (which is next to be de≈øcribed;) and la≈øtly to its own companion, viz. the Cheek-bone of one ≈øide to that of the other.

This Bone hath three perforations or holes, two of which are under the Orbit of the Eye; that is, on each ≈øide one, running from the lower part of the Eye outward. Their u≈øe is to tran≈ømit or let pa≈øs two branches of the fifth pair of Nerves out of the Orbit of the Eye to the Face, on the Parts whereof they are be≈øtowed.

The third of the≈øe holes is in the Palate, at the back≈øide of the Grinding-teeth where both Bones of the Jaw meet. It is pre≈øently divided into two, one of which runneth on one ≈øide of the ≈øeptum of the No≈øe, and the other on the other, to the No≈øtrils, to which there pa≈øs through the≈øe holes a ≈ømall Vein and a ≈ømall Artery.
It hath al≈øo a den or cavity on each ≈øide, by the ≈øide of the No≈øe under the Orbit of the Eye, which is covered with a very fine Membrane. This is often full of a mucous or ≈ølimy phlegm.

The fifth Bone of the upper Jaw doth with his companion make the bony prominence of the No≈øe. It is a ≈ømall Bone, in figure almo≈øt four-≈øquare. It is hard, ≈øolid, and rea≈øonable thick, having ≈øundry ≈ømall perforations in it. It is joined above to the Fore-head-bone, viz. to its internal Proce≈øs. In the ≈øides above it is joined to the fir≈øt Bone, and a little lower to the fourth Bone of this Jaw. In the middle it is joined to its companion, and below to the Gri≈øtles that make the lower part of the No≈øe.

The ≈øixth is that which makes up the Roof of the Mouth, with its companion; for you mu≈øt reckon every one of the≈øe Bones double, one on one ≈øide of the Face, and another on the other. It is a broad Bone, thin and ≈øolid, and in the end, where it is rough, it re≈øembleth a ≈øemicircle. It is joined behind to the Wing-like Proce≈ø≈øes of the Wedge-like Bone, and on the in≈øide, to the Partition-bone of the No≈øtrils. It is likewi≈øe joined to the fourth Bone of this Jaw or Cheek-bone, and la≈øtly to his companion or fellow in its back-part.
This Bone hath al≈øo two perforations, on either ≈øide one, running upward and backward to two of the holes of the Wedge-like Bone.

The lower Jaw comes next to be treated of, which makes the lower part of the capacity of the Mouth. This differs from the former in that it is moveable, whereas the upper is not. In ≈øhape it is long and prominent. At both the ends of it, there are two Proce≈ø≈øes, which are by ≈øome called Horns. The foremo≈øt of them runs upward, and from a broad ba≈øis grows ≈øharp, ending into a cone or point. This point receives the Tendon of the Temporal Mu≈øcle, which Tendon compa≈ø≈øeth it round about, and is ≈øtrongly implanted into it: from whence it is that a luxation of the lower Jaw, becau≈øe of the di≈øtention of this Tendon that happens thereupon, is very dangerous, and hard to cure.

The other being the backward Proce≈øs, is called Articularis, becau≈øe it ≈øerves for articulation. This hath a neck and a longi≈øh head, (called Condylus) that is covered with a Cartilage for its ea≈øier motion: By this head it is articulated into the Sinus of Os petro≈øum, that is al≈øo lined with a Cartilage, and is knit thereto ≈øtrongly by a membranous Ligament. At the ≈øides and roots of the≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes it hath ≈øhallow Sinus's or Cavities in its ≈øurface, but they are deeper on the in≈øide than on the out≈øide. The principal u≈øe of both ≈øeemeth to be for the pa≈ø≈øage or in≈øertion of the Mu≈øcles.

This Bone of the lower Jaw is very hard, and for the mo≈øt part very ≈øolid, to make it the ≈øtronger. Yet on each ≈øide (more backward than in Men) it hath a Cavity within it, which contains a marrowy juice for its nouri≈øhment. It hath al≈øo four perforations or holes, of which two are at the roots of the Proce≈ø≈øes, by which a branch of the fifth pair of Nerves, as al≈øo a Vein and Artery do pa≈øs to the Teeth. The two other
holes are in its fore-part by the ≈øides of the Chin, through which two twigs of the ≈øaid fifth branch of Nerves do pa≈øs out again to the lower Lip, and its Mu≈øcles and Skin.

This lower Jaw as well as the upper hath Sockets for the Teeth to ≈øtand in, in number equall to the Teeth, which Sockets are called by the Latins Alveoli or little Pits. The≈øe are digged deep, that the Teeth like ≈øo many Nails might be the firmlier fa≈øtned in them. When any of the Teeth fall out of them, (as the Foal-teeth, &c.) in a ≈øhort time they are obliterated, the Jaw becoming ≈ømooth without any pit in it in that place.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Figure, Magnitude, Number and Articulation of the Teeth.

argument.p: The Teeth. Their ≈øub≈øtance and Ve≈ø≈øels. 1. Three ≈øorts of them. Inci≈øores. 2. Canini. 3. Molares. How to know the age of an Hor≈øe by his Teeth.

div.p: THE Teeth are called in Latin Dentes, qua≈øi Edentes, from eating.They are of a very hard ≈øub≈øtance, yea, harder than any of the other Bones in the whole Body. That part of them that ≈øtands out above the Gumm, is ≈ømooth and free from any covering; but that part that is within the Sockets of the Jaws is more rough and covered with a thin Membrane or Perio≈øteum, which Membrane is of exqui≈øite ≈øen≈øe. Tho≈øe ≈øort of them which we call the Grinding teeth, have a manife≈øt Cavity within, but the Inci≈øores (or Fore-teeth) and Dog-teeth have but very ob≈øcure ones. Into the≈øe Cavities by the very ≈ømall holes that are in the roots of the Teeth, are received (into each Tooth) a Capillary Artery from the Carotides, al≈øo a ≈ømall Vein from the Jugulars, and a twig of a Nerve from the fifth pair; which Nerve being expanded through the thin Membrane that inve≈øts the ≈øaid Cavity, gives it a mo≈øt acute ≈øen≈øe; whereas the bony part of the Tooth is of it ≈øelf in≈øen≈øible. The≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels before-mentioned, namely, the Vein, Artery and Nerve, are united together and cloathed with a common Coat when they enter the Jaw, within which they have a proper chanel to run along in under the roots of the Teeth, to each of which roots they ≈øend ≈ømall twigs as they pa≈øs by, as afore≈øaid.

As in Men, ≈øo in Hor≈øes, there are three kinds of Teeth, namely, Inci≈øores, Canini and Molares. The Inci≈øores, Cutters or Shredders are tho≈øe we call the Fore-teeth from their being ≈øeated in the fore-part of the Jaw. They are ≈øharp-edged like a Knife, and broad al≈øo, that they may the better bite off or crop the Gra≈øs, &c. They are in number twelve, that is to ≈øay, in each Jaw ≈øix. They have each but one root or phang, though that root is indifferent large, mo≈øt times larger than any one of the phangs of the great or Grinding-teeth.

The next to the≈øe are tho≈øe which in Hor≈øes we call the Tu≈øhes, but in Men they are called the Dog-teeth or Canini, not onely becau≈øe in figure they are like the Teeth of a Dog, and ≈øtand out of the Gumms as Dog's-teeth do; but from their u≈øe al≈øo, which is to gnaw upon and break (with their ≈øharp points) what is too hard for the Fore-teeth to cut or ≈øhear in ≈øunder. The roots of the≈øe as of the former are ≈øingle, having but one phang.

Tho≈øe of the third rank, are the double Teeth, which are called Molares, or Grinders, becau≈øe the Meat is broken or ground by them, even as Corn is ground by the Mill-≈øtone. The≈øe are in Hor≈øes twenty four in number, in each Jaw twelve. Their ≈øeat is in the inner part of the Mouth, being environed in their out≈øide by the Cheeks, le≈øt the broken or ≈øhredded Meat, being rowled by the Tongue upon the Teeth, ≈øhould ≈ølip over them out of the Mouth, before it be ≈øufficiently ground.

The two foremo≈øt of the≈øe Teeth, ≈øtanding next to the Dog-teeth or Tu≈øhes, are tho≈øe by which the age of an Hor≈øe is known till after ≈øeven years old, and that by their unevenne≈øs at the top, having ≈øeveral little thin ≈øhells or ≈øcales as it were ≈øticking up round the out≈øide of the top of them, whereby their middle part is made to appear hollow; which hollowne≈øs where it is found, is a certain ≈øign of the Hor≈øe's being under ≈øeven years of age. And it is al≈øo to be ob≈øerved, that the nearer the Hor≈øe comes to that age, the more doth that hollowne≈øs grow out by degrees: ≈øo that when he comes to be full ≈øeven years old it is quite obliterated, and ≈øo the Hor≈øe's age to be no more known by that ≈øign, being pa≈øt the mark in the Mouth as we ≈øay: for by the perpetual u≈øe that the Hor≈øe makes of his Teeth, the before-mentioned Shells at the top of them, which cau≈øe their hollowne≈øs, are worn down even with the other parts of the Teeth, ≈øo that the whole top of the Tooth becomes even, ≈ømooth and plain.

Neither are the re≈øt of the Grinding-teeth without ≈øome hollowne≈øs or at lea≈øt roughne≈øs in their tops; but this is of a different nature from the other: which roughne≈øs or unevenne≈øs is very nece≈ø≈øary, for by it they are made more fit for the comminution of the Meat: For as Millers when their Mil≈øtones are grown ≈ømooth, do pick them anew, to make them grind the better; ≈øo hath Nature made the upper part of the≈øe Grinding-teeth, elegantly to imitate the rough ≈øuperficies of a Mil≈øtone, having here and there formed little pits in them. We ≈øhall not need to ≈øhew the u≈øes of the≈øe, or of either the foregoing ≈øorts of Teeth, that being intimated ≈øufficiently in the de≈øcription of them.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Bone of the Tongue called Os hyoides.

argument.p: Os hyoides. Its figure and parts. Its ∆≤≈øe.

div.p: THAT Bone which is called Os hyoides, is of the ≈øhape of a Greek v (yp≈øilon) and is ≈øeated under (or at the root of) the Tongue, being as it were the foundation and ≈øupporter of it. It is compounded of three Bones, viz. one in the middle, (being larger than the other two) which is gibbous forwards (or outwards) and ≈øomewhat hollowed inwards; by its gibbous ≈øide it is joined to the ba≈øis or bottom of the Tongue: The other two Bones are lateral, and are called Cornua, or Horns. To the fir≈øt Bone there are affixed two Gri≈øtles, and to each of the≈øe one. They are all tied to the adjacent parts, partly by a fle≈øhy, partly by a nervous ≈øub≈øtance. It hath three Sinus or Cavities; above, a tran≈øver≈øe depre≈ø≈øed Sinus, to admit the ≈øecond pair of Mu≈øcles proper to it; and in the ≈øides of this Sinus there are two other, which give way unto the fir≈øt pair of Mu≈øcles that are implanted into the ≈øides of this Bone.

The u≈øe of this Bone (although it be but a little one) is very great;for mo≈øt if not all the Mu≈øcles that move the Tongue either are in≈øerted into it or ari≈øe from it. It ≈øerves al≈øo to keep the Throat open, admitting the Epiglottis or Throat-flap into its bo≈øom, when it is lifted up in breathing. And la≈øtly ≈øome of the Mu≈øcles of the Larynx or Throttle ari≈øe from it.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Bones of the Neck.

argument.p: The Collar-bones, their ≈øub≈øtance and u≈øe. The Vertebrae of the Neck, their number and holes. 1 The fir≈øt de≈øcribed. 2 The ≈øecond, &c. de≈øcribed.

div.p: HAving treated of the Bones of the Head, we come in the next place to ≈øpeak to tho≈øe of the Neck, which, in dividing the Body into three Parts at the beginning of this Fifth Book, (viz. the Head, Trunk and Limbs) we con≈øidered as annext to the Head. Its Bones are of two ≈øorts, viz. the Collar or Chanel-bones, and the Vertebrae. But fir≈øt of the Collar-bones.

The≈øe are in number two, one on each ≈øide. They are called Claviculae, either from their re≈øembling the ≈øhape of old-fa≈øhioned Keys, which were of the ≈øhape of an Italick ≈ø; or becau≈øe they lock up as it were and clo≈øe the Che≈øt; for by ≈øome they are accounted as belonging to it. Their ≈øub≈øtance is ≈øpongy and thick, e≈øpecially about their heads; but in their middle they are thin and flat. By one end they are joined to the top of the Brea≈øt-bone, and by the other to the fir≈øt Rack-bone of the Back, wherein they differ from tho≈øe in Man, which are jointed into
the Proce≈øs of the Shoulder-bone. Their u≈øe is to uphold the Shoulder-blades, that they ≈øhould not ≈ølide down upon the Brea≈øt together with the Shoulder-bone, which upon a di≈ølocation or fracture of the≈øe Collar-bones doth often come to pa≈øs.

The number of the Vertebrae or Rack-bones of the Neck is ≈øeven, and they are reckoned from the Head downward; that next the Head being the fir≈øt. They have in each of them a large Cavity as tho≈øe of the Back and Loins have, to give way to the Spinal Marrow to de≈øcend by. Be≈øides this large hole which is common to the≈øe with tho≈øe others, they have al≈øo each of them two other ≈ømaller holes in their tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes, through which the Cervical Veins and Arteries do pa≈øs to the Head. And betwixt their jointing one with another there is a third hole, or rather half of one, for one half is formed out of the lower ≈øide of the upper, and the other out of the upper ≈øide of the lower Vertebra: By the≈øe the Nerves pa≈øs out from the Spinal Marrow.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe Bones is called Atlas, becau≈øe in Men the Head ≈øtands upon it like the Globe of the World, as the Poets feigned Atlas to bear the Cele≈øtial Globe upon his Shoulders. The body of this Bone is more ≈ølender, but ≈øolider than the re≈øt, and it wanteth its hinder Proce≈øs or Spine, having onely a kind of a ≈øemicircular knob jetting out in≈øtead of it: the rea≈øon of which ≈øeems to be, le≈øt the greater ≈øtreight pair of Mu≈øcles of the Head that ≈øpring from the ≈øecond Vertebra of the Neck, and march over the back-≈øide of this, ≈øhould be hurt in bending the Head forwards. But it has all its other Proce≈ø≈øes, viz. a≈øcending, de≈øcending and tran≈øver≈øe. Within on the fore-≈øide of its great Foramen, it has a Sinus, in ≈øhape ≈øemicircular, which is lined with a Cartilage or Gri≈øtle, and which receiveth the Tooth-like Proce≈øs of the ≈øecond Vertebra.

The ≈øecond Vertebra is called Dentata, becau≈øe out of its upper ≈øide, between its two a≈øcending Proce≈ø≈øes, there ≈øprings an Appendix or Proce≈øs, round and long, like the Dog-tooth in Man (or Tu≈øh in a Hor≈øe.) This Tooth is covered with a Cartilage, and is jointed into the fore≈øaid Sinus of the fir≈øt Vertebra, and upon it, as upon an Axle-tree, the head turns round, from whence the whole Bone is called by ≈øome Axis. That part of the Tooth which enters not into the ≈øaid Sinus (viz. its ba≈øis) is encompa≈ø≈øed with a Ligament, which knits it to the Occiput. This and the four following have Spines or hinder Proce≈ø≈øes, each of which are divided into two for the better connexion of the Ligaments and Mu≈øcles to them. We ≈øhall not need to de≈øcribe particularly any more of them, ≈øeeing they are in all things like to the ≈øecond, ≈øaving that their lateral Proce≈ø≈øes are larger, and divided into two as well as the hinder: yea the ≈øeventh it ≈øelf differs not from the re≈øt, though in Man it do.

The bodies of the≈øe Vertebrae of the Neck are longer than tho≈øe of the Back or Loins; for though the Neck of an Hor≈øe be of ≈øo con≈øiderable length, yet as hath been ≈øaid its Vertebrae are but ≈øeven (as they are in Man) whereas tho≈øe of the Back and Loins are twenty four in all, which ≈øpace notwith≈øtanding is not ≈øo long again as the Neck is; whereas were the Vertebrae of a proportionable length, it ≈øhould be more than three times the length.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the Vertebrae of the Back and Loins; and of the Ribs.
div.p: THE Back con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øeventeen Vertebrae or Rack-bones, ju≈øt ≈øo many as there be Ribs on a ≈øide, for on each ≈øide of every Rackbone is there a Rib articulated. But ≈øeeing, as we have ≈øaid, the Collar-bone is in≈øerted into the fir≈øt Vertebra of the Back, it will ≈øo fall out that the la≈øt Rib will be articulated into that Vertebra which we reckon for the fir≈øt of the Loins: into which the Rib indeed is ≈øo jointed, that it is not ea≈øy to ≈øay whether it be into the top of this, or into the lower end of the ≈øeventeenth of the Back The Bodies of the Racks as well as their Proce≈ø≈øes do differ ≈øomewhat from the Bodies and Proce≈ø≈øes of the Racks of the Neck; for the Bodies of the Racks of the Neck are longer than the≈øe, and more flat on their in≈øide, that the Gullet might re≈øt the more ≈øecurely on them: and as for their Proce≈ø≈øes, the hinder are not cleft into two as tho≈øe of the Neck are, and the tran≈øver≈øe ones are more ≈øhort and blunt, having (in≈øtead of the holes that are in tho≈øe of the Neck) each a ≈øhallow Sinus, into which the Ribs are partly articulated. But the Proce≈ø≈øes are in both of an equal number, namely four oblique ones, (that is, two tending obliquely upwards, and two obliquely downwards) two tran≈øver≈øe or lateral ones, and one acute or hinder one, which is called the Spine.

The Bodies of the≈øe Vertebrae are not ≈øo ≈øolid as tho≈øe of the Neck, but they are more bulky or thicker about, and are full of ≈ømall perforations for the admi≈ø≈øion of the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels to the Spinal Marrow, and be≈øides have two at each Joint for the egre≈øs of the Nerves from the Spinal Marrow. They have each of them on each ≈øide a Sinus or Cavity for the inarticulation of the head of the Rib, which Sinus tho≈øe of the Neck want, as having no Bones to joint into them.

Note that the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes of two or three of the lowe≈øt of the≈øe Racks begin to grow ≈øhorter and ≈øhorter, and their Spines are more blunt, and ≈øtand evener out, declining not ≈øo much downwards as tho≈øe before-going. As for the great Cavity or Perforation in the middle of the Bodies, it is proportionable to the Marrow which it contains.

Next to the Bones of the Neck we come to tho≈øe of the Loins, which make the third part of the Spine. They are in number ≈øeven, and are bigger than any of the fore-going either of the Neck or Back. Their hinder Proce≈ø≈øes or Spines are ≈øhorter, but broader and thicker than tho≈øe of the Back, ≈øomewhat bending upwards as mo≈øt of tho≈øe decline downwards; but as for the lateral or tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes, they exceed tho≈øe of the Back in length. The≈øe Vertebrae are joined one to another by a clammy Gri≈øtle, and likewi≈øe the uppermo≈øt of them to the la≈øt of the Back, and the lowe≈øt to the fir≈øt of Os ≈øacrum in like manner.

Be≈øides their lateral Perforations betwixt their jointings for the tran≈ømi≈ø≈øion or letting forth of the Nerves, they have al≈øo ≈øeveral other little holes for the intromi≈ø≈øion of the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels. As for their middle Perforation, nothing need be ≈øaid particularly of it, ≈øeeing it differs not from
that of tho≈øe of the Back, being of capacity equal to the thickne≈øs of the Marrow that it contains.

The Ribs (in Latin Co≈øtae) are in number thirty four, that is to ≈øay, on each ≈øide ≈øeventeen. Their ≈øub≈øtance is partly bony, and partly cartilaginous or gri≈øtly; the fir≈øt ≈øerving for firmne≈øs, and the latter for articulation, that upon occa≈øion they might yield a little without breaking. They are divided into two ≈øorts, the one called true, and the other the Ba≈øtard-ribs. The true are the nine uppermo≈øt, ≈øo called becau≈øe each with its fellow makes a compleat circle, being joined together by the mediation of the Spondyls of the Back behind, and the Brea≈øt-bone before. I ≈øay the Ribs are articulated into the Back-bones behind, ≈øomething of a cartilaginous ≈øub≈øtance coming between: (the manner whereof is well expre≈øt in the following Figure.) At this articulation into the Vertebrae each Rib has two knobs, one of which is received into the Sinus of the Body of the Vertebra, and the other which is le≈øs, into that of the tran≈øver≈øe Proce≈øs. And they are joined before to the Brea≈øt-bone by way of articulation al≈øo; for their Cartilages end into little heads which are received into the ≈ømooth Sinus's of the Brea≈øt-bone.

The Ba≈øtard-ribs are the eight lower, being of a more ≈øoft and gri≈øtly ≈øub≈øtance than the other; becau≈øe being articulated onely at one end, it was nece≈ø≈øary they ≈øhould be of a more yielding and pliable nature, otherwi≈øe they would have been very apt to break. Yea their yielding is not onely a ≈øecurity to them≈øelves, but very convenient in re≈øpect to the parts that are contained under or within them. For ≈øeeing the Stomach lies in this region which u≈øes to be di≈øtended with Meat or Water, the≈øe Ribs ought to give way to it when it or the intermediate parts, as the Liver and Spleen, bear again≈øt them.
The figure of the Ribs is (as you may al≈øo ≈øee in the following Figure) ≈øemicircular, like a Bow when it is drawn; which Nature hath ≈øo ordered to make the Che≈øt ≈øtronger and more capacious.

They are on the out≈øide rough and unequal, e≈øpecially near the Vertebrae, that the Ligaments might take the firmer hold on them, by which they are tied to the Rack-bones: but on their in≈øide they are ≈ømoother (being covered with the Pleura) le≈øt they ≈øhould hurt the Lungs and other Parts that bear again≈øt them. They are all of them narrower and roundi≈øh toward the Back, and broader and flatter toward the Brea≈øt. In their lower and inner part they have a furrow that runs along them, in which a Nerve and the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels are conducted.

The u≈øes of the Ribs are, fir≈øt, to be a defence to the Bowels within the Brea≈øt, and to the Stomach, Liver and Spleen in the Lower Belly; and ≈øecondly, to ≈øupport the Mu≈øcles which ≈øerve for re≈øpiration, and to be moved by them: for which cau≈øe the Brea≈øt ought not to con≈øi≈øt of one Bone, for then it would have been immoveable; whereas now it ea≈øily admits of dilatation and contraction.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Sternum or Brea≈øt-bone, and of the Scapula or Shoulder-blade.

argument.p: The Sternum, its figure and ≈øub≈øtance. What parts articulate into it. Its ∆≤≈øe. The Scapula, its ≈øituation, figure and connexion. Its Proce≈ø≈øes. Its Appendixes. Its Cavities.

div.p: THE Brea≈øt-bone in an Hor≈øe is not flat on the out≈øide as it is in Men, but ≈øtands out with a ridge, and is ≈øomething like the keel or bottom of a Boat, jetting out with its middle on the out≈øide, and is hollow on the in≈øide. It is of a ≈øpongy ≈øub≈øtance, neither ≈øo ≈øolid nor ≈øo white as mo≈øt of the other Bones of the Body. In Foals it is rather gri≈øtly than bony, and does then con≈øi≈øt of more parts than it does in grown Hor≈øes; for as by age the Gri≈øtles grow into a bony ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øo they do unite ≈øo one to another in time, that no foot≈øteps are left of their fir≈øt divi≈øion.

In its upper part towards the Throat it is rather pointed and ≈øharp, than horned as it is in Men; however on the in≈øide it is hollowed, for t he more convenient de≈øcent of the Wind-pipe. Without on each ≈øide of its upper end there is a little Sinus into which the heads of the Collar-bones are received or articulated. Betwixt which articulation of the Collarbones into it, and its lower end, there are ≈øeveral Sinus on each ≈øide of it, to the number of nine, into which the gri≈øtly ends of ≈øo many true Ribs are jointed. Its lower end terminates in a Gri≈øtle even in old Hor≈øes, who≈øe end is of a more obtu≈øe or blunt ≈øhape than in Men, in whom it is called Cartilago en≈øiformis, or the Sword-point-like Gri≈øtle.

Its u≈øe is for the articulation of one end of the Collar-bones and true Ribs into it, and to ≈øerve as a Brea≈øt-plate for the ≈øafeguard and defence of the noble Bowels (viz. the Heart and Lungs) that are lodged within it.

The Shoulder-blade is called in Latin Scapula. There are two of them (viz. on each ≈øide of the upper part of the Che≈øt one) as there are of all the ≈øorts of Bones in the fore and al≈øo in the hinder Legs; but we ≈øhall for brevity's ≈øake ≈øpeak of the Bones onely of one Leg before and another behind, becau≈øe the other two are in all things like unto the≈øe, wherefore it is not any way nece≈ø≈øary to repeat the de≈øcription of them, nor yet to ≈øpeak of them in the plural number.

The Shoulder-blade is ≈øeated upon the ≈øide of the true Ribs, (like a Target) reaching from the Vertebrae of the Back almo≈øt to the bottom of the Collar-bone. It is in figure after a ≈øort triangular, on the in≈øide concave or hollow, and on the out≈øide prominent or arched. It is jointed to no Bone but by its lower end to the Shoulder-bone; but yet it is knit to ≈øeveral Parts by the Mu≈øcles that are in≈øerted into it, or ri≈øe from it; as to the hinder-part of the Head by the Cucullar Mu≈øcles, being the fir≈øt of its movers; al≈øo to the Vertebrae of the Neck by its ≈øecond pair; and to the Back by the Mu≈øcle Rhomboides, &c.

It hath three Proce≈ø≈øes. The fir≈øt being the ≈øhorte≈øt, is called its Neck, which neck ends into a ≈øinuated or hollow cup or head, which receiveth the head of the Shoulder-bone, and its brim is compa≈ø≈øed with a thick
Gri≈øtle, whereby its Cavity is made the deeper that the head of the Shoulder-bone that is jointed into it ≈øhould not ≈øo ea≈øily ≈ølip out. The ≈øecond Proce≈øs, which by ≈øome is accounted the fir≈øt, is extended along its middle on the out≈øide, and is called its Spine; and that end of this Spine that by a ≈øhallow Sinus receives one of the Heads of the Shoulder-bone, is called Acromium, that is to ≈øay, its point or tip. The third and la≈øt of the≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes is toward the lower and in≈øide of the Bone, and from the likene≈øs it hath with an Anchor is called Ancyroides, Anchor-like; ≈øome al≈øo who compare it to a Crows Bill, do give it the name of Coracoides: This Proce≈øs doth ≈øomewhat help to hold the Shoulder-bone in its place, entring a little into a ≈øhallow Sinus of the ≈øaid Bone.
It hath five Appendixes about its Neck, three of which do afford an original to ≈øome Mu≈øcles, and from the other two do ≈øpring Ligaments which join the Shoulder-bone to the head of the Blade.

By means of the ≈øecond Proce≈øs that runs like a Ridge or Spine along the middle of its back there are formed on its out≈øide two long Furrows or Cavities, in which ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles lie, e≈øpecially the Supra≈øcapularis and Sub≈øcapularis, which are otherwi≈øe called Supra≈øpinatus and Infra≈øpinatus, from their being placed the fir≈øt above this Spine or on that ≈øide next the Neck, and the latter below it or on that ≈øide next the Ribs.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Os humeri or Shoulder-bone, and the next Bone under it called the Cubit.

argument.p: The Bones of the Fore-leg. 1 The Shoulder-bone. What Bones it articulates with. 2 The Cubit-bone, its Articulations.

div.p: THE Bones of the Fore-leg under the Scapula or Shoulder-blade are the Shoulder-bone, the Cubit-bone, the Seven O≈ø≈øelets or little Bones that make the Knee, an≈øwering to the eight little Bones that make the Carpus or Wri≈øt in Humane Bodies, the Shank-bone an≈øwering to the Bones of the Metacarpus or back of the Hand, the great Pa≈øtern an≈øwering to the fir≈øt Joint of the Fingers, the little Pa≈øtern to the ≈øecond Joint, and the Coffin-bone to the la≈øt Joint, on which the Nail grows, as doth the Hoof of the Hor≈øe on the Coffin-bone. Of the ≈øimilitude there is betwixt the≈øe ≈øeveral Joints in a Hor≈øe's Fore-leg, and tho≈øe in the Arm and Hand of a Man, I have already di≈øcour≈øed pretty fully in the Book of the Mu≈øcles, where I treated of the Mu≈øcles of the≈øe Parts: wherefore I ≈øhall in this place ≈øpeak no more of that, but proceed to the de≈øcription of the before-named Bones in their order.

The Shoulder-bone is that which reaches from the Shoulder-blade to the Elbow. Both its ends are called Heads, being thicker than the re≈øt of the Bone, the upper of which that is in≈øerted into the cup of the Blade-bone, is naturally an appendix to the Bone, but in time grows to be a part or proce≈øs of the Bone it ≈øelf.

This Head is large and orbicular, covered over with a Gri≈øtle, that it might be turned more glibly within the cavity of the Cup of the Blade. On the out≈øide of this Head there bunch out two rough and uneven Proce≈ø≈øes, into which two Ligaments are in≈øerted for the ≈øtrengthning of the Joint; (one of which is like a ≈øecond Head, and is articulated into the ≈øhallow cavity of the acromium, or end of the Spine of the Shoulder-bone;) and betwixt the≈øe two Proce≈ø≈øes there is a long and round chink
through which the nervous Head of the Mu≈øcle Biceps doth pa≈øs. There is al≈øo on the in≈øide another round Cavity in the ≈øide of the Head, out of which the ≈øtrong Ligament ≈øprings that ties this Head in the cup of the Scapula.

The lower Head of this Bone which in Men is articulated with two Bones, viz. the ∆≤lna and Radius, in a Hor≈øe is jointed but with one, (which I call the Cubit-bone) yet is ≈øo jointed to that one, that it receives it and is received by it, having three Proce≈ø≈øes, and two Sinus betwixt them, much like the ≈øame Proce≈ø≈øes and Sinus in the ≈øame Bone of a Man.

Be≈øides the≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes already mentioned, it hath on its in≈øide another notable one, from which ari≈øe the Mu≈øcles that lie on the in≈øide of the Leg upon the Cubit-bone: and on its out≈øide it hath yet another Proce≈øs, but ≈øomething le≈øs than the former, from whence do ari≈øe the Mu≈øcles that lie on the out≈øide of the Leg upon the Cubit-bone. About the middle of this Bone, on its in≈øide, may be perceived a hole, through which both Veins and Arteries pa≈øs to the Marrow contained in this Bone, for its nouri≈øhment.

The next part of the Leg is called the Cubit, con≈øi≈øting, as hath been ≈øaid, in Men of two Bones, but in a Hor≈øe onely of one: The two Bones in Men reach from the Elbow to the Wri≈øt; and this one in Hor≈øes from the Elbow to that Joint commonly called the Knee, but which might properly enough have the ≈øame name as in Men, ≈øeeing it is of a like fabrick. This Cubit-bone in its hinder and upper part hath a notable Proce≈øs, long and round, onely ≈øomething flatti≈øh, which entreth into the larger Sinus or Cavity of the lower Head of the Shoulder-bone, and maketh that bunching-out which we call the Elbow. This Proce≈øs is ≈øomething rough and uneven, partly that the Ligaments might be the more ≈øtrongly knit to it that encompa≈øs the Joint; and partly for the in≈øertion of ≈øome Mu≈øcles of the Cubit, as al≈øo to give original unto the Mu≈øcles that bend the lower part of the Leg and Foot; for which cau≈øe al≈øo the Bone it ≈øelf is rough at the root of the Proce≈øs. The circumference of the Sinus into which it is in≈øerted, is al≈øo rough, that from thence Ligaments might i≈ø≈øue. Its le≈ø≈øer and inner Proce≈øs is received by the le≈ø≈øer Sinus of the Head of the Shoulder-bone. There are three cavities in this upper Head, for the reception of as many Proce≈ø≈øes of the lower end of the Shoulder-bone. Its lower end articulates with the three upper little-Bones of the Knee (that make the fir≈øt range) as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in the next Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the ≈øeven O≈ø≈øeletts or little Bones of the Knee, of the Shank-bones which reach from the Knee to the great Pa≈øtern, and al≈øo of the two Pa≈øtern-bones and the Coffin-bone.

argument.p: The number of the little Bones of the Knee. 1 The upper rank. 2 The lower. The Shank-bone, its Articulation. The Splent-bones. The great Pa≈øtern. The little Pa≈øtern. The Coffin-bone. Its figure, ≈øub≈øtance and Sinus's. The cau≈øe and cure of a Founder.

div.p: BEtween the Cubit-bone and the Shank-bone there are two ranges of little Bones, one above another, being in number ≈øeven, that is to ≈øay, three in the fir≈øt and four in the ≈øecond range: all which are joined one to another ≈øo firmly, that they are not ea≈øily to be ≈øeparated. The upper range are articulated with the lower end of the Cubit-bone, and the lower range with the upper end of the Shank-bone.

The≈øe Bones do differ one from another in their magnitude, form and ≈øituation, and are ≈øaid in their fir≈øt generation to be all Gri≈øtles and not Bones, but in proce≈øs of time they become hard and grow bony. Their ≈øub≈øtance is ≈øpongy, as are all the re≈øt of the Bones which of Gri≈øtles become bony, of which kind are all the Appendices of Bones, the Bones of the Brea≈øt and ≈øuch like. They are all covered over with both a membranous and gri≈øtly Ligament, whereby they are ≈øo compacted together, that without dividing the ≈øaid Ligaments, and ≈øeparating the Membranes or Skins, it is a hard matter to di≈øtingui≈øh them one from another, ≈øo that at the fir≈øt view they may be thought to be all of them but one Bone.

They have a double Superficies, one outer, which is gibbous or bunching, and another inward which is concavous or hollow; and in their upper part where they join to the Cubit-bone, they are ≈ømooth and cru≈øted over with the before-mentioned Gri≈øtle.

The≈øe Bones I will not undertake to give proper names to, but ≈øhall di≈øtingui≈øh them by their order and number, calling that the fir≈øt that is placed on the in≈øide of the upper rank. This is ≈øomething longi≈øh and curved inward, articulated with the Cubit-bone above, and below with the ≈øecond Bone of the lower rank, yea it toucheth both the third and fourth of the ≈øame rank. Its in≈øide joineth clo≈øely to the in≈øide of the ≈øecond Bone of its own rank.

The ≈øecond of the≈øe Bones is clo≈øe knit to the former, being ≈øomething le≈øs than it. It is joined to the Cubit-bone in its upper part, which part is hollowed to receive the Appendix of the ≈øaid Bone. It is al≈øo joined with the fir≈øt Bone by one ≈øide, and by the other or rather hinder part to the third Bone, and la≈øtly by its bottom to the ≈øeventh Bone or fourth of the lower rank.
The third is al≈øo joined above with a plain Super≈øicies to the Cubit-bone, by its in≈øide to the ≈øecond Bone of its own rank, and by its lower part to the fourth Bone of the next rank.

The fourth Bone or fir≈øt of the lower rank, is ≈øomething ≈ømaller than any of the before-mentioned three, and is in ≈øhape almo≈øt round. It is ≈ømooth, not being hollow nor protuberated as the re≈øt are. It is joined
above to the out≈øide of the lower-part of the fir≈øt Bone, below to the Shank-bone, and on its in≈øide to the fifth Bone or ≈øecond of its own rank.

The fifth (or ≈øecond of the lower rank) hath ≈øeveral little Sinus's; It hath one notable one above into which the fir≈øt Bone of the upper rank is articulated, and another below for the reception of part of the Head of the Shank-bone.
The ≈øixth (or third of the lower rank) is joined with a plain Superficies on each ≈øide to the ≈øeventh (or fourth) and to the foregoing; above, to the ≈øecond, and below to the Shank-bone.

The ≈øeventh (or fourth of the lower rank) is not much unlike the former, on its in≈øide being joined to the foregoing, on its upper ≈øide to the third of the upper rank, and on its lower to the head or top of the Shank-bone.

The next part of the Leg which an≈øwers to the After-wri≈øt or back of the Hand in a Man, is made of three Bones, one of which is long and round and much larger than the other two. It reaches from the Knee to the great Pa≈øtern, being articulated above with every one of the lower rank of the little Bones of the Knee; and below it is joined to the great Pa≈øtern by a mutual articulation, having two round heads and three ≈ømall Cavities at that end of it for that purpo≈øe. This we call the Shank-bone.

To each ≈øide of this Bone is fa≈øtned another long thin Bone, in figure ≈øomething like a Bodkin, being ≈øomewhat thick and round at their upper part, and from thence as they run down towards the Foot, becoming thinner and ≈øharper, till at la≈øt they end in a ≈øharp point, a little above the joining of the Shank-bone with the great Pa≈øtern. Between the≈øe two Bones do run the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles that move the Foot, as they de≈øcend down the Shank-bone. The≈øe two we may call the Splent-bones, ≈øtanding on each ≈øide of the Shank-bone like two Splents, ≈øuch as Bone≈øetters u≈øe for broken Bones.

The next is the Bone which an≈øwereth to the fir≈øt joint of the Fingers in Man, in whom they are five in number, by the wonderfull wi≈øedom of the Creator ≈øo ordained as was fitte≈øt for that variety of motions to which they are de≈øign'd. But an Hor≈øe being Solidipes or a whole-footed Creature, hath all his Foot nece≈ø≈øarily moved together, and the Bones thereof in each Joint being ≈øingle, an≈øwer but to the Bones of one Finger.

The form of this Bone, which is called the great Pa≈øtern, is gibbous and crooked. At its top, where it is articulated with the Shank-bone, it has three ≈ømall Proce≈ø≈øes and two Cavities betwixt them: al≈øo two ≈ømall triangular Bones fa≈øtned to its back-part. Its out≈øide is plain and ≈ømooth, and without any roughne≈øs at all. Its lower end con≈øi≈øts of two heads which are round and bunching and are articulated into the Sinus of the le≈ø≈øer Pa≈øtern which is under it.

The next is the little Pa≈øtern, an≈øwering to the ≈øecond Joint of the Fingers. This is not much unlike the former, onely it differs in the length, for it is not much above half ≈øo long. Its upper end (as was ≈øaid) is articulated with the great Pa≈øtern, and its lower end is received by the Coffin-bone in the ≈øame manner as it ≈øelf received the lower end of the great Pa≈øtern by its own upper end.

The next and la≈øt Bone of the Foot is the Coffin-bone, ≈øo called (I ≈øuppo≈øe) from its hollowne≈øs on its under-≈øide. Its figure is ≈øemilunary or Half-moon-fa≈øhioned. It is thick at its top, (where it has cavities to receive the heads of the lower end of the little Pa≈øtern) but thin and broad at its bottom and toward its edges, for its more firm fixing upon the ground. Its ≈øub≈øtance is fungous or ≈øpongy, having innumerable little holes piercing through its ≈øides for the pa≈ø≈øage of the Ve≈ø≈øels; as al≈øo very many ≈ømall Sinus's whereinto are implanted the ends of the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles that move the lower part of the Leg, and the Foot: who≈øe Fibres being at any time affected either by brui≈øes, ill ≈øhooing, or by ≈øtanding in the water after hard riding whil≈øt the Hor≈øe is hot, or but by ≈øtanding ≈øtill in the Stable for ≈øeveral days without having the Feet ≈øtopt up, and the like; I ≈øay the tendinous Fibres being affected by the≈øe or other means, cau≈øe the Hor≈øe to have ≈øuch great pain in his Feet, that he can ≈øcarce endure to tread upon them; which lamene≈øs we call a Founder. Now this di≈øtemper is ≈øo much the harder to cure by rea≈øon the≈øe Fibres lie ≈øo far out of reach, mo≈øt of them running on the upper ≈øide of the Bone (betwixt it and the Hoof) and not to its bottom; ≈øo that the Hoof growing upon the ≈øides as the Soal doth at the bottom, there is great hazard but we ≈øhall mi≈øs of effecting a cure, if we onely pull the Soal out, and do not cut part of the Hoof off al≈øo. This is not my bare opinion, but the experience of tho≈øe that have had good ≈øucce≈øs in curing foundred Hor≈øes, who by ra≈øing the Hoof from the Coronet or top of it to the very bottom, in five or ≈øix places, untill they have made the Bloud come, and then applying their remedies to tho≈øe places, have made tho≈øe Hor≈øes ≈øound, whom the drawing out of their Soals would not cure.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Os ≈øacrum or holy Bone, together with the Coccyges or Rump-bones, otherwi≈øe called the Bones of the Dock or Tail.

argument.p: Os ≈øacrum, its ≈øeat, connexion, ≈øigure and ≈øurface. Its Vertebrae. Its Holes. The Rump-bones.

div.p: THE Os ≈øacrum or holy Bone, is ≈øeated at the lower end of the Back, at the end of the Vertebrae of the Loins, to the la≈øt of which one end of it is articulated, and the other end to the fir≈øt of the Bones of the Dock or Rump-bones. It is much the broade≈øt and large≈øt of all the Bones of the Back. Its figure is almo≈øt triangular, having a broad beginning, and ending by degrees into a narrowne≈øs. On the in≈øide it is ≈ømooth and hollow, but ≈øomething unequal; behind or on its out≈øide it is gibbous and al≈øo rough, becau≈øe of the Mu≈øcles of the Back and their Ligaments cleaving unto it. Its acute Proce≈ø≈øes or Spines are very ≈ømall; and the tran≈øver≈øe ones but ob≈øcure: as for the oblique, there is no appearance of them, ≈øave in the fir≈øt Vertebra. On its outer ≈øide near its edges there are certain Sinus's or hollowne≈ø≈øes, to which the Haunch-bones do cleave firmly by an intervening Cartilage.
Its Vertebrae are in number ≈øix, who≈øe Spines are much le≈øs than the Spines of the Vertebrae of the Loins, and the lower or nearer to the Rump-bones, the le≈ø≈øer they are ≈øtill.

This holy Bone is perforated in ≈øeveral places; as fir≈øt, quite through its length it hath a large hole or cavity to receive the Spinal Marrow; out from which there go many other le≈ø≈øer for the egre≈øs of the Nerves;
and the≈øe are not in the ≈øides of the Vertebrae as tho≈øe are that be in the Vertebrae of the Neck, Back and Loins, but on the in≈øide and out≈øide or and above, of which tho≈øe below are much the larger.

To this Bone at its lower end are joined the Rump-bones, which in this Animal we are treating of are in number eighteen. The≈øe are joined to each other by a Cartilage or Gri≈øtle, but ≈øo loo≈øely, that the Hor≈øe can bend his Rump which way he will. Tho≈øe of the≈øe Bones that are next to the holy Bone, are ≈øomething thicker and broader, than tho≈øe further from it; for as they de≈øcend down, they each grow le≈øs and le≈øs, ≈øo that the lowe≈øt grows into a cartilaginous or gri≈øtly point, as you may ≈øee in the figure of the Skeleton, where they are all lively repre≈øented in ≈øitu. The≈øe Bones are not ≈øo hard as mo≈øt of the other Bones are, but more ≈øoft and ≈øpongy; neither have they any Proce≈øs, or any hollowne≈øs, except the fir≈øt of them, which hath a ≈ømall cavity or den to receive the la≈øt Vertebra of the Os ≈øacrum, which Vertebra, is the furthe≈øt part whither the Spinal Marrow reaches.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the namele≈øs Bone, commonly divided into the Hip, Haunch and Share-bones.

argument.p: Os innominatum, or namele≈øs Bone. 1 Os ilium or Haunch-bone. Its Spine. 2 Coxendix or Hip-bone. 3 Os pubis or Share-bone. Pelvis or the Ba≈øon.

div.p: THE Hip-bone (commonly ≈øo called) is by Anatomi≈øts divided into three parts. Fir≈øt, Os ilium, ≈øo named becau≈øe the Gut Ilium lieth under it. The next is called Os coxendicis, or I≈øchium, which is the lower and outer part of the namele≈øs Bone, (or Os innominatum) which is the name of the≈øe three Bones as joined all together, for they are truly but one Bone in old Hor≈øes, though in Colts they are divided one from another by Cartilages, from whence this di≈øtinction is made, and they come to be di≈øcour≈øed of by three ≈øeveral names. The third part of this Bone is called Os pubis, al≈øo Pectinis, or the Share-bone.

That part that is called Os ilium, is the uppermo≈øt and broade≈øt, which is joined to the holy Bone. In figure it is ≈øemicircular, and its ≈øemicircular circumference is called its Spine. On its out≈øide it is ≈øomething arched, but within hollow; the arched part is called dor≈øum, its Back, the hollow part co≈øta, or its Rib.

That part which is called its Spine, is in many places unequal, that ≈øome Mu≈øcles might take their original from it, viz. the Oblique a≈øcendent Mu≈øcle of the Abdomen or Paunch, the Deltoides of the Thigh, the fir≈øt Extender of the Leg called Membrano≈øus, &c. And on the back of this Bone there are unequal in≈øcriptions or lines for the ri≈øe of the three Mu≈øcles of the Thigh that help to make the Buttocks (called Glutaei;) and al≈øo for other Mu≈øcles that lie under the≈øe.

The ≈øecond of the parts of this namele≈øs Bone is called Os coxendicis.This is the lower and outer part of it, in which there is a great Sinus, called Acetabulum, the Cup or Sawcer, into which the head of the Thigh-bone is exceeding ≈øtrongly articulated. This Cup has its edges environed with a Gri≈øtle, called Supercilium, its brow; in who≈øe circumference there are ob≈øerved three Sinus, two Protuberations and an acute Proce≈øs, and la≈øtly an Appendix that is very thick: all which were ordained for the production partly of Ligaments and partly of Mu≈øcles.

The third and la≈øt part of this namele≈øs Bone is called Os pubis, or the Share-bone. This is originally two Bones, parted one from another in the middle with a Gri≈øtle, but in continuance of time the Gri≈øtle it ≈øelf becomes bony, and ≈øo unites them into one Bone. It is placed at the bottom of the Paunch, betwixt the two hinder Legs as the Hor≈øe ≈øtands. On its out≈øide it has on each ≈øide a Sinus for the de≈øcent of the crural Ve≈ø≈øels. On the ≈øame ≈øide al≈øo it is rough to give the firmer original to the ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles of the Abdomen and to the ≈øecond Bender of the Leg. It is but a thin Bone, being hollow within, and perforated with the greate≈øt hole of any ≈øuch-like Bone in the whole Body. On its hinder and inner ≈øide it has two Proce≈ø≈øes, from whence the nervous bodies of the Yard, and ≈øome Mu≈øcles take their original.

The≈øe Bones with the holy Bone do make that cavity which is called the Ba≈øon, which is the place wherein are contained part of the Guts, and the Bladder in a Hor≈øe; and in a Mare part of the Guts, the Bladder and the Womb.
