div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Thigh-bone and Patella or little Bone of the Stifle.

argument.p: The Thigh-bone. Its upper Head. Its Neck Its lower Head is divided into two. Their Cavities. The Patella.

div.p: THE Thigh is called by the Latins Femur √† ferendo to bear, becau≈øe the Creature is born up or ≈øu≈øtained by it. This Bone (like the Bone of the Shoulder) is but one, reaching from the Hip-bone to the Stifle. The figure of it is long, round and ≈øtreight, except where its Heads and Protuberances bunch out; of which it hath, above, one Head, one Neck, and two Proce≈ø≈øes; and below, it determins into a Head which hath two Productions and a Cavity between them.

The upper Head is an orbicular Appendix ≈øtanding upon the Neck, and is the thicke≈øt and large≈øt Head of any Bone in the whole Body. It is round and long the better to enter into the Cup of the Hip-bone, which is not onely deep of it ≈øelf, but rendred deeper by a large Gri≈øtle that compa≈ø≈øeth the edges thereof. For it was nece≈ø≈øary that a very firm articulation ≈øhould be in this place, becau≈øe of the huge weight which the Thigh was to ≈øu≈øtain. And be≈øides, to ≈øtrengthen it the more, and to fa≈øten the
two Bones the firmer together, there ari≈øeth out of the Cup of the Hip-bone an exceeding ≈øtrong and round Ligament, which is implanted into a little Sinus that is in the Head of the Thigh-bone. This Head is ≈ømooth and cru≈øted over with a Gri≈øtle, that it might move the more glibly within the Cup.

The ≈ølender part under this Head is called the Neck of the Thigh-bone.This is pretty long and oblique, reaching upward but inclining inward, and is a Proce≈øs of the Bone. At its lower end, where the Bone grows broader, do ari≈øe two other Proce≈ø≈øes, called Trochanters or Rotatores, from the Mu≈øcles of that name that are in≈øerted into them. The upper of the≈øe Proce≈ø≈øes is greater than the lower, nay greater indeed than any Proce≈øs in the whole Body which is not joined to another Bone; It bends upward and outward; but the other which is much le≈øs than this, bendeth backward and ≈øomewhat inward.

The Thigh-bone below its middle becometh thicker, and its lower end terminateth into an ample and broad Head; out of the back≈øide of which are produced two Proce≈ø≈øes, as it were two other Heads, betwixt which there is a large ≈øpace left about two inches wide, which receiveth a protuberation or ≈øwelling of the Head of the Leg-bone.

The≈øe two Heads at the lower end of the Thigh-bone are on their out≈øides rough, but their in≈øides are covered with a Gri≈øtle, and thereby are made ≈ømooth and ≈ølippery for the more ea≈øy motion of the Joint. One of the≈øe Heads is thicker, and is ≈øeated inward; the other is thinner but broader, and is ≈øeated outward. From them do ≈øome of the Mu≈øcles that move the Leg ari≈øe; and into them are ≈øome that move the Thigh in≈øerted. The ≈øides of the≈øe Heads are full of little holes, out of which do i≈ø≈øue the roots of the Ligaments which ≈øtrengthen the Stifle-joint.

The≈øe Heads have al≈øo four Cavities, two of which are in the middle between the two Heads, and one on the out≈øide of either of them. One of the middle Cavities, being the foremo≈øt, is made to receive the protuberation of the Patella or Pan, and is therefore cru≈øted over with a Gri≈øtle for that purpo≈øe. The ≈øecond of the middle Cavities being more backward, is deeper than the other, al≈øo rough and unequal, made to receive the protuberation of the Leg-bone. The third is at the out≈øide of the outer head, and the fourth at the out≈øide of the inner, through both which the Tendons of ≈øeveral Mu≈øcles of the Leg de≈øcend.

At the lower end of this Thigh-bone, betwixt it and the Head of the Leg-bone, on the fore-≈øide, is placed a ≈ømall roundi≈øh Bone, (called the Patella or Stifle-pan) about three inches broad, being plain without, but within bunching, bored through with many ≈ømall holes. It is covered over on its in≈øide with a Gri≈øtle, and is made firm in its place by the broad Tendons of the ≈øecond, third and fourth Mu≈øcles that extend the Leg, to which the Patella is very firmly knit. This Bone ≈øtrengtheneth the jointing of the Thigh-bone with the Leg-bone, and hindreth their di≈ølocation forwards.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Leg-bone and Ranges of O≈ø≈øelets which make that part we call the Hock, an≈øwering to the Heel of a Man.

argument.p: The Shank-bone is but one. Its figure. Its upper Head. Its lower Head. Its Sinus's and Appendices. Its Cavity. The ≈øeven little Bones of the Hock. The In≈øtepbones. The Pa≈øternbones and Coffin-bone.

div.p: THERE is the ≈øame difference between the hinder Legs of an Hor≈øe and a Man's Legs, as we ≈øhew'd above to be between the Fore-legs of an Hor≈øe and a Man's Arm. For as in Man there are two Bones which reach from the Elbow to the Wri≈øt, and but one Bone in that Joint of an Hor≈øe's Fore-leg that an≈øwers to this (reaching from his Elbow to that Joint we commonly call the Knee;) ≈øo whereas in a Man's Leg there are two Bones, called Tibia and Fibula; in the ≈øame Joint of an Hor≈øe that reaches from the Stifle to the Heel, there is but one, which we ≈øhall call by the name of Tibia, or the Shin or Shank-bone, becau≈øe the Bone of a Man's Leg that goes by that name, is the more con≈øiderable of the two.
The figure of this Bone is long, and round in an Hor≈øe, but in a Man it is three-≈øquare. The upper part of it which joins with the Thigh-bone, is broader and thicker than the lower.

Its upper Head in which are two cavities and a prominence betwixt them, is cru≈øted over with a Gri≈øtle, and both receives and is received by the two Heads and cavity of the Thigh-bone; which Gri≈øtle is fa≈øtned to it by Ligaments. This Gri≈øtle is ≈ølippery and ≈ømooth, and the cavities which it lines are full of an unctuous or oily matter or humour, which ≈øerves to further the motion of the Joint by rendring it moi≈øt and ≈ølippery.

The lower part of this Bone, or its lower Head, is round and likewi≈øe covered with a Gri≈øtle, with which it is made ≈øomething broad, but notwith≈øtanding equals not the largene≈øs of the upper Head.

This Bone hath ≈øeveral Sinus's and Appendices, as well as the Thigh-bone hath; the former for conveniency of the Tendons of ≈øome Mu≈øcles to de≈øcend by, and the latter for the ri≈øe or original of other Mu≈øcles which are to move the Foot.

This Bone as well as the Thigh-bone (and mo≈øt other Bones) is notably hollowed within, having its cavity filled with Marrow. It is al≈øo perforated in ≈øeveral places, admitting through its perforations ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels to the ≈øaid Marrow.

Next come we to the little Bones of the Hock, which Joint an≈øwereth to the In≈øtep and Heel of a Man. The≈øe are of the ≈øame number as tho≈øe of the Knee in the Fore-legs were, and do al≈øo lie in two ranges, the one above the other, viz. three in the upper, and four in the lower. The≈øe Bones, as tho≈øe in the Knee, are ≈øo clo≈øely articulated one with another, and ≈øo clo≈øely wrapt up and bound together with membranous Ligaments, that it is not ea≈øie for the Di≈ø≈øector to di≈øcover where all of them are divided: ≈øo that without diligent in≈øpection they may be taken to be not above half the number they are truly of.

To treat of every particular Bone of them and of their connexion one with another, or la≈øtly of their jointing with the Shank-bone above, or with the three Bones of the Metatar≈øus below, would be in a manner the
repeating of the ≈øame de≈øcription over again that we gave above of the ≈øeven little Bones of the Knee. Onely that which is the hindmo≈øt and large≈øt of them de≈øerves to have particular notice taken of it, and that is it which is truly, and ought to be called the Heel-bone, who≈øe ≈øhape and po≈øture you may ≈øee in the following Figure. Into this Bone it is that ≈øeveral of the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles that bend the Leg are in≈øerted. On its in≈øide it has a large Sinus by which the Tendons of tho≈øe Mu≈øcles that move the lower Parts of the Foot do de≈øcend, as al≈øo the larger Ve≈ø≈øels thereof.

The next Bones to the≈øe are the three that an≈øwer to tho≈øe five that make that part of the Foot in Humane Bodies which is called the Metatar≈øus or In≈øtep. The≈øe I ≈øay are but three in a Hor≈øe, though in a Man they are five, to an≈øwer to the number of the five Toes. They reach from the lower range of the little Bones of the Hock before-mentioned, down to the great Pa≈øtern. One of them is a large, long and round Bone; the other two are much more ≈ølender, and ≈øhorter, being the one of them placed on the in≈øide and the other on the out≈øide of it, adhering ≈øo clo≈øely thereunto, that they are not ea≈øily to be ≈øeparated from it. The≈øe little Bones an≈øwer in all things to the like Bones which run down by the ≈øides of the Shank-bone of the Fore-legs, which from their ≈øhape I called the Bodkin-like Bones, (as likewi≈øe the Splent-bones, becau≈øe they ≈øtand by the ≈øides of the middle great Bone, like the Splents that Bone≈øetters make u≈øe of for ≈øtrengthning broken Bones till they are knit again;) I ≈øay the≈øe are like tho≈øe, and therefore may be called by the ≈øame names.

The remaining part of the Bones of the hinder Leg and Foot are the great Pa≈øtern (with the two little triangular Bones adhering to the top of it,) the little Pa≈øtern, and the Coffin-bone; of all which having already treated where I de≈øcribed the Bones of the Fore-legs, (with which the≈øe of the Hinder-legs agree in every particular) I ≈øhall for brevitie's ≈øake omit ≈øpeaking particularly of them, and here conclude my di≈øcour≈øe of the Bones.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Hoofs of an Hor≈øe an≈øwering to the Nails of a Man's Fingers or Toes.

argument.p: How the Hoofs are nouri≈øhed, and how fa≈øtened upon the Foot.

div.p: COncerning the Nails of a Man's Fingers and Toes (to which the Hoofs of Hor≈øes bear a re≈øemblance) learned Men are divided into ≈øeveral opinions about their generation. Hippocrates is affirmed to be of opinion, that they are made of a glutinous matter or moi≈øture parched and dried by heat, and driven to the extreme parts. Empedocles thinks them to be made of the extremities of the Nerves, calling them Nervorum clau≈øulas ≈øummas, the utmo≈øt terminations or boundaries of the Nerves; and that therefore when the≈øe fall off, it is a ≈øign of great weakne≈øs. Ari≈øtotle in lib. 2. cap. 6. de generatione Animal. ≈øaith, that the Nails, Hairs, Beaks of Birds, Hoofs of Bea≈øts, and ≈øuch like, are ingendred of adventitious aliment. And la≈øtly, Columbus thinks they take their original partly from the Skin, and partly from the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles which move the Fingers and Toes, and that they are encrea≈øed like the Teeth by an appo≈øition of aliment to their root.

As for the Hoofs of Hor≈øes, whatever be their original matter, out of which they are formed, their growth ≈øeems to be (according to the opinion of the la≈øt mentioned Authour) from the addition of new particles to their roots, which drive down ≈øucce≈ø≈øively tho≈øe before them. They are of a middle ≈øub≈øtance betwixt Bones and Gri≈øtles: not ≈øo hard as Bones, for then they would be apt to ≈øplinter and break; nor ≈øo ≈øoft as Gri≈øtles, for if they were, they could not ≈øupport ≈øo great a bulk as
the Body of an Hor≈øe, much le≈øs endure to travel among≈øt ≈øtones, &c. But they are of a horney ≈øub≈øtance, without ≈øen≈øe, growing pretty firmly to the parts included within them, and fa≈øtened to the Coffin-bone by a Ligament that proceeds from their top or root, which root the Skin al≈øo ≈øomewhat encompa≈ø≈øeth.

Under them lie many twigs of Nerves, and Tendons of Mu≈øcles, which run even to the very bottom of the Hoof or Soal of the Foot, upon pricking of which with a Nail or the like, or when they are but brui≈øed with riding in hard way, the Hor≈øe pre≈øently bemoans him≈øelf, as was more at large ≈øhewed before in the twelfth Chapter of this Book.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of a Cartilage or Gri≈øtle.

argument.p: A Gri≈øtle what. Their u≈øes.

div.p: AS an Appendix to the hi≈øtory or doctrine of the Bones, it will not be unnece≈ø≈øary to ≈øpeak ≈øomewhat of the Cartilages or Gri≈øtles: e≈øpecially ≈øeeing through the whole di≈øcour≈øe of this Fifth Book we have had occa≈øion ever and anon to mention them, but have not as yet given any particular account of them; as neither of a Ligament, which we have al≈øo often mentioned: but of this latter in the next Chapter, and onely of the Gri≈øtles in this, becau≈øe they come neare≈øt to the nature of Bones.

A Cartilage is a ≈øimilar part, cold and dry, made (as ≈øome Authours affirm) out of the mo≈øt glutinous part of the Seed. They are ≈ølexible and without ≈øen≈øe, and are much ≈øofter than a Bone, though the nature of the one is not ≈øo much di≈øtant from the other, but that ≈øeveral Gri≈øtles in tract of time, and as the Creatures grow old, harden into Bones.

The u≈øes of the Gri≈øtles are many. For fir≈øt they help the motion of the Bones at their jointings one with another. For which end in the Joints that are ≈øubject to great motions, the edges of the Sinus, or Cups and Cavities of the Bones that articulate one with another, are generally lined with a Gri≈øtle, to make the motion more glib and ≈øecure; ≈øuch are the articulation of the Shoulder-bone with the Shoulder-blade, of the Thigh-bone with the Hip-bone, and ≈øeveral others.

A ≈øecond u≈øe of the Gri≈øtles is by yielding, a little to give way to the violence of outward injuries; whereas if Bones had been in their places, they would have been in danger of breaking, from their hardne≈øs and ≈øtiffne≈øs: for which end the ends of many Bones which are expo≈øed to external injuries are furni≈øhed with Gri≈øtles, as the No≈øe and Ears, and the like.
Another u≈øe of the Gri≈øtles is, that by their mediation, as it were by a glue, ≈øome Bones might be conjoined; as the Share-bones in particular are by this means united to one another.

There are many other peculiar u≈øes of particular Gri≈øtles, ≈øome belonging to the Sight, ≈øome to the Hearing, ≈øome to Smelling, ≈øome to Re≈øpiration or breathing, and the like; all which have their ≈øeveral denominations:
But of the≈øe we have already treated as they fell in our way, when we di≈øcour≈øed of the parts to which each did belong. I ≈øhall not therefore need to inlarge any further upon them in this place.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of a Ligament.

argument.p: A Ligament what. Their differences. Their u≈øes.

div.p: AS the lubricity or ≈ølipperine≈øs of Gri≈øtles makes the motion of the Bones more ea≈øie and glib; ≈øo the Ligaments do ≈øecure that motion by ≈øtrengthning the articulation of one Bone with another.

A Ligament is a ≈øimilar part, cold and dry, of a middle nature betwixt a Gri≈øtle and a Membrane; harder than Membranes, le≈øt in vehement motions they ≈øhould be broken; and ≈øofter than Gri≈øtles, that they might the more ea≈øily follow and obey the Mu≈øcles which move the Bones. Tho≈øe that tie one Bone to another are generally in≈øen≈øible, as well becau≈øe they receive no Nerves into them, as al≈øo le≈øt being perpetually moved they ≈øhould breed perpetual pain. But ≈øuch as tie other parts, as the Ligaments of the Liver, of the Womb, the bridle of the Tongue, &c. the≈øe are endued with ≈øen≈øe.

The differences of Ligaments are many, being taken fir≈øt from their ≈øub≈øtance, whence ≈øome are ≈øaid to be hard, others ≈øoft, the former of which are called cartilaginous, and the latter membranous Ligaments. The epithet of membranous is likewi≈øe given to ≈øome from their breadth, in oppo≈øition whereto others are called nervous, becau≈øe they are round like Nerves.

They are al≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhed from their original and in≈øertion; for ≈øome ari≈øe from Bones, ≈øome from Gri≈øtles, and ≈øome from Membranes; and are accordingly diver≈øly in≈øerted. And la≈øtly they are differenced from their ≈øtrength and figure. To give particular in≈øtances of all which, would be a needle≈øs curio≈øity: I ≈øhall therefore break off when I have added a word of their u≈øe.

The u≈øes of the Ligaments, as well as Gri≈øtles, are many: for fir≈øt they confirm and ≈øtrengthen the articulations of the Bones: they al≈øo bind and fa≈øten the Bones to one another where there is no true articulation. Thirdly, they ≈øerve as an outward garment to the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles, many of which are throughout their whole length covered with Ligaments and Membranes. Fourthly, they interpo≈øe like a Pillow betwixt the Bones and the Tendons of the Mu≈øcles. Fifthly and la≈øtly, ≈øome of them do ≈øerve to ≈øu≈øpend the Bowels, that they ≈øhould not fall with their great weight, ≈øuch are the Ligaments of the Liver, &c.

div.head: THE APPENDIX, Containing Two DISCOURSES: The one, of the GENERATION OF ANIMALS: And the other, of the MOTION of the CHYLE, And the CIRCULATION of the BLOUD.
SECTION I. Of the Generation of ANIMALS.
The PREFACE.
div.p: IN the Introduction to the foregoing Anatomical Treati≈øe I premi≈øed, that my inducement to compile and publi≈øh it was to in≈øtruct tho≈øe of my own Profe≈ø≈øion in the frame and u≈øe of the Parts of that Creature which is the Subject of our Art. And becau≈øe mo≈øt Farriers are Per≈øons of ≈ømall literature, I promi≈øed and intended to write the Di≈øcour≈øe in ≈øuch plain and familiar phra≈øe as they might be capable of apprehending, that they might reap that benefit from it which was de≈øigned them. (And I have as much as I could endeavoured to ≈øerve that fir≈øt intention.) But upon publi≈øhing my Propo≈øals for printing this Book, finding that it would not be unacceptable to Per≈øons of the be≈øt rank, as well of the Nobility as Gentry, I thought it advi≈øeable not to pen it in too paltry and homely a ≈øtyle, le≈øt it might be nau≈øeous and unplea≈øant to ≈øuch worthy Per≈øons as by their Sub≈øcriptions were plea≈øed to give me encouragement to go on with the Work. So that I hope in the peru≈øal of it, it will both be delightfull to the≈øe latter ≈øort of Readers, and yet in≈øtruct and benefit the former, for whom onely (as I ≈øaid) it was at fir≈øt intended.

But now as to the following Di≈øcour≈øe which was al≈øo mentioned in the Propo≈øals, I found that not onely the Men of my own Profe≈ø≈øion made ≈ømall reckoning of it; but I was cen≈øured by ≈øome of note, for pretending to treat of things above my capacity. I mu≈øt confe≈øs I was a little aba≈øhed and di≈øcountenanc'd at this Cen≈øure, as having but a ≈ømall ≈øhare of that confidence whereby ≈øo many recommend them≈øelves to the World: in≈øomuch as growing jealous of my own ability, I took advice upon it. And it was my good fortune to meet with a Per≈øon, that upon my imparting my thoughts to him, encouraged me to go forward, promi≈øing, if I needed any, to lend me ≈øome a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. And I mu≈øt acknowledge that the Reader (and my
≈øelf) are very much owing to his kindne≈øs for the beginning of this Treati≈øe; and partly al≈øo for the compo≈øure of the Remainder; (though the Ob≈øervations, which are the ground of the Di≈øcour≈øe, be wholly mine own:) for I dur≈øt not tru≈øt my Pen alone in what I perceived would be ≈øcan'd with ≈øome ≈øeverity. He that doth not under≈øtand it, may believe it was not writ for his u≈øe; and he that doth, is de≈øired to accept it in good part.
And now to give ≈øome more particular account of it:

It will not be expected that an Appendix or Supplement ≈øhould contain an Hi≈øtory of the Generation of all Animals; for that would require ≈øeveral Volumes: but it will ≈øuffice to de≈øcribe the Generation of one Oviparous and another Viviparous Creature (the Young of one being formed without, and the other within the Body) to which all others what≈øoever may be reduced.

By Animal I under≈øtand every thing that hath ≈øen≈øe and motion. Concerning which it will not fall in my way to di≈øcour≈øe of their ≈øeveral natures or actions, tho≈øe con≈øiderations lying before him that would treat of Animals already perfectly generated and matured: but my province will be to ≈øhew (1) from what original matter, and (2) by what efficient cau≈øe Animals are generated, and (3) in what order and by what degrees their Parts are fir≈øt delineated, and at la≈øt come to be perfected.

1. The original matter of Animals. Fir≈øt then as to their original matter, I affirm univer≈øally of all Animals, that it is an Egg, either formally, or ≈øomething analogous thereto, and which upon many accounts may not improperly have that appellation given it: Yea this term may be applied not onely to Animals, but to the Seeds of Plants or Herbs, and Kernels of the Fruit of Trees al≈øo. And indeed ≈øeeing the Young of every Animal in their ≈øeveral ≈øpecies arrives to a con≈øiderable bulk before it hath any Animal life, during which time it encrea≈øes and grows merely as a Vegetable; there is no ≈øuch great difference in the fir≈øt principles and manner of growth of Vegetables and Animals as is commonly conceived. And therefore to ≈øatisfy the Curious, and to lay the lower and firmer foundation for my de≈øign, I ≈øhall in the fir≈øt place premi≈øe the manner of procedure in the vegetation of Seeds from the micro≈øcopical ob≈øervations of Malpighius in his ≈øecond Part of the Anatomy of Plants.

Now that both Vegetables and Animals ≈øhould proceed from Eggs, will ≈øeem no very ≈øtrange notion to him that hath read the Saying of ≈øome old Philo≈øophers, Ex Ovo omnia, that all things are from an Egg: though I mu≈øt confe≈øs that it is not nece≈ø≈øarily to be under≈øtood in my ≈øen≈øe, but po≈ø≈øibly means no more than that the fir≈øt formation of all things was from an Egg, according to the opinion delivered by Ari≈øtophanes in his Aves, p. 573. (quoted by Doctour Cudworth in his True Intellectual Sy≈øteme of the Univer≈øe, p. 121.) namely that at fir≈øt there was nothing but Night and Chaos, which laying an Egg, from thence was produced Love, and that mingling again with Chaos begot Heaven and Earth, and Animals, and all the Gods. Who≈øe Greek Ver≈øes to this purpo≈øe are thus tran≈ølated by the afore≈øaid Learned Doctour.

q.l: Fir≈øt all was Chaos, one confu≈øed heap,
In a mixt croud the jumbled Elements were,
Nor Earth, nor Air, nor Heaven did appear;
Till on this horrid va≈øt Aby≈øs of things
Teeming Night, ≈øpreading o'er her cole-black wings,
Laid the fir≈øt Egg; whence after Time's due cour≈øe
Gli≈øtring with golden Wings, which flutt'ring o'er
Dark Chaos, gendred all the numerous ≈øtore

div.p:
I know that the term Egg is not alike properly applicable to the fir≈øt ≈øeed or principle out of which every thing is formed; but for di≈øtinction ≈øake it may ≈øeem more proper and intelligible to call ≈øuch principle by ≈øeveral names; as in Humane kind and Quadrupeds to call it a conception; in Fi≈øhes to name them Roes (though in Latin they have no other name but Ova, Eggs;) in Frogs, the Spawn; in In≈øects, as Butterflies, &c. Worms (according to Ari≈øtotle;) as likewi≈øe in Plants to term them Seeds; in the fruits of Trees, Kernels. I ≈øay it may ≈øeem more proper to retain this vulgar way of ≈øpeaking, and rather u≈øe the≈øe ≈øundry appellations, than to confound them all under one general one: I will not therefore contend about words, but ≈øhall readily permit every man to u≈øe his own phra≈øe; onely I contend for the thing, hoping to make it
appear that there is ≈øo great an analogy or likene≈øs in Nature among≈øt all the≈øe, that nothing (but the common way of ≈øpeaking) hinders, why they might not all be included under one denomination.

If any think I begin too far off my ≈øcope, to treat of the vegetation of Plants, when my de≈øign is to explain the generation of Animals; be≈øides what Apology the thing it ≈øelf will make for me with every Intelligent Reader, Mo≈øes's Hi≈øtory of the Creation ≈øeems to authori≈øe ≈øuch a method, and to chalk out my way for me. We find the Almighty proceeding every day from the more imperfect and ignoble Creatures to the more perfect and noble: Whence on the third day he commands the Earth to bring forth Gra≈øs, the Herb yielding Seed, and the Fruit-tree yielding Fruit after his kind, who≈øe Seed is in it ≈øelf, upon the Earth. On the fifth day he commands the Waters to bring forth abundantly the moving Creature that hath life, and Fowl that may flie above the Earth in the open Firmament of Heaven. And la≈øtly on the ≈øixth day he bids the Earth bring forth the Living Creature after his kind, Cattel and creeping thing, and Bea≈øt of the Earth after his kind: and on the ≈øame day he created Man in his own image to have dominion over the Fi≈øh of the Sea, and over the Fowl of the Air, and over the Cattel, &c. Whether God ob≈øerved ≈øuch a ≈øucce≈ø≈øive order of time in the Creation, as the holy Text de≈øcribes, or whether the Hi≈øtory be onely ≈øo delivered for our better apprehen≈øion, is too deep and bold a ≈øpeculation for me to meddle with: but it is plain that it literally accords with the nature of the things created; ≈øeeing the progre≈øs is natural from Vegetation to Animality, and from thence to Rationality. For thus a Man is for ≈øome months onely a ≈øort of Vegetable, capable of increa≈øe of Parts, but without ≈øen≈øe or motion, which afterwards he comes to be indowed with, but without any exerci≈øe of Rea≈øon till ≈øome time after his birth. But this la≈øt con≈øideration is beyond my purpo≈øe, and onely mentioned to ≈øhew, that the ≈øame method Mo≈øes ob≈øerves in the Hi≈øtory of the Creation, is natural enough to follow in an Hi≈øtory of Generation.

2. The efficient Cau≈øe of Generation. As to the efficient Cau≈øe of Generation, that is the geniture of the Male. I ≈øpeak of proper generation, and of ≈øuch Animals who≈øe ≈øpecies con≈øi≈øts of Males and Females. For there is a generation called equivocal, ≈øuch as that is ≈øaid to be of
Frogs generated out of the Mud of the River Nile by the heat of the Sun: and there are ≈øome Animals who≈øe whole Species are Hermaphrodites as it were, partaking of both Sexes, and generating within and of them≈øelves, even as Plants do. Of the≈øe I mu≈øt not be under≈øtood, but of ≈øuch who≈øe generation is performed by a copulation of Male and Female.

3. The order of the formation of the Parts. La≈øty, as to the method and order of the formation and increa≈øe of the Parts of the Animal, till it come to be a perfect one of its kind, it would be prepo≈øterous to enter upon the treating of them in this place; I ≈øhall therefore refer the Reader to the following Di≈øcour≈øe, to which I now addre≈øs my ≈øelf.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Vegetation of Seeds, particularly of a Wheat-corn.
div.p: THE conception of an Animal and the fir≈øt formation and encrea≈øe of an Embryo in the Womb, corre≈øponds very much (as we have already hinted) to the Seed of a Plant and its vegetation in the Bo≈øom of the great and common Mother, the Earth. Wherefore the ob≈øerving in what manner a Seed proceeds to a Plant being obvious to every Man; to give an account of ≈øuch ob≈øervation may much conduce to the better apprehending by what degrees a Conception grows to a perfect Foetus. But the parts of a Seed being ≈øo minute, that the naked Eye can make no perfect di≈øcovery of the fir≈øt rudiments of the Plant that is formed out of it, it is nece≈ø≈øary to make u≈øe of a Micro≈øcope to greaten the Objects, which the mo≈øt curious Malpighius hath done with that accuracy as to render further inquiry and examination needle≈øs. I ≈øhall therefore give you an account of his ob≈øervations of this kind in as few words and as plain as I can.

The manner of vegetation in Seeds. The Eggs (or Seeds) of Plants being excluded out of the Mother's Egg-bed (called a Pod, or Husk, or by whatever other name di≈øtingui≈øhed) requiring further fo≈øtering and brooding, are committed to the Earth by the officious Winds, or by the indu≈øtry of Men. This kind Mother having received them into her Bo≈øom, doth not onely give them incubation or brooding by her own halituous vapours joined with the heat of the Sun-beams; but doth by degrees abundantly ≈øupply what the fruitfull Seeds ≈øtand in need of. For ≈øhe every-where abounds with little chanels or ≈øinuous pa≈ø≈øages, in which the Rain-water ≈øatiated and impregnated with fruitfull Salts does run like the Bloud and Chyle in the Arteries of Animals; which moi≈øture is tran≈øcolated or ≈øtrained through the Pores or Pipes of the outer rind or husk (corre≈øponding to the Membranes that inve≈øt the Embryo's of Animals) on the in≈øide of which lie the thick ≈øeminal Leaves, which are commonly two, (though in that which we ≈øhall in≈øtance in by and by, it is but one) that an≈øwer to the Placenta or Womb-cake in Women, or to the Cotyledons in Brutes. For the ≈øub≈øtance of the≈øe two Seed-leaves con≈øi≈øts of a great number of little bladders or bottles, and of Navel-ve≈ø≈øels, or a Navel-knot. Into the bottles is received the fruitfull moi≈øture of the Earth that is ≈øtrained through the rind of the Seed, which makes a ≈ømall fermentation with that proper juice that was inherent originally in the Seed-leaves; and this fermented Liquor is conveyed by the umbilical Ve≈ø≈øel to the Trunk of the Plant, and to the Gemm or Bud that is continued to it; whereupon a vegetation and increa≈øe of the Parts ≈øucceed.

This, in ≈øhort, is the manner of procedure in the vegetation of Plants; how far it agrees with the fir≈øt formation and encrea≈øe of the Embryo's of
Animals, will be made more plain by and by. In the mean time, that what I have here ab≈øtracted out of the above-mentioned mo≈øt ingenious Authour, may be the better under≈øtood, I have thought good further to tran≈øcribe out of him an in≈øtance or example of this procedure, and to exhibit the ≈øame al≈øo in a curious Figure to the Eye of the Reader that cannot ≈øo well conceive of it by the bare verbal de≈øcription. My in≈øtance ≈øhall be in a grain of Wheat.

q.p: The fir≈øt day after it is ≈øown, it grows a little turgid, and the ≈øecundine or husk gapes a little in ≈øeveral places. The body of the Plant A being continuous with the conglobated Leaf, (which is called the fle≈øh of the Seed that makes the flowr) ≈øwells not onely with the Gemm or Sprout, that is, with the future Stem B, which is opened and waxeth green by degrees; but al≈øo the lateral Roots CC do bunch out a little; and likewi≈øe the lower Root D becoming green jets ≈øomewhat out; whence the Placenta or Seed-leaf E becomes loo≈øe and gapes. The body of the Plant is continued and knit, by the Navel-knot F, to the conglobated Flowr-leaf, which ≈øupplies matter for vegetation.

In two daies the Secundine or Husk G being broken through, the Stem, or top of the future Straw H appears on the out≈øide of it, and with its top is a little di≈øtant from the Leaf (that is continued to it) growing upward by degrees. The Seed-leaf I guarding the Roots, becomes turgid with the little bladders, and puts forth a white down; this Leaf being pulled away, you may ≈øee the Roots of the Plant made bare, of which the long one K is very apparent, but the two others LL are more ob≈øcure. The top of the Stem H is crooked; and within, the Gemm or Bud and future Leaves and Stalk lie hid. Between the Roots and a≈øcending Stem, the trunk of the Plant is knit by the Navelknot M to the Flowr-leaf which is very moi≈øt, but as yet keeps its white colour, and its proper and natural ta≈øte.

The third day approaching, the pulp of the conglobated or round Leaf becomes turgid with the juice that it has received from the Earth fermenting with its own genuine juice. The Plant encrea≈øes in bigne≈øs; and its Bud, or Stem N becoming taller, from whiti≈øh turns ≈øomewhat green; and the lateral Roots OO break forth greeni≈øh and pyramidal from the gaping Sheath P, which adheres clo≈øely to the Plant. The lower Root Q becomes longer and hairy, having many Fibres growing out of it. At the ≈øame time, in ≈øuch Seeds as are more quick and forward, the lower Root R is larger, growing green in its end, and the Side-roots ≈øprout out of the Sheath S that inve≈øted them: which Sheath ≈øwelling with white and thick bladders, is continued, like a bark, with the outer and inve≈øting ≈øub≈øtance. Abundance of hairy Fibres hang all along upon the Roots, except upon their tip: tho≈øe which grow about their ba≈øis are longer, and tho≈øe which follow, become ≈øhorter and ≈øhorter. They twirle about the ≈øaline Particles, and little lumps of Earth, like Ivy, whence they grow curled. The Placenta T fades by degrees, and above the lateral Roots SS there break out two other little ones UU. The Stem X being roundi≈øh and waxed bigger grows ≈øtreight upwards.

Towards the end of the third day, the Stem Y tending upwards, makes as it were a right angle with the ≈øeminal Leaf Z lying horizontally: it is ≈ølenderer and more longi≈øh; and its outer cover is white, and bright or tran≈øparent, guarding the tender and greeni≈øh Gem. The
la≈øt Roots a jet out more; and the other three growing larger are cloathed with a down, that ≈øtraitly embraces the lumps of Earth: this down is ≈øo luxuriant, e≈øpecially where it meets with any vacuity, that its hairs uniting with one another make a kind of net. The conglobated or Flowr-leaf Z is ≈øofter, and milky as it were; whence if one brui≈øe it, it yields a white and ≈øweeti≈øh juice like Barly-cream: if one pull the Plant from it, the Roots and Stem of the Plant are plain to be ≈øeen: al≈øo the intermediate Navel-knot b appears, who≈øe outer and inve≈øting part is more ≈øolid like bark; but the inner part is more ≈øoft and marrowy.

At the end of the fourth day, the Stalk tending upwards, (the outer or Sheath-leaf c being loo≈øened) puts forth the Stable-leaf d that is green and folded. Below, the afore-de≈øcribed Roots grow longer; and there appears a new tumour (≈øometimes two,) of a future Root e. The Seedleaf f al≈øo that hangs upon the Plant begins to fade, who≈øe remaining juice notwith≈øtanding is as yet white and uncorrupted. If one cut the Stem in≈øunder, the ri≈øe of the tender Stalk g appears to be from the Navel-knot, from which al≈øo the Roots take their beginning: outwardly likewi≈øe the Sheath-leaf c is to be ≈øeen, wherein the Stalk, and its Leaves, and the ri≈øe of the Roots are infolded.

About the ≈øixth day, the Stable-leaf h being loo≈øened, the Plant mounts upward, the thick Sheath-leaf i as yet cleaving about it like a bark. The Seed-leaf k on its out≈øide is ≈øinuous or full of crinkles, and faded: this being cut and freed from the husk or ≈øecundine, the Fle≈øh or Pericarpium is not alike all over; for its outer part, whereby the out≈øide of the Seed or Grain is heaved up, is more ≈øolid, and looks like a concave Leaf: it hath the ≈øame appearance al≈øo in that part whereby it ≈øticks and is continued to the Navel-knot: but its in≈øide is fi≈øtulous and fill'd with humour, e≈øpecially that part of it that is next to the Navel-knot. The Leaves being pull'd off, the Roots torn, and the Flowrleaf removed, the trunk appears, in which, not far from the Roots, the Navel-knot l bunches out, which is ≈øolid, and hard to cut: above, there is the mark of the Sheath-leaf i that was pull'd off: under this, as in an Arm-pit, the Gemm m is often hid; beyond which there is likewi≈øe a knot, with the skar of the torn off Leaf n, and in the top the ≈øoft Gem o is kept; and thus the whole bulk of the future Stalk is had in this compendium. The hinder-part al≈øo of the Plant ≈øhews the breakings forth of the Roots; likewi≈øe the faded Placenta or Seedleaf p, and the skar of the Sheath-leaf i, with the following Knots and Gemm o.

After the eleventh day, the Seed-leaf q often as yet ≈øticking to the Plant, is crumpled and almo≈øt corrupted; for being opened, it yields an humour with airy bubbles: within, it is hollow, and about the ≈øecundines the mucous and white ≈øub≈øtance of the Seed, being continued even to the Navel-knot, formes a cavity. All the Roots becoming longer put forth new Branches out of their ≈øides; and the Stalk, though it have taller Leaves, yet for the mo≈øt part it is no longer than the trunk above delineated: for as yet the knots and gems being very near to one another, are not far from the Navel-knot. Sometimes, the vegetation making progre≈øs, the ≈øpaces betwixt the knots are larger; and the Sheath-leaf r being pull'd off the ≈øide, a Knot ≈ø appears, out of which there ≈øprouts forth a Leaf t that fo≈øters the a≈øcending Stem. In the mean
time the ≈øeminal Leaf withers, and is emptied on its in≈øide; and if one pre≈øs it, it yields nought but Water. The white and ≈øolid internode (or ≈øpace between the Knots) is lengthned, and new Gemms appear; and the middle Root grows to be ≈øeveral inches long.

After a month, both the Roots and Stalk being grown longer, new Buds uu appear to be breaking forth of the fir≈øt Knot, and very little Tumours xx bunch out, which at length break forth into Roots: for Roots ≈øprout out ≈øo ea≈øily, that ≈øometimes if one pull off the fir≈øt Roots, there will abundance of new ones ari≈øe in their ≈øtead. Likewi≈øe at the ≈øame time, the Stem being e≈øtabli≈øhed with its u≈øual Roots, puts forth new ones yy which break through even the Sheath-leaf that cloaths it: and it al≈øo ri≈øes up with a white joint that is full within. Above the Roots from the ≈øame Knot grow two Buds zz, guarded with their proper Leaves; and the intermediate Stalk runs upwards.

div.p: This Hi≈øtory it was thought good to tran≈ølate at its full length, (though there are ≈øome particulars that may ≈øeem beyond our purpo≈øe, and which are not mentioned in the general de≈øcription of Vegetation that was premi≈øed) le≈øt we ≈øhould be injurious to the mo≈øt ingenious Authour by concealing any of his di≈øcoveries. But pa≈ø≈øing by them, it will appear plainly by the following di≈øcour≈øe, how little the formation of an Embryo and fir≈øt encrea≈øe of its Parts, differs from the fir≈øt ≈øpringing of a Vegetable; and then the Reader will further ≈øe√© how natural and rea≈øonable it was to begin with the de≈øcription of this latter, the better to explain the former.
