div.head: CHAP. II. Of the fir≈øt rudiment of an Egg, and what way it pa≈ø≈øes to the Uterus; al≈øo how it attains to its great bulk, and how it becomes fruitfull.
div.p: What the difference is between Oviparous and Viviparous Creatures. ANIMALS are commonly, di≈øtingui≈øhed into Oviparous and Viviparous; by which we are not to under≈øtand any ≈øpecifical difference in the fir≈øt principle or original matter of one and another, as if Oviparous Animals propagated their Species by Eggs, and Viviparous theirs by a mixture of the Male and Female's Seed in the Womb, out of which a Conception ≈øhould be formed; as many Philo≈øophers have taught: but no more ought to be meant by it, than that ≈øome Animals exclude their Eggs out of their Body, which are afterwards hatched either by incubation or brooding, (as in Fowls;) or by the bare warmth of the Sun, (as in In≈øects;) or by ≈øome other means; whereas others retain their Eggs within their Bodies, which are hatched (as it were) in their ∆≤terus or its Cornua, and when an Animal of their re≈øpective Species is formed out of any one, it is afterwards excluded. Which truth, that it may the better be entertained by the prejudic'd Vulgar, I will fir≈øt ≈øhew the procedure in the generation of Oviparous Animals, and afterwards examine what analogy thereto there is in Viviparous, and in both of the≈øe to Vegetables, as to the Embryo or fir≈øt lineaments of the Foetus, both as to formation and nutrition.

Being then in the fir≈øt place to deliver the Hi≈øtory of the generation of Oviparous Creatures, I ≈øhall wave ≈øuch as exclude Eggs that are le≈øs perfect, as In≈øects, Reptiles, and Aquatiles, (which la≈øt we have no opportunity to examine) and pitch upon Fowl who≈øe Eggs are mo≈øt perfect; and out of them ≈øhall chu≈øe an Hen, which is mo≈øt familiar and ready at hand for making ob≈øervations upon. And that I may omit nothing that will illu≈øtrate the ≈øimilitude, it will be convenient to begin with inquiring, fir≈øt, into the fir≈øt principle, or rudiment of an Egg; then, ≈øecondly, ≈øee by what way it pa≈ø≈øeth to the ∆≤terus; thirdly, how it attains to that great bulk it hath when excluded; fourthly, how it becomes fruitfull; and fifthly and la≈øtly, by what degrees a Chicken is formed out of it, exhibiting in Figures taken from the life, of what ≈øhape it appears each day from that time any of its Parts are ≈øo di≈øcernible as to be delineated, till it is become ≈øo perfect, that one cannot take a view of or examine its inward parts without di≈ø≈øection. The fir≈øt four heads of inquiry I ≈øhall di≈øpatch in this Chapter, leaving the la≈øt of them (which is the main one for our purpo≈øe) to the next.

1. The fir≈øt rudiment of an Egg. The fir≈øt thing to be examined is the Ovary or Egg-bed, where the fir≈øt rudiment of the Egg appears. And here it would be too far from our purpo≈øe to ≈øhew the differences of the Ovary of an Hen from that of ≈øome other Fowl, much more of Fi≈øhes, Serpents, &c. ≈øeeing tho≈øe differences con≈øi≈øt onely in le≈ø≈øer circum≈øtances, which concern not our ≈øcope: for in this they all agree that they have an Ovary, and that the fir≈øt principles of the Eggs are to be found therein.

The Ovary. This Ovary in an Hen is ≈øeated at the Back-bone upon the great Artery and Vein de≈øcending, a little lower than the Liver, at the ≈øame place where the Cock's Stones lie, which is about the place where in Viviparous Animals the preparing Ve≈ø≈øels that go to the Te≈øticles ari≈øe. In this the Eggs appear fir≈øt of a white colour, being as ≈ømall almo≈øt as Sea≈øand. But after they are grown a little bigger, viz. about as big as Hail-≈øhot they turn yellow, and are truly onely the Yelks of the Eggs that ≈øhall be, which afterwards acquire Whites, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew by and by. Each of the≈øe Yelks is inve≈øted with a proper Coat, and be≈øides, borrows another from the Ovary, by which they are ≈øeverally knit to its foundation, or root, that is, to that part of it that ≈øticks to the de≈øcending Trunks of the great Artery and Vein; ≈øo that hereby they are ≈øu≈øtained in their place, even as the Te≈øticles in Men are clad and ≈øu≈øpended by their vaginal Coat that is borrowed from the Rim of the Belly (or Peritonaeum.) Tho≈øe of the Yelks that are outmo≈øt are large≈øt, tho≈øe in the middle le≈øs, but tho≈øe the neare≈øt the foundation, lea≈øt of all.

2. Which way the Egg pa≈ø≈øes from the Ovary to the Uterus. Secondly, Adjoining unto and embracing the Ovary is the Infundibulum or Tunnel, which con≈øi≈øts of a very thin and yielding Membrane. With it Orifice it encompa≈ø≈øes the Ovary, and de≈øcending lengthways of the Back is continued unto the upper and narrower part of the ∆≤terus, by Doctour Harvey called the Proce≈øs of the Womb. As the Yelks of the Ovary come to maturity, they drop off it one after another, and fall immediately into the mouth of the Tunnel, in which they make no ≈øtay, but are conveyed by it quickly into the Proce≈øs of the ∆≤terus. This Proce≈øs hath many folds or cells, like as the Gut Colon has in mo≈øt Creatures, which contribute not onely to the longer ≈øtay of the Egg in it, but make it more convenient for the collection of that whiti≈øh clammy humour that ≈øo plentifully bedews it, out of which the Yelks gather their White. For

3. How it is encrea≈øed. Thirdly, Though the Yelks while they remain in the Ovary are nouri≈øhed and encrea≈øed by the Arterial bloud as all other Parts of the Body are; yet as ≈øoon as they are dropt off from thence, they never adhere afterwards or grow to any Part whereby any Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels ≈øhould be in≈øerted into them: but as they make no ≈øtay in the Tunnel, ≈øo do they not adhere to the ≈øides either of the ∆≤terus (≈øpecially ≈øo called) or of its Proce≈øs. But there being great ≈øtore of Arteries di≈øper≈øed through them both, the≈øe ≈øpew as it were out of their ≈ømall mouths (that open into the Cavity of the ∆≤terus and its Proce≈øs) a great quantity of a whiti≈øh chylous liquor, which the Yelks by an innate vegetative principle attract and a≈ø≈øimilate to them≈øelves, and which con≈øtitutes their White. Now ≈øeeing (as we noted above) that the Yelks as they come from the Ovary, have two Coats, one proper, and another borrowed; I am of an opinion that the White is collected betwixt the≈øe two; namely, that the uterine humour tran≈øudes through or is imbibed by the borrowed Coat, but is ≈øtopped from proceeding further towards the centre of the Egg by the proper Coat which is more den≈øe and clo≈øe. For the foundation of the Ovary from whence this outer Coat is borrowed, is of a loo≈øe ≈øpongy ≈øub≈øtance, whence 'tis probable the Coat is ≈øo likewi≈øe. Onely 'tis likely that ≈øome particles of this humour penetrate through the inner Coat al≈øo, by which the Yelk receives increa≈øe, and al≈øo ≈øome alteration in ≈øub≈øtance from what it was of, while it remained in the Ovary. Though I think this opinion is new, yet I am the bolder to profe≈øs it, not onely becau≈øe
it cannot well be conceived how a new Coat ≈øhould be acquired in the ∆≤terus, ≈øeeing the Egg adheres to no part from which it ≈øhould receive it; but much more from the Analogy there ≈øeems to be between the nutrition of an Egg (in Hens) and that of a Conception (in Viviparous Animals.) Now every Body knows that a Conception when it is never ≈øo ≈ømall, is clad with two Coats, the Chorion and Amnios, and that the Albugineous liquor of the Womb tran≈øudes through them both for the nouri≈øhment of the Embryo contained in the Amnios. I ≈øay it pa≈ø≈øes through both the Membranes of a Conception, becau≈øe it was nece≈ø≈øary it ≈øhould arrive at the Embryo which it nouri≈øheth; but ≈øeeing the Yelk is ≈øo far from re≈øembling the Embryo, that no Part of the Chicken is formed out of it, (for it onely ≈øerves for a gro≈ø≈øer ≈øort of nouri≈øhment for it) the like liquor in an Hen pa≈ø≈øeth onely through the outer Coat which an≈øwers to the Chorion, betwixt which and the inner it is collected for the u≈øe of the future Foetus. But if we will ≈øuppo≈øe with Doctour Harvey, that there are two Whites, the inner of a thicker con≈øi≈øtence, and the outer of a thinner, and that the≈øe are included each in a particular Membrane; then as the≈øe Membranes an≈øwer exactly to the Chorion and Amnios, ≈øo mu≈øt we ≈øuppo≈øe that the Coat that was borrowed from the Ovary, was originally double, and now onely begins to appear ≈øo. (But enough of this.) The Egg then beginning to encrea≈øe in bulk on this manner at fir≈øt in the Proce≈øs of the ∆≤terus, doth by degrees de≈øcend down into the ∆≤terus it ≈øelf, wherein it grows to its full proportion.

The Uterus de≈øcribed. Now the ∆≤terus is of a carnous ≈øub≈øtance, but ≈øuch as may be ea≈øily ≈øtretched lengthways or breadthways, and except when it is di≈øtended with a perfect Egg, is very full of wrinkles and folds, as we de≈øcribed its Proce≈øs (above) to be. When the Egg hath arrived at its ju≈øt bigne≈øs, ≈øo that it can no longer be contained in the ∆≤terus, it begins to acquire a Shell, which according to Doctour Harvey is hard while the Egg is yet in the ∆≤terus; though according to Ari≈øtotle and Aquapendent the Shell owes its original to that vi≈øcous and clammy humour that bedews the ≈øurface of the Egg when it is lay'd, the watery part whereof evaporating, the remainder pre≈øently hardens into a Shell. But any Country Hou≈øewife may decide this controver≈øie as well as the≈øe great Philo≈øophers, who by feeling with their Finger whether the Hen be with ≈øoft or hard Egg (as they u≈øe to phra≈øe it) know whether ≈øhe will lay that day or no: for if ≈øhe do, the Egg feels, comparatively, hard, though not quite ≈øo hard as after it is lay'd.

4. How an Egg becomes fruitfull. Fourthly, If one compare an Egg lay'd by an Hen that hath never been trod by a Cock, one ≈øhall not find it differ in any one re≈øpect (≈øo far as the Eye can judge) from another that is lay'd by one that has u≈øed to be trod every day; ≈øo that it ≈øeems difficult to give a rea≈øon why the one ≈øhould be fruitfull, and the other not. I think it is peculiar to a tame Hen (of which we are ≈øpeaking) to lay as well without a Cock as with him: in whom therefore the treading is no efficient cau≈øe of the Egg, but onely of making it fruitfull.

Now it is very con≈øiderable what Doctour Harvey and others have ob≈øerved, that one treading is ≈øufficient to fertilize a whole knot of Eggs, be they twenty or a greater number; which be≈øides what we ≈øhall ≈øay afterwards, may ≈øufficiently detect the vulgar opinion of Errour, viz. that tho≈øe ≈øpecks in the Yelk which we commonly call the treddle, are the Seed of the Cock; for how can he be imagined to ≈øpend ≈øo much at one
time as all the≈øe mu≈øt amount to? But to pa≈øs by that, it is certain that none of the Cock's Sperm can come to the Ovary; for if the Cock have any Penis at all (which Doctour Harvey denies) yet it is ≈øo ≈øhort that it cannot reach one quarter of the way between the outer Orifice and the Ovary: yea that part that is between the ∆≤terus and outward Orifice, which an≈øwers to the Vagina in Viviparous Animals, is ≈øo full of folds and wrinkles that one cannot pa≈øs any thing from without inwards, not ≈øo much as a Bri≈øtle; ≈øo that it is not ea≈øy to conceive how the Cock's Penis (if he have any) ≈øhould penetrate even ≈øo far as the ∆≤terus, which yet is two or three inches di≈øtant from the Ovary. But notwith≈øtanding the impo≈ø≈øibility of the Sperm's reaching the Ovary, and the improbability that it is injected ≈øo far as into the ∆≤terus; yet it is without all que≈øtion that the fruitfulne≈øs of the Eggs is wholly owing to ≈øome virtue derived from the Seed. Not that any of its gro≈ø≈øer ≈øub≈øtance doth con≈øtitute any part of the Egg; but ≈øome ≈øubtil effluvia or ≈øpirituous ≈øteams exhale from it into the ∆≤terus, which a≈øcend from thence by the Proce≈øs and Tunnel to the Ovary, fecundating the ≈øame. I ≈øay the rudiments of the Eggs are fertilized in the Ovary; for it is not probable that the ∆≤terus onely ≈øhould be impregnated thereby with a fecundating virtue or power, which it imparts to the Egg after its de≈øcent from the Ovary into it. For though in a tame Hen the Yelks ≈øeparate and fall off from the Ovary of their own accord, whether ≈øhe be trod or no: yet in other Fowls it is not ≈øo, in whom, naturally, the Hen lays no Eggs if ≈øhe be withheld from the Cock: and it is not to be imagined but that the Eggs of both are made fruitfull in the ≈øame place. Seeing then it is owing to the geniture of the Cock not onely that the Eggs of wild Fowl become fruitfull, but that they lay any at all; (and therefore the prolifick virtue of the geniture mu≈øt be exerted upon the Ovary from whence the Eggs i≈ø≈øue:) we may from hence conclude, that though a tame Hen (by a peculiar property) do lay without treading; yet as the≈øe Eggs are all of them addle, ≈øo tho≈øe that are hatchable into Chickens were fecundated before they were parted from the Ovary; for it would be ab≈øurd and unrea≈øonable to ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øo great a difference in the impregnating the Eggs of the ≈øame Species of Animals, as the contrary opinion intimates, viz. that one ≈øhould be made fruitfull in the Ovary, and the other in the ∆≤terus.
But thus much may ≈øuffice to have ≈øpoken of the origine, encrea≈øe and fruitfulne≈øs of an Egg; it remains to examine by what means and degrees a Chicken is formed out of it.

div.head: CHAP. III. By what means and degrees a Chicken is formed out of an Egg.
div.p: An Egg what. ARi≈øtotle in his Fir≈øt Book of the hi≈øtory of Animals, ≈øays, an Egg is that ex cujus parte fit principio Animal, quod generatur: ex altera alimentum ip≈øi generato, i. e. of one part whereof the Animal is generated, and of another, nouri≈øhed. It is both the ≈øeed and principle of the Young, and al≈øo the Womb wherein it is formed, fo≈øtered and nouri≈øhed. Out of one Egg is but one Chicken generated: for if at any time there be two, then are there really two Eggs included in one Shell, as we many times ≈øee two Kernels in one Nut-≈øhell.
Its Parts. Now that we may the better know out of what part of the Egg the Chicken is formed, and by which part nouri≈øhed, we are to give an account of all the parts of an Egg.

The fir≈øt and outmo≈øt is the Shell, which is as the Womb wherein the Chicken is hatched. The next is the White (or as Doctour Harvey will have it, two Whites, the outer being thinner, and the inner thicker) which an≈øwers to the nutritious Juice or Chyle in the Womb of Viviparous Animals, and from which the Chicken by its umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels receives its fir≈øt nouri≈øhment. And indeed it might as properly be called Chyle, as the Chyle whereby the Foetus in Viviparous Animals is nouri≈øhed, is called Albumen or an albugineous Liquor, deriving that name from the White of an Egg, which is ≈øo called in Latin: for their names may well be confounded, ≈øeeing they are not onely of the ≈øame u≈øe, but of the ≈øame nature al≈øo both as to colour and ta≈øte, and agree particularly in this, that both of them by the warmth of the Fire will congeal into a gelly.

The next part is the Yelk, in Latin called Vitellum, from vita, becau≈øe the Chicken lives by it. It is otherwi≈øe named Luteum (the Yelk or Yellow) from its colour. This part al≈øo ≈øerves for the nutrition of the Chicken, but is of a more terrene and gro≈øs nature than the White, and therefore comes to nouri≈øh it onely in the ≈øecond place, when the White is ≈øpent, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed farther by and by. Both the Yelk and the White are each inve≈øted with a Membrane; yea if there be two Whites, as Doctour Harvey affirms, then is the inner and thicker White divided by a proper Membrane from the outer and thinner. Which two Membranes of the White an≈øwer exactly to the Chorion and Amnios in Viviparous Animals, which contain the chylous or albugineous Liquor for the nouri≈øhment of the Foetus, as was hinted in the foregoing Chapter. In the Membrane that cloaths the Yelk, towards each end of the Egg is placed a ≈øpeck or little tran≈øparent knot, which are commonly called the Treddles, from an opinion that they are the Sperm of the Cock, and that the Chicken is formed out of them. But ≈øeeing there are two in each Egg (one towards each end) if the≈øe were the Seed or fir≈øt vegetative principle of the Chicken, then ≈øhould there be two formed out of every Egg. But Doctour Harvey does mo≈øt ingeniou≈øly call them the Poles of this
Microco≈øm, ≈øerving for no other purpo≈øe, than for the uniting of the Yelk to the White; for though they adhere to the Membrane that inve≈øts the Yelk, yet does the larger diameter or half of them jet out into the White. They are called in Latin Grandines, Hail-≈øtones, from their colour, as being of a more white and lucid ≈øub≈øtance than the White, and re≈øembling much both in ≈øhape and colour the ≈ømaller Hail-≈øtones when they have been a little wet.

Having enumerated all the≈øe parts of an Egg, and not ≈øuppo≈øing any of them to be that which is the fir≈øt principle of the Chicken, it may be wondred by ≈øome, what part is left to which we can a≈ø≈øign that dignity. The opinion of the often before-cited Doctour Harvey is clear and convincing as to this, viz. That it is neither of the Knots before-mentioned, but another white, round and ≈ømooth Speck (about as big as a Lentil) that likewi≈øe adheres to the Coat of the Yelk, about the middle ≈øpace betwixt the Treddles. And though it is very little, yet that can be no prejudice to the opinion, with him that con≈øiders, that the Conceptions (or Ova) of Viviparous Animals, even of the mo≈øt bulky, are no bigger than a Mu≈øquet-bullet, when they are ≈øeparated from the Te≈øticle or Ovary, which ≈øtate this white Circle or ≈øpeck is now conceived to be in, and of which I ≈øhall ≈øay no more, le≈øt I ≈øeem to impo≈øe upon the learned and ingenious Reader, whom I would rather advi≈øe to peru≈øe Doctour Harvey him≈øelf as to this opinion, than ≈øatisfy his curio≈øity with this ≈øhort Ab≈øtract of it. But partly for the ≈øake of tho≈øe that want Doctour Harvey's Book De generat. Animal. and partly that what follows may be the better under≈øtood, I thought it convenient to give a touch of it.

5. By what means and degrees a Chicken is formed out of it. Having then concluded upon the fir≈øt Seed or principle out of which the Chicken is formed, let us next con≈øider by what means and degrees it vegetates, and has an Animal generated out of it. We have ≈øhewn in the foregoing Chapter, that as to the examination by the Eye, there is nothing in a fruitfull Egg which is not in an addle one; yea even this white Circle or Speck la≈øt mentioned is equally found in both: and the rea≈øon why it is barren in one and fruitfull in another is its being or not being impregnated by the Cock's Sperm; ≈øuch Hens as are not trod laying always addle Eggs, but ≈øuch as are, for the mo≈øt part prolifick. (But of this enough before.)

The means is Incubation. Now the means of putting this generative (or more properly, I think, vegetative) principle into act, is the incubation or brooding of the Hen, which influences this Seed (or Egg within an Egg) out of which the Chicken is formed, even as the cheri≈øhing and benign beams of the Sun fo≈øter the Seeds that are committed into the Bo≈øom or Womb of their kind Mother the Earth. Onely here is the difference, that the Seed or Egg of a Plant contains nothing but the vegetative principle, in which as ≈øoon as the pla≈øtick power is excited, it attracts nouri≈øhment from without it ≈øelf, from the Capillary Veins or meatus of the Earth, as was ≈øhewed at large in the fir≈øt Chapter; whereas the Egg is both Seed and Womb, containing all within it ≈øelf, nece≈ø≈øary both for the formation and nutrition of the Foetus. The rea≈øon of which is apparent, namely, that a Plant (be it an Oak of two or three hundred years old) is ≈øtill but an Infant in regard of its nutrition, by its Roots as by ≈øo many Mouths ≈øucking the turgid Brea≈øts of its teeming Mother: whereas a Chick (like all other Animals) as ≈øoon as its Parts are once formed and animated, is pre≈øently emancipated, as it were, from the Womb of its Mother, neither receiving nor needing any further
nutriment from thence, but becoming its own Caterer and Carver. Now though the ≈øitting of the Hen excite the pla≈øtick power in the afore≈øaid white Circle, yet is there no vertue derived to it from the Hen her ≈øelf, ≈øeeing an elementary heat which is as gentle, equal and con≈øtant as that of the Hen, will have the ≈øame influence upon it. Thus as Hi≈øtorians relate, the Egyptians u≈øed to hatch their Eggs by the warmth of a Stove; and thus the E≈øtriches Eggs being covered with Sand are hatched by the warmth of the Sun, (which in Africk where the≈øe Fowls are bred, is much more inten≈øe than in the≈øe European Countreys) the Hen her ≈øelf neglecting that office, if the opinion of divers Commentators upon the Book of Job may be relied upon, where chap. 39. ver≈ø. 14, 15, 16. it is ≈øaid, that ≈øhe leaveth her Eggs in the Earth, and warmeth them in the du≈øt, and forgetteth that the foot may cru≈øh them, or that the wild Bea≈øt may break them. She is hardned again≈øt her Young ones as though they were not hers, &c. Concluding then that a gentle warmth, be it Animal or Elemental, is the means whereby a Chicken is formed out of an Egg, we ≈øhall proceed to our every days ob≈øervations, by what degrees it is ≈øo formed.

The degrees or order of its formation. As for the fir≈øt three days all is ≈øo imperfect that the ≈øtate or condition of the Embryo could not with any elegancy or intelligiblene≈øs be drawn by the Painter, whom I employed to draw the following Figures for the Engraver: but from the fourth day forwards to the thirteenth, and afterwards on the fifteenth and ≈øeventeenth days, you have in the following Table in what ≈øtate it appeared every day, which I thought good to exhibit to the Eye, that the di≈øcour≈øe may be the better under≈øtood.

I therefore for this purpo≈øe ≈øet fourteen new laid Eggs (gathered from ≈øeveral Hens with mine own hands, that I might be ≈øure none of them had been ≈øat upon before,) under one Hen, July the fir≈øt, 1680. upon which I made the≈øe following ob≈øervations.

1 The progre≈øs of the fir≈øt day. At the end of the fir≈øt day (or of twenty four hours) the Yelk had changed its ≈øituation, being removed from the centre of the Egg up to its blunt end; and it was likewi≈øe half turned about; for the Treddles that were towards the two ends of the Egg (the one oppo≈øite to the other) were now turned towards the ≈øides: and that white Speck or Knot that adheres to its Coat (out of which the Chicken is formed) in≈øtead of being toward the ≈øide of the Egg, was now on that ≈øide of the Yelk that looked towards its ≈øharper end. This Speck was al≈øo a little bigger, but without any other ≈øen≈øible alteration. At the blunt end of the Egg the hollowne≈øs, which is natural to all Eggs, was ≈øomewhat enlarged, and the Yelk was ri≈øen ≈øo near it, that it might be ≈øeen through the White, or rather through the Membrane of the White, the White it ≈øelf being almo≈øt wholly retired to the ≈øharp end. The Shell, la≈øtly, looked a little more dusky than before.

2 Second day. At the end of two days (or 48 hours) the ≈øaid Speck was enlarged to the breadth of a ≈øilver Penny, and ≈øeemed to be of different colours, ≈øome Parts looking more bright and others more ob≈øcure; and its whole Body jetted out into the White without making any dimple or impre≈ø≈øion into the Yelk, to who≈øe inve≈øting Membrane notwith≈øtanding it ≈øtill adhered. Doctour Harvey compares it in this ≈øtate to an Eye (yea calls it by that name) ≈øuppo≈øing its Centre to re≈øemble the Pupilla or ≈øight of the Eye, and its outer Circle (as he calls it) the Iris; affirming that the Pupilla is the vegetative Seed or principle of the Chicken, and that the
outer Circle con≈øi≈øts of the mo≈øt pure and cry≈øtal-like part of the White (being contained within a proper Membrane) from which the Seed receives its fir≈øt encrea≈øe, and that therefore as the former dilates its ≈øelf, this latter is con≈øumed and obliterated. And this is ju≈øt what happens in Viviparous Animals, in whom the Ovum imbibes ≈øome of the pure albugineous Liquor that bedews the ≈øides of the Womb; yea it is the ≈øame that happens to the vegetable Seeds of Plants, which attract the like moi≈øture through their Husks (or Secundines) from the Earth: for they all three receive their nouri≈øhment this way, till their Navel-ve≈ø≈øels are formed, and the fir≈øt growth of all of them is pure (and alike proper) vegetation.

3 Third day. At the end of the third day, I took a third Egg, and breaking it at the narrow end, I found a great alteration in it from the ≈øtate it was in the day foregoing. For in the centre of the afore≈øaid Speck I ob≈øerved a little red Body of the colour of bloud, ≈øometime plain to be ≈øeen, and anon di≈øappearing (by turns.) In the circumference of the Speck a pretty di≈øtance from the centre there was a reddi≈øh Circle, betwixt which and the red Body in the centre there run very many ≈ølender red ≈øtreaks. The red Body ob≈øerved a con≈øtant turn of dilating and contracting it ≈øelf (like to the pul≈øation of the Heart, which Part it afterward proved) for almo≈øt a quarter of an hour, in which time the Egg being grown cold, its motion then cea≈øed. By this motion it appears there is now a progre≈øs made from vegetation to ≈øome degree of Animality. The ≈ølender red ≈øtreaks that run from the centre to the circumference, ≈øeemed all to ari≈øe from one Trunk, and afterwards proved the Navel-ve≈ø≈øels, which branching out both into the White and Yelk convey nouri≈øhment from thence to the Chicken.

4 Fourth day. At the end of the fourth day all the≈øe Parts before-mentioned appeared more plain. The little red Body in the centre now ≈øeemed to con≈øi≈øt of two parts, whereof whil≈øt the one contracted it ≈øelf, the other was dilated, and on the contrary; which gave me a ≈øu≈øpicion, that one of them was the Heart, and the other the Earlets, who≈øe contractions and dilatations (or ≈øy≈øtole's and dia≈øtole's) in perfect Animals ob≈øerve that tenour; and ≈øo I perceived they afterwards proved. The bloudy ≈øtreaks were now extended further than the reddi≈øh circle, both towards the White and towards the Yelk: and the Trunk from whence they ≈øprang, looked not now ≈øo fair red as it did before, but ≈øomewhat more dusky, as if ≈øomething of an a≈øhy or dull white colour adhered to its out≈øide, being as it were of a woolly ≈øub≈øtance, and ≈øticking upon the Trunk of the Vein like mo≈øs upon the bough of a Tree. The cavity at the blunt end of the Egg was grown a pretty deal larger than before. The two little red Bodies continued their beating longer than the one had done the day before; and as ≈øoon as they cea≈øed I took them out, and al≈øo the A≈øh-coloured part of the Trunk of the Vein, and put them in fair-water; wherein as the fir≈øt pre≈øently lo≈øt their colour, ≈øo the latter lo≈øt its ≈øhape and a≈øpect it had within the Egg; for I had fancied it to appear like the fir≈øt rudiment (or ≈øtamen) of the Body of the Chicken; but the woolly ≈øub≈øtance was not of con≈øi≈øtence firm enough to retain its former figure in the water: however I perceived as well by the experiment of the next days Egg, as al≈øo by another Egg that I ≈øince broke on the fourth day, that I had fancied right. The form it was in, when taken out of the Shell on this fourth day, you have delineated in the fir≈øt Figure of the following Table,
which ≈øhews the A≈øh-coloured Trunk and woolly ≈øub≈øtance, and ≈øome of tho≈øe red ≈øtreaks adhering to it, or proceeding from it.

5 Fifth day. At the end of the fifth day the two little red beating Bodies were grown of a fainter colour, for by this time the Parenchyma of the Heart was begun to gather about them. A little di≈øtance from the≈øe there appeared the fir≈øt rudiments of the Head, con≈øi≈øting of four bubbles, two of which were clear and tran≈øparent, but the other two of different colours. The two clear ones were the Brain and Cerebel, and tho≈øe of different colours were the Eyes: The≈øe two la≈øt appeared much bigger than either of the other. One might al≈øo di≈øcern the Bill which looked white. In the ≈øame Egg I ob≈øerved likewi≈øe the rudiments of the Lungs and Liver, which la≈øt gathered upon or grew out of the Umbilical Vein. The woolly ≈øub≈øtance before-≈øpoken of, that gathered about the Trunk of the Vein, was now of a more ≈øolid and clo≈øe contexture, and did plainly appear to be the fir≈øt rudiment of the Carka≈øe of the Chicken, out of which both Wings and Legs were begun to bud and to be very di≈øcernable. This Embryo, though all its Parts were imperfect, did yet appear to have life in it, for I could ob≈øerve it to bow it ≈øelf to and again. Of what form it appeared when it was taken out of the Liquor wherein it ≈øwam, you have delineated in the ≈øecond Figure of the following Table, being drawn by one that was taken out of an Egg that the Hen had ≈øat upon five days compleat; which Embryo as al≈øo all the re≈øt that we ≈øhall hereafter in the following di≈øcour≈øe ≈øpeak of, I did pre≈øerve by a Liquor prepared for that purpo≈øe, and have them all hanging up again≈øt a Board in the ≈øame po≈øture as they are repre≈øented in the ≈øaid following Table.

6 Sixth day. At the end of ≈øix days all the forementioned Parts were more vi≈øible,yea there is not any Part of the whole Body but a ≈øcheme of it now appeared. The Heart had acquired its proper ≈øhape, but looked white, as did al≈øo the Lungs and Liver; the Eyes ≈øtood gogling out of the Head, and each of them was as much bigger than the Brain, as the Head (taking in all its Parts) was bigger than all the re≈øt of the Body. The Brain and Cerebel were as yet onely of a watery ≈øub≈øtance, of which the latter ≈øtood jetting out above the former. One might make ≈øome faint di≈øcovery of the Spine or Back-bone, looking whiter than the re≈øt of the Parts about it, as al≈øo of the Ribs that were extended forward from it like the fine≈øt and white≈øt threads of Lawn. There were al≈øo the Lineaments of the Inte≈øtins, which, as al≈øo the Heart, Liver and Lungs, may be ≈øeen without di≈ø≈øection; for as yet and for ≈øome days after, all the trunk of the Body lieth open before, ≈øo that the Entrails lie bare, the fir≈øt rudiments of the Body beginning backwards and reaching forwards by degrees; even as Ship-carpenters begin with the Back or Keel of the Ship fir≈øt, and rai≈øe up her Sides from thence. The Legs were not onely apparent at this time, but the Feet were al≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhed into Claws, both which it could move. The form of it you have de≈øcribed in the third Figure of the following Table.

7 Seventh and eighth days. As for the ≈øeventh and eighth days, ≈øome bu≈øine≈øs calling me out of Town I was prevented from making my ob≈øervations on this brood of Eggs; but in others that had been ≈øat upon ≈øeven daies, I found no alteration from the appearances of the day foregoing, ≈øaving that every Part was more plain and compleat; as neither in others on the eighth day, ≈øaving that once in an Egg that had lain under the Hen but eight days, I could not ≈øee the Heart beat without a little di≈ø≈øecting the Brea≈øt, which
was begun to clo≈øe it ≈øelf over it. The ≈øtate of the Chicken on the≈øe daies you have delineated in the fourth and fifth Figures.

8 Ninth day. At the end of the ninth day (being returned home again) I broke another of the Eggs, and could not now di≈øcover the Heart, for the Che≈øt was clo≈øed over it though but very loo≈øely and imperfectly. (Though in another Egg broken at the ≈øame time, which another Hen had ≈øat on, I could ≈øee the Heart move without di≈ø≈øection.) I perceived the Chicken to move its Legs, Wings and Head, and indeed all its Parts: Its Head was almo≈øt as big as all its Body be≈øides; but e≈øpecially its Eyes continued of a prodigious bigne≈øs, ≈øtaring out of its Head: They were at lea≈øt as big as ≈ømall Pi≈øtol-bullets. The White of the Egg was a great part of it con≈øumed already on the nouri≈øhment of the Chicken; and I could plainly ≈øee its umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels now reach to the Yelk, which ≈øeemed as yet to have no part of it ≈øpent; its Parts were of different con≈øi≈øtence, ≈øome thinner and ≈øome thicker; that was thinner wherein I could perceive the capillary Threads of the Navel-ve≈ø≈øels to be di≈øper≈øed. Both the Heart, Liver and Lungs were ≈øtill of a whiti≈øh colour, and their Parenchyma had acquired no firmne≈øs of ≈øub≈øtance, though they had attained very near to their proper ≈øhape. The ≈øixth Figure expre≈ø≈øes the Chicken in the po≈øture of this day.

9 Tenth day. At the end of the tenth day I examined another, wherein I found the Che≈øt pretty firmly clo≈øed, but the Abdomen or lower Belly lay yet quite open, and the Stomach and Guts hung out of it. On its Back I di≈øcerned a great many blacki≈øh ≈øpecks, which were the rudiments of the Feathers breaking out. The Eyes continued much in the ≈øame po≈øture as on the day before, being as yet but very little drawn within their Orbits. Neither were the Brain and Cerebel as yet perfectly withdrawn to within the Skull. The White of the Egg was ≈øtill more decrea≈øed, but the Yelk little or nothing dimini≈øhed. Concerning which there is this one thing very remarkable; That though addle Eggs begin to ≈øtink and grow rotten by the warmth of the Hen, within four daies time from her fir≈øt ≈øitting on them, and every day encrea≈øe in their putrefaction the longer they are ≈øat on: yet till this time the White that remains and al≈øo the Yelk in fruitfull Eggs, retain their proper ≈ømell and ≈øavour; yea the Yelk, that is not all of it con≈øumed when the Chicken is hatched, (but is part of it received to within its Belly) I ≈øay what remains of it till then, ta≈øtes as ≈øweet as the Yelk of a new-laid Egg. (But this by the way.) See the Chickens ≈øhape of this day in the ≈øeventh Figure.

10 Eleventh day. At eleven days end I broke another, and admired to ≈øee the Feathers ≈øo much encrea≈øed; for not onely tho≈øe on the Back, which I ob≈øerved breaking out the day before, were now become plain Feathers, but all its Body over almo≈øt was covered with the like. Its Abdomen lay yet open, and its Guts jetted out of it; but the Brain and Cerebel were now withdrawn perfectly within the Skull; but its Eyes ≈øtood gogling out ≈øtill. One might di≈øcern its Rump al≈øo formed, and Feathers budding out of it re≈øembling the Tail. But though the Chicken had attained to this maturity, yet neither this, nor that I examined the day before, lived ≈øo long as tho≈øe on the two or three days before; but this I believe, happened through my chancing to wound the Navel-ve≈ø≈øels in both, which cau≈øed them to bleed, and thereby I ≈øuppo≈øe ha≈øtned their death. The eighth Figure expre≈ø≈øes this days Chicken.

11 Twelfth day to the ≈øeventeenth. All the Parts being now entirely formed, it would be but the repetition of the ≈øame things over again and again to give a particular account of each days proceeding, from the twelfth to the end of the ≈øeventeenth, till which time the Abdomen lies open ≈øtill: onely I ≈øhall give a ≈øhort account of ≈øome little alteration that happens in this interval; which is not ≈øo much in the Chicken it ≈øelf, as in the Liquors it is fed by, and in its umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels. Doctour Harvey ≈øays its umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels are five, three Veins and two Arteries. One of the Veins ari≈øes from the Cava above the Liver: this is the large≈øt, and ≈øends forth its branches into the White, which being now in a manner ≈øpent, the branches of the Vein begin to wither, and by degrees are obliterated: But the other two Veins which ≈øpring from the vena Portae continue longer, having their branches di≈øtributed into the Yelk, which as yet is but a very little of it con≈øumed. The≈øe are accompanied by two Arteries that ≈øpring from the Lumbares or Loin-arteries. As the White is ≈øpent, the Membranes that contain'd it, begin to ≈øhrivel up and contract them≈øelves, and to cleave one to another, as the Chorion cleaves to the Allantoides in Viviparous Animals. The Chicken now having no Liquor to ≈øwim in (as it did whil≈øt the White remained) re≈øts its Belly upon the Yelk (which is drawn clo≈øer towards its Abdomen by the Membranes, ≈øtill more and more contracting them≈øelves) with its Head commonly under the right Wing. If one di≈ø≈øect its Brea≈øt, one ≈øhall find its Heart and Lungs to have obtained almo≈øt their natural redne≈øs; but the Liver looks of ≈øomewhat a yellowi≈øh white. If one open the Head, the Brain hath acquired a pretty ≈øolid ≈øub≈øtance, whereas till of late both the Brain and Cerebel ≈øeemed to con≈øi≈øt of nothing but water. The Eyes continue ≈øtill to ≈øtand ≈øtaring out of their Orbits a pretty deal further than they do when the Chicken is hatched. Its gradual encrea≈øe in this interval, viz. on the twelfth, thirteenth, fifteenth and ≈øeventeenth days you have expre≈ø≈øed in the ninth, tenth, eleventh and twelfth Figures of the following Table.

12 Eighteenth day. On the eighteenth day the Guts are withdrawn to within the Abdomen, and together with them that which remains of the Yelk, from which the umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels continue to derive nouri≈øhment to the Chick, even after it is thus included in the Belly; yea, even after the Chicken is hatched: for it is not all ≈øpent till ≈øeveral days after. And this was a nece≈ø≈øary provi≈øion of Nature, that ≈øeeing the Hen affords it no nouri≈øhment (as Viviparous Creatures do to their Young ones) but it mu≈øt be its own Carver and feed it ≈øelf after the ≈øame manner as its Mother does; I ≈øay, Nature for this rea≈øon hath prudently provided, that it ≈øhould ≈øtill be nouri≈øhed by its umbilical Ve≈ø≈øels, till its Bill have acquired ≈øome ≈øtrength, and it have learned to pick for it ≈øelf. The large≈øt umbilical Vein that is derived from the Cava and was di≈øtributed into the White, is now quite obliterated, the White being all of it con≈øumed. One may perceive the Chicken to bu≈øtle about in the Egg, and if one hold it to his Ear, it may be heard ≈øometimes to peep, but more and more towards the twenty-fir≈øt day, which is the u≈øual day of hatching; till which time from this eighteenth day it were to no purpo≈øe to give any Figure of what ≈øtate the Chicken is in, ≈øeeing, now that the Abdomen is clo≈øed, there would appear no Part but onely the ≈øurface of its Body which is all covered with Feathers. We ≈øhall ≈øpeak therefore no further of the manner and degrees of its generation, nor exhibit its daily condition in Figures, but onely add a word or two of its hatching.

How the Chicken is hatched. Three weeks is reckoned the u≈øual and natural time for Chickens to be hatched in. At the one and twentieth day therefore, or at the longe≈øt on the two and twentieth the Chicken having ≈øpent all the provi≈øion Nature had provided for it in its little man≈øion; but more e≈øpecially wanting a freer Air to breath in, it begins to be unea≈øie, and to meditate and endeavour an exit. It is to be noted that naturally there is in every Egg a little cavity in its broader end, which is filled (as I may ≈øay) with congenit Air: As the cavity encrea≈øes, this Air mu≈øt needs be rarefied ≈øo as to fill up the empty ≈øpace; for the Shell ≈øeems of ≈øo den≈øe and compact a ≈øub≈øtance as to admit none of the external Air into it: or if we do ≈øuppo≈øe it to be ≈øo porous as that the outward Air can in≈øinuate it ≈øelf into it, yet will it not be ≈øufficient for ≈øo free a breathing as is nece≈ø≈øary for our mature and full grown Animal; much le≈øs would that congenit Air, before-mentioned, (≈øo much rarefied as it mu≈øt be) ≈øuffice for it. The Chicken hath however ≈øome ≈øort of re≈øpiration, or el≈øe it could not peep; for that voice mu≈øt be formed by the Air in expiration. But I ≈øay it requires a freer breathing than this comes to; and therefore by ≈øcratching and pecking again≈øt the Shell, it ≈øtrives to break pri≈øon. In doing which it hath no help from the Hen, (what≈øoever ≈øome may affirm of her breaking the Shell for it) as Viviparous Animals afford to their Young, who≈øe Wombs that contain the Foetus, being mole≈øted by its tumbling, are excited to endeavour an expul≈øion; whence the birth is almo≈øt wholly owing to the Dam, that by her throes excludes her Foetus, and to the Foetus no otherwi≈øe than as by its motion it cau≈øes an unea≈øine≈øs to the Dam. The Shell notwith≈øtanding (that is like an external Womb) is partly prepared for the ea≈øier exit of the Chicken; for by its having been kept warm ≈øo long by the Hen's brooding upon it, and by the White's being con≈øumed within it, it is now become dry and brittle, and readily admits of the impre≈ø≈øions of the Chickens Bill pecking again≈øt it; and much more ea≈øily will the Membranes wherein it is inve≈øted (which may be called its Secundines) be penetrated and broken through by ≈øuch means. The Chicken then is wholly owing to its own pains for its exclu≈øion out of the Egg; for by its Bill (as with a battering Ram) it demoli≈øhes and di≈ømantles the walls of its Pri≈øon, and pa≈ø≈øing out through the breach obtains its freedom.

Hitherto it may ≈øuffice to have pro≈øecuted this in≈øtance of the generation of an Oviparous Creature; it remains that in the next place we proceed according to promi≈øe, to give another in≈øtance of that of a Viviparous Animal; having done which we ≈øhall make a ≈øhort compari≈øon of the one with the other, and of both with the vegetation of the Seed of a Plant.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Generation of Viviparous Creatures.
div.p: HAving fini≈øhed the hi≈øtory of the generation of Oviparous Animals, we come in the next place to that of Viviparous, wherein we ≈øhall be the ≈øhorter, by rea≈øon there is that analogy betwixt them, that to be too particular would be tedious, ≈øeeing it were but to repeat the ≈øame things over again. For an Egg is as it were a Conception without the Body; and a Conception may properly enough be called an Egg within the Body. I have not had my ≈øelf opportunity to examine each days proceedings in the generation of this ≈øort of Animal (viz. of Viviparous) but have ≈øuch ob≈øervations made to my hand by the curious De Graef, who≈øe In≈øtance is in Rabbets. His ob≈øervations I ≈øhall make u≈øe of ≈øo far as they are for my purpo≈øe, omitting what is otherwi≈øe. But before I proceed to them, a few things are to be premi≈øed.

Fir≈øt, Tho≈øe parts which we commonly call the Te≈øticles in Females are truly Ovaries, from whence the Eggs (one or more at a time) as they are impregnated with the Geniture of the Male, ≈øeparate, and being conducted into the Womb or its Horns, by the Trumpets, become there what we call a Conception.

Secondly, This Animal who≈øe generation we in≈øtance in, forms its Conceptions not in the bottom of the Womb as a Mare and ≈øome other Creatures do, but in its Horns, into which it is pre≈øently divided from the Vagina it ≈øelf, without any fundus or bottom at all.

Thirdly, A Rabbet going with young but ≈øo ≈øhort a while, it is to be ≈øuppo≈øed that all things even from the very fir≈øt, proceed with ≈øo much greater ha≈øte, as their ge≈øtation is ≈øhorter than that of other Animals re≈øpectively.

Fourthly, A Rabbet is one of the placentiferous Animals, each Foetus having its proper Placenta; whereas Mares and very many other Creatures have no Placenta, but in≈øtead thereof Cotyledons, as was noted in the Fir≈øt Book, Chap. 28.
Having premi≈øed the≈øe things I now proceed to the ob≈øervations.

q.p: We made the fir≈øt tryal (≈øays the above-named Authour) on a Female Rabbet that had not yet accompanied with the Male, in whom the Te≈øticles were ≈ømall, but contained very many limpid Eggs, which being cut open there i≈ø≈øued out a clammy liquor like the White of an Egg.

We opened another (≈øays he) half an hour after ≈øhe had taken buck, the Cornua of who≈øe Womb lookt a little redder, but the Ova in the Te≈øticles were not yet changed, unle≈øs they had remitted a little of their clearne≈øs: but neither in the Vagina nor in the Cornua could we perceive any Seed or any thing like it.

About ≈øix hours after the coupling we di≈ø≈øected another, in who≈øe Te≈øticles the Ca≈øes of the Ova inclined to redne≈øs, out of which being prickt with a Needle a clammy and clear Liquor i≈ø≈øued fir≈øt, but Bloud followed, flowing out of the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels di≈øper≈øed through the Ca≈øes. There was no Seed to be ≈øeen in this neither.

Four and twenty hours after the coupling we opened another, in one of who≈øe Te≈øticles we found three, and in the other five Ca≈øes of the Ova very much changed; for being before the Coitus limpid and colourle≈øs, they were now turned duski≈øh and of a faint red, in the middle of who≈øe Superficies a little Papilla (or Teat) as it were, di≈øcovered it ≈øelf. When the Ca≈øes were cut open, there appeared a little limpid Liquor in their middle, and in their circumference a certain thicker and reddi≈øh Matter.

Twenty ≈øeven hours after the coitus we in≈øpected another, the Cornua of who≈øe Womb with the Oviducts or Trumpets looked more bloudy, al≈øo the extremity of the Oviduct did on every ≈øide embrace the Te≈øticle like a Tunnel. We found no Eggs in the Cornua, nor were their Ca≈øes in the Te≈øticles much altered from what they were three hours before.

Eight and forty hours after the coupling we examined another, in one of who≈øe Te≈øticles we found ≈øeven, in the other three Ca≈øes changed, in who≈øe middle the Teats were ≈øomething more eminent, through which, by pre≈ø≈øing the ≈øub≈øtance of the Te≈øticles, there i≈ø≈øued a little liquor like the White of an Egg; but the remaining reddi≈øh ≈øub≈øtance of the Eggs being now become ≈øomething thicker, was not ≈øo ea≈øily pre≈ø≈øed out as before.

Seventy two hours (or three days and nights) after the coitus we in≈øpected another, in which was great alteration; for the end of the Infundibulum or Oviduct did embrace the Te≈øticles mo≈øt clo≈øely, which being pull'd off we found in the Te≈øticle of the right ≈øide three Ca≈øes a little greater and harder, in the middle of who≈øe ≈øurface we ≈øaw a little knot with a ≈ømall hole in it like a Nipple; but di≈ø≈øecting the≈øe Ca≈øes through the middle, their Cavity was quite empty; wherefore we ≈øearched the ways through which the Eggs mu≈øt pa≈øs, again and again, and found in the middle of the right Oviduct one, and in the outer end of the Cornu of the ≈øame ≈øide two very ≈ømall Eggs little bigger than ≈ømall Pins heads, which notwith≈øtanding their ≈ømallne≈øs are cloathed with a double coat; out of the≈øe Eggs being pricked there i≈ø≈øued a mo≈øt clear Liquor. In the beginning of the left Horn we found onely one Egg.

The fourth day from the coupling we opened another, in one of who≈øe Te≈øticles we found four, in the other three Ca≈øes emptied, and in the Horns of the re≈øpective ≈øides, we found as many Eggs, greater than the former, which did not ≈øtick in the Oviducts or beginnings of the Cornua, but were now rolled on towards their middle; in their Cavity we beheld as it were another Egg ≈øwimming, far clearer than in the other before.

The fifth day from the coupling we di≈ø≈øected another, in who≈øe Te≈øticles we told ≈øix emptied Ca≈øes, that had each a notable Nipple, through who≈øe hole we ea≈øily put an ordinary Bri≈øtle into their Cavity. We found al≈øo the ≈øame number of Eggs, bigger than tho≈øe on the day before, in divers parts of the Cornua, in which they lay ≈øo loo≈øely, that by blowing onely, one might drive them this way or that way. The inner Tunicle of the≈øe, (or the Egg within an Egg as it were) was become yet more con≈øpicuous.

The ≈øixth day after the coitus we examined another, in one of who≈øe Te≈øticles we ob≈øerved ≈øix Ca≈øes emptied, and in the Cornu of the ≈øame
≈øide we could light of but onely five Eggs near the Vagina brought as it were upon an heap; but in the Te≈øticle of the other ≈øide we found four Ca≈øes emptied, and in the Horn of that ≈øide onely one Egg. The cau≈øe of which difference we ≈øuppo≈øe to be, either becau≈øe ≈øome Eggs by the Wave-like motion of the Cornua, (not unlike the peri≈øtaltick motion of the Guts) being carried downwards towards the Vagina were driven forth; or becau≈øe being con≈øumed in the Ca≈øes they came not to the ∆≤terus; or light on ≈øome other mi≈øchance. The≈øe Eggs were as big as ≈ømall Pea≈øe.

The ≈øeventh day from the coitus we examin'd another, in who≈øe Te≈øticles we found ≈øome Ca≈øes emptied that were greater, redder and harder than the foregoing, and ≈øaw as many tran≈øparent tumours or cells in divers parts of the Cornua; out of which being opened we turned Eggs as big as Pocket-pi≈øtol Bullets, in which we could di≈øcern nothing but the inner Tunicle very plain and a mo≈øt clear humour. It is wonderfull that in ≈øo ≈øhort a ≈øpace of time the Eggs ≈øhould imbibe ≈øo great plenty of liquor, that whereas before they might ea≈øily be taken out of the Womb, now they could very difficultly.

The eighth day after the coitus we opened another, in the right Horn of who≈øe ∆≤terus we ≈øaw one, in the left two cells; one of the≈øe was almo≈øt twice as big as the other: for Nature doth ≈øometimes ≈øo vary, that there are Eggs of divers bigne≈øs found not onely in divers Animals of the ≈øame ≈øpecies di≈ø≈øected at the ≈øame di≈øtance from the coitus, but al≈øo in one and the ≈øame Individual. In the Horns of the Womb being opened we ≈øaw the Eggs a little bigger than the day before; but all of them, their Tunicles breaking, poured out their clear liquor before we could take them quite out: for which rea≈øon we tried another di≈ø≈øected likewi≈øe the eighth day after the coitus, to take out who≈øe Ova we u≈øed the greate≈øt circum≈øpection; but their Tunicles were ≈øo very tender, that they bur≈øt as the former: which when we ≈øaw, the Eggs that remained we boiled with the Womb, whereby the liquor that was in them harden'd like the Whites of Hens Eggs.

The ninth day after the coitus we di≈ø≈øected another that was old; The Te≈øticles of this were almo≈øt as big again as tho≈øe of younger: In the right we ≈øaw two, in the left five Ca≈øes lately emptied; and be≈øides the≈øe, others that lookt very pale, which we judged to be tho≈øe that had been emptied the coitus before this, although for the mo≈øt part they leave onely ≈øome pali≈øh points or ≈øpecks, to which the increa≈øe of the Te≈øticles is owing. The Ca≈øes of the la≈øt coitus had each a Teat upon them, but the others were ≈ømooth. In the right Horn there were two, and in the left five Cells, who≈øe ≈øub≈øtance being more rare and clear than the other parts of the Womb, was interwoven with many twigs of Veins and Arteries. Opening ≈øome of the≈øe Cells, we could ≈øee the Eggs, but could not take them out whole; wherefore being compelled to examine the content of the Eggs in the very hollow of the Cells, we found it clear like Cry≈øtal; in the mid≈øt whereof a certain rare and thin cloud was ≈øeen to ≈øwim, which in other Coneys di≈ø≈øected likewi≈øe on the ninth day after the coupling, for its exceeding finene≈øs e≈øcaped our ≈øight. The inner ≈øub≈øtance of the Cells, namely that which receives the hypoga≈øtrick Ve≈ø≈øels, being more tumid than the re≈øt, exhibited the rudiments of the Placenta.

The tenth day after the coitus we in≈øpected another, in who≈øe right Te≈øticle we found one Ca≈øe alone emptied, which by rea≈øon of the Bloudve≈ø≈øels di≈øper≈øed plentifully through it was redder and had a le≈øs Teat; in the middle of it there appeared as yet a very ≈ømall Cavity: but in the left Te≈øticle we found ≈øix ≈øuch Ca≈øes. In the Horns of the Womb we found al≈øo ≈øo many Cells, namely one in the right and ≈øix in the left, di≈øtant a finger's breadth one from another; in the mid≈øt of which Cells lay a rude mucilaginous draught of the Embryo like a little Maggot; one might al≈øo plainly di≈øcern the Placenta, to which the Egg by means of its Chorion was annexed. The liquor of the Eggs being boiled with the Womb hardned like the White of an Egg, and ta≈øted like the boiled congealed ≈øub≈øtance of the Eggs in the Te≈øticles.

The twelfth day after the coitus we opened another, in one of who≈øe Te≈øticles we found ≈øeven, in the other five Ca≈øes emptied, and as many Cells in the Horns much bigger and rounder than the foregoing, in the middle of which the Embryo was ≈øo con≈øpicuous, that one might in a ≈øort di≈øcern its Limbs, having two bloudy ≈øpecks and as many white ones in its Brea≈øt: In the Paunch there grew a certain mucilaginous ≈øub≈øtance inclining here and there to red. We could not di≈øcern more in this ≈øhapele≈øs little Animal becau≈øe of its tenderne≈øs.

The fourteenth day after the coitus we di≈ø≈øected another, which had the Cells in the Cornua yet larger than the foregoing, and the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels more, and more turgid. We al≈øo noted that the Cells the larger they grew, came al≈øo nearer to one another, the ≈øpaces between them being ≈øhortned. The Membranes Amnios and Chorion were knit together, tearing which we ≈øaw an Embryo (≈øuch as the eleventh Figure of the following Table repre≈øents) with a clear and pellucid head, with the Cerebel copped: its goggle Eyes, gaping mouth, and in ≈øome ≈øort its little Ears might be di≈øcerned al≈øo. There was a draught of its Back-bone, of a white colour, which bending in about the Sternum, re≈øembled the Keel of a Ship: By its ≈øides there run very ≈ølender Ve≈ø≈øels, who≈øe Branches were extended to the Back and to the Feet. The two bloudy ≈øpecks in the Brea≈øt, being greater than the foregoing were the rudiments of the Ventricles of the Heart; at the ≈øides whereof were ≈øeen two whiti≈øh ≈øpecks for Lungs. In the Paunch being opened there fir≈øt ≈øhewed it ≈øelf a reddi≈øh Liver, then a white body, to which was knit a mucilaginous matter like a writhen thread, being the rudiments of the Stomach and Guts: All which in tho≈øe that we di≈ø≈øected afterwards, had acquired onely a greater bulk and perfection. And therefore to prevent tediou≈øne≈øs by repeating the ≈øame things, we will on purpo≈øe pa≈øs by all the other Di≈ø≈øections we made in this kind of Creature excepting onely one which we made the day before the kindling, that tho≈øe things that in the former were onely confu≈øedly di≈øcerned, may appear plain in this.

At length on the twenty ninth day after the coitus we in≈øpected another that had kindled ≈øix weeks before, and in the coitus by which ≈øhe was impregnated had voided all the thicker part of the geniture of the Male, which in ≈øome mea≈øure did re≈øemble the con≈øi≈øtence of a mo≈øt limpid gelly. In her Te≈øticles we found eleven little whiti≈øh Ca≈øes; and be≈øides the≈øe, others far le≈øs, little or nothing differing from the ≈øub≈øtance of the Te≈øtes. The≈øe Ca≈øes of the Eggs in the Te≈øticles ≈øeem not to vani≈øh wholly, but to leave a certain ≈øpeck in them; whence it

certainly comes to pa≈øs, that Conies the oftener or the more young ones they bring forth, have the greater and whiter Te≈øticles; ≈øo that one may gue≈øs by onely viewing the Te≈øtes, whether they have had many young ones or often. Having viewed the Te≈øticles we pa≈øt to the Horns of the Womb, which we found no longer di≈øtingui≈øhed into Cells, but all along di≈øtended like a Pudding: which was ≈øo agitated with a Wave-like motion, like the peri≈øtaltick of the Guts, that the young ones neare≈øt the Vagina as yet included in their Membranes, were excluded, and that ≈øo ha≈øtily, that if we had not cut out the whole ∆≤terus they had all certainly gone the ≈øame way. The Womb was no thicker than when they are not with young, (otherwi≈øe than it is in Women.) In its Cavity we ≈øaw eleven Foetus ≈øprawling, which were all ≈øo clo≈øely coupled together by the Membrane Chorion (wherein all are ≈øeverally involved) as if they had all been included in one and the ≈øame Chorion.

div.p: This is the account that the aforenamed curious Anatomi≈øt gives of the generation of this kind of Animal, and to it, that of all others that are Viviparous may be reduced, abating onely the differences mentioned at the beginning of this Chapter, or other like them, if there be any. And for the better illu≈øtration of this account, I have thought good to annex hereto a Table borrowed from the ≈øame Authour, expre≈ø≈øing as well the figure of a Rabbet's ∆≤terus, as the po≈øture or condition the Conception and Foetus are in on each day whereon the foregoing ob≈øervations were made.
