div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Analogy, or likene≈øs, between the generation of Oviparous and Viviparous Animals; and how far the generation of both agrees with the vegetation of Plants.
div.p: SUppo≈øing, what has been demon≈øtrated by the foregoing di≈øcour≈øe, that the fir≈øt principle of the Foetus both of Oviparous and Viviparous Animals, is an Egg, and that the Seeds of Plants have analogy thereto, and may properly enough be comprehended under the ≈øame denomination; we ≈øhall as briefly as may be, con≈øider the corre≈øpondence that one of the≈øe has to another in their procedure towards the production of a perfect Animal or Plant of their re≈øpective kinds.

As for Vegetables, the Sun is the common father of their whole genus or ≈øtock, for by his irradiation alone it is that any of their Seeds (or Eggs) are matured and become fruitfull: not but that the Mother-plant her ≈øelf produces the whole ≈øub≈øtance of the Seed; but its becoming fructiferous or vegetative, is owing wholly to the ethereal and mo≈øt pure and ≈øubtil influence of the Sun. In like manner the Matter of the Eggs in Oviparous Animals, or of a Conception in Viviparous is derived onely from the Female, who≈øe Egg or Conception it is; but the vegetative or pla≈øtick power re≈øiding therein is derived from the impregnation (or if you will, irradiation) of the ≈øpirituous geniture of the Male, by who≈øe influence alone they are rendred capable of producing a Foetus of their proper ≈øpecies.

The Seed, Egg or Conception then being indowed with a vegetative virtue by the≈øe means, have need of ≈øuitable nouri≈øhment for the encrea≈øe of the fir≈øt lineaments and rudiments of that which is produced out of them. Seeds are emancipated from the Womb of their natural Mother the Plant, (viz. the Pod or Shell) and committed to that of their Fo≈øter-mother, the Earth. Into which they are no ≈øooner received, but they begin to imbibe the nitrous and bal≈øamick juices wherewith ≈øhe abounds, through their hulls or husks, by which they are made to ≈øwell and increa≈øe in bulk. And even ju≈øt thus in Viviparous Animals, as ≈øoon as an Ovum is ≈øeparated from the Te≈øticle and arrives at the Womb, being cloathed with two Membranes (that an≈øwer to the husks of the Seed) it pre≈øently begins to imbibe ≈øome of the albugineous liquor that plentifully bedews the ≈øides of the Womb at the time when a Conception is made: this liquor I ≈øay is imbibed through the Membranes, for as yet there is no Ve≈ø≈øel formed to convey it, nor does the Conception ≈øtick to any part. And thus al≈øo the little white ≈øpeck in an Hen's Egg, as ≈øoon as the vegetative virtue thereof is excited by the gentle warmth of the Hen brooding upon it, attracts unto it ≈øome of the thinne≈øt and pure≈øt of the White, whereby it is enlarged in its dimen≈øion. And this encrea≈øe happens to all three, before there are any the lea≈øt lineaments of that which afterwards is produced from them.

In the next place the Seed begins to put forth a gemm or ≈øprout, which is as the fir≈øt Embryo of the Plant; and at the ≈øame time the Seedleaf (which ≈øerves for the Placenta) and Navel-knot are ≈øhaped. By the Navel-knot, which knits the Seed-leaf and trunk of the Plant together, is nouri≈øhment conveyed from that to this for its further growth. In like manner the fir≈øt thing that appears tending towards a Foetus in an Egg or a Conception, is the red beating ≈øpeck and ≈ømall reddi≈øh ≈øtreaks proceeding from it, that prove the Navel-ve≈ø≈øels, which in Viviparous Animals that are placentiferous, are implanted into the Placenta or Womb-cake, from whence they derive nouri≈øhment to the Embryo. In Oviparous, that have no Placenta, they are in≈øerted into the Membranes that contain the White and Yelk, which Membranes 'tis probable may have ≈øome Glands adhering to them, through which the ≈øaid liquors are tran≈øcolated into the Navel-ve≈ø≈øels, and therefore may an≈øwer to the Cotyledons in ≈øuch Brutes as are not placentiferous. At the ≈øame time or pre≈øently after appear ≈øome lineaments of the Spine, or trunk of the Body, an≈øwering to the trunk of the Plant.

The next progre≈øs of the vegetation of a Seed towards a Plant is the putting forth of Roots, which are as the Head and Mouth of the Plant, by which it ≈øucks nouri≈øhment all its life-long from its Nur≈øe-mother the Earth. In corre≈øpondence whereto the fir≈øt part (next to the before-mentioned) that attains to any con≈øiderable bulk or perfection of ≈øhape in the Foetus of Animals, is the Head, which by the two la≈øt before-going Figures you may perceive both in Chickens and Rabbets to be at fir≈øt well nigh as big as all the Body be≈øides. The rea≈øon of which ha≈øty procedure in the formation of this part ≈øeems to be for two rea≈øons: Fir≈øt, that the Brain whic his the ≈øpring of the Animal function, might arrive at a capacity of elaborating and tran≈ømitting the Animal Spirits, by the Nerves, to all the parts of the little Animal, for the performing of ≈øuch weak and imperfect motions as are nece≈ø≈øary for it in that ≈øtate. And ≈øecondly, that its Mouth might be in a forwardne≈øs towards ≈øo much perfection as is nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øipping or ≈øucking and ≈øwallowing that albugineous nutritious juice wherein it fluctuates, and which its parts being now grown more bulky and firm begin to ≈øtand in need of for their further nouri≈øhment and encrea≈øe.

But now our Foetus (whether the off-≈øpring of a Viviparous or Oviparous Creature) being advanced beyond the ≈øtate and rank of Vegetables into that of Animals, we cannot deduce the parallel any further with that propriety and accuracy as hitherto: though it might ≈øtill be further pro≈øecuted according to the mo≈øt ingenious ob≈øervations of Doctour Grew in his Anatomy of Trunks, who hath di≈øcovered in them not onely ≈øeveral Sap-ve≈ø≈øels an≈øwering to the Veins and Arteries (yea to the Milky-ve≈ø≈øels and Lympheducts) but Air-ve≈ø≈øels likewi≈øe, as if Plants were partakers of Re≈øpiration al≈øo, and con≈øequently of ≈øome degree of Animality, wanting onely local motion and (perhaps) ≈øen≈øe to difference them from true Animals. But to doe this would carry me beyond my purpo≈øe, which was to compare the generation (or rather fir≈øt vegetation) of the one to the other, and not their after-nouri≈øhment and life. I ≈øhall therefore here break off the parallel or analogy of Vegetables with Animals; but ≈øhall continue a little further that of Oviparous and Viviparous Animals one with another.

By that time the purer part of the White of an Egg is the greate≈øt part of it exhau≈øted by the umbilical Veins, and ≈øpent in the encrea≈øe of the parts of the Chicken; its Bill, Mouth, Throat, &c. have attained to that perfection as that they can perform their office of ≈øipping and ≈øwallowing, whereby the remainder of the White, that is more thick and earthy, comes to be con≈øumed al≈øo. For that the Chicken ≈øwallows ≈øome of it, is plain, ≈øeeing if one open the Crop of one newly hatched, there is a clear liquor in it of the ≈øame con≈øi≈øtence, colour and ta≈øte with the White, which can be conveyed thither no other way but by ≈øwallowing. In like manner the Foetus of Viviparous Animals having arrived at ≈øuch maturity as to have their Mouths, Stomachs, &c. perfected, though they continue ≈øtill to receive part of their nouri≈øhment by the umbilical Vein, (even as a Chicken after it hath con≈øumed all the White, yet ≈øtill derives nouri≈øhment from the Yelk by other branches of the ≈øame Ve≈ø≈øel) yet partly that the Stomach may be initiated into that office it is to perform after the birth (viz. concoction,) and partly that the Foetus may be trained up and accu≈øtomed to that way of feeding whereby they are to be ≈øu≈øtained after their expul≈øion from the Womb, they ≈øuck in at their Mouth a gro≈ø≈øer ≈øort of nutritious juice, (an≈øwering to the thicker White in an Egg) wherein they ≈øwim in the Amnios: which liquor is conveyed thither by the umbilical Arteries of the Foetus in this manner. The umbilical Vein being implanted into the Placenta, or Cotyledons of the Womb, does imbibe therefrom that nutritious juice that is conveyed thither by the hypoga≈øtrick and ≈øpermatick Arteries of the Dam: which juice con≈øi≈øting of various particles is conducted to the Foetus, with who≈øe Bloud it mixes, and its purer particles are a≈ø≈øimilated to it; but the gro≈ø≈øer and more earthy pa≈øs from the Foetus by its umbilical Arteries towards the Placenta or Cotyledons again; but in their way thither-ward they divert into tho≈øe branches of the≈øe Arteries that are di≈øper≈øed through the Amnios, and are ≈øpued out of their extremities into its cavity, where this liquor is collected in great quantity for the u≈øe afore≈øaid.

La≈øtly, when the Chicken hath ≈øpent all its provi≈øion, and is grown ≈øo big that it becomes unea≈øie in its narrow Cloi≈øter, and likewi≈øe wants a freer air to breathe in, the Shell which is the Mother's (external) Womb, begins to be brittle and apt to chap, ≈øo that upon the Chickens bu≈øtling about and pecking again≈øt it, it cracks and gives way to its Exit. Thus when the Foetus (in Viviparous Creatures) is full grown, and the ≈øides of the pelvis permit not any further exten≈øion of the Womb, the Foetus wanting Elbow-room as we ≈øay, tumbles about and creates an unea≈øine≈øs to the Dam, and the Womb it ≈øelf is provoked to an endeavour to exclude its burthen which is now become trouble≈øome: whence partly from the endeavours of the Young to free it ≈øelf of its confinement, and partly by the ≈øtraining of the Dam (Nature having prepared the pa≈ø≈øage) the birth ≈øucceeds.

Thus I have pro≈øecuted the hi≈øtory of the Generation of Animals from the fir≈øt principles of their Foetus till their bringing them forth; wherein I mu≈øt confe≈øs to have borrowed much from other Mens ob≈øervations: but as the Reader may have ob≈øerved me ≈øo ingenuous as to mention my Authours where I have done ≈øo; ≈øo I hope it will be acknowledged I have produced ≈øome of my own, and improved tho≈øe I have borrowed
to other purpo≈øes than they were fir≈øt publi≈øhed to the world for by their Authours: wherein if there be any who≈øe curio≈øity I have not ≈øatisfied, I hope there is at lea≈øt enough to excite his emulation, and to put him upon endeavours further to inform him≈øelf, and others. Either of which effects ≈øhall make me think the pains I have taken well be≈øtow'd.

div.head: SECTION II. Of the Motion of the Chyle, and Circulation of the Bloud.
div.p: I Am now entring upon ≈øo trite a Subject, and which has exerci≈øed the Pens of ≈øo many learned Anatomi≈øts, that I cannot invite the learned Reader to the peru≈øal of this Di≈øcour≈øe with the promi≈øe of outdoing tho≈øe worthy Per≈øons that have gone before me: but the main inducement of the annexing this to the before-going Treati≈øe, was from a pro≈øpect that this Book will probably fall into the hands of ≈øuch as never read the before-mentioned Authours, ≈øo that this Doctrine will be as new to them as if never any thing had been writ before on the ≈øame Subject. But yet I would not ≈øo prejudice even the learned (Anatomical) Reader again≈øt it, as that he ≈øhould expect nothing but Crambe recocta, and ≈øo nau≈øeate and reject it: for be≈øide that the manner and method of the di≈øcour≈øe is (I think) new, he will find ≈øomething of Experiment, which (for any thing that I know) hath not been made by any other. However in the whole I ≈øhall be very conci≈øe, as having ≈øaid ≈øomething to the ≈øame purpo≈øe in the Fir≈øt and Second Books, in the Chapters of the Stomach, Guts, and Me≈øentery, and of the Heart.

I. ¬ß. Of the motion of the Chyle. In the fir≈øt place we ≈øhall begin with the motion of the Chyle, becau≈øe Chyle is that out of which Bloud is made. Chyle is defined to be a milky juice, like Barley-cream, prepared and concocted in the Stomach from the Food that is taken. For when the Animal has chew'd his Meat ≈øufficiently, and thereby minced and prepared it, (in which action the Saliva or Slaver mixes with it) he ≈øwallows it down into his Stomach, which ≈øo contracts it ≈øelf, that be the Meat little or much, it embraces it clo≈øely, and keeps both its Orifices ≈øhut. The Meat being thus ≈øtew'd as it were by the mild heat of the Stomach, enters upon a fermentation, which proceeds from the acidity of the Saliva and the acid or acrimonious ≈øerment of the Stomach working upon the ≈øalt particles of the Food and di≈ø≈øolving or precipitating the ≈øame, (and together with them the ≈øulphureous) which being ≈øo di≈ø≈øolved are diluted and turned into a fluid ≈øub≈øtance by the water or other liquor that the Animal drinks, and this is that we call Chyle. As for the other particles of the Food which are not thus di≈ø≈øolved and made fluid, as being of a more gro≈øs and earthy ≈øub≈øtance, they become like the Chymi≈øt's caput mortuum, and make that we call the faeces or Dung, which having once mentioned, my de≈øign will not give me occa≈øion to take much further notice of.

The Chyle then being thus prepared in the Stomach pa≈ø≈øes by degrees out at its lower Orifice into the Guts, along which it is gently conducted (together with the faeces) by their peri≈øtaltick or Worm-like motion. Now into every one of the Guts are in≈øerted more or fewer of tho≈øe Veins which are called milky, from the whiti≈øh chylous liquor that is commonly to be found in them, and to di≈øtingui≈øh them from the Bloud-ve≈ø≈øels that look of a blui≈øh or dusky red. The≈øe milky Veins being laid (as I may ≈øay) into the Guts like ≈øo many ≈ømaller (leaden) Pipes into a large Trunk, do every one of them imbibe or drink in part of the Chyle, and convey it whither and in what manner we ≈øhall ≈øhew pre≈øently. The part that ≈øu≈øtains the≈øe Veins is the Me≈øentery, in who≈øe folds the greate≈øt part of the Guts are gathered (all but the beginning of the fir≈øt (≈ømall) Gut, and la≈øt (≈øtreight) Gut.) But as for the fabrick of the≈øe parts I would rather de≈øire the Reader to con≈øult the ninth, tenth, eleventh and twelfth Chapters of the Fir≈øt Book, than be tedious with repetition. I ≈øay then the≈øe Veins being laid into the Guts, receive into their mouths the afore≈øaid liquor through the ≈øpongie ≈ølime that bedaubs the in≈øide of the Guts, which ≈øerves as a ≈øtrainer for the confu≈øed ma≈øs of the Chyle. But for the more ea≈øie ≈øeparation of its purer parts from the impure and feculent, there happens in the Guts them≈øelves a new kind of fermentation in the Chyle by the commixture of the bile and pancreatick juice with it, as was ≈øhewed in the afore≈øaid Chapters and the thirteenth of the ≈øame Book. Now the rea≈øon why the Chyle ≈øhould rather divert into the≈øe ≈ølender Ve≈ø≈øels than continue its cour≈øe down the wide Guts, is not from any magnetick or electrick attractive faculty in the Ve≈ø≈øels them≈øelves, but from the continual agitation and ≈øqueezing of the Guts partly by their own peri≈øtaltick motion, and partly by their being heaved up and down by the continual motion of the Mu≈øcles of the Paunch, and of the Midriff in Re≈øpiration. The≈øe motions indeed ha≈øten al≈øo the de≈øcent of the chylous ma≈øs down the Guts them≈øelves; but he that con≈øiders the various windings of the Guts, and ob≈øerves that the ≈ømall ones lie the greate≈øt part of them in the lower and fore-part of the Belly (into which mo≈øt of the milky Ve≈ø≈øels are in≈øerted) whil≈øt the Colon (that lies more backward) a≈øcends up again as high as the bottom of the Stomach, and commonly is pretty full ≈øtuft with dige≈øted excrement of a pretty firm con≈øi≈øtence, mu≈øt needs conceive it to be a very natural motion for the Chyle to regurgitate as it were, or ≈ølide into the milky Veins while the Inte≈øtins are thus compre≈ø≈øed. And if this may be allowed for a ≈øufficient mechanical rea≈øon of its fir≈øt entrance into them, we ≈øhall not need to be much thoughtfull for another, why it ≈øhould a≈øcend by them and the thoracick Duct to the Heart; ≈øeeing that which comes behind mu≈øt needs drive on that which went before ≈øo far as there is pa≈ø≈øage for it, at lea≈øt ≈øo high as the place from which their de≈øcent was. For every body knows that any Aqueduct will convey the water as high as the Fountain or Well-≈øpring where it receiv'd it, though in its pa≈ø≈øage from the Spring-head to the place where it is di≈øcharged, it de≈øcends through a valley that is (≈øuppo≈øe) an hundred paces perpendicular lower than either. All Meat and Drink then being received in at the Mouth, it is no wonder that the Chyle that is made of it ≈øhould a≈øcend up as high as the Heart, though it fir≈øt de≈øcend to the lowe≈øt parts of the Abdomen, ≈øeeing the Heart comes ≈øo much ≈øhort of the height of the Mouth. But this motion of the Chyle that we are ≈øpeaking of, has a notable advantage above that of water
in a Tree or Pipe; ≈øeeing water de≈øcends, and con≈øequently a≈øcends therein onely by its own gravity, and is a≈ø≈øi≈øted in neither by the Ve≈ø≈øels that contain it: whereas the Meat and Drink are not onely driven down into the Stomach by the motion of the Throat and Gullet; but the upper mouth of the Stomach pre≈øently clo≈øing upon them, hinders their a≈øcent back again, and the afore≈øaid peri≈øtaltick motion of the Guts, and reciprocal dilatation and contraction of the Belly (as well as Brea≈øt) in re≈øpiration, force the Chyle along the pipes it pa≈ø≈øes through, as well as it ≈øelf makes its way by its own weight. The milky Veins have al≈øo another advantage above an Aqueduct, in that they have Valves that hinder the relap≈øe or retreat of the liquor contained in them; ≈øo that upon what≈øoever agitation or compre≈ø≈øion of the Ve≈ø≈øels there is a way open for it forwards, but it cannot return back again.

The Chyle then being received into the Lacteals as afore≈øaid, holds on its cour≈øe in them through the Me≈øentery to the common Receptacle at the Loins. In this pa≈ø≈øage the venae Lacteae enter ≈øeveral glands of the Me≈øentery, out of which other branches ari≈øe again, and the≈øe al≈øo are in≈øerted into other glands, and other branches ≈øpring from them again, the branches them≈øelves likewi≈øe ino≈øculating one with another; but they all hold on forwards towards the great gland at the centre or root of the Me≈øentery where it adheres to the Loins, into which ≈øome enter and ≈øome march over it: But tho≈øe that enter it, ari≈øe again out of it, and joining with the others that ran over it, di≈øcharge them≈øelves all together into the common Receptacle before-mentioned.

This Receptacle is called common, becau≈øe it is common both to the Chyle and Lympha (which latter humour what it is, you may ≈øee in the above-cited twelfth Chapter.) It is ≈øeated behind and a little above the great gland at the centre of the Me≈øentery, rather towards the left ≈øide, by the ≈øide of the Cava de≈øcending, and near the left Kidney. It is like a little bag or bladder, and is nothing el≈øe but the wider part or root of the thoracick Duct, which is continued from it. All the Chyle being imported into this Receptacle, and al≈øo the Lympha returning from all the Bowels of the Abdomen, and the inferiour parts, mixing with and diluting of it, a≈øcend up the Loins and Back by the ≈øaid thoracick Duct, which is a long Pipe (very thin and almo≈øt tran≈øparent) running up the whole length of the Thorax under or behind the Aorta (on the in≈øide of the Spine) but rather inclining towards its left ≈øide; and at la≈øt pa≈ø≈øing under the Thymus it opens into the lower ≈øide of the left ≈øubclavian Vein, over again≈øt that place where the left jugular Vein opens into it on the upper ≈øide. Though the Duct u≈øually be but one, yet it opens with five or ≈øix mouths into the ≈øaid Vein, all which on the in≈øide the Vein are covered with one broad valve, which permits the Chyle and Lympha to enter into the Vein, but hinders either them or Bloud to ≈ølide out of the Vein into the Duct. This Duct has ≈øeveral Valves in it as well as the Lacteals of the Me≈øentery that hinder the retreat of the humours contained in it. You have this Duct with the Receptacle, &c. expre≈øt in the next Table but one, viz. the forty ninth and la≈øt.

Thus the Chyle being di≈øcharged into the Subclavian Vein is therein mixed with the Venal bloud, and pa≈ø≈øes along with it to the right Ventricle of the Heart, where it begins to be alter'd into Bloud. We cannot therefore pur≈øue its motion any further under its own name: for though it be not perfectly turned into Bloud, it may be, in ≈øeveral times pa≈ø≈øing
through the Heart in its circulation with the Bloud; yet it is ≈øo jumbled and mixt with the Bloud, that it is e≈øteemed to be of the ≈øame ma≈øs with it. So that we ≈øhall leave it here, and onely adverti≈øe this further, that according to the ≈øtricte≈øt examination and mo≈øt accurate experiments of the be≈øt Anatomi≈øts, all the Chyle pa≈ø≈øes the≈øe ways we have de≈øcribed, and no part of it is conveyed either to the Liver or Spleen, nor yet to the Womb in the time of its Ge≈øtation, or to the Udder in giving ≈øuck; I mean immediately and by proper Ve≈ø≈øels; for it does indeed pa≈øs thereto, ≈øome part of it, by the Arteries, being confounded with the Bloud, from which it is there ≈øeparated again, for the nouri≈øhment of the Foetus or Young, as was ≈øhewed at large in the twenty eighth and twenty ninth Chapters of the Fir≈øt Book.

II. ¬ß. Of the circulation of the Bloud. That the Bloud is continually ≈øome of it i≈ø≈øuing from,and other ≈øome returning to the Heart, by a circular motion, is now an opinion ≈øo generally entertained, that I need not take any pains to prove That it is ≈øo, but ≈øhall onely ≈øhew How and by what Ways this motion is performed.

Its pa≈ø≈øage from the right to the left Ventricle of the Heart. In the foregoing Paragraph we had traced the Chyle to the right Ventricle of the Heart, into which it enters mixed with the venal Bloud in the Heart's dia≈øtole or dilatation. Herein the Chyle and Bloud are more intimately mixed one with another, and 'tis probable enter upon ≈øome degree of fermentation, but it cannot be much, con≈øidering their ≈øhort ≈øtay therein, which is but during the interval betwixt the dilatation and the contraction that next ≈øucceeds it: for by the following ≈øy≈øtole is all that Bloud and Chyle expelled out of the Ventricle into the pulmonary Artery, that was imported into it from the Cava by the foregoing ≈øy≈øtole. The≈øe humours then, which from henceforward we ≈øhall ≈øpeak of under the notion of Bloud onely, being entred into the pulmonary Artery, are conveyed by its two branches into both Lobes of the Lungs; the ≈ømaller twigs of which branches ino≈øculating with the like twigs of the pulmonary Vein transfu≈øe the Bloud into them, which by this latter Vein is conducted to the left Ventricle. The Bloud in its pa≈ø≈øage through the Lungs being in≈øpired or impregnated with the nitrous particles of Air received into the Lungs in In≈øpiration and there in≈øinuating them≈øelves into the Bloud, undergoes a greater fermentation in the left Ventricle than it had done before in the right, though it make no longer ≈øtay in the one than in the other. For the ≈øy≈øtole's and dia≈øtole's of both Ventricles are performed at the ≈øame time, and therefore the interval or ce≈ø≈øation betwixt the≈øe two motions is equal. In the next ≈øy≈øtole therefore of the Heart the ≈øame Bloud is driven forth of this left Ventricle into the Aorta or great Artery, which is the root of all the Arteries in the Body (except the pulmonary.) I ≈øhall not need here to de≈øcribe the Valves at the orifices of the Ventricles, which hinder the recour≈øe of the Bloud into them (≈øuch are tho≈øe of the pulmonary Artery and Aorta) nor tho≈øe that hinder the regurgitation of the Bloud out of them into the Cava and pulmonary Vein; for of the≈øe we have ≈øpoken enough in the eighth Chapter of the Second Book: but we ≈øhall proceed to trace the cour≈øe the Bloud further takes, now that we have follow'd it as far as the beginning of the Aorta.

Its pa≈ø≈øage from the left Ventricle to the habit of the Body. The Heart is the Authour of the motion of all the humours that have once pa≈øt it, be they Bloud, Lympha, Choler, the nervous Juice, or any other. For the Heart (like a Pump) ejecting the Bloud forcibly out of it, and that Bloud which comes behind ≈øtill driving forward that which
goes before, and having all other humours either formally or materially in it; as new ≈øupplies are conveyed by it or along with it to any part, that which was in the part before the ≈øupply came, mu≈øt give way to it and hold on its cour≈øe, till either it be ejected out of the Body if it be an excrement, or be returned back again to the Heart if it be a profitable Humour, abating ≈øo much of it as is ≈øpent on the nouri≈øhment and refection of the parts, or may evaporate by in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration. More particularly: The Aorta having received the Bloud from the left Ventricle is pre≈øently divided into two Trunks, the A≈øcending, and the De≈øcending. The A≈øcending Trunk of the Aorta. The A≈øcending Trunk climbing up by the Wind-pipe to the top of the Brea≈øt ≈øends forth two branches, called the ≈øubclavian, becau≈øe they run under the lower ≈øide of the claviculae or Chanel-bones. The≈øe ≈øend out ≈øeveral branches both from their upper and lower ≈øide. From their upper ≈øide ≈øpring tho≈øe Arteries called Mammariae (in Men) the Cervical (that are partly ≈øpent on the Mu≈øcles of the Neck, and afterwards entring to within its Vertebrae, a≈øcend into the Brain by that hole by which the Spinal Marrow de≈øcends from it) and la≈øtly the Mu≈øculae (that are al≈øo be≈øtow'd on the Mu≈øcles of the Neck.) Out of their lower ≈øide proceed the ≈øuperiour Interco≈øtals. After having ≈øent forth the≈øe branches, they pa≈øs out of the Che≈øt to the Arms (or Fore-legs in Brutes) on the parts whereof they are be≈øtowed. Ju≈øt where the great a≈øcending Trunk of the Aorta ≈øends forth the ≈øubclavian Arteries ≈øide-ways, it is divided into two large branches (called the carotid Arteries) that a≈øcend directly upwards, which fir≈øt ≈øending ≈øome ≈ømall ≈ølips to the Tongue, the Mu≈øcles of the Os hyoides, &c. are afterwards each ≈øubdivided into the External and Internal branches. The External are be≈øtowed on the Mu≈øcles of the Lips, Cheeks, Temples, &c. The Internal entring the Skull at the hole by which the wandring pair of Nerves (or eighth pair) come out of it, are di≈øper≈øed through the Brain, the dura and pia mater, in which they make the Rete mirabile and Plexus Choroides, uniting with ≈øome twigs of the cervical Arteries before-mentioned. The Bloud that flows by the≈øe Arteries to the Brain, &c. after it hath ≈øerved the nece≈ø≈øities thereof, returns back again towards the Heart by the Jugular Veins, which are al≈øo External and Internal, ob≈øerving the ≈øame cour≈øe with the Arteries. The External Jugular is that which appears ≈øo fair in the Neck, which we commonly open in Hor≈øes. And here it may be convenient to inquire in what manner the Bloud pa≈ø≈øes out of the Arteries into the Veins, whether by ino≈øculating the one with the other, or by what other way. That I might ≈øatisfie my ≈øelf herein I made the following Experiment.

An Experiment to prove, that there are no Ana≈øtomo≈øes of the Arteries with the Veins. Having bled an Hor≈øe to death, that both Veins and Arteries might be empty, with the greate≈øt di≈øpatch I could, whil≈øt the Hor≈øe was warm, I took up one of the carotid Arteries and cut an hole in it pretty near the Brea≈øt, into which hole putting a quill I blew into it as hard as I could, whereupon I perceived the branches of Arteries on both ≈øides of the Face, &c. to ≈øwell, yea and al≈øo the carotid Artery on the other ≈øide of the Neck: but I no ≈øooner left off blowing, but they were immediately emptied again, the wind, 'tis likely, proceeding forward, on the contrary ≈øide, towards the Heart. Upon which I tyed the Artery on the other ≈øide about the ≈øame place where I had made the hole on this, to ≈øtop the progre≈øs of the wind, and then blew again; upon which the Arteries on both ≈øides were very much di≈øtended: and then I ≈øpeedily made a ligature a little above the Orifice, whereby the Arteries and all their
branches in the Neck, Face, &c. continued di≈øtended. Which having viewed a-while, I took off both the Ligatures one after the other, and perceived the wind to retire both ways, and to leave the Arteries and all their branches empty. But all this while the jugular Veins were not ≈øwelled at all: upon which I made this conclu≈øion, That the Arteries did not ino≈øculate with the Veins at all, but onely with one another. In which opinion that I might be further confirmed, I afterwards took up the external jugular Vein on one ≈øide, making a hole in it, and tyed the ≈øame Vein on the other ≈øide; I put my quill into the orifice I had made, and blew into it as I had done into the Artery before; whereupon the jugular Vein on the other ≈øide of the Neck ≈øwelled as well as that on this ≈øide, and both their branches about the Face, &c. As ≈øoon as they were all well filled, I made a ligature above the orifice, whereby the Air was pent in, and both Veins and their branches continued to be ≈øwell'd till I unloo≈øed the Ligatures, upon which they pre≈øently became empty. But by thus blowing into and filling the Veins, the Arteries were not at all moved, which further ≈øatisfied me, that there are no Ana≈øtomo≈øes between the Veins and Arteries, by which the Bloud ≈øhould pa≈øs out of the≈øe into tho≈øe or out of tho≈øe into the≈øe; but that ≈øuch are onely to be found among≈øt Ve≈ø≈øels of the ≈øame kind. I ≈øpeak as to the habit of the Body; for that there are ≈øuch in ≈øome of the Bowels, as particularly of the pulmonary Artery and Vein in the Lungs, of the ≈øplenick Artery and Vein in or near the Spleen, and of the Porta and Cava in the Liver (the fir≈øt of which from its double coat may be e≈øteemed rather an Artery than a Vein) is pa≈øt di≈øpute. It may be wondred then, if indeed there be a circulation of the Bloud, how it ≈øhould pa≈øs out of the Arteries into the Veins, if there be no communication by ino≈øculation betwixt them. But we mu≈øt con≈øider that in living Bodies all the parts are much more porous and ≈øpongie than in a dead Carca≈øe; for upon the ce≈ø≈øation of the motion of the humours many of the ≈ømaller pa≈ø≈øages by which they u≈øe to be conveyed, are ≈øtopt by the coinciding of their ≈øides. So that although, according to the Experiment, there is after death no pa≈ø≈øage even for wind out of the Arteries into the Veins, nor on the contrary out of the Veins into the Arteries; yet in living Bodies it is not, from hence, nece≈ø≈øary to deny it. For though we cannot grant any ino≈øculation of the one with the other (in the habit of the Body, as was above≈øaid;) yet there is another way whereby the humours may be transfus'd out of one into another, and that is thus: The Arterial bloud by the pul≈øation of the Heart is extrava≈øated or driven forth of the utmo≈øt ends of the Arteries into the very ≈øub≈øtance of the parts; which being rare and porous permits the Bloud to flow in; but the pores being very ≈øtrait can contain but a ≈ømall quantity, and therefore ≈øeeing the influx of the Bloud is continual, there mu≈øt al≈øo be a continual efflux or di≈øcharge of the ≈øame, for which office there are no other Ve≈ø≈øels adapted but the Veins, which by their extremities imbibe or ≈øuck up the Bloud being thus extrava≈øated, and convey it back into the larger branches, and the≈øe di≈øcharge it into the Cava, and that, to the Heart. Now that the Bloud is extrava≈øated out of the Arteries into the ≈øub≈øtance of the parts is very certain, ≈øeeing if it were not ≈øo, the parts could receive no nouri≈øhment from the Bloud; for while it is in the Ve≈ø≈øels, it may indeed contribute warmth to the parts through which it flows, but it cannot nouri≈øh them, ≈øeeing even the larger Ve≈ø≈øels them≈øelves are not nouri≈øhed by that ≈øtream of Bloud
that glides along their cavity, but by capillary Ve≈ø≈øels running along their coats. Again≈øt this manner of the Blouds pa≈ø≈øing out of the Arteries into the Veins I know nothing can be objected, unle≈øs it be the ha≈øty circulation of the Bloud, which according to the computation of the mo≈øt accurate Anatomi≈øts is ≈øuppo≈øed to be ≈øo quick, as that the whole ma≈øs of Bloud pa≈ø≈øes ≈øeveral times through the Heart in one hours ≈øpace: from whence ≈øome think it nece≈ø≈øary to admit of Ana≈øtomo≈øes of the Arteries with the Veins all the Body over, whereby the Bloud may run in a fuller current out of one into the other, than 'tis probable it can do by way of extrava≈øation; though from the nutrition of the parts, they believe it nece≈ø≈øary to admit this latter way too. To this objection I ≈øhall onely oppo≈øe the before-going Experiment, which to me ≈øeems a plain demon≈øtration that there are no ≈øuch Ana≈øtomo≈øes at all. Having therefore ≈øhewn all the branches of the A≈øcending Trunk of the Aorta, we ≈øhall proceed to tho≈øe of the De≈øcending.

The De≈øcending Trunk of the Aorta. The De≈øcending Trunk of the Aorta is larger than the A≈øcending, as being to ≈øupply more parts with heat and nouri≈øhment. It de≈øcends by the Gullet towards the Midriff, at which before it arrive, it ≈øends forth the inferiour Interco≈øtal branches, and the Bronchial, which latter accompany the branches of the Wind-pipe in the Lungs. When it arrives at the Midriff, there ≈øpring out of it, the Phrenick Arteries, which are di≈øper≈øed through the Midriff, and Media≈øtinum or Partition-membrane of the Che≈øt. Having pierced the Midriff, it de≈øcends in one Trunk as far as the la≈øt Vertebra of the Loins, but by the way ≈øends forth many branches: as fir≈øt the Coeliaca or Stomach Artery, which ari≈øes ≈øingle, but is divided afterward into its right and left branches. The right furni≈øheth the right ≈øide of the Stomach, (viz. the Pylorus) the inve≈øting Membrane of the Liver, the Gall-bladder, the right ≈øide of the Caul and that part of the Colon on which it cleaveth, the beginning of the ≈ømall Guts, and the Me≈øentery: The left (called its Splenick branch) ≈øends ≈øome twigs to the middle part, left ≈øide and upper orifice of the Stomach, and to the left part of the Caul; but the greate≈øt part of it runs to the Spleen, into which before it enters, it ≈øometimes ≈øends forth the vas breve arterio≈øum, which goeth to the left part of the bottom of the Stomach: but in Hor≈øes this vas breve ≈øpringeth from it after it is entred into the Spleen, as may be ≈øeen in the ≈øeventh Table annexed to the ≈øixteenth Chapter of the Fir≈øt Book, where all the≈øe branches of the ≈øplenick Artery are delineated. The Veins that accompany this Coeliack Artery are branches of the Porta, and have the ≈øame names with tho≈øe of the Artery. Next to the Coeliack there ≈øprings out of the Trunk of the Aorta the upper Me≈øenterick, that is be≈øtowed upon the upper part of the Me≈øentery and the ≈ømall Guts. The next are the Emulgent Arteries, the right and left; each of which dividing them≈øelves into two or more branches, enter into the Kidneys of their re≈øpective ≈øides, and di≈øcharge there the ≈øerum or wheyi≈øh part of the Bloud that makes the Urine. Below the≈øe the Aorta ≈øends forth the ≈øpermatick Arteries, which in Hor≈øes are commonly two, and in Mares o≈øt-times more, on each ≈øide. The≈øe run to the Te≈øticles, Womb, &c. Then the lower Me≈øenterick, that go to the lower part of the Me≈øentery and to the great Guts. By this time the Trunk of the Aorta being come to the top of Os ≈øacrum, having thus far de≈øcended under the Cava, begins to climb upon it, and is divided into two equal branches, called the Iliack; which are pre≈øently ≈øubdivided into the interior and exterior. From the interior ≈øpring the Mu≈øculae, or
Mu≈øcle-arteries, being be≈øtowed on the P≈øoas, the Buttock-mu≈øcles, &c. al≈øo the Hypoga≈øtrick, that run to the parts of Generation in both Male and Female, and al≈øo to the Bladder, &c. and la≈øtly the ∆≤mbilical Arteries, which in the Foetus a≈øcending by the ≈øides of the Bladder, proceed to the Navel, and run to the Womb-cake or Cotyledons; of which in the twenty eighth Chapter of the Fir≈øt Book. From the exterior Iliack branches ari≈øe fir≈øt the Epiga≈øtrick Arteries, which turning upwards run on the out≈øide of the Rim of the Belly, betwixt it and the ≈øtreight Mu≈øcles, as far as the Navel, and there meet the Mammary. Secondly, the Pudendae, which are ≈øpent upon the Privities of both Male and Female. Afterwards the Iliack branches de≈øcend to the Thighs, and then begin to be called Crural.

Thus we have given an hi≈øtory of all the larger branches of the Aorta, whereby the Bloud is conveyed from the Heart to all the parts of the Body; it would not be very material to give the like of the Veins, ≈øeeing every one of the≈øe Arteries has a Vein accompanying it, for the mo≈øt part of the ≈øame denomination; ≈øo that by knowing the Artery that comes to any part, we mu≈øt know the Vein al≈øo that returns the Bloud from it, e≈øpecially in the Limbs and outward parts. For indeed within the Body, e≈øpecially in the Abdomen, there is ≈øome variation: the rather becau≈øe ≈øome of the Veins thereof ≈øpring from the Cava, and others from the Porta. This latter ≈øupplies the Bowels that perform the fir≈øt concoction, as the Stomach, Guts and Me≈øentery; as al≈øo the Spleen, Sweetbread, Caul, and the Liver in part. The≈øe branches of the Porta receiving into them that Bloud that is ≈øuperfluous to the nouri≈øhment of tho≈øe parts into which they are in≈øerted, unite into one Trunk in the lower or under ≈øide of the Liver; which Trunk ≈øpreading it ≈øelf into many roots through the whole ≈øub≈øtance of the Liver, does transfu≈øe its Bloud into the like roots of the Cava that ari≈øes out of the upper ≈øide. In which pa≈ø≈øage of the Bloud out of the Porta into the Cava, the Bile is ≈øeparated from it. But that Bloud which is received immediately by the branches of the Cava di≈øper≈øed to the other parts of the Lower Belly, as al≈øo by tho≈øe that run to all other parts of the Body, whether from its A≈øcending or De≈øcending Trunk, pa≈ø≈øes through no Bowel in its return towards the Heart: But being imbibed by the capillary twigs out of the pores of the parts, is conveyed fir≈øt into the ≈ømaller branches, and from them into the larger, and la≈øtly from the≈øe into one of the great Trunks of the Cava, by which it is poured again into the right Ventricle of the Heart, there to be in≈øpirited anew and ≈øent about in a ≈øecond circulation.
